1.01.060. - Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code. 
    The last ordinance included in this code was Ordinance No. 62-94, passed September 28, 1994. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to Ordinance No. 62-94, but prior to adoption of this code, are adopted and made a part of this code: Ordinance Nos. 63-94; 64-94; 65-94; 66-94; 67-94; 68-94; 69-94; 70-94; 71-94; and 1-95. 
(Ord. 6-95 § 6, 1995) 
1.01.070. - Effect of code on past actions and obligations. 
    The adoption of this code does not affect prosecutions for ordinance violations committed prior to the effective date of this code, does not waive any fee or penalty due and unpaid on the effective date of this code, and does not affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit posted, filed or deposited pursuant to the requirements of any ordinance. 
(Ord. 6-95 § 7, 1995) 
1.01.080. - Constitutionality. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code. 
(Ord. 6-95 § 8, 1995) 
1.01.090. - References to prior code. 
    References in city forms, documents and regulations to the chapters and sections of the former city code shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code. 
(Ord. 6-95 § 9, 1995) 
Chapter 1.04. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

1.04.010. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the construction of these Codified Ordinances and of all ordinances hereafter enacted that amend or otherwise are made a part of these Codified Ordinances, the following interpretations shall be placed on the words and phrases hereinafter mentioned, unless such construction or interpretation is manifestly inconsistent with the evident intent of council or the qualified voters, or repugnant to the context or to the evident purport of any ordinance: 
    And. "And" may be read "or," and "or" may be read "and," if the sense requires it. 
    Authority. Words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or persons. 
    City or Municipality. The words "the city" or "the municipality" mean the City of Newport in the County of Newport and the State of Rhode Island. 
    Computation of Time. The time in which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, and if the last day is a Sunday or a legal holiday, it shall be excluded. 
    Council. The word "council" means the city council of the City of Newport. 
    County. "County" means the County of Newport, Rhode Island. 
    Gender. Words used in the masculine gender include the feminine and neuter. 
    General Laws. "General laws" or the "general law" means the 1956 edition of the General Laws of Rhode Island and all amendments and re-enactments thereof. 
    May and Shall. "May" is permissive; "shall" is mandatory. 
    Month. The word "month" means a calendar month. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" includes a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a natural person. 
    Plural and Singular. Words importing the singular include the plural; words importing the plural include the singular. 
    Preceding and Following. The words "preceding" and "following" means next before and next after, respectively. 
    State. "State" means the state of Rhode Island. 
    Tenant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease for, or who occupies, the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Time. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Ways, Streets and Highways. The words "ways," "streets" and "highways" shall be construed as including boulevards, avenues, courts, lanes, alleys, squares, places and sidewalks, and each of these words includes the others. 
    Writing. The words "writing" and "written" including printing. 
(Prior code § 202.02) 
Chapter 1.08. - CITY SEAL 

1.08.010. - City seal. 
    The following shall be the device of the seal of the city: Around the margin of the same there shall be a circle, the upper half containing the words: "The City of Newport, R.I., incorporated 1784"; in the lower half thereof shall be the words "Rechartered, 1853"; within which circle shall be a device representing the breakwater at Goat Island with the lighthouse thereon and a general view of the city taken from the northwest, with a steamboat and vessels in the harbor, and in the foregoing the words: "Settled 1639." 
(Prior code § 204.01) 
1.08.020. - Probate court seal. 
    The following shall be the device of the seal of the probate court: Around the margin of the same there shall be a circle, the upper half containing the words: "Court of Probate"; in the lower half thereof shall be the words: "Newport, R.I."; and within the circle shall be a device representing a monument and a book. 
(Prior code § 204.02) 
1.08.030. - Seal keepers. 
    The city clerk shall be ex officio keeper of the city seal and the clerk of probate shall be ex officio keeper of the seal of such court. 
(Prior code § 204.03) 
Chapter 1.12. - GENERAL PENALTY 

1.12.010. - General code penalty. 
A.  Fine and Imprisonment. Whenever, in these Codified Ordinances, or in any technical or other code adopted by reference in these Codified Ordinances, or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated or made under authority of any provision of these Codified Ordinances, or under authority of any technical or other code adopted by reference in these Codified Ordinances, or under authority of state law, an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is otherwise provided, whoever violates or fails to comply with any such provision shall be fined not to exceed the maximum fine allowable in Newport Municipal Court, plus the costs of prosecution for each offense, or imprisoned not more than thirty (30) days, or be required to perform community service, or any combination thereof. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues, unless otherwise provided. 
B.  Surcharges-Equitable Remedies. The imposition of any penalty provided for in this section shall be in addition to any surcharge levied for a violation of or noncompliance with a provision of these Codified Ordinances, or a provision of a technical or other code adopted by reference in these Codified Ordinances, or a rule, regulation or order promulgated or made under authority of either, or under authority of state law, and shall be in addition to any equitable remedy provided by a provision of these Codified Ordinances, or a provision of a technical or other code adopted by reference in these Codified Ordinances, or a rule, regulation or order promulgated or made under authority of either, or provided by state law, or a rule, regulation or order promulgated or made under authority of state law, including the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
C.  Licenses Generally. Notwithstanding any provisions of these Codified Ordinances to the contrary, for any violation of the terms, provisions, or conditions for the granting of any license, the city council or City of Newport may revoke or suspend such license, unless otherwise prohibited by the General Laws of Rhode Island or other enabling legislation, rule or regulation, in addition to any other disciplinary action authorized by ordinance or law. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 1, 2003; prior code § 202.99) 
(Ord. No. 2010-10, § 1, 4-28-2010) 
Chapter 1.14. - SPECIFIC PENALTIES FOR CERTAIN VIOLATIONS 

1.14.010. - Violation of Chapter 2.06, STANDARDS OF ETHICAL CONDUCT FOR COUNCIL MEMBERS. 
    Any council member violating the provisions of Chapter 2.06 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not more than the maximum fine allowable in Newport Municipal Court, plus the costs of prosecution for each offense, or imprisoned not more than thirty (30) days, or be required to perform community service, or any combination thereof, and shall forthwith cease to be a council member. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.020. - Violation of Chapter 5.04, BUSINESS LICENSING AND REGISTRATION GENERALLY. 
    Any violation of Chapter 5.04 shall be subject to a fine of twenty-five ($25.00) dollars for each day on which a business operates without a certificate of registration. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.030. - Violation of Chapter 5.28, CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEMS. 
    In addition to the penalty provided in Section 1.12.010, a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter may also be grounds for revocation by council of permission to use public rights-of-way within the city, whether or not criminal charges are brought. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.040. - Violation of Chapter 5.36, FORTUNETELLERS. 
    A license granted under this chapter shall be canceled and revoked by council upon the conviction of the holder thereof for any misdemeanor or felony by any court of competent jurisdiction or upon the conviction of such holder for a violation of any of the provisions of these codified ordinances, or any other ordinance, rule or regulation of the city. Any false or fraudulent representation by advertising or otherwise shall be sufficient grounds for revocation of a license issued under this chapter. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.050. - Violation of Chapter 5.40, HOTELS. 
    A violation of this chapter shall be subject to a minimum fine of two hundred ($200.00) dollars. Each day on which a hotel operates without a certificate of registration shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.060. - Violation of Chapter 5.48, JUKE BOXES AND MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES. 
    Whoever shall have or keep in any store, shop, tavern, restaurant or any other place of business, or for public use or profit, within the city, any juke box or mechanical amusement device without the owner thereof having obtained a license therefor from the city upon payment of a license fee as provided for in Chapter 5.48, shall be subject to the penalties defined in Chapter 1.12, and fined not less than fifty ($50.00) dollars per day for each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.070. - Violation of Chapter 5.60, PRIVATE DETECTIVES. 
    Whoever engages in the general business of a private detective without such license, or holds him or herself out as a private detective, or pretends to be a detective police officer, shall be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred ($200.00) dollars nor more than the maximum fine allowable in Newport Municipal Court, plus the costs of prosecution for each offense, or imprisonment in the adult correctional institutions not exceeding six months, or by both such fine and imprisonment; but nothing herein contained shall apply to a detective of another state coming within this state in the performance of his or her duties, for a temporary period and on a specific matter. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.080. - Violation of Chapter 5.68, PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENT. 
    Failure to obtain a license shall be subject to the imposition of a sentence or fine as provided for in Chapter 1.12. In addition, upon a complaint brought by the director of public safety, the city council shall hold a show-cause hearing to determine if a violation of the license, or any conditions thereto, has occurred. After hearing, the council may, if it finds that a violation has occurred, take disciplinary action against the license holder, including, but not limited to, suspension and/or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.090. - Violation of Chapter 5.70, SPECIAL EVENTS. 
    Failure to obtain a license shall be subject to the imposition of a sentence or fine as provided for in Chapter 1.12. In addition, upon a complaint brought by the director of public safety, the city council shall hold a show-cause hearing to determine if a violation of the license, or any conditions thereto, has occurred. After hearing, the council may, if it finds that a violation has occurred, take disciplinary action against the license holder, including, but not limited to, suspension and/or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.100. - Violations of Chapter 5.96, HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES. 
    Failure to obtain a license shall be subject to the imposition of a sentence or fine as provided for in Chapter 1.12. Upon notice of a violation of Chapter 5.96, the licensee shall correct the situation immediately. The license shall be temporarily suspended until said violation has been corrected. Upon a complaint brought by the director of public safety, the city council shall hold a show-cause hearing to determine if a violation of the license, or any conditions thereto, has occurred. After hearing, the council may, if it finds that a violation has occurred, take disciplinary action against the license holder, including, but not limited to, suspension and/or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.110. - Violations of Title 6, ANIMALS. 
A.  Whoever violates or fails to comply with Section 6.08.010, Licensing-Dogs, shall be fined ten dollars to be applied to the benefit of the city. Such fine shall be in addition to all other fees, penalties and fines and shall not relieve the owner or keeper from forthwith obtaining a license as provided in such section and paying the required fee therefor. 
B.  Whoever violates Section 6.08.020, Exemptions for thoroughbred dogs-Kennel licenses, shall be fined five dollars for each day such kennel is kept without a license therefor as required by such section. 
C.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, whoever is cited under Section 6.08.030(F), Collaring of Dogs-Impoundment, or Section 6.08.070(H), Control of vicious animals, animals in heat and wild animals, shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first such violation; fifty dollars ($50.00) for the second violation; and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the third violation and for each violation thereafter. Such fines shall be payable to the city at the police division in person or by mail within seven days from the issuance of such citation. If the owner neglects or refuses to dispose of such citation within such seven-day period, he or she shall be brought before the State District Court, Second Division, for trial and for such disposition as the court determines to be proper, in which case the provisions of Section 4-13-1 of the General Laws shall apply. 
D.  Upon redemption of a dog or other animal, under Section 6.08.030, the owner shall be required to pay, in addition to the daily charge for keeping the animal as may be fixed by law, the sum of ten dollars for a first or second offense of a like nature and twenty dollars ($20.00) for any and all subsequent like offenses. 
E.  Whoever violates Section 6.08.040(A), Wrongful removal of collars-Poisoning-Shooting, shall be fined not more than the maximum allowable in Newport Municipal Court, or imprisoned not more than thirty (30) days. One-half of such fine, as provided by statute, shall be for the use of the complainant and one-half for the use of the school fund of the city. 
F.  Whoever violates Section 6.08.040(B) shall be punished as provided in Section 4-13-1 of the General Laws. 
G.  Whoever violates the provisions of Chapter 6.08, restraint of animals, shall be subject to citation and the maximum penalties allowable as provided in Chapter 1.12. H. Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter for which no penalty is otherwise provided for in this section shall be punished in accordance with Sections 4-13-1 and 45-6-2 of the General Laws, as the same may be applicable. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003: Prior code § 612.99) 
1.14.120. - Violation of Chapter 8.08, FIRE CODE. 
A.  No person shall violate any of the provisions of the state Fire Safety Code adopted in Section 8.08.010 or the provision of this chapter, or fail to comply therewith, or violate or fail to comply with any order made there under, or build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved there under, or any certificate or permit issued there under, or fail to comply with an order that is affirmed or modified by the city manager or by a court of competent jurisdiction within the time fixed by either, then upon such violation, said person shall be subject to the general penalty provisions found in Section 1.12.010. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue. When not otherwise specified, each day that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
B.  The application of the penalty provided in Section 1.12.010 shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
C.  In addition to the penalty provided in Section 1.12.010, any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall result in the prompt termination of the authorization to maintain a fire, and the fire shall be promptly extinguished. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.130. - Violation of Chapter 8.12, NOISE ABATEMENT. 
    Any person who violates this Chapter 8.12 shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter 1.12, plus costs of prosecution for each offense. Any person who commits a second violation of this chapter within six months of the first violation shall be fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both, plus costs of prosecution for each offense. In the case of a third violation within six months of the first or second violation, the maximum fine allowable shall apply. In those instance where the violation occurs: between eleven p.m. and eleven fifty-nine p.m., a minimum fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall apply; between twelve a.m. and twelve fifty-nine a.m., a minimum fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) shall apply; and between one a.m. and seven a.m., a minimum fine of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall apply. However, notwithstanding the aforementioned provision, for any violation of this chapter which occurs in an area zoned residential by the zoning ordinance of the city, there shall be imposed a minimum mandatory fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
    A minimum, mandatory fine for keeping a disorderly house shall be seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the first offense and not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. 2006-3 § 1, 2006; Ord. 2004-8 § 1, 2004: Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.140. - Violation of Chapter 8.20, PRIVATE ALARM SYSTEMS. 
A.  A system installed in a single-family residence may suffer three false alarms within a six-month period without penalty. The fourth false alarm within the six-month period shall subject the user to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). The fifth false alarm within the six-month period shall subject the user to a fine of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Each subsequent false alarm within the six-month period shall subject the user to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
B.  A violation of any other provision of Chapter 8.20 occurring within and/or in relation to a single-family residence shall subject the user to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus the costs of prosecution, for the first offense; a fine of seventy-five dollars ($75.00), plus the costs of prosecution, for the second offense; and a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus the costs of prosecution, for all subsequent offenses. 
C.  Systems installed in buildings other than single-family residences may suffer three false alarms within a six-month period without penalty. The fourth false alarm within the six-month period shall subject the user to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). The fifth false alarm within the six-month period shall subject the user to a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each subsequent false alarm within the six-month period shall subject the user to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
D.  A violation of any other provision of Chapter 8.20 occurring within and/or in relation to buildings other than a single-family residence shall subject the user to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus the costs of prosecution, for the first offense; a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus the costs of prosecution, for the second offense; and a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus the costs of prosecution, for all subsequent offenses. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.145. - Violation of Chapter 8.24, SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of Chapter 8.24, Solid Waste Management, shall be subject to prosecution before the municipal court of the city of Newport and subject to a fine up to an amount within the jurisdiction of said court. 
(Ord. No. 2015-05, § 1, 2-25-2015) 
1.14.150. - Violation of Chapter 9.04, OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND DECENCY. 
A.  Whoever violates Section 9.04.020, Alcoholic beverages-Consumption or possession in public places, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and/or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days. 
B.  Whoever violates Section 9.04.030, Intoxication, shall be fined not more than twenty dollars ($20.00) or imprisoned for not more than ten days for each offense. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.160. - Violation of Chapter 9.08, OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY. 
    Whoever violates Section 9.08.090 shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and/or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days. All other violations of Chapter 9.08 shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter 1.12. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.170. - Violation of Chapter 10.12, VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC-ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT. 
A.  Parking Violations. Pursuant to Section 12-14-2 of the General Laws, all overtime parking in a parking zone shall carry a minimum penalty of forty dollars ($40.00) for each violation. All other violations of parking ordinances of the city shall be punishable by a fine of not less than forty dollars ($40.00) for each violation. Such fines may be paid by mail within thirty (30) days of issuance. If such fines are not paid by mail within thirty (30) days, such fines shall double. Owners of vehicles with accumulated parking fines and penalties of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more may have their vehicles towed, at the owner's expense, to a designated impound lot, or otherwise seized, such as by use of the so-called Denver Boot, pending the payment of outstanding fines and penalties. Any vehicle which has been seized by means of the so-called Denver Boot, or the like, for which the fines have not been paid and the "boot" removed shall be immediately towed to an impound lot, at the owner's expense, after the passage of forty-eight (48) hours. In all respects the provisions of Section 12-14-2 of the General Laws shall prevail. The offender shall be brought before the municipal court of the city for disposition of the matter. The owner of any vehicle which is booted shall pay a fifty-dollar ($50.00) fee for the removal of the boot prior to towing. 
B.  A violation of the handicapped parking regulations shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), in accordance with the Rhode Island General Laws. 
C.  Other Violations. Whoever violates or fails to comply with any other provision of title ten, for which no specific penalty is provided, shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter 1.12. 
(Ord. 2005-13 § 1 (part), 2005; Ord. 2004-29 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2003-26 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
(Ord. No. 2019-23, § 1, 6-12-2019) 
1.14.180. - Violation of Chapter 10.20, PARKING GENERALLY. 
A.  Whoever violates Section 10.20.140, Parking boat trailers, shall be fined forty dollars ($40.00) per violation. 
B.  Whoever violates Section 10.20.160, Unregistered and junk vehicles, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and/or imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days or both. 
C.  A parking meter violation shall result in a minimum fine of forty dollars ($40.00). 
D.  Payment of fines shall be subject to the provisions of Section 10.12.100A of the city code. 
E.  No person shall use a fishing vehicle parking permit to park in an area where parking is restricted or prohibited, unless such area has met the provisions of Section 10.20.230. 
F.  No person shall use a fishing vehicle parking permit in a manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
G.  Whoever violates Section 10.20.220 shall be fined forty dollars ($40.00), and be subject to possible revocation of such fishing vehicle parking permit. 
H.  Violations of all other sections of this chapter shall be subject to the imposition of a sentence or fine, not to exceed the maximum allowable in Newport municipal court. 
(Ord. 2005-13 § 1 (part), 2005; Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
(Ord. No. 2019-23, § 1, 6-12-2019) 
1.14.190. - Violation of Chapter 10.32, RESIDENTIAL PARKING PROGRAM. 
A.  No person shall park a vehicle in violation of the residential parking provisions established in this chapter. 
B.  No person shall use a residential parking permit, visitor pass, fleet pass or tenant pass in a manner contrary to any provisions of this chapter. 
C.  Violations of the provisions of Chapter 10.32, residential parking program, shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the Newport Municipal Court and the penalties provided in Chapter 1.12. 
D.  Whoever violates subsection A of this section shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00). 
E.  Violations of all other provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter 1.12. 
(Ord. 2005-13 § 1 (part), 2005; Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
(Ord. No. 2013-001, § 1, 4-10-2013) 
1.14.200. - Violation of Chapter 10.72, BICYCLES. 
A.  Whoever, under the age of eighteen (18), violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be, for the first offense, reprimanded in writing by the police department, which writing shall be addressed to the parents or guardian of the offender, stating the nature of the violation and containing a warning that a repetition of the violation or any other violation must be prevented by the parent or guardian or the offender's registration certificate will be suspended after the offender's third violation in a one-year period. No violation of or noncompliance with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be considered a criminal offense or made a matter of court record. 
B.  Whoever, being over eighteen (18) years of age, violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense; fifty dollars ($50.00) for the second offense; and seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for the third offense within a one-year period, which fine may be payable by mail within thirty (30) days of issuance. Four or more violations of Chapter 10.72 within a one-year period shall result in a summons to municipal court. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
(Ord. No. 2011-005, § 1, 3-9-2011) 
1.14.205. - Violation of Chapter 12.08, EXCAVATIONS AND CURB CUTS. 
    Failure to comply with application for permit procedures will be subject to a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per incident. All work shall halt while appropriate permits are applied for and obtained. 
(Ord. 2008-28 § 1, 2008) 
1.14.210. - Violation of Chapter 12.16, STREET USE REGULATIONS. 
    Whoever violates Section 12.16.050, Putting injurious materials on street prohibited-Cleaning up after accidents, shall be subject to the provisions of Chapter 1.12, but shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.215. - Violation of Chapter 12.32, EASTON'S BEACH REGULATIONS. 
    Whoever violates Section 12.32.060.A.9. shall be assessed a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense and a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 2009-27, 8-26-2009) 
1.14.220. - Violation of Chapter 13.08, SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM. 
    In addition to the penalties provided in Chapter 1.12 and any other remedy available, the city may seek injunctive relief, pursuant to state law, for any actual or imminent violation of Chapter 13.08. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.230. - Violations of Title 17, ZONING-GENERALLY. 
    Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of the zoning code or violates the terms or conditions of any action imposed by the zoning board of review or by any other agency or officer charged in the zoning code with enforcement of any of its provisions shall be subject to the penalties provided under Chapter 1.12, unless otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.240. - Violation of Chapter 17.04, GENERAL PROVISIONS. 
    Whenever a violation of Section 17.04.050(A)(2)(b) occurs, the property owner shall be fined a minimum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for each day of the violation; and, additionally, each tenant on the lease shall be fined a minimum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for each day of the violation. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.250. - Violation of Chapter 17.76, SIGNS. 
    Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, or maintains or displays any sign without a license as required by Chapter 17.76, shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for every day such violation, maintenance or display continues. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
1.14.260. - Violation of Chapter 17.82, SIDEWALK CAFES. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the department of planning, zoning, development and inspections. A person who continues to violate this chapter after a written request to take corrective action is guilty of a municipal infraction and shall be fined no less than fifty dollars ($50.00) per day for each conviction plus court costs. In addition, the city council may revoke or suspend a permit issued pursuant to this chapter upon a second or subsequent conviction under this section in any twelve (12) month period. 
(Ord. 2003-8 § 2 (part), 2003) 
Title 2. - ADMINISTRATION 
Chapter 2.04. - CITY COUNCIL 

2.04.010. - Enacting clause of ordinances. 
    The enacting clause of all ordinances shall be "BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY OF NEWPORT." 
(Prior code § 214.01) 
2.04.020. - Authentication of ordinances and resolutions-Publication. 
    Upon its final passage, each ordinance or resolution of council shall be authenticated by the signature of the city clerk and shall be recorded in a book kept for that purpose. Copies of such ordinances and resolutions shall be available to the general public in the city clerk's office for public inspection and posted on the city's website. 
(Prior code § 214.02) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 2, 12-9-2009) 
2.04.030. - Attendance of officials at meetings. 
A.  City officials not otherwise specifically required to attend council meetings shall attend such meetings at which their presence is desired or required by council or the city manager. 
B.  The city clerk shall notify city officers of all meetings of council at which their presence is desired or required. 
(Prior code § 210.01) 
2.04.040. - Compensation. 
A.  Each member of the council shall receive an annual salary of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per year. Pursuant to Section 2-4 of the City Charter, such salary shall be not changed during the current term of the councilors enacting such an ordinance. Compensation may include benefits, such as health, life and dental insurance. 
B.  The chairman or chairwoman of the council shall receive as compensation for performance of his or her duties as mayor, in addition to his or her duties as councilor, two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per year, or such other compensation as council, by ordinance, prescribes, but such compensation shall not be changed during the term for which he or she was elected. 
(Prior code §§ 210.02, 212.01) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 3, 12-9-2009) 
2.04.050. - Annual reports. 
    All division heads shall make annual reports to their respective department heads. All department heads shall make annual reports to the city manager. The city manager shall consolidate all reports and make an annual report of the state of the city to council. 
(Prior code § 216.01) 
Chapter 2.06. - STANDARDS OF ETHICAL CONDUCT FOR COUNCIL MEMBERS 

2.06.010. - Preamble. 
    Public service is a public trust. Each council member has a responsibility to the state of Rhode Island, the city and their citizens to place loyalty to the Constitution, laws, ordinances, and ethical principles above private gain. To ensure that every citizen can have complete confidence in the integrity of the government of the city of Newport, each council member shall respect and adhere to the principles of ethical conduct as set forth in this ordinance as well as the implementing standards set forth in state law and regulations and the City Charter. 
(Ord. 2000-1 § 1 (part), 2001) 
2.06.020. - Basic principles. 
    The following basic principles apply to each councilor and form the basis of the standards contained in this chapter. Where a situation is not covered by the standards set forth in this chapter, councilors shall be governed by the principles set forth in this section in determining whether their conduct is proper. 
A.  Public service is a public trust, requiring councilors to place loyalty to the Constitution, laws, ordinances, and ethical principles above private gain. 
B.  A councilor shall not have any financial interest, direct or indirect, that conflicts with the conscientious performance of his or her duties. 
C.  Councilors shall not engage in financial transactions using nonpublic governmental information or allow the improper use of such information to further private interests. 
D.  Councilors shall put forth honest effort in the performance of their duties. 
E.  Councilors shall not use public office for private gain. 
F.  Councilors shall act impartially and not give preferential treatment to any private organization or individual. 
G.  Councilors shall satisfy in good faith their obligations as citizens, including all just financial obligations, especially those - such as federal, state, and local taxes - that are imposed by law. 
H.  Councilors shall adhere to all laws, ordinances, and regulations that provide equal opportunity to all individuals regardless of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, or age. 
(Ord. 2001-1 § 1 (part), 2001) 
2.06.030. - Acceptance of gift. 
A.  Except as specifically provided for in this chapter, no councilor shall, either directly or indirectly, solicit or accept a gift: 
1.  From an individual, business, agency, organization, club or similar institution: 
a.  Which is seeking official action from the city, 
b.  Which does business or seeks to do business with the city, 
c.  Which conducts business regulated by the city, 
d.  Which is a lessee of the city, 
e.  Which is a licensee or receives a license from the city, or 
f.  Which has an interest that may be substantially affected by the performance or nonperformance of the councilor. 
B.  Notwithstanding any exception provided in this ordinance, a councilor shall not: 
1.  Accept a gift in return for being influenced in the performance of an official act; 
2.  Accept gifts from an individual or business source on a basis so frequent that a reasonable person would be led to believe that the councilor is using his or her public office for private gain; or 
3.  Accept a gift in violation of any federal, state, or municipal law or regulation. 
C.  For the purpose of this chapter, a gift includes any gratuity, favor, discount, entertainment, membership, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other item having monetary value. It does not include: 
1.  Modest items of food and refreshments, such as soft drinks, coffee and donuts, offered other than as a part of a meal; 
2.  Greeting cards and items of little intrinsic value such as plaques, certificates, and trophies which are interned solely for presentation; 
3.  Loans from banks and other lending institution on terms available to the general public; 
4.  Opportunities or benefits available to the general public or to a class to which the councilor would otherwise be a member; 
5.  Rewards and prizes given to competitors in contests or events, including random drawings, open to the public; and 
6.  Anything for which market value is paid by the councilor. 
D.  Notwithstanding the above, a councilor may not accept for personal use any benefit to which the city is entitled as a result of the expenditure of city funds. 
(Ord. 2001-1 § 1 (part), 2001) 
2.06.040. - Exceptions. 
A.  Gift of five dollars or less. A councilor may accept an unsolicited gift having an aggregate market value of five dollars or less, providing the aggregate market value of individual gifts received from any one person or entity under the authority of this section shall not exceed fifteen dollars ($15.00) per calendar year. This exception does not apply to gift of cash, checks or investment interests such as stocks, bonds or certificates of deposit. Gifts of such items are specifically prohibited. When the market value of the gift exceeds the limits of this section the councilor may not pay the excess in order to accept the gift. 
B.  A councilor may accept gifts given under circumstances that make it clear that the gift is motivated by family relationship or personal friendship rather than the position of the councilor. 
C.  Gifts based on one's outside business or employment relationship may be accepted. 
D.  When a councilor is assigned to participate as a speaker or panelist or otherwise present information on behalf of the city, he or she may accept free attendance on the day of the participation. When the gathering is a widely attended gathering and there has been a determination that the councilor participation is in the interest of the city, the councilor may accept the sponsor's unsolicited offer of free attendance. 
(Ord. 2001-1 § 1 (part), 2001) 
Chapter 2.08. - CITY CLERK 

2.08.010. - Duties generally. 
A.  In addition to the duties prescribed by the laws of the state and by the City Charter, these Codified Ordinances and other ordinances of the city, the city clerk shall record all votes, orders, resolutions, ordinances, rules and regulations made and passed by council. However, it shall not be necessary to record these Codified Ordinances; publication of the same in book form shall be sufficient for all purposes. The city clerk shall furnish the director of finance with a certified copy of all votes of council requiring the expenditure of money as soon as practical after such votes have been passed. 
B.  Whenever the city sergeant is absent or unable to perform his or her duties or there is a vacancy in such office, his or her duties shall be temporarily performed by a person designated by the city clerk and the fact of such inability or vacancy shall be recorded in the records of the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 220.01) 
2.08.020. - Disposition of fees. 
    The city clerk shall strictly collect and receive, for the use of the city, all fees legally pertaining to his or her office, or due to or earned or demandable by him or her, as a recording officer or otherwise, and shall pay the same monthly to the director of finance, rendering a true and particular account thereof, under oath, with every such payment. 
(Prior code § 220.02) 
2.08.030. - Records of councilmanic action. 
    The city clerk shall record the ayes and nays on any ordinance, resolution or vote on any subject and make such vote a matter of public record of the action of council. 
(Prior code § 220.03) 
Chapter 2.12. - CITY SOLICITOR 

2.12.010. - Qualifications-General duties. 
A.  The city solicitor shall be a resident of the city and an attorney admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the state. 
B.  The city solicitor shall be principally responsible for the administration of the office of the city solicitor and shall supervise the work of the assistant city solicitors. 
(Prior code § 218.01) 
2.12.020. - Assistant city solicitor for law enforcement. 
    The city solicitor shall, with the approval of council, appoint an assistant city solicitor for law enforcement. The assistant city solicitor for law enforcement shall be a resident citizen of the city and admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the state. He or she shall work under the direction of the city solicitor and shall, in all cases, have the same powers and duties as the city solicitor, subject to the orders of the city solicitor. The assistant city solicitor for law enforcement shall serve at the pleasure of council and shall receive an annual salary as determined by council. 
(Prior code § 218.02) 
2.12.030. - Assistant city solicitor for civil litigation. 
    The city solicitor shall, with the approval of council, appoint an assistant city solicitor for civil litigation. The assistant city solicitor for civil litigation shall be a resident citizen of the city and admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the state. He or she shall work under the direction of the city solicitor and shall, in all cases, have the same powers and duties as the city solicitor, subject to the orders of the city solicitor. The assistant city solicitor for civil litigation shall serve at the pleasure of the council and shall receive an annual salary as determined by council. 
(Prior code § 218.03) 
Chapter 2.20. - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE 

2.20.010. - Composition-Divisions-Responsibilities of director. 
    Pursuant to Section 7-10 of the City Charter, a department of finance shall consist of the office of the director and such divisions as may be assigned. There shall be a chief of each such division who shall be responsible for the operation, supervision and control of the services assigned to each of the divisions. The chiefs of the divisions shall be subject to the direction of the director of finance. During the absence of the city treasurer, the director of finance shall have all the powers and duties granted or imposed upon the office of the city treasurer by any general or special law of the state or by any ordinance of the city. The office of the director shall maintain the records of bonds, the retirement thereof and the interest due thereunder and shall report to and advise the city manager relative to all matters pertaining thereto. It shall discharge such duties and render such services to the board of commissioners of the sinking funds as may be assigned to it by the city manager. 
(Prior code § 222.01) 
2.20.020. - Deputy director of finance. 
    The city treasurer shall be the deputy director of finance and, pursuant to Section 44-7-6 of the General Laws, as amended, shall perform all the duties and exercise all the powers which by law are imposed and conferred upon the collector of taxes. 
(Prior code § 222.02) 
2.20.030. - Division of purchasing-Controller. 
    There shall be a division of purchasing within the department of finance. The controller shall be charged with the duty of making all purchases for the city and all departments and divisions thereof, shall issue specifications and draft all proposals for bids, shall see that there is complete compliance with the provisions of all contracts entered into by the city, shall provide for inspection and shall see that all materials, supplies and equipment purchased by the city are in accordance with the specifications prescribed. 
(Prior code § 222.03) 
2.20.040. - Division of billing and collection. 
    The division of billing and collection shall be charged with the duty of collection of taxes, license fees, water charges and all other revenues and receipts of the city and all departments and agencies thereof. 
(Prior code § 222.04) 
2.20.050. - Division of accounts. 
    The division of accounts shall be charged with the duty of making all payments and disbursements on behalf of the city and all departments and agencies thereof. 
(Prior code § 222.05) 
2.20.060. - Division of assessment of taxes. 
    The division of assessment of taxes shall be charged with the duty of making assessments of taxes as required by law. The chief of this division shall be known as the assessor of taxes and shall have all of the powers, duties and responsibilities granted or imposed by law upon assessors of taxes. The assessor of taxes shall also be in charge of maintaining the land evidence records of the city and shall be known as the recorder of deeds of the city. 
(Prior code § 222.06) 
2.20.070. - When division chiefs to be under direction of city manager-Appointment and compensation of chiefs. 
    In the event of a vacancy in the office of the director of finance, or because of his or her absence or inability to act, each of the chiefs of the divisions shall be subject to the direction of the city manager. The chief of each division shall be a member of the classified civil service system of the city and shall be appointed by the city manager pursuant to the classified civil service system, and the salary of each division chief shall be determined by the city manager subject to the approval of council. 
(Prior code § 222.07) 
2.20.080. - Reassignment of duties. 
    The city manager may rearrange or reassign the work and duties of the divisions of the department of finance in such manner as, in his judgment, may promote efficiency and economy in the department and to ensure that all revenues and disbursements of the city are handled and audited through the department. 
(Prior code § 222.08) 
Chapter 2.24. - DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING, ZONING AND DEVELOPMENT 

2.24.010. - Composition. 
    The department of planning, zoning and development shall be composed of a director of planning, zoning and development who shall be responsible for planning, supervising and coordinating the physical planning and zoning activities of the city, under the general direction of the city manager, including the interpretation and enforcement of the zoning code. The department shall also consist of such employees as council deems proper. The salaries of such employees shall be as council determines. This department shall become effective on July 1, 1982. 
(Prior code § 230.01) 
Chapter 2.28. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS 

2.28.010. - Organization. 
A.  The department of public works shall consist of the division of highways and the division of equipment and maintenance. 
B.  The division of highways shall embrace the construction and maintenance of streets and sidewalks, the maintenance of all bridges, public parks, public buildings and cemeteries, street lighting and tree preservation. 
C.  The division of equipment and maintenance shall embrace the maintenance, service and repair of all equipment of all the departments of the city. 
D.  The city manager may rearrange the divisions or the work of the divisions in the department of public works if, in his judgment, greater economy and efficiency will be obtained. 
(Prior code § 232.01) 
Chapter 2.32. - DEPARTMENT OF WATER 

2.32.010. - Creation-Appointments-Control of water works. 
    In accordance with state law and with the provisions of the City Charter, there is created a water department as an integral part of the city government. The officers and personnel of the water department shall be appointed and shall serve as the officers and personnel of the other departments of the city. No individual entity or corporate entity shall exist in the Newport Water Works other than in the water department of the city. 
(Prior code § 238.01) 
Chapter 2.36. - DEPARTMENT OF WATER POLLUTION CONTROL 

2.36.010. - Creation-Responsibilities of director. 
    The department of water pollution control is created. It shall be headed by a director, who shall have supervision and control of the department subject to the direction of the city manager. The director shall be responsible for the operation and maintenance of the city sewage treatment plant, the main pumping station and all outlying city sewage pumping and ejector stations and shall also be responsible for the cleaning, maintenance, inspection and supervision of construction of the city storm and sanitary systems. The director shall perform all other duties required of him for the proper and economical function of the entire city sewerage system. 
(Prior code § 240.01) 
2.36.020. - Moratorium on new sewer connections. 
    To safeguard the health of the public, effective January 1, 2007, there shall be a moratorium on all new sewer connections to the city's waste water treatment system until such time as the city is in compliance for three consecutive months with the waste water discharge permit issued by the Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management. 
(Ord. 2006-42 § 1, 2006) 
Chapter 2.40. - POLICE DIVISION 

2.40.010. - Composition-Appointments. 
A.  The chief of police shall be appointed pursuant to the City Charter and shall be in the unclassified service. 
B.  The assistant chief of police shall be appointed in the same manner as the chief of police and shall also be in the unclassified service. 
C.  All other members of the police division shall be members of the classified service and shall be appointed and promoted in accordance with civil service laws of the city. 
D.  The reserve force and auxiliary force shall be appointed in accordance with the ordinances of the city. 
E.  Council shall determine the number of employees of the police division by its adoption of the annual budget ordinance and other ordinances that council may from time to time adopt. 
(Prior code § 226.01) 
2.40.020. - Police cadets. 
A.  Police cadets are those persons who are eligible to become regular members of the police division upon completion of the Municipal Police Training School, who have signified in writing their intention to join the division upon their graduation and who have been approved by the director of public safety. 
B.  Police cadets may be sworn in as temporary members of the division, but shall not be considered members of the permanent and regular division and shall not be entitled to any of the benefits afforded permanent police officers. 
C.  Police cadets shall be given training courses in all phases of police work. They shall have authority to issue parking and traffic tickets for motor vehicle violations and they shall be eligible to serve special details. 
(Prior code § 226.02) 
2.40.030. - Rules and regulations. 
    The director of public safety and the chief of police shall promulgate rules and regulations for the police division consistent with the provisions and rules of the classified civil service. Such rules and regulations shall become effective after approval of the city manager pursuant to Section 5-4(h) of the City Charter. 
(Prior code § 226.03) 
2.40.040. - Reserve police officers. 
    Whenever council declares by public act that because of the imminent presence in the city of three thousand (3,000) or more visitors during a specified period, a condition exists that such action is required for the preservation of public safety, health and welfare, the director of public safety is authorized and directed to engage and swear in as reserve police officers as many persons as he deems necessary to preserve public safety, health and welfare, for such period of time as he deems necessary. 
(Prior code § 226.04) 
2.40.050. - Auxiliary police force. 
A.  Purpose. An auxiliary police force is authorized, to consist of as many men as the director of public safety deems necessary, to assist the permanent police force in the performance of police duties within the city. 
B.  Chain of Command. The auxiliary police force shall be under the command of the chief of police, who shall appoint its officers. 
C.  Rules and Regulations. The chief of police, with the advice and consent of the director of public safety, shall establish rules and regulations which shall set forth qualifications for membership in the auxiliary police force, the manner in which auxiliary police officers shall perform their duties, the uniform to be worn, training and all other items for which rules and regulations are necessary. 
D.  Appointment of Members-Oath of Office. Members of the auxiliary police force shall be appointed by the director of public safety, upon the written approval of the chief of police, and shall take an oath of office to be administered by the city clerk. 
E.  Removal of Members. Members of the auxiliary police force may be removed by the director of public safety on the recommendation of the chief of police. 
F.  Compensation Generally. Members of the auxiliary police force shall not be on salary and shall not be considered regular employees of the city for pension or other purposes, but they shall be compensated for particular details and duties, as is set forth in the rules and regulations. 
(Ord. 20-89 § 1, 1989; prior code § 226.05) 
Chapter 2.44. - FIRE DIVISION 

2.44.010. - Composition. 
    The division of fire of the department of public safety shall consist of a chief, deputy chiefs, captains, lieutenants and firefighters as provided by the budget ordinance of the city. 
(Prior code § 228.01) 
2.44.020. - Powers of fire chief. 
    The fire chief shall have full power and authority over the direction, management and operation of the fire division, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 228.02) 
2.44.030. - Arrest of persons interfering with firefighters at fires. 
    The fire chief and all officers of the fire division shall have the power to cause the arrest of any person who hinders, obstructs or distracts a firefighter in the performance of his or her duties at a fire. 
(Prior code § 228.03) 
Chapter 2.48. - MUNICIPAL COURT 

2.48.010. - Establishment. 
    Pursuant to Chapter 511 of the Public Laws of 1987, there is established in and for the city a municipal court. 
(Prior code § 299.01) 
2.48.020. - Jurisdiction. 
A.  Council confers on the municipal court original jurisdiction to hear and determine causes involving violations of: 
1.  Any ordinance of the city; 
2.  Historical area zoning and zoning ordinances as well as proceedings brought pursuant to Section 23-27.3-122.2 of the General Laws of Rhode Island and to have jurisdiction conferred on courts therein; and 
3.  Minimum housing ordinances, including any violation of Title 45, Chapter 24.3 of the General Laws of Rhode Island, entitled "The Rhode Island Housing Maintenance and Occupancy Code." 
    However, any defendant found guilty of any offense, excluding violations of the minimum housing ordinance or Chapter 24.3 within the jurisdiction of the municipal court, may, within seven days of such conviction, file an appeal from such conviction with the Newport County Superior Court and be entitled in the superior court to a trial de novo. Further, any defendant found guilty of any violation of a minimum housing ordinance or of Chapter 24.3 may, within seven days of such conviction, file an appeal from the conviction to the Second Division of the District Court and be entitled to a trial de novo in accordance with Sections 8-8-3(a)(4) and 8-8-3.2 of the General Laws of Rhode Island. 
B.  With respect to violations of either municipal ordinances dealing with minimum housing, historical area zoning or zoning ordinances or Chapter 45-24.3 et seq. of the General Laws of Rhode Island dealing with housing maintenance and occupancy, or Chapter 45-24 et seq. of the General Laws of Rhode Island dealing with the enforcement of zoning regulations, or Section 23-27.3-122.2 of the General Laws of Rhode Island regarding prosecution of violations of the state building code, the council confers upon the municipal court, in furtherance of the jurisdiction mentioned in subsection A of this section, the power to proceed according to equity: 
1.  To restrain, prevent, enjoin, abate or correct a violation; 
2.  To order the repair, vacation or demolition of any dwelling existing in violation; or 
3.  To otherwise compel compliance with all provisions of such ordinances and statutes. 
(Ord. 2000-3 § 1, 2000: prior code § 299.07) 
2.48.030. - Judge. 
A.  The municipal court shall be composed of one judge appointed by council. Such judge shall serve until his or her successor is duly appointed. 
B.  The term of appointment for such judge shall be temporary in nature, until a permanent judge is appointed by council for the balance of the council elective term. 
C.  The judge shall be a lawyer admitted to practice before the Supreme Court of the state, in good standing, and shall have not less than two years of experience in the active practice of law. 
D.  Nothing in this section shall preclude the appointment of the probate judge of the city as judge of the municipal court. 
(Prior code § 299.02) 
2.48.040. - Acting judge. 
    In the case of sickness, absence or other disability or ineligibility of the municipal court judge, council may, by resolution, appoint an acting municipal court judge for the term of such sickness, absence, disability or ineligibility at such salary as council may determine. An acting judge shall perform all duties of the municipal court judge, and in the performance of such duties shall have the same effect as if performed by the municipal court judge. 
(Prior code § 299.12) 
2.48.050. - Clerk of court. 
A.  The city manager shall appoint a clerk of court in accordance with normal personnel procedures. 
B.  The clerk of court shall keep a regular docket of all cases disposed of; shall record the judgments, orders and sentences of the court; and shall furnish certified copies thereof when required, for which copies the clerk shall charge the same fees as are allowed to clerks of the superior court. The clerk's office shall be open to the public during such hours as the municipal court shall determine. 
(Prior code § 299.04) 
2.48.060. - Seal-Oaths. 
A.  The municipal court shall have a seal which shall contain such words and device as council shall adopt and approve. 
B.  The judge and the clerk of court may administer oaths and affirmations. 
(Prior code § 299.05) 
2.48.070. - Compensation of judge. 
A.  The compensation of the judge of the municipal court shall be seven thousand, five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) for the first six months. 
B.  The compensation of the judge may be increased by council. 
(Prior code § 299.11) 
2.48.080. - Complaints-Warrants-Writs. 
    The judge of the municipal court may prescribe and vary the form of all complaints, warrants, writs or other processes so as to make the same consistent with the organization, style and jurisdiction of such court. Such complaints, warrants, writs and other processes shall have the same effect, validity and extent, and shall be served, obeyed, enforced and returned in the same manner and by the same officers, as if issued from the district courts, and they may be served by any constable of the city who is authorized to serve process in civil or criminal cases. 
(Prior code § 299.09) 
2.48.090. - Witnesses-Attendance-Subpoenas. 
    The municipal court may issue writs or summonses for witnesses, compel their attendance and punish contempt by fine or imprisonment. Such court shall also issue writs of habeas corpus and testificandum, and upon continuance of any complaint or proceeding before it, may take recognizance to the state, with surety or sureties in such sum as the court thinks proper, with the condition to appear before such court and make further answer to such complaint or proceeding, and in the meantime to keep the peace, and in want thereof, may commit the person to the state adult correctional institution until such recognizance is given or the parties lawfully discharged therefrom. 
(Prior code § 299.03) 
2.48.100. - Time and place of sessions. 
    The municipal court shall be considered to be in session at all times, at such place or places in the city as the court or judge holding the same shall appoint. 
(Prior code § 299.06) 
2.48.110. - Failure to appear. 
    Failure to appear in the municipal court, upon receipt of a summons or complaint, shall constitute a separate violation of the ordinance codified in this section. 
(Ord. 17-91 § 1 (part), 1991: prior code § 299.13) 
2.48.120. - Costs. 
A.  Costs taxed by the municipal court shall be the same as those taxed by a district court for misdemeanor violations under the General Laws of Rhode Island, except, however, for zoning violations there shall be a minimum cost taxed of one hundred dollars ($100.00). The payment of such costs shall be a part of the sentence to the extent it would be in district court. 
B.  All payments shall be deposited to the city in the appropriate fund. 
C.  The costs incurred by the city in securing a policeman's presence, upon the request of the defendant, shall be charged to the defendant in the event s/he shall fail to appear. 
(Ord. 5-96 § 1, 1996; Ord. 17-91 § 1 (part), 1991; prior code § 299.10) 
2.48.130. - Maximum penalties. 
    The municipal court may impose a sentence not to exceed thirty (30) days in jail and/or impose a fine not in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and/or require community service, or any combination thereof, and shall be authorized to punish persons for contempt. 
(Ord. 2002-55 § 1, 2002; Ord. 99-28 § 1, 1999: Ord. 42-93 § 1, 1993: Sec. 1, Chapter 91, P.L., 1993: prior code § 299.08) 
2.48.140. - Fines or costs constituing a lien. 
    All fines or costs ordered to be paid by landowners of real property located in the city, by final judgment of the municipal court in any proceeding dealing with minimum housing, historical area zoning or Chapter 45-24.3, regarding housing maintenance and occupancy or prosecutions pursuant to Section 23-27.3-122.2, shall constitute a lien on the property in the city giving rise to the violation in question. 
(Ord. 2000-3 § 2, 2000) 
Chapter 2.52. - PROBATE COURT 

2.52.010. - Sessions-Compensation of judge. 
    The judge of the probate court shall hold court in the city hall twice a month, and at such other times and places as necessity may require. The judge, instead of the fees of the court, shall be compensated as provided by the council. 
    Whenever the judge of probate court is a party, or is interested in any proceeding about to be heard in his or her court, or is absent or unable to perform his or her duties, or there is a vacancy in such office, the duties shall be temporarily performed by the municipal court judge, and the fact of such interest, absence, inability, or vacancy shall be recorded in the records of said court. 
(Prior code § 298.01) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 4, 12-9-2009) 
2.52.020. - Compensation of clerk-Disposition of fees-Accounts and notices. 
    The probate clerk, instead of fees, shall be compensated as provided by Section 2.52.010, as his entire and only compensation. However, the clerk shall collect and receive, for the use of the city, all lawful fees pertaining to the court and clerk, respectively, or due to, earned, or demandable by, the clerk, as a recording officer, or otherwise, or due to, or demandable by or for, the court, and the clerk shall pay all the same to the director of finance every month, rendering a true and particular account thereof, under oath, with every such payment, provided that in all applications for letters of administration, letters testamentary or letters of guardianship, the actual collection of any fees accruing prior to the granting of such letters may be postponed until such letters have been granted, but no longer. The probate clerk shall file weekly in the office of the tax assessor notice of the pendency of wills, administration, trust estate, etc., in probate court. Such notice shall recite the declared value of such estates, the appraisers' estimate, reports of executors, administrators and trustees, the names of heirs, devisees and legatees, or persons having an interest by operation of the law of descent with the amounts or estate to which it appears such heirs, legatees or devisees may be entitled. 
(Prior code § 298.02) 
2.52.030. - Remission of probate fees. 
    The probate court is authorized to remit the fees due to or collectible by the court thereof from those estates which, from their poverty or the poverty of the parties interested therein, in the judgment of the court, render such remission just and reasonable, but the probate clerk shall, in his or her monthly accounts to the director of finance, render a true and particular account of all fees remitted as herein provided, giving, together with the amount of such fees, the names of the respective estates on which such remissions are made, and, if requested, the condition of the same at the time of remission. 
(Prior code § 298.03) 
2.52.040. - Clerk's bond. 
    The probate clerk shall give bond to the city treasurer, in such sum and with such surety as are satisfactory to council, for the faithful collection and the faithful payment to the director of finance, as aforesaid, of all the fees aforesaid. 
(Prior code § 298.04) 
Chapter 2.56. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS GENERALLY 

2.56.010. - General provisions. 
A.  With the exception of the Film Commission, the Hospitality Commission, and the Tree and Open Space Commission, all members of boards and commissions must be registered voters in the City of Newport and reside in the city on a year-round basis. 
B.  Appointments to all boards and commissions shall be for specified terms. A member of a board or commission may serve no more than two consecutive full terms. Nothing herein shall prohibit the appointment of a member for an additional term beyond that described above, provided the individual has been absent from the board or commission for at least one full year, or the appointment is to a different board or commission. 
C.  In the event a member of a board or commission has special qualifications and the board or commission requires those special qualifications, or for other good reason, the city council, with five members concurring, may reappoint such member, notwithstanding the fact that such member has already served two consecutive terms. 
D.  No person shall serve concurrently on more than two boards or commissions. 
E.  Failure of a member of a board or commission to attend at least seventy-five (75) percent of the board or commission's scheduled meetings shall be grounds for replacing said member. 
F.  Upon submitting an application for membership on a city board, committee, or commission, the applicant shall sign an ethics statement declaring that said appointment does not, and will not, constitute or create a known conflict of interest and that said applicant will respect and uphold the high standard of dignity and integrity espoused in the city's core values of honesty, trust and integrity. 
(Ord. 2008-35 § 1, 2008; Ord. 2002-52 § 1, 2002: Ord. 12-89 § 1 (part), 1989: prior code § 271.01) 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 4-22-2009; Ord. No. 2011-007, § 1, 4-27-2011; Ord. No. 2015-17, § 1, 7-8-2015) 
2.56.020. - Expiration of terms-Notification. 
    Upon the expiration of a board or commission member's term, the city clerk shall notify the chairperson of said board or commission in order that the member may request reappointment. 
(Ord. 12-89 § 1 (part), 1989: prior code § 271.02) 
2.56.030. - Chairperson. 
A.  A member of a board or commission may serve no more than one full term as chairperson. 
B.  Unless otherwise specific by state statute, each board or commission shall elect its own chairperson. If a board or commission does not elect a chairperson within ninety (90) days of a vacancy, the city council shall elect the chairperson for that particular board or commission. If this section is found to be in conflict with other ordinance provisions that relate to a specific board or commission, this section shall govern. 
(Ord. 12-89 § 1 (part), 1989: prior code § 271.03) 
2.56.040. - Annual reports. 
    Every December, all boards and commission shall submit an annual report to the city council setting forth a summary of their yearly activities, including the attendance record of its members. 
(Ord. 12-89 § 1 (part), 1989: prior code § 271.04) 
2.56.050. - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall apply prospectively and members of boards and commissions may serve two consecutive terms following the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
(Ord. 12-89 § 1 (part), 1989: prior code § 271.05) 
Chapter 2.60. - RESERVED. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-18, § 1, adopted July 18, 2015, repealed §§ 2.60.010-2.60.040, which pertained to the building code board of appeals and derived from Prior Code §§ 1442.01-1442.04; Ord. No. 62-94, § 1, adopted 1994. 
Chapter 2.62 - JUVENILE HEARING BOARD 

2.62.010. - Purpose-Establishment. 
A.  Pursuant to Chapter 45-2 of the Rhode Island General Laws, and for the purpose of promoting the public health, safety, morals and general welfare, a juvenile hearing board shall be established in the city for the purpose of hearing all cases referred to it by the chief of police of the Newport police department or his/her designee, with respect to persons under the age of eighteen (18) who are charged with violating the penal laws of the state of Rhode Island or the ordinances of the city. 
B.  Said board shall be called the Newport juvenile hearing board. 
(Ord. 99-43 § 1 (part), 1999) 
2.62.020. - Membership. 
A.  The membership of the Newport juvenile hearing board (the board) shall consist of six members who shall be qualified electors of the city. In addition, there may be two additional auxiliary members who shall serve as active members at the request of the chairperson of the board in the event any regular member or members are unable to serve at any hearing or proceeding. These auxiliary members shall also be qualified electors of the city. 
B.  The members shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city council of the city. The members of the board shall elect a chairperson who shall serve for a two-year term. 
C.  The term of appointment shall be for three years except that the initial appointment may be for a term of less than three years in order to stagger the appointments. 
D.  Appointed members of the board shall be eligible to be reappointed and, upon expiration of their term, shall continue to serve until another is appointed in their place or until reappointed. 
(Ord. 99-43 § 1 (part), 1999) 
2.62.030. - Referral to juvenile hearing board. 
A.  Persons who are under the age of eighteen (18) years may be referred to the board, which shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the Rhode Island family court, if the alleged act would support a finding of waywardness or delinquency in the family court, including but not limited to violation of compulsory school attendance laws or, if such act constitutes an offense which if committed by an adult would be a violation, petty misdemeanor or misdemeanor provided, however, that no referral shall be made in the case of any person: 
1.  Who shall have been twice previously referred to the board; or 
2.  Who shall have been once previously referred to the board and refused or failed to abide by the sanctions imposed or to have made the restitution recommended; or 
3.  Who shall, at the time of the commission of the offense, be within the custody and control of the Rhode Island family court, with the exception of guardianship proceedings. 
B.  The chief of police for the city of Newport police department or his/her designee may order referral to the board of any other juvenile offender where, in the opinion of the chief of police or his/her designee, such referral would be beneficial to the juvenile concerned or the community at large. 
C.  No referral to the board shall be made until such person, together with his/her legal guardian or legal representative, shall have in writing waived such person's right to an initial hearing in the family court with respect to the offense charged, has admitted to the offense and has agreed to abide by the decision of the board. 
(Ord. 99-43 § 1 (part), 1999) 
2.62.040. - Duties of the board. 
A.  The board shall be authorized to hear all cases referred to it by the chief of police of the city of Newport police department, or his/her designee, and to impose and order sanctions other than incarceration. Sanctions may include, but are not limited to, the following or any combination thereof: 
1.  Fines up to a maximum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense charged; 
2.  Community service; 
3.  Restitution for any injuries or property damage, where appropriate, resulting from the commission of the offense; 
4.  Imposition of a reasonable curfew; 
5.  Denial, suspension or revocation of driving privileges for a period of up to two years; 
6.  Referrals for counseling/intervention services; 
7.  Letter of apology as deemed appropriate to victims and other interested parties, a written explanation to the board, or other written composition by the offender. 
B.  In any such proceedings the board shall, prior to the imposition of any sanctions, request the juvenile offender and his/her parents, legal guardians and legal representative to agree to the sanctions imposed, the amount of restitution ordered and the manner of making same. In ordering restitution, the board shall consider the juvenile offender's ability to pay and the amount of actual damages caused as a result of the commission of the offenses. 
(Ord. 99-43 § 1 (part), 1999) 
2.62.050. - Quorum-Rules. 
A.  A majority of the board's members shall constitute a quorum and a majority of the members present shall be required to take any action. Any juvenile offender may be represented by counsel and may present evidence in his/her own behalf. 
B.  The board shall have power from time to time to adopt and publish any and all rules and regulations necessary to carry out its functions under the provisions of this act or ordinance establishing the board. 
C.  The board shall give notice of the date, time and place of its meetings to the city of Newport police department, the chief of police, or his/her designee, the juvenile offender and his/her parents, legal guardians or legal representative not less than seven days prior to the date of the hearing. 
D.  Board proceedings shall be closed to the public and the provisions of Chapter 42 of title 46 of the Rhode Island General Laws shall not apply to such proceedings. All records of proceedings, including records concerning the arrest, apprehension or detention of any juvenile offender shall be withheld from public inspection but such records shall be available to the parent, guardian or legal representative of the juvenile for inspection. 
(Ord. 99-43 § 1 (part), 1999) 
Chapter 2.64. - PERSONNEL APPEALS BOARD 

2.64.010. - Established-Membership. 
A.  A personnel appeals board shall be established consisting of three members. Two shall be appointed by council and the third elected from among employees in the classified service. Members shall respect the application of merit principles to public employment. No member of the board shall hold or be a candidate for any elective office. 
B.  Employees in the bargaining unit designated by the State Labor Relations Board in Certification No. EE 1764 shall not be eligible to participate in the election of, or to serve as members of, the personnel appeals board. 
(Prior code § 292.03 (a), (c)) 
2.64.020. - Organization. 
A.  The personnel appeals board shall organize itself by electing one member as chairman annually. Each member shall take an official oath of office before assuming his duties and affirm a will and belief to support the merit system. Vacancies during any term will be filled by council or by employee election for the balance of the term of the vacancy. Members shall serve without compensation. 
B.  The board shall meet at least once every three months. 
(Prior code § 292.03 (d), (f)) 
2.64.030. - Terms of members. 
    Members of the board shall serve for a term of three years. The incumbent members of the existing board shall continue in their present term. 
(Prior code § 292.03 (b)) 
2.64.040. - Duties. 
A.  The board shall serve as the final board of appeals on questions arising in the administration of Chapters 3.04 through 3.52. 
B.  The board shall act in an advisory capacity to the city manager. 
C.  The board shall investigate all appeals from employees relating to the administration of Chapters 3.04 through 3.52. 
(Prior code § 292.03 (e), (g), (h)) 
Chapter 2.68. - PLANNING BOARD 

2.68.010. - Creation-General powers. 
    The planning board of the city, which was established by ordinance pursuant to Chapter 847 of the Public Laws of 1940, is reconstituted and appointed pursuant to the provisions of Chapters 22 and 23 of Title 45 of the General Laws, and the board shall hereafter have all the powers granted to planning boards by Chapters 22 and 23 of Title 45 of the General Laws. 
(Prior code § 246.01) 
2.68.020. - Composition-Officers-Compensation-Meetings. 
A.  The planning board shall consist of nine members, who are residents of the city, to be nominated by the mayor and elected by council. The present members of the board shall continue to hold office until their successors have been elected and qualified. On November 1, council shall elect such members for a term of three years as are necessary to fill the office of those whose terms expire that year. Any vacancies on the board shall be filled by council for the balance of the unexpired term. In January of each year, the board shall organize by electing a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary. 
B.  Members of the board shall serve without compensation but shall be compensated for their necessary and actual traveling expenses in the performance of their official duties, to be paid out of any funds appropriated for the use of the board. 
C.  Regular meetings of the board shall be held at least once a month on such days as the board may determine, and special meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman or on the written request of three members.
