The board shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep permanent and complete records of its proceedings, meetings, hearings and recommendations. Five members of the board shall constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting and no action shall be taken except by the concurring vote of not less than five members. 
D.  As of December 11, 1968, all members of the board who have been holding over since their terms expired on October 31, 1968, and the two new members herein provided for, shall be appointed to serve staggered terms in the following manner: three members for one year, their terms to expire October 31, 1969; three members for terms of two years each, to expire October 31, 1970; and three members for a term of three years each, to expire October 31, 1971. As each member's term expires, his successors shall be appointed for a term of three years. 
(Prior code § 246.02) 
2.68.030. - Duties generally-Master plan. 
    The planning board shall, when requested by council, make studies and, when necessary, prepare plans of the resources and needs of the city, with reference to its physical growth and development as affecting the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the people and the economy and efficiency of communal life. Such studies and plans may include, among other things, the following: land use; zoning; transportation facilities; public utilities; public facilities, including schools, parks, beaches and other public areas and structures; blighted areas, including plans for the redevelopment, rehabilitation and prevention of slum districts; air and water pollution; natural resources; protection from disaster; and economic and sociological characteristics of the city. The master plan or the comprehensive master plan for the city previously adopted by the board shall remain in full force and effect and may be amended or modified by the board as it deems advisable. Such plan shall show, among other things, the existing and proposed location and arrangement of the uses of land in the city; zoning districts; highways and appurtenant structures; transportation and utility routes, facilities and structures; public schools, parks and recreation areas; and public buildings and facilities. The board shall not adopt, modify or amend such comprehensive plan until after a public hearing. The board shall give notice specifying the time and place of such hearing by publication of such notice in a newspaper of general circulation within the city at least twice a week for three successive weeks prior to the date of such hearing. At such hearing, an opportunity shall be given to all persons interested in being heard upon the matter of the proposed comprehensive plan or of such modification or amendment. 
(Prior code § 246.03) 
2.68.040. - Federal, state and local assistance. 
A.  The planning board may call upon all other departments, boards or agencies of the city and agencies of the state and federal governments for assistance in the performance of its designated functions and shall cooperate with such other city departments and with state and federal agencies on community, regional and state planning and development. All city officials, boards and agencies shall, upon request, furnish the board such available information as it may require for its work. 
B.  Technical review committee. The following members of city departments or their designees shall sit from time to time as a technical review committee: 
City planner (administrative officer). 
Zoning officer. 
Director civic investment. 
Director public services. 
Director utilities. 
Director zoning and inspections. 
Preservation planner. 
City engineer. 
Buildings and grounds supervisor fire marshal. 
Traffic sergeant, or other selected official from the Newport Police Department. 
    The purpose of the technical review committee shall be to assist the planning board by providing professional and technical advice, comment and recommendations on matters referred to the technical review committee by the planning board and also for any required zoning development plan review with the intent to promote more informed decision making by the planning board. Reports from the technical review committee providing findings and recommendations shall be advisory and non-binding on the planning board. 
    The technical review committee shall also serve as the review agency for development plan review for applications for uses that are permitted by right if it is set forth in and established by the zoning ordinances as the review agent for the same. A written record of the technical review committee's proceedings shall be maintained and made a part of the record of any development application. 
    The city planner shall serve as the administrative officer of the technical review committee which shall meet as necessary. 
(Prior code § 246.04) 
(Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, 9-12-2018) 
2.68.050. - Annual report to council-Approval of plans. 
    The planning board shall report annually, in April, to council, summarizing the work of the preceding year and recommending plans of future development. All plans and reports of the board shall be first submitted to council and thereafter, subject to approval by council, the board may publish and distribute copies of plans and reports to promote public interest in and understanding of the work of the board. 
(Prior code § 246.05) 
2.68.060. - Employees-Expenditures. 
    The planning board, subject to approval by the city manager, may appoint such assistants and employees as it may deem necessary and may also employ consultants or enter into agreements with state, federal or regional agencies. The board may incur any expense necessary therefor, but it shall not for any purpose contract for or incur any expense larger than the amount appropriated or available therefor in the annual city budget. 
(Prior code § 246.06) 
2.68.070. - Submission of proposed ordinances to board for recommendations. 
    Council may submit any proposed ordinance or resolution to the planning board for its recommendation where the subject matter of such proposed ordinance or resolution may concern any matters within the scope of Section 2.68.040. Nothing in this section, however, shall be construed to require council to submit any proposed ordinance or resolution to the board, or to restrict or prevent council from acting on any ordinance or resolution contrary to or in the absence of a recommendation of the board. 
(Prior code § 246.07) 
2.68.080. - Subdivision regulations. 
    For the purpose of promoting the general health, safety and general welfare, by governing and restricting the plotting and subdivision of land in the city, the planning board is authorized to adopt rules and regulations governing and restricting the plotting or other subdivision of land within the city, and from time to time to modify and amend such rules and regulations as it may adopt. The board is further authorized to control the subdivision of land within the city pursuant to such rules and regulations and subject to and in accordance with the provisions of Title 45, Chapter 23, of the General Laws. 
(Prior code § 246.08) 
Chapter 2.72. - NEWPORT BEACH COMMISSION 

2.72.010. - Establishment-Composition-Terms of office. 
    There is established in and for the city a Newport beach commission. The commission shall consist of nine members appointed by council for staggered three-year terms. The director of recreation and public services shall serve as an ex officio member. 
(Prior code § 265.01) 
2.72.020. - Powers and duties. 
    The Newport beach commission shall be charged with the following: 
A.  Reviewing all improvements proposed to council, including capital improvement, budget and parking and user fee recommendations, and advising council on its findings; 
B.  Submitting plans, reviews and recommendations to council on all private and public development; 
C.  Holding public hearings and requesting interested residents of the city to appear at these hearings to offer suggestions or provide information concerning beach operations, maintenance and improvements; 
D.  Establishing its own procedures and organization to most effectively accomplish its task of advising council on beach matters and in gaining public support and patronage of the beach; 
E.  Being responsible and accountable to council for its recommendations; and 
F.  Making recommendations for King Park and People's Beach. 
(Prior code § 265.02) 
Chapter 2.76. - CLIFF WALK COMMISSION 

2.76.010. - Creation-Function. 
    There is created a Cliff Walk commission to be appointed by council, which commission shall raise, manage and expend all funds contributed to or by the city for the repair, renovation, improvement and maintenance of that certain walk known as "Cliff Walk," situated in the city and passing along the face of the cliffs and land between Easton's Beach and Bailey's Beach, which walk was originally created by the owners of land abutting on the cliffs and which walk shall be open to the general public for the purpose of passing and repassing on foot along the face of the cliffs. 
(Ord. 200-13 § 1, 2000: prior code § 256.01) 
2.76.020. - Composition-Terms-Vacancies-Compensation-Meetings. 
A.  The Cliff Walk commission shall consist of six members. The mayor shall be an ex officio member and council shall elect five other members, as follows: one to hold office until November 1, 1967; one to hold office until November 1, 1968; one to hold office until November 1, 1969; one to hold office until November 1, 1970; and one to hold office until November 1, 1971. Thereafter, beginning on November 1, 1967, council shall elect one member to hold office until November 1st in the fifth year next following the time of such election. Each member of the commission shall hold office until a successor is elected and qualified. In the case of a vacancy on the commission from any cause, council shall elect a person to the commission to fill the vacancy for the remainder of the unexpired term. The members of the commission shall serve at the pleasure of council and may be removed by council for any reason it may deem sufficient. 
B.  Members of the commission shall serve without compensation, but shall be compensated for their necessary and actual traveling expenses in the performance of their official duties, to be paid out of any funds appropriated for the use of the commission. 
C.  Regular meetings of the commission shall be held at least once every two months on such days as the commission may determine or as often as may be deemed necessary. Special meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman or at the written request of two members. 
D.  The commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep permanent and complete public records of its proceedings and meetings, all of which meetings shall be open to the general public. Three members of the commission shall constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting and no action shall be taken except by the concurring vote of not less than three members. In November of 1966 and in the month of November every two years thereafter, the commission shall organize by electing a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary. 
(Prior code § 256.02) 
2.76.030. - Funds and disbursements-Records. 
A.  All moneys contributed to the city and specifically designated to be used for the renovation, improvement, repair and maintenance of the Cliff Walk shall be held by the director of finance, who shall report to the chairman of the Cliff Walk commission all contributions so made. The director shall expend all such moneys only upon written invoices signed by the chairman and secretary and approved by the commission at a regular or special meeting. 
B.  The director shall keep a record of all moneys which come into his or her possession and of all disbursements therefrom, and as often as called upon to do so, he or she shall render to the commission an account in detail of all receipts and disbursements of moneys coming into his or her possession specifically designated for the use of the commission. The director shall, when called upon, give such other further information in regard to the moneys in his or her possession as may be requested of him or her by the commission and his or her books shall at all times be open to inspection. 
(Prior code § 256.03) 
2.76.040. - Rules and regulations-Limitation on expenditures. 
    The Cliff Walk commission may make such rules and regulations for use by the public of the Cliff Walk as it may deem advisable, and the commission shall have full authority and power to solicit contributions for the purposes hereof and to enter into and execute such contracts in relation to the repair, renovation, improvement and maintenance of the Cliff Walk, and any other expenditures incidental thereto, as it may deem necessary and expedient, provided, however, that the commission shall have no power to obligate the city in excess of any contributions or appropriations made for such purposes. 
(Prior code § 256.04) 
2.76.050. - Cooperation from city departments. 
    The Cliff Walk commission is authorized to call upon any city department, through the office of the city manager, for assistance in implementing its duty of restoring and maintaining the Cliff Walk for the use of the general public. 
(Prior code § 256.05) 
2.76.060. - Annual report. 
    The Cliff Walk commission shall report annually in the month of November to council, summarizing the work of the preceding year and including the recommendations of future plans. 
(Prior code § 256.06) 
Chapter 2.80. - NEWPORT CULTURAL COMMISSION 

2.80.010. - Creation-Function-Responsibilities. 
    There is created a Newport cultural commission to be appointed by council, which commission shall manage and expend all funds contributed to or by the city to enhance the cultural environment and welfare through ensuring the development, promotion and vitality of the city's cultural resources and encouraging participation in and awareness of the arts by all residents of the city. To do this, the commission shall undertake to provide services and assistance to cultural organizations and artists; to initiate, sponsor and conduct public programs with other public or private agencies; to represent the city in cultural matters before state and federal agencies; to advise and assist the city in matters relating to cultural resource development; to undertake inventories of local cultural resources; to secure such information as is necessary to carry out its mandate. 
(Ord. 36-90 § 1 (part), 1990: prior code § 260.01) 
2.80.020. - Composition-Appointments-Terms-Vacancies-Compensation. 
    The Newport cultural commission shall consist of fifteen (15) members representing the major agencies involved in the cultural affairs of the city. Members shall be appointed by council. Each member shall serve a term of three years, beginning on the date of his or her appointment. Members shall be eligible for reappointment for one additional full term only. Each member of the commission shall hold office until a successor is elected and qualified. In the case of a vacancy on the commission, from any cause, council shall elect a person to the commission to fill such vacancy for the remainder of the unexpired term. The commission may recommend qualified replacements, but the members of the commission shall serve at the pleasure of the council and may be removed by council for any reason it may deem sufficient. Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. 47-93 § 1, 1993) 
2.80.030. - Meetings-Rules-Records-Officers. 
A.  Regular meetings of the Newport cultural commission shall be held at least once every three months on such days as the commission may determine, or as often as may be deemed necessary. Special meetings shall be held at the call of the chairman or at the written request of three members. 
B.  The commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep permanent and complete public records of its proceedings and meetings, all of which meetings shall be open to the general public. A simple majority shall constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting and no action shall be taken except by the concurring vote of not less than a majority of the quorum present. 
C.  The commission shall elect a chairperson, vice-chairperson, secretary and treasurer annually. 
(Ord. 36-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.80.040. - Receipts and disbursements. 
A.  All funds contributed to the city and specifically designated to be used for the development and promotion of cultural resources shall be held by the director of finance who shall report to the chairman of the Newport cultural commission and the council all contributions so made. The director shall expend funds not exceeding one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for any one purchase or purpose upon written invoice submitted to the director by the chairman of the cultural commission. For any expense exceeding one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), the director shall expend funds only upon written invoice submitted to the director by the council upon the recommendation of the commission. The commission may recommend to council, from time to time, such expenditures in excess of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) as it sees fit, and council shall, by vote of the council and resolution evidencing such vote, approve or disapprove the recommendations of the commission. No funds in excess of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be disbursed without council approval. 
B.  The director shall keep a record of all funds which come into his or her possession, and of all disbursements therefrom, and, as often as he or she is called upon to do so, shall render to council and the commission an accounting in detail of all receipts and disbursements of funds coming into his or her possession specifically designated for use for cultural affairs as provided for under this chapter. He or she shall, when called upon, give such other information regarding the funds in his or her possession as may be requested by the commission and the books shall be at all times open to inspection. 
(Ord. 48-92 § 1, 1992) 
2.80.050. - Rules and procedures-Contracts. 
    The Newport cultural commission may adopt such rules of procedure as may be necessary to accomplish is purposes and elect from its members such officers as it deems necessary. The commission shall not have the authority to enter into contracts without the advice and consent of council, which consent may be obtained by resolution; provided, however, that in no event shall the commission, with or without the approval of council, obligate the city in excess of any contributions or appropriations made for such purposes. 
(Ord. 36-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.80.060. - Assistance of city departments. 
    The Newport cultural commission is authorized to call upon any city department through the office of the city manager, for assistance in implementing its duty. 
(Ord. 36-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.80.070. - Annual report. 
    The Newport cultural commission shall report annually in the month of November to council, summarizing the work of the preceding year and including recommendations of future plans and the results of its efforts. 
(Ord. 36-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.80.080. - Historian of Newport. 
    There is created an honorary position of historian of Newport, to be appointed by council, who shall advise council and the city manager regarding the effective preservation of city records for future historical research. The term of appointment of the historian shall coincide with the term of council. 
(Prior code § 260.08) 
Chapter 2.84. - TRUST AND INVESTMENT COMMISSION 

2.84.010. - Creation-Membership-Conflicts of interest-Compensation. 
    Pursuant to Section 4-7 of the City Charter, there is created a trust and investment commission, which shall consist of five qualified electors of the city who shall be elected by council on the basis of their knowledge of investments and financial management. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 6, 12-9-2009) 
2.84.020. - Rules and regulations. 
    The trust and investment commission may make such rules and regulations as in its judgment are necessary for the proper functioning and discharge of the duties of the commission. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.84.030. - Records and reports. 
    The trust and investment commission shall keep a record of its proceedings and shall annually submit a written report to council of the value and condition of all funds and of the income thereof received during the preceding municipal fiscal year. The commission shall furnish council with such information relating to the funds as council may from time to time require. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.84.040. - Powers and duties generally. 
A.  The trust and investment commission shall have the custody and control of all trust funds established by the city. 
B.  The commission shall have the power: 
1.  To invest and reinvest all sums forming the corpus of, or appropriated to, such funds, and income thereof as it accrues, in the particular bonds, notes or securities for the redemption of which such trust funds were established, or in other bonds of any city or town, or in temporary loan notes, or notes of the city issued in anticipation of taxes, or in securities, except personal securities, but no portion of the same shall be loaned to the city, except as herein provided, and the commission is authorized to sell, exchange, invest and reinvest securities held by it as aforesaid; 
2.  To execute and deliver by and on behalf of the city all documents, instruments and certificates which may be necessary to carry out the foregoing powers; 
3.  To vote in person or by proxy, on behalf of the city, upon securities in the custody and control of the commission; 
4.  To exercise, on behalf of the city, conversion privileges or rights to subscribe for additional securities and to make payments therefor, or to sell or surrender such conversion privileges or rights; 
5.  To consent to or participate in dissolutions, reorganizations, recapitalizations, consolidations, mergers, sales, leases, mortgages, transfers or other changes affecting securities held by them; and 
6.  To hold and accept negotiable securities as well as registered securities and, if registered, to hold such securities in the name of the "City of Newport, Trust and Investment Commission," or nominee, and the same shall not be negotiable until transfer thereof is authorized by the commission. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.84.050. - Control of pension funds. 
    The trust and investment commission shall have the custody and control of all funds established to provide for the payment of pensions and health benefits and premiums for city and school department employees. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 6, 12-9-2009) 
2.84.060. - Control of trust funds. 
A.  The trust and investment commission shall have the custody, care and control of all funds now held or hereafter left in trust to the city by will, deed, gift or indenture, unless otherwise provided for by law. 
B.  The commission is authorized to sell, exchange, invest and reinvest funds held by its as aforesaid and to receive, collect and hold all income received by reason of such sale, exchange, investment or reinvestment in such manner as is provided in such will, deed, fit or indenture, and unless otherwise provided therein, to pay over the same to the officer, official, commission or board designated by council to receive the same, at such time or times and in such manner as council, by ordinance, resolution or otherwise, may direct. 
C.  The sale, exchange, investment and reinvestment of funds by the commission, as aforesaid, shall be in accordance with the provisions of the will, deed, gift or indenture, unless authorized to the contrary by a court of competent jurisdiction. It shall be the duty of the commission to see to the application of the funds and the income thereof to the purposes specified in the will, deed, gift, or indenture. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.84.070. - Deposits. 
    The director of finance shall, under the direction of the trust and investment commission, deposit in a special account entitled, "City of Newport, Trust and Investment Commission," all cash in the custody or under the control of the commission and shall cause payments to be made by check drawn on such account by the controller in such sum as may be directed by the commission. The commission shall determine the depository of the funds and the securities held by the commission. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.84.080. - Duties of director and deputy director of finance. 
    The director of finance and, in his absence, the deputy director, shall discharge such duties and render such serves to the trust and investment commission as may be required. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
2.84.090. - Employment of experts. 
    The trust and investment commission may engage the services of consultants and experts in the matter of investment and management of trust funds, as it may deem necessary, and the cost thereof shall be a proper expense to the apportioned among the various funds as provided in Section 2.84.010. 
(Ord. 1-90 § 1 (part), 1990) 
Chapter 2.88. - WATERFRONT COMMISSION 

2.88.010. - Membership-Terms. 
A.  The waterfront commission shall consist of nine members appointed for staggered three-year terms. 
B.  On January 11, 1989, three members shall be appointed for one-year terms, three members for two-year terms and three members for three-year terms. All subsequent appointments shall be for three-year terms, unless an appointment is to fill the unexpired term of a previous appointee. 
C.  The harbor master shall serve as a technical advisor to the commission. 
(Prior code § 264.01) 
2.88.020. - Attendance at meetings. 
A.  The waterfront commission shall meet at least monthly or more frequently when necessary. 
B.  If any member fails to attend three meetings during any twelve-month period, the chairperson of the commission shall advise the mayor of such poor attendance so that council may consider the removal of the member from the commission as well as advertise the vacancy so that a new appointment may be made to fill the unexpired term of the individual being replaced. 
(Prior code § 264.02) 
2.88.030. - Functions. 
    The waterfront commission shall act as an advisory body to council in regard to the overall organization of the harbor and related marine affairs. More specifically, the commission shall: 
A.  Make suggestions, recommendations and proposals as to the utilization, diversification, maintenance and safety of Newport Harbor; 
B.  Prepare specific proposals or suggestions on harbor and marine matters when so directed by council; 
C.  Advise council on marine-related issues that would impact Newport Harbor; 
D.  Recommend areas to be designated for anchorages and moorings, as well as suggested rules and regulations governing the placement and administration of assigned moorings; 
E.  Review all applications to the Rhode Island Coast Resources Management Council, as well as the Army Corps of Engineers, for any permit to build or alter any waterfront property in the city, and provide opinions and recommendations which shall be submitted to council; 
F.  Provide advice on marine-related issues to other duly constituted boards and commissions, when required; 
G.  Establish its own procedures and organization to most effectively accomplish its tasks, subject to the approval of council; and 
H.  Submit an annual report by April 1st of each year detailing the activities of the commission over the past year, as well as reporting on the operational conditions of the harbor. 
(Prior code § 264.03) 
Chapter 2.92. - BICYCLE SAFETY COMMITTEE 

2.92.010. - Membership-Terms. 
A.  Council shall appoint a bicycle safety committee consisting of six interested residents to meet with a representative of the police division, designated by the city manager, to review existing ordinances which govern bicycles, to review existing and potential bicycle paths and to review any other existing rules or laws that pertain to bicycles and to advise council on programs for bicycle education, safety and control in the city. 
B.  The term of the committee members shall expire on January 1, 1981, at which time three members shall be appointed for two-year terms and three members for one-year terms, and the committee shall cease to exist five years after the adoption of this resolution (Resolution 41-80, passed April 9, 1980) unless extended at that time by council. 
(Prior code § 266.01) 
Chapter 2.96. - CITIZENS ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

2.96.010. - Creation-Purpose-Functions. 
    The citizens advisory committee of the city which was established in 1961 in accordance with federal provisions is reconstituted for the purpose of serving as the formal means through which active citizen participation is provided to aid and support the development and the implementation of the workable program for community improvement for the city as it is in effect from time to time. The functions of the committee will include: 
A.  The use of the skills, knowledge and experience of its members and the organizations and groups they represent to assist and advise the local government with respect to programs for the orderly growth, development and improvement of the community; 
B.  Keeping the general public informed about such programs and of progress thereunder; and 
C.  Serving as a medium for the promotion of private programs in support of workable program objectives. 
(Prior code § 258.01) 
2.96.020. - Composition-Appointments-Terms-Vacancies-Officers-Compensation. 
A.  The members of the citizens advisory committee shall be residents of the city and appointed by council so as to be representative of the economic, civic, church, educational, governmental, minority, welfare and information media groups. 
B.  Effective January, 1972, the membership of the committee shall consist of not more than twenty-six (26) members all of whom shall be appointed for not more than two years with one-half of the terms expiring annually on December 31st of each year. 
C.  Council shall appoint members as necessary to constitute the committee as provided above. Any vacancies shall be filled by council for the balance of the unexpired terms. 
D.  In January of each year, the committee shall organize by electing from among its duly appointed members a chairman, a vice-chairman and a secretary-treasurer. 
E.  Members of the committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Prior code § 258.02) 
2.96.030. - Bylaws-Records. 
    The citizens advisory committee shall adopt bylaws for the transaction of business and shall keep permanent and complete records of its proceedings, meetings and recommendations. The bylaws may include membership requirements whereby vacancies may be declared should a member not demonstrate an interest in remaining active on the committee. The bylaws may also include provisions for an executive committee. 
(Prior code § 258.03) 
Chapter 2.100. - KEEP NEWPORT CLEAN COMMITTEE 

2.100.010. - Establishment-Membership. 
    There is established in and for the city a committee to be known as the "Keep Newport Clean Committee," such committee to consist of twelve (12) members, to be appointed by council, the chairman to be elected by the members of the committee. All vacancies shall be duly advertised. Each member of the committee shall serve for a term of two years. 
(Prior code § 269.01) 
2.100.020. - Duties. 
    The duties of the keep Newport clean committee shall include, but not be limited to: 
A.  The proposal to council of an updated and improved litter control ordinance; 
B.  The identification of sources of litter; 
C.  The proposal of a plan for improved litter control and refuse pick-up techniques within the city; and 
D.  The establishment of an ongoing public education and participation program for a cleaner city. 
(Prior code § 269.02) 
Chapter 2.104. - SCHOOL COMMITTEE 

2.104.010. - Compensation. 
A.  Each member of the school committee shall receive an annual salary of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year. Pursuant to Section 8-3 of the City Charter, such salary shall not be changed through enactment of an ordinance by city council during the current term of the members of the school committee. Compensation may include benefits, such as health, life and dental insurance. 
B.  The chairman or chairwoman of the committee shall receive as compensation for the performance of his or her duties as chairman or chairwoman, in addition to his or her duty and salary as a member of the school committee, five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year. Such compensation shall not be changed during the current term for which he or she was elected. 
(Prior code § 248.01) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 5, 12-9-2009) 
Chapter 2.106. - PUBLIC NUISANCE TASK FORCE 

2.106.010. - Purpose-Establishment. 
    A public nuisance task force is hereby established. The purpose of and primary goal of the task force is to work with property owners to establish a plan to abate identified nuisances in a timely manner through a collaborative effort of task force members and the property owner(s). Where there is ineffective cooperation from a property owner(s), the task force may review appropriate legal remedies to abate the nuisance. 
(Ord. 2003-53 § 1 (part), 2003) 
2.106.020. - Members. 
    The members of the public nuisance task force shall consist of the following members: 
(1)  The police chief or his/her designee: 
(2)  The fire chief or his/her designee; 
(3)  The director of the planning department or his/her designee; 
(4)  The city solicitor or his/her designee; 
(5)  The city council person from the ward in which the subject property is located; 
(6)  A city council person at-large chosen by the mayor; 
(7)  And other persons or agencies deemed necessary by the task force members; 
(8)  When deemed appropriate, the attorney general may designate a representative to assist the task force with continuing, chronic nuisances. 
(Ord. 2003-53 § 1 (part), 2003) 
2.106.030. - Mission. 
    The task force shall investigate problem properties by reviewing police reports; building, housing and zoning code violations; fire safety code violations; and complaints of properties with potentially hazardous conditions. The primary focus of the task force shall be on properties that present ongoing, chronic code violations, and numerous calls for police, fire or emergency service. 
(Ord. 2003-53 § 1 (part), 2003) 
2.106.040. - Procedures. 
    Members of the task force shall identify properties that present chronic public nuisance issues for the city and, after adequate review and investigation, notice shall be sent to the property owner(s) to abate the identified nuisance(s) or provide the task force with a comprehensive plan for abatement within ten (10) days. A request will be made to the property owner(s) to meet with the task force to discuss the public nuisances maintained on the subject property and develop an abatement plan. The plan must resolve all nuisance related issues within ninety (90) days following the task force's approval of the plan. Upon request, the task force shall provide general but limited guidance during the abatement process. However, the property owner(s) shall remain solely responsible for knowing all laws, codes and regulations applicable to the maintenance of the property. 
(Ord. 2003-53 § 1 (part), 2003) 
2.106.050. - Chair and meeting. 
    The director of planning department shall serve as chair of the public nuisance task force. The task force shall meet regularly, as necessary, to consider and review subject properties and to meet with notified property owner(s) regarding the abatement of public nuisance. 
(Ord. 2003-53 § 1 (part), 2003) 
Chapter 2.108. - HENDERSON HOME 

2.108.010. - Board of commissioners. 
A.  Membership. The board of commissioners of Henderson Home shall consist of five members who shall be residents of the city. They shall be elected by council annually and shall serve without compensation. Whenever a vacancy occurs on the board, council, at its next meeting, shall proceed to fill such vacancy for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
B.  Officers. The officers of the board shall consist of a chairman, a secretary and a treasurer. They shall be annually elected by the commissioners and shall hold their respective offices for one year or until their successors are chosen and qualified in their stead. 
C.  Records. The board shall keep a record of its proceedings and a full and accurate account of all moneys which may come into its hands and under its management from the bequest of William H. Henderson or from any other source, including the uses and applications thereof, in a suitable book or books kept for such purposes, which shall, at all reasonable times, be kept open for public inspection at the home. 
D.  Annual Report to Council. At each annual meeting of council in the month of January, the board shall make a written report of the general state of the home, consisting of a statement of the number of inmates and beneficiaries at the beginning of the year, the number admitted, deceased, left or discharged, and the number remaining, together with a written report of the treasurer with an account of the receipts and expenditures of the board. 
E.  Meetings Generally. A meeting of the board shall be held at least once in each month at a time fixed by the board. Special meetings shall be called by the secretary at any time upon the request of the chairman or upon the request of any two commissioners. In each instance, the purpose and object of such special meeting shall be set forth in the notice. 
F.  Annual Meeting. The annual meeting of the board shall be held on the last secular day of December. 
G.  Quorum. Three members of the board present shall constitute a quorum. 
H.  Duties of Chairman, Chairman Pro Tem. The chairman shall preside at all meetings if present. In his absence, a chairman pro tempore shall be elected. 
I.  Duties of Secretary. The secretary shall keep a correct record of the proceedings of each meeting, file and preserve all documents belonging to the board, cause notice of all meetings to be given to each commissioner and generally perform such other duties appertaining to his or her office as the board may, from time to time, require. 
J.  Secretary Pro Tem. In case of the secretary's absence or inability to act, the board shall elect a secretary pro tempore who shall perform the duties of that office accordingly. 
(Prior code § 1066.01) 
2.108.020. - Officers and servants. 
    The board of commissioners shall appoint such officers and servants as are necessary for the operation and care of the home and shall fix their compensation. The board shall have the right to remove any officer or servant whenever it deems such action desirable. 
(Prior code § 1066.02) 
2.108.030. - Duties of treasurer. 
A.  Under the control and direction of the board of commissioners, the treasurer shall receive all moneys which may come to the board in the transaction of its business and shall deposit the same in the name of the board in such depositary or depositaries as it directs. The treasurer shall make payments when directed by the board and only upon warrants signed by the chairman and the secretary. The treasurer shall keep a record of all moneys which come into his or her possession and of all disbursements therefrom. 
B.  At the annual meeting and as often as called upon to do so, the treasurer shall render to the board an account in detail of all receipts and disbursements and a statement of the property under its management. The treasurer shall, when called upon, give such other information in regard to the property in his or her possession as may be requested of him or her by the board and his or her books shall at all times be open to the board's inspection. 
C.  The treasurer shall perform such other duties as usually appertain to the office of treasurer. 
(Prior code § 1066.03) 
2.108.040. - Treasurer pro tem. 
    In case of the treasurer's absence or inability to act, the board of commissioners shall elect a treasurer pro tempore who shall perform the duties of that office accordingly. 
(Prior code § 1066.04) 
2.108.050. - Record of applicants. 
    The board of commissioners shall keep a record in which shall be entered the names of all applicants, their respective ages, places of birth and residences, by whom recommended, the dates of application, the decisions of the board in respect thereto, and all other facts the board may deem advisable. 
(Prior code § 1066.05) 
2.108.060. - Acquisition of real estate. 
    The board of commissioners shall purchase or erect in the city a suitable estate or building, which shall be used and maintained as a home for aged men of good moral character who are unable to support themselves and which shall be called "The Henderson Home for Aged Men." 
(Prior code § 1066.06) 
2.108.070. - Management of home-Contracts. 
    The board of commissioners shall manage the home in accordance with the provisions contained in the will of William H. Henderson, deceased, and shall have full authority and power to enter into and execute such contracts in relation thereto as it may deem expedient. 
(Prior code § 1066.07) 
2.108.080. - Admission and expulsion of applicants. 
    The board of commissions shall have the right to exercise its discretion as to the admissibility of any applicant, but no applicant shall be admitted unless he has been a resident of the city for at least five consecutive years. The board shall have the right to dismiss and expel from the home any inmate who violates any of the rules or whose presence, in its judgment, is prejudicial to the best interests of the home, or who, for any reason, is deemed not to be a proper recipient of the benefits of the bequest. 
(Prior code § 1066.08) 
2.108.090. - Inspection-Visiting rights. 
    The home shall always be open to the commissioners and it shall be open at all reasonable times to public inspection. The board of commissioners shall designate in each week at least one afternoon during which inmates may receive visitors at such hours and under such conditions as the board may establish. 
(Prior code § 1066.09) 
2.108.100. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board of commissioners may make such additional rules and regulations for its own guidance and for the government of its officers and servants, for the care of the inmates and the proper conduct of the home, as it may deem advisable, provided the same do not conflict with the provisions of the will of William H. Henderson, deceased. 
(Prior code § 1066.10) 
Chapter 2.110. - PURCHASING AGENT 

2.110.010. - Designation. 
    Pursuant to Section 3 of Chapter 55 of Title 45 of the Rhode Island General Laws, the city manager is designated as purchasing officer (the "purchasing agent") for the city of Newport for purposes of exercising the powers and duties as set forth in Chapter 55 of Title 45 of the Rhode Island General Laws and Title 2 of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Newport. 
(Ord. 99-13 § 1 (part), 1999) 
Chapter 2.112. - PURCHASING SYSTEM-COMPETITIVE BIDDING 

2.112.010. - Amounts less than one thousand dollars. 
    Any purchase of or contract for supplies, materials or equipment up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) may be made without competitive bidding by the purchasing agent with the approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. 2002-29 § 1 (part), 2002) 
2.112.020. - Amounts from one thousand dollars to five thousand dollars. 
    Any purchase of or contract for supplies, materials or equipment over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) but not over five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall be made by the purchasing agent with the approval of the city manager only after informal quotations have been received. 
(Ord. 2002-29 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 7, 12-9-2009) 
2.112.030. - Amounts of more than five thousand dollars. 
    Any purchase of or contract for supplies, materials or equipment of between five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder after one public advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the area by an award committee consisting of the purchasing agent, a requesting department representative and a disinterested city employee selected by the city manager. The award committee shall have power to award or reject all bids and advertise for new bids within their threshold dollar limit. Alterations in any contract entered into may be made within the threshold dollar limit when authorized by the award committee on a written recommendation from the city manager. Any purchase of or contract for supplies, materials or equipment of more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be awarded by the city council. However, any purchase of or contract for proprietary articles or replacement parts or equipment may be made from the manufacturer or his authorized agent without public advertisement or competitive bidding upon the approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. 2-90 § 1 (part), 1990; prior code § 222.22(c)) 
(Ord. No. 2009-32, § 7, 12-9-2009) 
2.112.040. - Proposals. 
    Proposals must be in sealed envelopes addressed to the Purchasing Division, City Hall, Newport, Rhode Island, 02840, and plainly marked on the lower left hand corner: "Bid for (insert item being bid for) ..." 
(Prior code § 222.22(d)) 
2.112.050. - Bidder's responsibility. 
    It is the bidder's responsibility to see that his bid is delivered within the time and at the place prescribed. Bids received prior to the time of opening will be securely kept, unopened. Bids may be withdrawn on written request (on the letterhead of the bidder and signed by the person signing the bid) which must be received prior to the time fixed for opening. Bids may be modified in the same manner. No bid or modification thereof received after the time set for opening will be considered, even if it is determined by the city that such nonarrival before the time set for opening was due solely to delay in the mails for which the bidder is not responsible. 
(Prior code § 222.22(e)) 
2.112.060. - Taxes. 
    Federal excise taxes and/or Rhode Island use taxes are not to be included in the quotation. Exemption certificates will be executed by the city if furnished by the contractor when submitting his invoice. 
(Prior code § 222.22(g)) 
2.112.070. - Discounts. 
    Any cash discount offered shall be for payment within a period of not less than fifteen (15) days. All prices quoted shall be net and delivered F.O.B. Newport, Rhode Island, to the purchasing division. All invoices shall be rendered in duplicate to the purchasing division. 
(Prior code § 222.22(h)) 
2.112.080. - Bonds. 
    Each bid must be accompanied by an acceptable bid bond, certified check, cashier's check or cash in an amount set by the purchasing agent. Deposits of unsuccessful bidders will be returned, without interest, as promptly as possible after the award is made. The deposit of the successful bidder will be retained as a performance bond or until a substitute performance bond (in the same amount) is furnished to guarantee that all conditions and specifications will be met. 
(Prior code § 222.22(i)) 
2.112.090. - Bid papers. 
    One set of bid papers is furnished to bidders, which must be returned if a bid is rendered. All figures must be written in ink, if not typewritten. 
(Prior code § 222.22(j)) 
2.112.100. - City's rights. 
    The right is reserved, as the interest of the city may require, to reject any or all bids, to waive any technical defect or informality in bids received and to accept or reject any bid or portion thereof. 
(Prior code § 222.22(k)) 
2.112.110. - Failure of successful bidder to complete contract. 
    If the bidder to whom the contract is awarded fails to complete the contract in a timely and workmanlike manner, the city may remove the contractor from the job pursuant to the terms of the contract. The city may then offer the remaining work to the next lowest responsible bidder from that list established for the bids received for the specific job. 
(Prior code § 222.22(l)) 
2.112.120. - Exceptions. 
    Any bidder taking exception to or questioning any of the provisions, procedures, conditions or specifications herein stated should make such exception known to the city, in writing, not less than five days before the bid opening. Any change or interpretation made as a result thereof will be published in an addendum and mailed to all prospective bidders. Should a bidder still not be satisfied, he may, in his bid, set out and stipulate his exception, with enough explanation to be understood by the city, and within the stipulation, the increase or decrease in his bid price, because of the exception, shall be stated. The city may, at its discretion, accept or reject any or al exceptions. 
(Prior code § 222.22(f)) 
Chapter 2.114. - USE OF COMPETITIVE NEGOTIATION IN AWARD OF CONTRACTS 

2.114.010. - Purpose. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is adopted pursuant to Section 6 of Chapter 55 of Title 45 of the Rhode Island General Laws and the Charter of the City of Newport to provide for the conduct of competitive negotiation in the award of contracts by the city. 
(Ord. 99-13 § 1 (part), 1999) 
2.114.020. - Contract award-Statutory process-Determination. 
A.  Notwithstanding any otherwise applicable provisions of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Newport with regard to the award of contracts, a contract may be awarded by the city through a process of competitive negotiations as outlined in Section 6 of Chapter 55 of Title 45 of the Rhode Island General Laws and this chapter if the purchasing agent determines in writing that the use of competitive sealed bids for the award of the contract by the city, as set forth in Section 5 of Chapter 55 of Title 45 of the Rhode Island General Laws, is not practicable. In making a determination as to the practicability of competitive sealed bidding for purposes of these regulations, the purchasing agent shall consider all factors he or she deems relevant to the particular procurement, including the following: 
1.  Whether specifications can be prepared that permit award on the basis of either the lowest qualified bid price or the lowest qualified evaluated bid price; 
2.  Whether the available sources, the time and place of performance, and other relevant circumstances are appropriate for the use of competitive sealed bidding; 
3.  Whether competition as to matters of design, construction approach, materials and methodology, performance guarantees, repair and replacement obligations, relative strength of financial backing, and similar matters affecting the overall value of the resulting contract, as well as competition as to price, will best serve the interests of the city; 
4.  Whether the contract is expected to involve combined, multiple, complex or diverse services or elements of performance that lend themselves to an evaluation of offers on a basis other than lowest qualified bid price or lowest qualified evaluated bid price; 
5.  Whether optional offers are desired and encouraged; 
6.  Whether judgment is required in evaluating competing proposals and it is in the best interest of the city to require a balancing of price, quality, experience and other factors, and 
7.  Whether clarification, development and negotiation of the terms and conditions of the contract are necessary or desirable to achieve the city's goals in the transaction. 
B.  If determination that the use of competitive sealed bidding is not practicable has been made, then the procedures of Section 6 of Chapter 55 of Title 45 of the Rhode Island General Laws and this chapter shall be followed notwithstanding any otherwise applicable provisions of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Newport. 
(Ord. 99-13 § 1 (part), 1999) 
2.114.030. - Competitive negotiation process-Procedures. 
    In undertaking a competitive negotiation process for the award of a contract pursuant to this chapter, the purchasing agent shall comply with the following procedures: 
A.  A request for proposals shall be developed which shall indicate the relative importance of price and other evaluation factors (which may include to the extent appropriate, without limitation, previous experience on similar projects, previous similar projects with the city, financial status and adequacy of financial guarantees of performance, technical feasibility of proposal, degree and types of contractual risk assumed, guarantees of performance to be provided, ability to meet its construction and/or performance guarantees, and commitment to equal opportunity), and may include other appropriate items, including, without limitation, detailed performance or design specifications, as appropriate; environmental standards which must be conformed with, a description of other services that may be required; and any other information deemed appropriate by the purchasing agent. 
B.  The request for proposals shall also contain a description of the evaluation and selection procedures which shall be followed in awarding the contract, including procedures which govern written or oral discussions with proposers, the proposal clarification process, concurrent or sequential negotiations, discontinuance and resumption of negotiations and rights reserved to the city. 
C.  Adequate public notice of the request for proposals shall be given in the manner provided in Section 45-55-5(3) of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
D.  Award shall be made to the responsible offeror whose proposal is determined in writing to be the most advantageous to the city, taking into consideration price and nonprice evaluation factors set forth in the request for proposals. 
E.  Prior to issuance of the request for proposals and pursuant to Section 12 of Chapter 55 of Title 45 of the Rhode Island General Laws, a request for qualifications may be issued in order to develop a short list of pre-qualified companies. Such request for qualifications shall indicate the criteria (including the relative importance of the criteria and any minimum qualifications criteria) and process for evaluation of the submissions received and the maximum number of companies that would be included on the short list. The pre-qualifications criteria may include financial condition, management and organization approach, relevant project experience and capabilities, project approach, past performance, and other criteria as may be set forth in the request for qualifications. If this paragraph E. request for qualifications process is utilized, distribution of the request for proposals shall be limited to the short list of pre-qualified companies developed pursuant to the request qualifications and adequate public notice of the request for qualifications shall be given in the manner provided in Section 45-55-5(c) of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
(Ord. 99-13 § 1 (part), 1999) 
(Ord. No. 2009-24, 8-26-2009) 
Chapter 2.116. - SURPLUS PROPERTY 

2.116.010. - Procedure for disposition of surplus property. 
    All real and personal property of the city, which is declared surplus after a circulation of all departments as to its usefulness and which is to be disposed of, shall be sold at pubic auction after suitable public notice, with a fair market value set as a minimum price, and such property shall be sold to the highest bidder who complies with the conditions of the sale. 
(Prior code § 222.09) 
2.116.020. - Waiver of procedure. 
    The provisions of Section 2.116.010 may be waived by a vote of five members of council when such waiver is in the best interest of the city and for the common good. A statement by council shall set forth the basis of the best interest of the city and the common good. 
(Prior code § 222.10) 
2.116.030. - Use of proceeds of sale of property. 
    The proceeds received from the sale of surplus property, as provided in Sections 2.116.010 and 2.116.030, shall be set aside in a fund to be used only for capital expenditures to be appropriated by council. The proceeds of the sale of any water department surplus property shall be set aside in the water department capital account. 
(Prior code § 222.11) 
Chapter 2.120. - GENERAL FEE SCHEDULE 

2.120.010. - Fees for permits and licenses. 
    The following fees for permits and licenses issued by the city are established: 
1. Alcoholic Beverage Licenses. Class A (Package Store) $ 1,000.00 per year Class B Tavern (Hotel) 2,000.00 per year Class B Limited (Beer and Wine) 1,500.00 per year Class B Victualer (Restaurant) 2,000.00 per year Class C (Saloon) 800.00 per year Class D (Full Privilege) 800.00 per year Class D (Beer and Wine) 400.00 per year Class E (Druggist) 200.00 per year Class F (Beer and Wine) 15.00 per day Class F-1 (Full Privilege) 35.00 per day An applicant for a Class F or F-1 daily liquor license who files an application out of time for approval at a council meeting prior to the event shall pay to the city clerk, in addition to the license fee, a fifty dollars ($50.00) filing fee. Class J 2,000.00 per year Class B-H 500.00 per year Class T 500.00 per year Renewal - All Classes 25.00 per year A penalty of five dollars ($5.00) per day shall be imposed on the holder of an alcoholic beverage license who does not meet the requirements for the issuance of said license and/or who does not pick up the license by the December 1st expiration date, unless an extension has been approved by the board of license commissioners.
