Title 3. - PERSONNEL 
Chapter 3.04. - PERSONNEL SYSTEM GENERALLY 

3.04.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in Chapters 3.04 through 3.52: 
    "Allocation" means the placing of a position in its proper class, based upon duties performed and authority and responsibilities exercised. 
    "Applicant" means an individual who has completed and submitted an application for employment with the city. 
    "Appointment" means the act of the appointing authority in selecting and certifying in writing the person whom he deems best qualified for the position which is to be filled in accordance with the provisions of Chapters 3.04 through 3.52. 
    "Assembled examination" means an examination for which applicants are required to appear at a special place for the purpose of taking a test. 
    "Break in service" means any separation from the classified service of one scheduled work-day, or more, whether by resignation, lay-off, dismissal, disability, retirement or absence without leave of one work-week or more when the employee is subsequently re-employed. An authorized leave without pay shall not be considered as constituting a break in service. 
    "Call-out time" means authorized time worked by any employee who, after departing from his shift, receives orders to return to work for emergency service. 
    "Candidate" means an applicant or employee who is under consideration for a position. 
    "Certification" means endorsement as meeting required minimum standards for a vacant position. 
    "Class" means a group of positions which are sufficiently alike in general duties and responsibilities to warrant the use of the same title, specification and pay range. 
    "Class specification" means a written description of a class, consisting of a class title, a general statement of the level of work and of the distinguishing features of work, some examples of duties and the desirable qualifications for the class. 
    "Class title" means the official title of the class as specified in the class specifications. The term applies to all positions allocated to the class and shall be used in all personnel and administrative processes, except that other titles may be used for purposes of internal administration and in any connection not involving the official personnel or payroll processes. 
    "Classification plan" means the official or approved system of grouping positions into appropriate classes, consisting of an index to the class specifications, the class specifications and rules for administering the classification plan. 
    "Classified service" means all full-time and part-time offices and positions which are appointed directly or indirectly by the city manager. They shall be divided into supervisory and nonsupervisory positions. 
    "Compensation" means the standard rates of pay which have been established for the respective classes or work, as set forth in the compensation plan. 
    "Compensation plan" means the official schedule of pay approved by council assigning one or more rates of pay to each class title. 
    "Continuous service" means employment without interruption, except for absences on approved leaves or absences to serve in the Armed Forces of the United States. 
    "Demotion" means assignment of an employee from one class to another which has a lower maximum rate of pay. 
    "Department" means the primary organizational unit which is under the immediate charge of a department head who reports directly to the city manager. 
    "Dismissal" means separation from city employment for cause. 
    "Eligible" means a person whose name is on an appropriate employment list and who is not ineligible for appointment for other reasons. 
    "Eligible list" means the ranking of eligibles for a vacancy in order of overall qualifications. 
    "Employee" means an individual who is legally employed by the city and is compensated through the city payroll for his or her services. Individuals or groups compensated on a fee basis are not included. The word is synonymous with incumbent. 
    "Examination" means the process of testing, evaluating or investigating the fitness and qualifications of applicants and employees. 
    "Grievance" means a wrong, real or fancied, considered by an employee as grounds for complaint. 
    "Immediate family" means spouse, children, mother, father, brother, sister, mother-in-law and father-in-law. 
    "Intoxication" and drunkenness are synonymous and one may be said to be intoxicated when liquor has affected his faculties to such an extent as to cause him to lose self control, that is, normal control of his bodily and mental faculties. 
    "Lay-off" means the involuntary nondisciplinary separation of an employee from a position. 
    "Leave" means any authorized absence during regularly scheduled working hours that has been approved by the proper authority. Leave may be authorized with or without pay. Absence without leave is considered unauthorized absence. 
    "Open examination" means an examination open to the public and not limited to employees in city service. 
    "Overtime" means authorized time worked by an employee in excess of his total normal working hours per week. 
    "Overtime pay" means compensation paid to an employee for overtime work performed in accordance with these Codified Ordinances. 
    "Part-time appointment" means an appointment which consists of less than full-time hours and more than a twenty-week period. It is less than a regular and more than a temporary appointment in relation to the amount of hours assigned. 
    "Part-time employee" means an individual who works any arrangement of hours weekly for more than twenty (20) consecutive weeks. Such an employee is only paid for the hours he or she works. Part-time employees are not eligible for any pension benefits, group health, life and dental insurance, sick leave or annual leave benefits. 
    "Pay grade" means a symbol indicating the pay range of a class of positions. 
    "Pay rate" means a specific dollar amount, expressed as either an annual rate, a weekly rate or an hourly rate, as shown in the pay plan of the city. 
    "Permanent employee" means an employee who has completed his designated probationary period and who occupies a permanent position. A permanent employee shall also be referred to as a regular employee. 
    "Permanent position" means a group of duties and responsibilities requiring the full-time employment of one person for thirty-five (35) or more hours per week on a regular schedule throughout the year. 
    "Position" means any office or employment, whether occupied or vacant, full-time or part-time, consisting of duties and responsibilities assigned to one individual by competent authority. 
    "Position number" means a number assigned each position for purposes of identification. 
    "Probationary period" means a working test period of six months duration during which an employee is required to demonstrate his fitness by actual performance of the duties for the class to which he is appointed. 
    "Promotion" means assignment of an employee from one class to another which has a higher maximum rate of pay. 
    "Reclassification" means the movement of an employee to a different class because of a change in duties and responsibilities. 
    "Regular appointment" means an appointment without time limitation, or special restrictions as to continued employment, to a permanent position authorized to be filled and made as a result of a certification as prescribed by these Codified Ordinances. 
    "Regular employee" means an individual receiving a regular appointment in either the classified or exempt service. 
    "Seasonal employee" means an employee who works for a set amount of time. Such an employee shall be considered an unclassified employee. 
    "Separation" means leaving a position by any type of action, including resignation, lay-off, dismissal, removal, disability and death. 
    "Suspension" means an enforced leave of absence for disciplinary purposes or pending investigation of charges made against an employee. 
    "Temporary appointment" means an appointment to a position authorized to be filled for a limited period and made as a result of a certification as prescribed by these Codified Ordinances. 
    "Temporary employee" means an individual whose appointment to a temporary position does not exceed nineteen (19) weeks and whose position falls under the rules of unclassified employees. A temporary employee is only paid for the hours he or she works. 
    "Temporary position" means a group of duties and responsibilities requiring the temporary employment of one person on either a full-time or part-time hourly basis. This position shall not exceed a period of nineteen (19) weeks and shall fall under the rules for unclassified service. 
    "Transfer" means the movement of an employee within or between departments, divisions or classes. 
    "Unclassified service" means offices and positions that are appointed by council, including council itself. The term also includes temporary and seasonal employees. 
    "Vacancy" means a position which has been newly established or which has been vacated by a previous incumbent. 
    "Work-day" means the scheduled number of hours an employee is required to work per day. 
    "Work-week" means the number of days in any calendar week, Sunday through Saturday, that an employee is scheduled to work. 
(Prior code § 272.01) 
3.04.020. - Declaration of policy. 
    It is the declared personnel policy of the city that: 
A.  Employment in the city government shall be based on merit and fitness, free of personal and political considerations. 
B.  Conditions of employment shall encourage employees to initiate and continue efficient and economical operation of municipal business. 
C.  Positions with similar duties and responsibilities shall be classified and compensated on an equitable and uniform basis at the highest level consistent with the economic capability of the community. 
D.  All personnel actions shall be based on a comprehensive evaluation of an individual's qualifications to perform duties and responsibilities of the position and meet working standards for municipal employees. 
E.  The rights and interests of employees shall be respected, consistent with the interests of the city and the public through a fair administration of Chapters 3.04 through 3.52. 
F.  A permanent career service for all persons covered by Chapters 3.04 through 3.52 shall be governed by consistent standards of professional conduct, necessity for continuance of the position and sufficient funds. 
G.  High morale shall be promoted by the fair administration of Chapters 3.04 through 3.52. 
H.  Every employee has a moral obligation and is expected to comply with the spirit and intent of this merit system. 
(Prior code § 272.02) 
3.04.030. - Creation of classified civil service system. 
    There is created a classified civil service system pursuant to Section 6-1 of the City Charter. 
(Prior code § 272.03) 
3.04.040. - Division of positions into classified and unclassified service. 
    All offices and positions in the city government are divided into the classified and unclassified service. Classified service is divided into supervisory and nonsupervisory positions. 
(Prior code § 272.04) 
3.04.050. - Unclassified service. 
    The unclassified service shall include the following: 
A.  All elected officials and members of boards and commissions; 
B.  Persons appointed to fill vacancies in elected offices; 
C.  Officials appointed by council; 
D.  Volunteer personnel and personnel appointed to serve without pay, fire division callmen and police division auxiliary members; 
E.  Seasonal employees; 
F.  Temporary employees; and 
G.  On-call employees. 
(Prior code § 272.05) 
3.04.060. - Classified service. 
    The classified service includes all positions appointed by the city manager which do not fall under the unclassified service. The classified service is divided into two categories: supervisory and nonsupervisory. These positions are identified in Section 3.12.020. 
(Prior code § 272.06) 
3.04.070. - Responsibilities of city manager or designee. 
    The personnel program established by Chapters 3.04 through 3.52 shall be administered by the city manager or his or her designee. The city manager or his or her designee: 
A.  Shall develop, maintain and apply procedures for the recruitment, compensation, promotion, training and disciplining of city personnel and related aspects of personnel management; 
B.  Shall develop and maintain a classification and comprehensive pay plan; and 
C.  Shall develop and issue such other supplemental personnel rules as are necessary for the effective implementation of Chapters 3.04 through 3.52. 
(Prior code § 274.01) 
3.04.080. - Delegation of authority and records maintenance. 
A.  The city manager may delegate, in writing, to department directors the authority to promote, suspend, transfer or take any other established personnel action for employees in the particular department. This authority may not be redelegated by department directors, and the delegation shall not change any provisions of the City Charter. 
B.  The city manager shall maintain an adequate record of his official acts under Chapters 3.04 through 3.52 and the employment record of every employee. 
C.  Department directors shall submit promptly data on proposed appointments, status changes or separation pertaining to the classified service at such time, in such form and with such supporting information as these Codified Ordinances prescribe or as the city manager deems necessary. 
D.  The city manager shall make available to authorized persons, upon request, personnel records and reports. Authorized persons are councilmen, court officers and any person designated by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Prior code § 274.02) 
3.04.090. - City manager covered by certain provisions of classified service. 
    The city manager is in the unclassified service but shall be considered a regular employee and shall be entitled to the benefits provided in Chapter 3.28 and shall be covered by Sections 3.04.110 and 3.04.130. All other conditions of employment shall be specified in the City Charter or by council. 
(Prior code § 272.07) 
3.04.100. - Working conditions-Employee welfare. 
    The city manager shall cooperate with the employees and others to promote measures directed toward more sanitary, safe and healthful working conditions, toward affording better facilities for employees' recreation, toward greater security and economic advantage as by means of group insurance, group hospital plan and credit union facilities, and toward any other means of bettering the conditions and improving the morale of city employees. 
(Prior code § 272.08) 
3.04.110. - Standards of conduct. 
    It shall be the duty of all employees to maintain high standards of cooperation, efficiency and economy in their work. Any conduct which is unbecoming an employee of the city shall be grounds for disciplinary action as provided under Chapter 2.32. 
(Prior code § 272.09) 
3.04.120. - Pecuniary interests prohibited. 
A.  In accordance with Section 2-9 of the City Charter, no officer or employee of the city shall directly or indirectly make a contract with the city or receive any commission, discount, bonus, gift, contribution or reward from, or any share in, the profits of any person making or performing such contract, unless, immediately upon learning of the existence of such contract, or that such contract is proposed, he or she notifies council in writing of the nature of his or her interest in such contract and abstains from doing any official act on behalf of the city with reference thereto. In the case of any such interest on the part of any officer whose duty it is to sign such contract on behalf of the city, the contract may be signed by any other officer of the city duly authorized by the city manager. When a contractor with the city is a corporation or a voluntary stock association, the ownership of less than five percent of the stock or shares actually issued shall not be considered as involving any interest in the contract within the meaning of this section, and such ownership shall not affect the validity of the contract unless the owner of such stock or shares is also an officer or agent of the corporation or association or solicits or takes part in the making of the contract. 
B.  In matters relating to an employee's official duties, no employee shall: 
1.  Appear before any agency, commission, board or official body of the city on behalf of any person, unless specifically authorized to do so by the city manager; 
2.  Assist for compensation any person in preparation of a presentation or appearance before any agency, commission, board or official body of the city, unless specifically authorized to do so by the city manager; or 
3.  Engage in any contract where the contract is made or originated for the benefit of the division or department of the city in which the individual employee is employed. 
(Prior code § 272.10) 
3.04.130. - Political activity. 
    It is the intent of council that city employees should not be subjected to direct or indirect political activities. Accordingly: 
A.  All officers and employees of the city, except school department employees, may become candidates for nomination or election to any public office, with the exception of the office of councilman of the city. School department employees may become candidates for nomination or election to any public office, with the exception of the office of school committeeman of the city. 
B.  No officer or employee of the city shall use his official authority or influence on any other officer or employee for the purpose of interfering with an election or a nomination for office or affecting the result thereof (except by casting his vote). 
C.  No officer or employee of the city shall directly or indirectly coerce, attempt to coerce, command or advise any other such officer or employee to pay, lend or contribute any part of his or her salary or compensation or anything else of value to any party, committee, organization, agency or person for political purposes. 
D.  Violations of subsections B and C of this section by officers or employees of the city, other than councilmen, shall subject such officers or employees to the procedures set forth in Section 3.32.050. 
E.  Violations of subsections B and C of this section by members of council shall subject such councilmen to the procedures set forth in Sections 2-7 and 2-8 of the City Charter. 
(Prior code § 272.11) 
3.04.140. - Acceptance of Workers' Compensation Act. 
    The city elects to accept the provisions of Chapters 29 to 38, inclusive, of Title 28 of the General Laws of Rhode Island, 1956, as amended, known as the "Worker's Compensation Act," for all employees of the city, with the exception of the employees of the police and fire divisions (which employees are excluded by Section 28-29-2 of the General Laws of Rhode Island, 1956, as amended). Such acceptance shall be effective July 1, 1983. 
(Prior code § 272.12) 
Chapter 3.08. - RECRUITMENT, SELECTION AND APPOINTMENT OF EMPLOYEES 

3.08.010. - Recruitment policy. 
    To most effectively serve the needs of the community, it shall be the policy of the city to carry on such recruitment programs as are necessary to seek out and secure the most qualified individuals to fill positions at all levels of the city service. 
(Prior code § 276.01) 
3.08.020. - Eligibility and requirements. 
A.  Competition for a position in the municipal service shall be open to all applicants who meet the standard qualifications for the class or position applied for and who are at least eighteen (18) years of age, with the following exceptions: (1) police officials, who must be at least twenty-one (21) years of age; and (2) temporary and seasonal employees, who must be at least sixteen (16) years of age, with a further exception for persons fourteen (14) and fifteen (15) years of age, in accordance with applicable Rhode Island Child Labor Laws and Department of Labor regulations, who assist in the recreation department programs. No person shall in any way be favored or discriminated against because of race, sex, religion, national origin, political affiliation or a physical handicap which will not interfere with the adequate performance of duties. 
B.  At the time of appointment, any applicant for a supervisory, unclassified or part-time position must live in the city and maintain residency therein. In the absence of qualified city residents for positions in the classified service, the city may select nonresidents for any position in the classified service. 
(Ord. 2008-4 § 1, 2008; prior code § 276.02) 
3.08.030. - Applications. 
    Applications for employment shall be accepted at any time. As a result of a single application, a candidate shall be considered for all classes of positions in which his principal qualifications might profitably be used. Each candidate for municipal employment shall make application on the standard form prescribed and provided by the city manager. Such information may be required as is deemed necessary in order to judge the applicant's fitness for service in the city. 
(Prior code § 276.03) 
3.08.040. - Reference checks. 
    As part of the pre-employment procedure, former supervisors, employers (for a reasonable past period) and references provided by candidates on the standard application form shall be checked as a precaution against obtaining undesirable employees. Reference checks made by personal or telephone contact shall be documented and made a part of the applicant's file. These reference checks shall be completed prior to an offer of employment and the information shall be made a part of the application file. All such information shall be handled as privileged information. 
(Prior code § 276.04) 
3.08.050. - Competitive examinations. 
A.  All applicants for positions in the classified service shall be subject to competitive examination. The examination shall pertain to those matters which test fairly the capacity and fitness of the candidate to discharge efficiently the duties of the class for which the examination is held. Examinations may be assembled or unassembled and may include written, oral, physical or performance tests, or any combination thereof. They may take into consideration such factors as education, experience, aptitude, knowledge, character, physical fitness or other qualifications which enter into the determination of the relative fitness of applicants. 
B.  Any domiciled resident of the city with at least five consecutive years of residency shall be accorded, upon proof of residency satisfactory to the city, ten additional points on any written examination for initial employment. 
(Ord. 2004-26 § 1, 2004; Ord. 18-97 § 1, 1997; Ord. 26-95 § 1, 1995; Ord. 46-93 § 1, 1993: prior code § 276.05) 
3.08.060. - Publishing notices of examinations. 
    All examinations for positions in the classified service shall be published by posting announcements of the same in the personnel office, on the official departmental bulletin boards and in such other places as the city manager deems advisable, including at least one newspaper of general circulation in the Newport area. 
(Prior code § 276.06) 
3.08.070. - Minimum passing score. 
    In all examinations, including original entrance examinations, candidates shall be required to attain at least a minimum rating of seventy (70). 
(Prior code § 276.07) 
3.08.080. - Physical and psychiatric examinations. 
A.  Appointment and continued employment in the classified service shall be contingent upon the candidate or incumbent satisfactorily passing a physical examination to ensure that physical standards prescribed for the different classes of positions by the city manager are met. All required examinations shall be paid for by the city and shall be given by physicians designated by the city. The results of the examinations will be evaluated against the criteria of whether the person could perform the particular required duties without hazard to himself or herself or others. 
B.  Pre-employment physical or psychiatric examinations shall be passed prior to selection for all positions in the fire division and the police division or any other position requiring a high degree of physical fitness. 
C.  Pre-employment physical examinations for other types shall be passed prior to actual employment. However, these examinations may be delayed until after the appointment, provided that the employment offer and appointment are made subject to satisfactorily passing the prescribed physical examination. 
D.  Employees may be required by the city manager to pass physical and/or psychiatric examinations at any time to ensure their continued fitness for duty. However, such examinations shall be limited to a determination of fitness for duty. 
(Prior code § 276.08) 
3.08.090. - Removal of names from consideration. 
    The city manager may remove from further consideration at any time the application of any applicant who: 
A.  Does not possess the minimum qualifications required for any acceptable position; 
B.  Has established an unsatisfactory employment or personal record as evidenced by reference checks of such a nature as to demonstrate unsuitability for employment; 
C.  Has made a false statement of any material fact or practiced deception in his application; 
D.  Is afflicted with any mental or physical disqualifying disease or defect that would prevent satisfactory performance of duties; 
E.  Is believed to be addicted to the habitual excessive use of drugs or intoxicants; 
F.  Has been convicted of crimes other than minor traffic violations; 
G.  Does not reply to a mail inquiry within ten days or does not return a telephone inquiry within two days; 
H.  Fails to accept appointment within two days or to report for duty within a reasonable time prescribed in the offer; 
I.  Fails to file by the announced closing date for receiving applications unless prior to such date an extension has been publicly announced. 
(Prior code § 276.09) 
3.08.100. - Notification of rejection. 
    Whenever the city manager determines that an application shall be rejected, the applicant shall be notified in writing of such rejection. Applications, whether accepted or rejected, shall remain on file and shall not be returned. Applications may be disposed of from time to time when it is determined that they are of no further value to the city. 
(Prior code § 276.10) 
3.08.110. - Eligibility list. 
    The personnel director shall maintain lists of candidates who have successfully completed the examination procedure. The names shall be ranked on the list in the order of their total rating in the examination. 
(Prior code § 276.11) 
3.08.120. - Maintenance of lists-Preferences. 
A.  All original entrance and promotional examinations shall be conducted and graded under the direct and sole supervision of the personnel director. Whenever a vacant position is to be filled, the responsible department director shall submit to the city manager on the prescribed form a request for certification of names of eligibles, if any, from the current eligibility list for the class of position to be filled. The department director shall consider the candidates certified and recommend one to the city manager. 
B.  Preference in entrance examinations shall be granted once to qualified applicants who have been members of the United States Armed Forces in war time: the Korean War, from June 27, 1950, to July 27, 1953; and the Viet Nam War, from August 5, 1964, to January 27, 1973; the Lebanon Operations, from August 20, 1982, to December 31, 1987; the Grenada and Panama Operations, from December 20, 1989, to January 31, 1990; and the Persian Gulf War, from August 2, 1990, to July 13, 1992. To the final earned ratings of veterans in competitive examinations who receive at least the minimum required score and at least the minimum required final ratings, service credits of five points will be added and ten points for those with a disability rating. 
C.  In the case of ties in the final rating, names shall be placed on the list in the order of ratings earned in the part of the examination given the greatest weight. Any remaining ties shall be broken by arranging names in the order in which the applications were received, except that in promotional lists seniority shall be used for this purpose. 
D.  In order of priority, eligibility lists shall be re-employment, promotion and original appointment. 
E.  Permanent employees with a satisfactory employment record who have been separated from the service through no fault of their own shall be placed on an appropriate re-employment list prior to any appointment by examination. 
F.  Employees who are still serving their probation and whose service has been terminated for lack of work or funds may have their names restored to the eligibility list on which they were first rated by the city manager. 
G.  No name shall remain on an eligibility list for a period exceeding two years from the date on which it was originally established thereon by the city manager. 
H.  If a vacancy occurs as a result of a resignation, retirement or termination, at a time when the previous eligibility list has expired and a new eligibility list for any class of position has not yet been established, the city manager may, for a period of time not to exceed six months, permanently fill the vacancy by utilizing the previous eligibility list. A vacancy may also be filled by temporary appointment with the city manager's written approval. 
I.  It shall be the responsibility of eligibles to notify the city manager in writing of any change of address or change affecting availability for employment. However, the city manager may circularize lists or use other methods to determine at any time the availability of eligibles. 
J.  Preference in entrance examinations shall be granted once to firefighter candidates who have been members of the Newport call force and to police officer candidates who have been members of the Newport police auxiliary for one year or more. Credits of two points per year of service, but not to exceed ten points, shall be added to the final earned rating of such candidates in competitive examinations who receive at least the minimum required score. 
(Ord. 7-96 § 1, 1996; Ord. 71-94 § 1, 1994; prior code § 276.12) 
3.08.130. - Order of certification. 
    The city manager shall certify to the department head, except in the department of public safety, where certification shall be to the police chief and the fire chief, names of those persons standing highest on the eligibility list. When more than one vacancy is to be filled, the number of names submitted shall equal the number of vacancies plus two. 
A.  After interview and investigation, the department head, except in the department of public safety, where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief, shall make recommendations for appointments from among those certified, and shall immediately notify the city manager of the person or persons so recommended. 
B.  The department head, except in the department of public safety, where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief, shall be allowed to select and recommend to the city manager the appointment of any of the top three candidates referred to him or her from the eligibility list established by the city manager. 
    With respect to the divisions of police and fire, a promotional rating form, to be established by the city manager, shall be completed by three officers, superior in grade to a candidate for promotion, upon application of such candidate to take an examination for promotion. Thus, with respect to the police and fire divisions, the eligibility list for promotion shall be established according to the following formulas: 
Police Division Maximum (Percent) Written examination 80 Seniority 20 / 100Fire Division Maximum (Percent) Written examination 75 Seniority 25 / 100 
    Seniority in promotions shall be used only to break a tie in the event two equally qualified candidates attain the same score. 
    With respect to all other departments, eligibility for an original appointment or promotion shall be determined by the city manager pursuant to the job classification as to a written, oral or performance test. 
C.  If, after interview and investigation, the department head, except in the department of public safety, where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief, files an undesirable character report to the city manager, such eligible shall have his name removed from the existing list. 
D.  If, after certification from a department head, except in the department of public safety, where it shall be the police chief and the fire chief, such person refuses to accept appointment, his name shall be removed from the eligibility list. 
(Ord. 48-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 6-90 § 1 (part), 1990; prior code § 276.13) 
3.08.140. - Appointments. 
    All vacancies in the classified service shall be filled by regular appointment, promotion, transfer or demotion. 
A.  Regular appointment indicates that the employee is to work for the city on a continuing basis. Every regular employee shall serve a probationary period of six months after original appointment, except for a police officer, who shall serve a one-year probationary period after successful graduation from the municipal police training school. A police officer who may already be a graduate of the municipal police training school, upon valid certification of that fact, shall serve a one-year probationary period from the time of appointment. The probationary period shall be regarded as an integral part of the evaluation process and shall be utilized for closely observing the employee's work, for obtaining the most effective adjustment of a new employee to his position and for separating any new employee whose performance does not meet the required standards. 
    During the probationary period, at least two performance ratings shall be made on all probationary employees. The first report is due at the end of three months' employment and the second is due at the end of the fifth month (third, eighth and eleventh months for those employees serving the one-year probationary period). 
    The probationary period, applicable to both new and promoted employees, is an extension of the examining process. It enables supervisors to observe the individual employee on the job and to determine the presence or absence of various factors necessary for successful job performance which cannot be determined or measured by pre-employment examination or interview. 
B.  The status of the appointment shall not be changed from probationary to regular until a certification is made by the department director to the city manager that the employee's services are satisfactory. An employee shall not acquire full status as a regular employee until approved by the city manager. If, after a period of one week, the department director does not certify to regular appointment, the employee shall be removed from the position immediately. 
C.  Employees appointed to part-time positions may receive regular or temporary appointments as appropriate. 
D.  Temporary appointment indicates that the employee is to work for the city for a period of less than nineteen (19) consecutive weeks. Prospective police officers who are attending the municipal police training school shall be considered temporary employees until successful graduation from the training school and appointment as regular police officers. When the appointment of an employee is changed from temporary to regular, crediting of annual leave and sick leave becomes retroactive to the date of the original appointment, provided that there has been no break in service as defined in Section 3.04.010. The pay of temporary employees shall be computed on an hourly basis and no pay shall be given for time not worked, except as otherwise provided herein. Temporary employees may be separated at any time within the nineteen (19) weeks of appointment when their services are no longer required. The separation is not subject to the rules under Chapter 3.32. 
(Ord. 6-90 § 1 (part), 1990; prior code § 276.14) 
3.08.150. - Nepotism. 
    Employees shall not be employed in positions under the supervision of a member of the immediate family. 
(Prior code § 276.15) 
3.08.160. - Destruction of examination papers, etc. 
    The examination papers and other work of applicants for positions, including any correspondence in relation thereto, may be destroyed upon the expiration of the eligibility list or lists resulting from such examination. 
(Prior code § 276.16) 
3.08.170. - Employee development program. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the city manager to foster and promote programs of training for the city service and in-service training of employees for the purpose of improving the quality of personal services rendered to the city and of aiding employees to equip themselves for advancement in the service. The city manager shall: 
A.  Establish standards for training programs; 
B.  See that training is carried out as approved and have prepared certificates or other forms of recognition to persons who satisfactorily complete approved courses and programs; 
C.  Provide assistance to department directors in developing and conducting training to meet the specific needs of their departments and in developing and utilizing other techniques for increasing employee efficiency; 
D.  Develop supervisory and management training and other types of employee development programs common to all departments; 
E.  Provide assistance to department directors in establishing standards of performance and procedures for evaluating employee efficiency; 
F.  Make available information concerning requirements and training opportunities in order to guide employees in increasing their efficiency in their present positions and in preparing themselves for promotions to higher positions in the city service; and 
G.  Keep a record of all approved training courses and programs and a record of employees who successfully complete such courses and programs. 
(Prior code § 276.17) 
Chapter 3.12. - CLASSIFICATION PLAN 

3.12.010. - General requirements for classification of positions. 
    All positions in the nonsupervisory classified service shall be grouped into classes and each class shall include those positions sufficiently similar as to character, difficulty and responsibility that: 
A.  Descriptive Title. The same descriptive title may be used to designate each position in the class. 
B.  Experience, Etc. The same level of education, experience, knowledge, ability and other qualifications may be required of incumbents, 
C.  Fitness. Similar tests of fitness may be used to select incumbents. 
D.  Range of Compensation. The same range of compensation will apply with equity under substantially the same employment conditions. 
(Prior code § 278.01) 
3.12.020. - City manager to maintain specifications for classes-Annual review of specifications-Enumeration of classes. 
    The city manager shall maintain and publish a complete set of specifications for all classes in the classified service. Such specifications shall include title, class features, typical tasks and minimum and desirable qualifications. Such specifications shall be reviewed not less than once every fiscal year with a view to maintaining their accuracy. The establishment of new or revised classes, or the abolishment of existing classes, shall be initiated by the city manager and such classification plan shall be submitted to council for adoption by ordinance, to be effective every July 1st with the adoption of the annual budget. The city manager, at any time and at his discretion, shall determine and fix the pay of all classified positions within the grade limits set forth in the classification plan. The approved class specifications are listed below by title and grade.

No. 2019-22, § 1, 6-12-2019) 
3.12.030. - Position classification studies. 
    The city manager shall make position classification studies of individual positions or groups of positions whenever he or she deems it necessary, whenever the duties or responsibilities of existing positions have undergone significant changes or whenever new positions are to be created. 
(Prior code § 278.03) 
3.12.040. - Class specifications. 
    In determining the class to which any position shall be allocated, the specification of each class shall be considered as a whole. The class specifications shall be descriptive and explanatory and are not restrictive. The use of a particular expression or illustration as to duties, qualifications or other attributes shall not be held to exclude others not mentioned, if such others are similar in kind or quality, and shall not limit the power of supervisors to alter the detailed tasks involved in the duties of a position. Qualifications expected of all incumbents of positions, such as a valid driver's license (if the position requires driving), good physical condition, freedom from disabling defects which, in the opinion of the city manager, would adversely affect work performance, honesty, sobriety, courtesy and industry, shall be deemed to be implied in the qualification requirements of each class even though not specifically mentioned in the class specification. 
(Prior code § 278.04) 
3.12.050. - Interpretation of class specifications. 
    The class specifications shall be descriptive and explanatory and are not restrictive. The use of a particular expression or illustration as to duties, qualifications or other attributes shall not be held to exclude others not mentioned if such others are similar in kind or quality, nor to limit the power of supervisors to alter the detailed tasks involved in the duties of a position. 
(Prior code § 278.05) 
3.12.060. - Allocation of positions-Change of duties-New positions. 
    Supervisors shall notify the city manager through channels promptly of each change of duties, responsibilities or work assignment. Whenever a new position is established, supervisors shall submit, in writing, a comprehensive job description describing in detail the duties of such position. The city manager shall thereupon investigate the actual or suggested duties and shall classify the position by assigning it to the appropriate class or initiate the establishment of a new class. 
(Prior code § 278.06) 
3.12.070. - Requests for reclassification. 
    Any employee who considers his position improperly classified shall first submit his request for reclassification to his supervisor who shall review such request as to its justification. If the supervisor finds that there is merit in the request, he shall immediately transmit his recommendation to the city manager. If the supervisor finds that the request is not justified, he shall so advise the employee of the decision and also of the employee's right to appeal under the grievance procedure set forth in Chapter 3.36. 
(Prior code § 278.07) 
3.12.080. - Method of filling reclassified positions. 
    Upon the reclassification of a position from one class to another class of the same level, a lower level or a higher level, the method of filling the position shall be determined in accordance with the rules regarding transfers, demotions or promotions, as may be appropriate. 
(Prior code § 278.08) 
3.12.090. - When employee to remain in reclassified position. 
    An employee occupying a reclassified position at the same grade level shall continue in the position if the change is in class title only, or if the change is in recognition of a gradual change in duties and the employee has been satisfactory or better in performance of the duties of the position. 
(Prior code § 278.09) 
3.12.100. - Evidence of fitness for reclassified positions. 
    The city manager may, before recognizing an employee's right to retain a position reclassified to a higher level, require evidence of the qualifications and fitness of the incumbent, including hearings, investigations and noncompetitive examinations. 
(Prior code § 278.10) 
Chapter 3.16. - PAY PLAN 

3.16.010. - Establishment of pay plan. 
    Council shall determine the pay plan in the form of a salary ordinance and may amend the plan from time to time. The pay plan shall be re-examined annually by the city manager who shall submit recommendations for changes to council. In making such re-examination and recommendations, the city manager shall include and give appropriate consideration to the following factors: 
A.  Maintenance of equitable relationships between classes based on their relative duties; 
B.  The general level of rates in the appropriate labor markets for comparable work under similar working conditions; and 
C.  Current recruitment and retention experiences and the city's financial position and resources. 
(Prior code § 280.01) 
3.16.020. - Compensation in lieu of fees, commissions, etc. 
    The compensation of officers and employees, as fixed or otherwise provided for by Chapters 3.04 through 3.52, shall be in full payment for all official services of such officers or employees and shall be in lieu of any and all fees, commissions and other compensation which may be receivable by such officers in the performance of the duties of their offices. Such fees, commissions and compensation shall belong to the city, shall be collected and accounted for by such officers and shall be paid over to the city. 
(Prior code § 280.02) 
3.16.030. - Fringe benefits. 
A.  Section 3.16.020 does not preclude the granting of fringe benefits, such as overtime pay, vacations, retirement, insurance, etc. 
    All full time city employees who regularly work no less than thirty-five (35) hours per week and maintain continuous regular full time employment are eligible to enroll in one of the group health insurance and dental insurance plans offered by the city. 
    Changes to health and dental insurance plans can be made during the annual open enrollment period or following a qualifying life event, such as a marriage or birth of a child. 
    For new hire enrollment, eligible coverage in a family or individual city group health and dental insurance plan will occur on the first day of the month following a new hire's original date of city employment and upon completion of the required forms. 
B.  Non-union supervisory employees shall receive the same fringe benefits as that which accrue to Council 94 nonsupervisory employees, including any enhancements, unless specifically exempted by the city council. 
C.  With regard to insurance premiums, all city employees shall be required to contribute towards the cost of the healthcare premiums, which shall be deducted biweekly from the employee's salary or paid directly to the city by the employee (i.e. COBRA, leave without pay). Employee cost shares are determined by the collective bargaining agreement between the city and the employee organization/union representing the employee classification. For non-union Supervisory employees, an employee contribution of ten (10) percent of the health plan's premium is required from employee's earning less than forty-two thousand dollars ($42,000.00) per annum or fifteen (15) percent of the health plan's premium for salaries greater than forty-two thousand dollars ($42,000.00) per annum. Unclassified employee contributions shall be the same as non-union supervisory employees unless specified differently by the city council. 
(Ord. 2003-29 § 2, 2003; Ord. 4-90 § 1 (part), 1990; prior code § 280.03) 
(Ord. No. 2013-014, § 1, 10-9-2013) 
3.16.040. - Rates for full-time and part-time employment. 
    The rates of pay prescribed are for full-time employment. Compensation for a work week of less than the full-time schedule (see Chapter 3.24) shall be in proportion to the time actually worked, except as otherwise specifically provided in Chapters 3.04 through 3.52. 
(Prior code § 280.04) 
3.16.050. - Studies of factors affecting salary levels. 
    The city manager shall make comparative studies of factors affecting the level of salary ranges at least once each fiscal year. On the basis of information derived from the studies, requests for adjustments in salary ranges shall be initiated by the city manager and submitted to council for adoption by ordinance. 
(Prior code § 280.05) 
3.16.060. - Pay schedule for classified service. 
    Following is the pay schedule showing salaries on an annual basis. Any revision of the pay schedule shall take effect on the first pay period pursuant to the fiscal accounting year associated with the adoption of the annual operating budget. Hourly rates are computed by dividing the weekly pay period, as specified in Section 3.24.010, for the different groups. Part-time employees in any of the groups will be compensated on a proportional basis for actual hours worked.

(Ord. No. 2009-01, § 1, 1-14-2009; Ord. No. 2009-15, § 1, 6-24-2009; Ord. No. 2010-20, § 2, 6-23-2010; Ord. No. 2011-012, § 3, 6-8-2011; Ord. No. 2012-013, § 1, 6-27-2012; Ord. No. 2013-005, § 3, 6-26-2013; Ord. No. 2013-011, § 1, 9-11-2013; Ord. No. 2014-018, § 1, 6-25-2014; Ord. No. 2015-15, § 3, 6-24-2015; Ord. 2016-11, § 3, 6-22-2016; Ord. 2016-19, § 1, 10-26-2016; Ord. 2017-13, § 3, 6-28-2017; Ord. 2018-06, § 3, 6-27-2018; Ord. No. 2019-22, § 3, 6-12-2019) 
3.16.080. - Beginning rate for new employees. 
    The beginning rate for new employees will normally be the minimum rate in the established grade for his or her classification. In unusual situations, a pay rate above the minimum rate may be authorized to: 
A.  Meet difficult recruiting problems or to obtain a person with markedly superior qualifications; 
B.  Correct salary inequalities or give credit for prior service; or 
C.  Recognize outstanding performance. 
(Prior code § 280.08) 
3.16.090. - Beginning rate for former employees. 
    A former employee who is rehired at the same grade level or at a lower grade may be appointed at any merit step rate that does not exceed the existing salary applicable to the highest step rate previously obtained as a city employee. 
(Prior code § 280.09) 
3.16.100. - Requirement for pay increases. 
    For each employee to become eligible for an increase in pay, the director of the department for which the employee works shall submit a written statement with a personnel evaluation form to the city manager at least twenty (20) days prior to the increase date as to the manner in which the employee has performed his assigned duties since the original appointment or last advance in pay. The department directors shall submit written recommendations that the employee be granted or denied an advance in pay. If the employee's work has been properly and diligently performed, has been satisfactory in light of the length of service in the position and has shown the improvement normally to be expected with increased periods of service and other factors considered relevant to employment, the department director shall recommend that the employee be granted the next regular increase in pay. If, in the judgment of the department director, the employee's work has been below standards that are expected, he shall recommend that no increase be granted. The city manager shall authorize or deny pay increased for city employees as recommended by department directors, unless, in the employee's opinion and based on supporting information, the recommendation is unsound. In those cases, a department director shall notify the employee in writing of the recommended action, including the reason therefor, at the same time he notifies the city manager. Ordinarily, salary increases shall be limited to one per year, with an exception for outstanding service. 
(Prior code § 280.10) 
3.16.110. - Consideration for advancement- Creditable employment. 
    Service requirements for advancement within the pay schedule and for the other purposes specified shall be based on the employee's continuous service. Some considerations are: 
A.  Leaves of absences with pay, and leaves of absences of thirty (30) days or less without pay, shall not interrupt continuous service and are completely creditable. 
B.  Absences on leave without pay in excess of thirty (30) days shall be deducted from total creditable service, but shall not constitute a break in continuous service. 
C.  Absences for extended service in the armed forces of the United States are completely creditable in computing total service. 
D.  Absences without leave of one work-week or more shall interrupt continuity of service and shall be deducted from total service. 
E.  Leave for injury in line of duty is completely creditable. 
(Prior code § 280.11) 
3.16.120. - Salary increase for exceptional service generally. 
    An employee who performs the duties and responsibilities in his or her position in an outstanding manner may be considered for an increase for exceptional service in an amount of five percent of his or her pay, and this increment may be authorized for periods of three, six or nine months. The recommendation shall be written in detail to the city manager, showing precise justification and use of strict criteria. This increase shall be approved by council upon the recommendation of the city manager. As standards for exceptional service, the following are recommended: 
A.  Exceptional service means that the employee, on his or her own initiative and by his or her own efforts and abilities, is rendering service above the level of proficiency normally expected in the class or is producing results consistently superior to that normally expected or employees in the class. 
B.  Exceptional service does not include usual acts or results which are caused by unusual conditions beyond the control of the employee, to which he or she demonstrated a normal reaction under the circumstances. 
C.  The following are some examples of the kinds of performance which might be considered exceptional service: 
1.  Developing or discovering a concept, technique, practice or procedure related to the work of the class which improves the quality of the service or results in financial savings. Developments of this character unrelated to the employee's own class or work should be recognized through a suggestion and award system; 
2.  Performing the work of his or her class at a standard consistently above that normally expected, with resulting improvement of service or financial savings; 
3.  Consistently demonstrating ingenuity in the solution of difficult problems, with resulting improvement of service or financial savings; and 
4.  Activity in community service or professional organizations on the employee's own time which contribute measurably to enhancing the prestige of the public service. 
(Prior code § 280.12) 
3.16.130. - Pay rates after promotion, demotion or transfer. 
    When an employee is promoted, demoted or transferred, his or her rate of pay in the new position shall be established in accordance with the following: 
A.  Upon promotion, an employee shall be placed in the first step of his or her new pay grade, except that in cases where the first step should not be a one-step increase, the promoted employee shall be placed in such step in the new pay grade as may be necessary to give a one-step increase. A fire captain, fire lieutenant, police captain, police lieutenant or police sergeant shall reach his maximum salary upon satisfactory completion of his six months probationary period. 
B.  Upon demotion, an employee normally shall receive a one-step decrease in pay. However, it shall be the responsibility of the city manager in each instance to determine the amount of the pay decrease, if any, upon demotion of an employee. 
C.  When an employee is transferred from a position of one class to a position of another class at the same grade, he or she shall continue to be paid at the same step. 
(Prior code § 280.13) 
3.16.140. - Service in armed forces. 
    Any employee who leaves the city service to enter the armed forces and is reinstated to his previous position or its equivalent shall be paid at least the same step rate received at the time of entrance into the armed forces. He or she may be granted additional step rates if he or she has gained appropriate experience in the armed forces. 
(Prior code § 280.14 (a)) 
3.16.150. - Effective date of salary increases. 
A.  When the application of these pay rules results in a supervisor, for an extended period of time, receiving a pay rate less than an employee under his or her supervision, the city manager may authorize an increase to any step rate considered appropriate to correct this inequity. 
B.  All pay increases shall be effective not earlier than the first day of the next pay period following approval. 
(Prior code § 280.14 (b), (c)) 
3.16.160. - Police and fire details beyond normal police and fire hours and functions. 
    All members of the permanent police division and permanent fire division who are assigned or who volunteer for details approved or ordered by the chief of police or the fire chief, when such details are for a private activity and paid out of private funds, as compared to a governmental activity, shall be remunerated at the following rates of pay, except for jazz, folk, music, cultural and drama festivals, noncivic details, and dine and dance details: 
A.  Members of the permanent police division shall receive the rate of pay as outlined in the agreement between the city and Lodge No. 8, Fraternal Order of Police. 
B.  Members of the permanent fire division shall receive the rate of pay as outlined in the agreement between the city and Local 1080, I.A.F.F. 
C.  Police sergeants through police captains shall receive the patrolman's rate unless the detail specifically requires a ranking officer, as determined by the chief of police. 
D.  Fire lieutenants and fire captains shall receive the firefighter's rate unless the detail specifically requires a ranking officer, as determined by the fire chief. 
E.  For jazz, folk, music, cultural and drama festivals and noncivic details, all members of the permanent police division and permanent fire division who are assigned by the chief of their respective divisions shall be paid at one and one-half times their regular hourly rate. 
F.  For dine and dance details, all members of the permanent police division who are assigned by the chief of police shall be paid the rates as stated above. 
G.  For assignments such as election duty, Presidential detail and other types of public functions, Section 3.24.030 shall apply. 
(Prior code § 280.15) 
3.16.170. - Pay differential for certain fire personnel. 
    Fire division personnel who are assigned to work five eight-hour shifts per week shall receive compensation as outlined in the agreement between council and Local 1080, I.A.F.F., AFL-CIO. 
(Prior code § 280.16) 
3.16.180. - Uniform allowances. 
A.  A uniform allowance shall be paid to each member of the division of fire as outlined in the agreement between council and Local 1080, I.A.F.F., AFL-CIO. 
B.  A uniform allowance shall be paid to each member of the division of police as outlined in the agreement between the city and the Fraternal Order of Police, Lodge No. 8. 
(Prior code § 280.17). 
3.16.190. - Authorized deductions. 
    Deductions for various reasons shall be made from an employee's pay after written authorization of the individual employee has been filed with the city. The deductions shall be for union dues, hospitalization and savings bonds. The number of different deductions shall be limited by the mechanical ability of the finance department from time to time. Compensation paid to employees shall be subject to a deduction for the tax under the Federal Insurance Contribution Act (Social Security), except police and fire division employees under a pension plan. 
(Prior code § 280.18) 
Chapter 3.20. - PROMOTIONS, TRANSFERS AND DEMOTIONS 

3.20.010. - Promotions. 
A.  Promotions Within Service. Promotions shall be from within service if possible. Qualified employees shall be considered for promotion to fill any vacant position in the classified service before outside applicants are considered. 
B.  Procedure for Union Members. Promotions to positions covered in the bargaining unit established by the State Labor Relations Board in Certification No. EE 1764 shall follow the promotion procedure as outlined in the agreement between council and the State Public Employee Council No. 94. 
C.  Eligibility List for Police and Fire Divisions. For members of the police and fire divisions, the following shall apply: Whenever an eligibility list is reduced to two names, the list shall be abolished and a new list shall be established, provided that no appointments are available at the time the list is reduced to two. 
D.  Promotional Tests. Advancement within the service shall be through promotional tests which shall be open to all permanent employees who meet the necessary requirements and who are serving in an appropriate class as determined by the city manager. Promotional examination may be limited to a single department or subdivision thereof. 
E.  Encouragement of Employees. The city encourages employees to develop skills, attain greater knowledge of their work and make known their qualifications for promotion to more responsible and more difficult positions. 
F.  Supervisors Not to Deny Permission to Apply for Promotion. No supervisor shall deny an employee permission to apply for a promotional opportunity in any city office or department. 
G.  Candidates for Promotion to Come From Next Lower Classification. A minimum of three candidates in the next lower classification to the position sought, pursuant to the examination announcement, shall be an adequate number of candidates for consideration. 
H.  Probationary Period After Promotion. Employees shall serve a probationary period of six months after promotional appointment. 
I.  Reserved. 
J.  Order of Certification Lists to Prevail. The order of certification of promotional lists shall prevail as outlined in Sections 3.08.110 and 3.08.120. 
K.  Probationary Employees Not Eligible to File for Promotional Examination. A probationary employee is not eligible to file for a promotional examination within his classification until he has acquired the status of a regular employee in such classification. Such regular status shall be as of the date of the official posted examination announcement. 
(Prior code § 282.01) 
(Ord. No. 2011-027, § 1, 9-28-2011) 
3.20.020. - Transfers. 
A.  Transfer of an employee from one position to another without change in grade may be effected when: 
1.  The employee meets the qualification requirements; 
2.  It is in the best interests of the city; 
3.  Further training and development of an employee in another position would be beneficial to future staffing potential of the city; 
4.  It meets a personal need of the employee and is consistent with paragraphs 1 and 2 of this subsection A. 
B.  Transfer of an employee from one position to another may be effected on a temporary basis because of an emergency, and the employee's grade may be increased for the time during the emergency when the interest of the city is served. 
C.  Transfers from the police and fire divisions of personnel covered by respective pension rights are prohibited except with the consent of the individual. Transfers into the police and fire divisions to positions covered by the respective pension plan shall follow the established procedures for appointment to these divisions. 
(Prior code § 282.02) 
3.20.030. - Demotions. 
    An employee may be demoted to a position of a lower grade, for which he or she is qualified, for any of the following reasons: 
A.  When he or she would otherwise be laid off because his or her position is reclassified to a lower grade; because of lack of work; because of lack of funds; or because of the return to work from authorized leave of another employee to such position in accordance with the rules on leave; 
B.  When he or she does not possess the necessary qualifications to render satisfactory service in the position he or she holds, or when removed during probation; or 
C.  When or she voluntarily requests such demotion. 
(Prior code § 282.03) 
Chapter 3.24. - WORKING HOURS 

3.24.010. - Normal work-week. 
    The number of hours an employee is required to be on duty each day, week or month shall, as far as practical, be uniform for all regular employees in the same class. The normal work-week for regular employees in different classes shall be: 
A.  Fire Division. In the fire division, the regular work schedule shall be a total of forty-two (42) hours per week (Sunday through Saturday), including meal and rest periods, for employees whose regular duties are principally the prevention or extinguishing of fires, but who are on call at any time for necessary duty. 
B.  Police Division. The regular work schedule for policemen shall consist of four consecutive days of work, followed by two consecutive days off. The regular work-day for such policemen shall comprise a tour of duty of eight and one-half hours, less one-half hour for lunch. This will include a one-half hour overlap of shifts. The above schedule is for employees in the police division whose regular duties are principally the prevention or investigation of crime, but who are on call at any time for necessary duty. 
C.  Police and Fire Chiefs. The fire and police chiefs are scheduled for forty (40) hours per week (Sunday through Saturday), consisting of five consecutive work-days of eight hours each, but such chiefs shall be on call at anytime for necessary duty. 
D.  Employees on Seven-Day Rotating Schedule. A total of forty (40) hours per week (Sunday through Saturday) are scheduled for all employees working on a rotating schedule for activities required to be covered on a seven-day week schedule. 
E.  City Hall, Administrative and Clerical Employees. A total of thirty-five (35) hours per week (Monday through Friday) are scheduled for all city hall and administrative and clerical employees of the various departments. 
F.  Others. A total of forty (40) hours per week (Sunday through Saturday), consisting of five consecutive work days of eight hours each, are scheduled for all other employees. 
G.  Deviations. The scheduled work-week of an individual employee shall normally be established consistent with the above work-week for his particular organizational unit. However, the city manager may approve deviations from the normal scheduled work-week of an individual employee to suit the needs of the city so long as the weekly total is observed. 
(Prior code § 284.01) 
3.24.020. - Inclusion of meal periods as part of work-week. 
    The city manager may authorize the inclusion of the meal period as time actually worked for shift-type positions. 
(Prior code § 284.02) 
3.24.030. - Overtime. 
A.  Overtime work shall be kept to a minimum and authorized by the city manager or his designee only under circumstances which call for immediate action or in special situations due to the nature of the operation or status of the activity. Except as hereinafter otherwise provided, no employer shall employ an individual for a work-week longer than the regularly scheduled work-week unless the employee is compensated at a rate of one and one-half times the regular rate at which he or she is employed for all hours worked in excess of regularly scheduled hours per week. 
B.  Seasonal, temporary and part-time employees shall be compensated at the rate of one and one-half times the regular rate for all hours worked in excess of forty (40) hours per week. Such an employee shall be scheduled for at least three hours work at the beginning of a shift or be paid not less than three times his or her regular hourly rate. 
C.  Supervisory employees who make more than two hundred dollars ($200.0) per week shall not receive compensation for overtime hours worked. Such employees may be credited with and granted some compensatory leave for such overtime provided that such time off does not exceed the actual hours worked. 
D.  Upon written recommendation of the department director, and at the discretion of the city manager, an employee who performs authorized overtime work for which the city is reimbursed by a private contractor may be paid at the employee's straight-time rate in lieu of being given compensatory time off if it is impossible to grant compensatory time off without seriously disrupting the department work schedule. 
(Ord. 5-90 § 1, 1990; prior code § 284.03) 
3.24.040. - Stand-by pay. 
    Stand-by pay shall be compensated in accordance with the agreement between the city and Local 911, Council 94, AFSCME, AFL-CIO. 
(Prior code § 284.04) 
3.24.050. - Records. 
    An official record shall be maintained for all employees reflecting actual hours worked, call-out time and time in leave status by type of leave. 
(Prior code § 284.05) 
Chapter 3.28. - LEAVES AND HOLIDAYS 

3.28.010. - Basis for granting leave-Delegation of authority. 
    Leave shall be granted in accordance with this chapter on the basis of the work requirements of the departments and, whenever possible, the personal wishes of the employees. The city manager may delegate the authority to approve leave to department heads, who shall not have the power of redelegation. 
(Prior code § 286.01) 
3.28.020. - Maintenance of leave records. 
    The finance department shall be responsible for the maintenance of accurate leave records. Such records shall be kept on forms prescribed by the city manager, who may periodically inspect them to ensure adherence to the provisions of these Codified Ordinances. 
(Prior code § 286.02) 
3.28.030. - Annual leave generally. 
    It is the policy of the city to promote the efficiency, health and morale of employees through periodic interruption from their duties. It should be scheduled with due consideration to the needs of the activity, but supervisors should avoid conveying the impression that the non-use of annual leave is in itself desirable or commendable. 
(Prior code § 286.03) 
3.28.040. - Accrual of annual leave. 
A.  Full-time employees shall accrue annual leave as follows: 
1.  One through ten years of service - four hours for each biweekly pay period; 
2.  Eleven (11) through fifteen (15) years of service - six hours for each biweekly period; 
3.  Over fifteen (15) years of service - eight hours for each biweekly pay period; and 
4.  In addition, annual leave shall be added every July 1st to the annual leave of employees as outlined in the agreements between the city and Local 1080, I.A.F.F.; Lodge No. 8, F.O.P; and Local 911, Council 93, AFSCME, AFL-CIO. 
B.  All full-time employees are entitled to accumulate annual leave until it totals not more than four hundred (400) hours. 
C.  All full-time employees shall be entitled to sell back to the city a maximum of one hundred (100) hours to accumulated annual leave in increments of at least fifty (50) hours at a time. 
D.  For the purpose of charging annual leave, all work-day shifts shall be assumed to be eight-hour shifts. 
E.  All members of Lodge No. 8, F.O.P., and Local 911, Council 94, AFSCME, as well as supervisory personnel, will earn one additional day of annual leave as a reward for not taking any sick leave during a specified period of four months. The time periods shall generally consist of July 1st to October 31st; November 1st to February 28th or 29th; and March 1st to June 30th. However, for administrative purposes, the pay period dates nearest the above calendar dates shall govern. Any additional day or annual leave so earned must be used within six months, with no reimbursement upon retirement. 
(Ord. 49-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 8-90 § 1, 1990; prior code § 286.04) 
3.28.050. - Requests for annual leave- Approval-Limitations. 
    Requests for annual leave shall normally be submitted in advance of the proposed absence. Approval shall be determined consistent with the desires of the employee and the work requirements of the city. 
A.  An employee shall have been employed for a continuous period of thirty (30) days, without a break in service of one or more workdays, before he or she is entitled to use annual leave. 
B.  Annual leave granted shall not exceed the total amount accrued to an employee at the start of the biweekly pay period. 
C.  Unless an employee has a minimum balance of eight hours at the start of the biweekly pay period, he or she is not entitled to use annual leave. 
D.  Annual leave shall not be granted when it is known that the employee does not expect to return to duty. Separations shall be effected as of the last day worked, except in the case of separations for disability or death. 
(Prior code § 286.05) 
3.28.060. - Computation of leave for employees whose status changes. 
    Employees who change to a position with a different work-week shall have their annual leave converted to an equivalent status in the new work-week. 
(Prior code § 286.06) 
3.28.070. - Payment for unused leave. 
    Upon separation, retirement or death, the employee or his or her estate shall be paid for the unused portion of his or her accrued annual leave, subject to Section 3.32.020. 
(Ord. 37-95 § 1 (part), 1995: Ord. 50-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 8-90 § 1 (part), 1990; prior code § 286.07) 
3.28.071. - Payment for unused sick leave. 
    All full-time employees shall be paid, upon retirement, death or voluntary termination (as to voluntary termination only after a minimum of ten (10) years of service), for their accrued sick leave as follows: 
A.  1. Employees hired prior to July 1, 1995 who are members of Local 911, Council 94, AFSCME, AFL-CIO, shall be paid sixty-five (65) percent of their accrued sick leave with a maximum payout of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). In the event that any employee has accrued in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in sick leave prior to the passage of the ordinance codified in this section, then the employee's maximum payment shall be capped as of October 11, 1995. 
2.  Employees hired after July 1, 1995 who are members of Local 911, Council 94, AFSCME, AFL-CIO, shall be paid sixty-five (65) percent of their accrued sick leave with a maximum payout of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
B.  Full-time employees who are members of Local 1080, IAAF and Lodge 8, FOP, shall be paid sixty-five (65) percent of their accrued sick leave. 
C.  1. Supervisory employees hired prior to July 1, 1995 shall be paid sixty-five (65) percent of their accrued sick leave with a maximum payout of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). In the event that any employee has accrued in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in sick leave prior to the passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter, then said employee's maximum payment shall be capped as of October 11, 1995. 
2.  Supervisory employees hired after July 1, 1995 shall be paid sixty-five (65) percent of their accrued sick leave with a maximum payout of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(Ord. 37-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
3.28.080. - Religious observances and family illness. 
    A liberal leave policy may be maintained in circumstances such as, but not necessarily limited to, the following: 
A.  Religious observances, in the case of which activities can usually find means whereby the needs of the service and the sincere religious scruples of employees can both be satisfied. Absence on holy days shall be charged to annual leave; 
B.  Illness in the employee's immediate family where the employee's care and attendance are required but where the illness is not of a nature to permit the use of sick leave under Section 3.28.090. 
(Prior code § 286.08) 
3.28.090. - Sick leave generally. 
    Sick leave shall be granted to employees when: 
A.  The employee is incapacitated for the performance of his or her duties by sickness, injury, confinement or medical, dental or optical examination or treatment; 
B.  When a member of the immediate family of the employee is afflicted with a contagious disease requiring isolation, quarantine or restriction of movement for a particular period and requiring the care and attendance of the employee; and 
C.  Through exposure to contagious disease, the presence of the employee at his post of duty would jeopardize the health of others. 
(Prior code § 286.09) 
3.28.100. - Accrual of sick leave. 
    Full-time employees shall accrue sick leave as follows: 
A.  Employees accrue sick leave on the basis of four hours for each biweekly pay period. 
B.  There is no limit on the accumulation of sick leave for members of Lodge No. 8, Fraternal Order of Police, and Local 1080, International Association of Fire Fighters. Members of Local 911, Council 94, AFSCME, AFL-CIO, and supervisory employees hired on or after July 1, 1995, shall accumulate no more than one hundred twenty (120) days (nine hundred sixty (960) hours) in sick leave. 
C.  For the purpose of charging sick leave, all work-day shifts shall be the actual hours worked but not less than an eight-hour shift, except that all leave taken by employees of the fire division shall be outlined in the agreement between council and Local No. 1080, I.A.F.F., AFL-CIO. 
(Ord. 38-95 § 1, 1995; prior code § 286.10) 
3.28.110. - Requests for sick leave-Approval- Limitations-Personal day. 
    Sick leave with pay may be granted to regular employees in accordance with the following provisions: 
A.  An employee shall have been employed for a continuous period of thirty (30) days, without a break in service of one or more work-days, before he or she is entitled to use sick leave. 
B.  Sick leave granted shall not exceed the total amount accrued to an employee at the start of the biweekly pay period. 
C.  Unless an employee has a minimum balance of eight hours at the start of the biweekly pay period, he or she is not entitled to use sick leave. 
D.  If an employee has no sick leave balance, absences due to illness may be charged in accordance with annual leave, Section 3.28.050, or leave without pay, Section 3.28.200. 
E.  A so-called personal day shall be granted and charged to sick leave for members of the fire division, as outlined in the agreement between council and Local No. 1080, I.A.F.F., AFL-CIO, and for members of Council 94, Local No. 911, as outlined in the agreement between council and Local No. 911, A.F.S.C.M.E., AFL-CIO. 
(Prior code § 286.11) 
3.28.120. - Advance sick leave. 
A.  Advance sick leave, not to exceed four work-weeks, may be granted by the city manager to regular employees after the first six months of employment in cases of serious disability or ailments when it is to the advantage of the city to do so. This authority may not be delegated. 
B.  Advance sick leave may be granted irrespective of whether or not the employee has annual leave to his credit.
