C.  Requests for advance sick leave shall be submitted in writing stating the circumstances and the need for such leave, the time and date when the accrued sick leave will be exhausted, the amount of advance sick leave requested, and the date to which such leave will extend. 
D.  Requests for advance sick leave shall be evaluated against the following considerations: 
1.  The employee's past leave record; 
2.  The nature, seriousness and extent of illness or disability; 
3.  The probability of return to duty and prospect for continued employment; 
4.  The probability of the employee liquidating the leave to be advanced. 
E.  Individuals who, upon separation from city employment, are indebted for advance sick leave, shall reimburse the city, or appropriate deductions shall be made from his or her salary or any leave due him or her. This requirement may be waived in cases of separation for a serious illness (which does not include maternity situations) or disability which is confirmed by the statement of a licensed physician. 
(Prior code § 286.12) 
3.28.130. - Absence on nonwork-days. 
    Sick leave shall not be debited for absence on observed holidays or other nonwork-days. 
(Prior code § 286.13) 
3.28.140. - Reports and investigations-Medical certificates-Fraud. 
    Reporting and investigating sickness, together with other miscellaneous factors relative to sick leave, shall be handled as follows: 
A.  Reporting of Sickness. Employees, except police and fire employees, who are absent from duty for reasons which entitle them to sick leave, shall ensure that their respective supervisors are notified within two hours after their usual reporting time, if physically able to do so. Upon return to work, the employee shall immediately submit to his supervisor an authorization for leave form. Police and fire employees shall notify their respective supervisors before their scheduled duty. 
B.  Medical Certificate. A medical statement may be required for any absence chargeable to sick leave; such statement shall normally be required for sick leave in excess of five work-days. 
C.  False or Fraudulent Use of Sick Leave. The city may investigate any absence for which sick leave is requested. False or fraudulent use of sick leave shall be cause for dismissal or appropriate disciplinary action against the offending employee. 
(Prior code § 286.14) 
3.28.150. - Leave for injury or illness in line of duty. 
    Leave for absence with compensation, as provided by the provisions of Chapters 29 through 38, inclusive, of Title 28 of the General Laws of Rhode Island, 1956, as amended, know as the "Worker's Compensation Act," shall be granted to permanent employees who become incapacitated as a result of injury or occupational disease incurred through no misconduct of their own while during actual performance of duty. Compensation shall consist of payment of all bills incurred as a direct and necessary result of such injury, which bills are not compensable by any insurer or voluntary health program. Such leave shall start at such time as the employee is unable to perform his customary duties. Every application for such leave shall contain a statement by the employee, affirmed by his supervisor, setting forth the details of the accident and supported by the certificate of a licensed physician setting forth the nature and extent of the leave for injury in the line of duty. The employer's first report of injury form (DWC1) shall be submitted by the department head within twenty-four (24) hours of the injury for approval by the insurer named by the city. Every period of leave granted under this section shall be considered creditable service and shall be recorded on the employee's leave card, but shall not be charged to any other type of leave. 
(Ord. 13-96 § 1, 1996) 
3.28.160. - Military leave. 
A.  As used in this section, "military duty" means: 
1.  Training and service performed by an inductee, enlistee or reservist, or any entrant into a temporary component of the armed forces of the United States; 
2.  Time spent in returning for and returning from such training and service, or if a rejection occurs, from the place of reporting therefor; and 
3.  Active duty training as a reservist in the armed forces of the United States where the call is for training only. 
B.  Any regular employee who leaves the city service for military duty shall be placed on military leave without pay, such leave to extend through a date forty (40) days after his release, or hospitalization continuing after release, for not more than one year. 
C.  A regular employee shall also be granted a leave of absence for the purpose of being inducted or otherwise entering military duty. If not accepted for such duty, the employee shall be reinstated in his position without loss of seniority or status and without reduction in his rate of pay. During such period, the employee shall for all purposes be considered to have rendered service and to have been compensated therefore at his regular rate of pay. 
D.  Such an employee, as mentioned in subsections B and C of this section, shall be entitled to restoration, provided he makes application therefor within forty (40) days after the date of his release from duty under conditions other than dishonorable and is physically and mentally capable of performing the duties of the position involved. 
E.  An employee returning from military service shall normally be restored to the position which he vacated upon entering the military service. In the event that the vacated position no longer exists at the time he qualifies for return to work, such person shall be entitled to be re-employed in another existing position of the same class specification, provided such re-employment does not necessitate the laying off of another person with greater seniority. 
F.  A regular employee who leaves the service directly for military leave without pay may elect to be paid for any accrued annual, personal or compensatory leave as he may be entitled to if he were actually separating from the city service. His decision shall be noted on the personnel action form effecting the leave. If the employee elects not to be paid for such leave, the accrued leave credits shall be reinstated upon return of the employee. 
G.  Employees restored to duty under this section shall have unused sick leave credits restored for their use. 
(Prior code § 286.20) 
3.28.170. - Annual leave for reservists- Compensation. 
    A regular employee who is a member of any reserve component of the United States Armed Forces will be allowed leave of absence for required training or duty without loss of pay for a single period each year not exceeding two calendar weeks. In the event that the time of such training is optional, the time shall be designated at the discretion of the city. By loss of pay it is meant that the city shall make up the difference of the pay received from military training and the employee's normal salary. 
(Prior code § 286.21) 
3.28.180. - Deferment from service. 
    In order to ensure uniformity, requests for deferment of employees from service in the armed forces shall be made only by the city manager. 
(Prior code § 286.22) 
3.28.190. - Compensation upon return. 
    If, in the opinion of the city manager, the military duties of an employee on military leave were closely related to his duties as a city employee and con-stituted an addition to his training and experience for city work, the employee, when returned from his military leave, may be given a pay rate not higher than that which he would have attained had he remained in continuous employment. 
(Prior code § 286.23) 
3.28.200. - Leave without pay. 
    The city manager may grant regular employees leave without pay for a period not to exceed one year, subject to the following conditions: 
A.  Leave without pay may be granted only when it is in the interests of the city to do so. The needs of the employee shall be considered when he has shown by his record to be of more than average value to the city and when it is desirable to retain the employee even at some sacrifice. 
B.  During an employee's approved leave of absence, his position may be filled by temporary appointment, a temporary promotion or detail of another employee. At the expiration of a leave without pay, the employee has the right to, and shall be reinstated in, the position he vacated if the position still exists or, if not, to any other vacant position in the same class. If this is not possible, he shall be transferred to another position for which he qualifies and for which a vacancy exists, or normal lay-off procedures shall be used to assign the employee to a position or to determine which employee shall be separated. 
C.  Approved leave without pay shall not constitute a break in service. 
D.  Failure on the part of the employee to report promptly at the expiration of a leave without pay may be cause for dismissal. 
E.  With respect to benefits, including salary and wages, paid by the city to any employee pursuant to the above, the city shall be subrogated to all rights the employee may have against any person causing the amount paid by the city. 
F.  When injury leave is used, the employee shall receive the difference between the workmen's compensation insurance payments and his regular salary, if any. 
(Prior code § 286.24) 
3.28.210. - Holidays. 
A.  The following holidays are observed by the city and shall be granted to all employees without charge to leave, to regular employees with pay, and to temporary and seasonal employees without pay, unless such temporary or seasonal employees are required to be on scheduled duty: 
    New Years Day (January 1) 
    Martin Luther King Day (third Monday of January) 
    Washington's Birthday (third Monday of February) 
    Rhode Island Independence Day (May 4) 
    Memorial Day (last Monday of May) 
    Independence Day (July 4) 
    Victory Day (second Monday of August) 
    Labor Day (first Monday of September) 
    Columbus Day (second Monday of October) 
    Armistice Day (November 11) 
    Thanksgiving (fourth Thursday of November) 
    Christmas Day (December 25) 
B.  It shall be the police of the city to ensure that all regular employees enjoy the same number of holidays each year. They will be celebrated by regular employees working a thirty-five (35) or forty (40) hour week, Monday through Friday. For these groups, when a holiday falls on a Saturday, it shall be observed on the preceding Friday. When a holiday falls on a Sunday, the following Monday shall be observed as the holiday. For regular employees on a work-week of other than Monday through Friday, the city manager shall designate the work-day that shall be observed. 
    Members of the police and fire divisions and all other employees who are on a seven-day rotating shift shall receive holiday pay in lieu of time off. This holiday pay shall be one-fifth the employee's weekly salary and shall be paid to each employee over and above his or her biweekly salary the pay period in which the holiday occurs whether he or she is scheduled to work the holiday or not. 
C.  Part-time employees shall be paid for observed holidays which fall on days for which they would otherwise be scheduled to work, according to the number of hours for which they are scheduled to work on that day. 
D.  In order to receive pay for an observed holiday, an employee must be in a work or paid leave status either his scheduled work-day immediately preceding or following the holiday, and not have been absent without authorization either the work-day before or after the holiday. 
E.  The appointment or separation of a regular employee shall not be effected on a day to be observed as a holiday, except when the employee works that day. 
(Prior code § 286.25) 
3.28.220. - Civil leave. 
    An employee shall be given necessary time off without loss of pay when: 
A.  Performing jury duty; however, jury fees received (other than meal or travel allowances) shall be returned to the city; 
B.  Required by duties, or subpoenaed, to appear before a court, public body or commission as a witness on behalf of the city, because of his or her official capacity with the city; 
C.  Performing emergency civilian duty in connection with national defense; or 
D.  For the purpose of voting when the polls are not open at least one hour before or after the employee's scheduled hours of work. 
(Prior code § 286.26) 
3.28.230. - Administrative emergency leave. 
    The city manager may excuse employees from duty in emergency situations for short periods of time. Examples of emergencies are extreme weather conditions, disaster such as fire, flood or other natural phenomena which prevent employees from working or reporting to work, breakdown of machines, and emergency rescue or protection work. 
(Prior code § 286.27) 
3.28.240. - Unauthorized absences. 
A.  An employee who is absent from duty without approval shall: 
1.  Receive no pay for the duration of the absence; and 
2.  Be subject to dismissal or other appropriate disciplinary action. 
B.  It is recognized that there may be extenuating circumstances for unauthorized absence and due consideration shall be given each case as to the type of leave to be approved or other appropriate disciplinary action. 
C.  Failure of an employee to report for work at the expiration of an authorized leave or to request an extension of such leave shall be considered an absence without leave. 
D.  Under ordinary circumstances, unavoidable or necessary absence from duty of less than one hour or tardiness may be excused without charge to leave if such absence or tardiness can be fully justified by the employee to his supervisor's satisfaction. Otherwise, such absence shall be handled administratively by requiring additional work, or by a charge against compensatory time which the employee may have to his or her credit, or by charging the time to the employee's leave account. If the employee is tardy, the supervisor shall determine the cause of the tardiness in order to plan with the employee the corrective steps to be taken. 
(Prior code § 286.28) 
3.28.250. - Maternity leave. 
    Employees who have completed two years of service with the city shall be granted a leave of absence, without pay or any benefits, for maternity. Written application for maternity leave must be filed with the personnel director at least sixty (60) days prior to the start of such leave. An employee who wishes to work beyond the fourth month of pregnancy must file a doctor's certificate with the personnel director. Maternity leave shall not exceed six months. If an employee has not returned to full-time city employment at the end of the six months maternity leave, it shall be considered an automatic resignation. Temporary replacements for employees on maternity leave shall not be covered by this section. An employee shall notify the personnel director two weeks prior to the end of the six months leave if she expects to return to duty. 
(Prior code § 286.29) 
3.28.260. - Death leave. 
A.  Leave for death in the immediate family shall be granted for a period not to exceed three days. Such leave shall not be charged to any other type of leave. 
B.  Additional leave when required shall be charged to annual leave. 
C.  Leave for death in the immediate family for members of Council 94 will be in accordance with the agreement between council and Public Employees Council 94. 
D.  Leave for death for members of Local No. 1080, I.A.F.F., shall be in accordance with the agreement between the council and Local No. 1080, I.A.F.F. 
E.  Leave for death for members of Lodge No. 8, Fraternal Order of Police, shall be in accordance with the agreement between council and such lodge. 
(Prior code § 286.30) 
3.28.270. - Leave for union business. 
    Reasonable leave shall be granted for the conduct of union business and such leave shall not be charged to any other type of leave. 
(Prior code § 286.31) 
3.28.280. - Procedure for requesting leave. 
A.  For all leave other than official holiday, sick and administrative emergency leave and leave for death in the family, a written request indicating the kind of leave, the duration and the dates of departure and return must be approved prior to the taking of leave. The request for leave should be submitted prior to beginning the leave. In the case of sick leave, the leave form shall be completed and submitted for approval immediately upon the employee's return to duty. 
B.  Unless an absence is substantiated by a leave form approved by the city manager or his designee, an employee shall not be paid for any absence from scheduled work hours. 
(Prior code § 286.32) 
Chapter 3.32. - SEPARATIONS AND DISCIPLINARY ACTIONS 

3.32.010. - Return of records, etc., prior to payment. 
    At the time of separation and prior to final payment, all records, assets or other items of city property in the employee's custody shall be transferred to the city manager and a certification to this effect shall be executed by the departing employee. Any amount due because of a shortage in the above shall be withheld from the employee's final compensation or collected through other appropriate action. 
(Prior code § 288.01) 
3.32.020. - Final payment and adjustments. 
    Employees who separate shall receive payment for all earned salary and earned annual leave, subject to deduction for: 
A.  Any indebtedness pursuant to Section 3.32.010; and 
B.  Sick leave advanced prior to accrual, unless the separation is for disability. Separation because of pregnancy shall be considered a resignation and shall not be considered for disability. 
(Prior code § 288.02) 
3.32.030. - Resignation and retirement. 
A.  Purpose. To set forth administrative guidelines for the proper and timely separation from service for employees of the city. 
B.  Policy. When a city employee leaves municipal service, of his or her own volition, a number of administrative tasks are required, including, but not limited to: computing any earned severance benefits, initiating process for pension benefits, reclaiming and cataloguing any city-issued equipment or inventorying other property, formally issued to the employee, for which the city claims or retains ownership. The enactment of an employee separation process will expedite the formal notification of appropriate supervisors and department heads of an impending employee separation and subsequent work force vacancy. This procedure is intended to provide reasonable and adequate notice of an employee departure to appropriate city supervisors and administrators, and is not intended to supersede, contradict or circumvent, any codified employee protection, right, or privilege. Further, it is not intended to limit, alter, or restrict any state or federal employee protection or law, or provision of an employee's collective bargaining agreement. 
C.  Procedure. Prior to resigning or retiring from city employment, an employee must provide a letter to his or her department head, indicating the employee's intention to leave service and specifying the employee's last projected date of work. Subsequently, the department head shall prepare an employee separation report, and forward the same, with the employee's letter, to the human resources administrator. With such notification from the employee, the department head shall also execute appropriate department-level internal procedures to separate the employee from service, such as: inspecting, collecting, and cataloguing from the employee all department-issued equipment and other property belonging to the city. 
    With receipt of the employee separation report, the human resources administrator shall schedule an exit interview with the employee, at which time the employee will be provided with information concerning severance, post-employment benefits, obligations, and/or duties. Subsequently, the employee separation report will be forwarded to the city manager for approval. The form shall specify circumstances, benefits, contingencies and/or conditions related to the employee's separation; consistent with provisions of the city of Newport Codified Ordinances, R.I. General Laws, and the employee's employment conditions (including provisions of any applicable collective bargaining agreement). 
    Failure on the part of an employee to submit a letter of intended separation from employment, or delays in the completion of employee separation report, or the subsequent exit interview, may create administrative delays in the computation and delivery of severance and post-employment benefits for the employee leaving city service. 
(Ord. 2006-34 § 1, 2006) 
3.32.040. - Lay-off. 
A.  When a position is discontinued or abolished because of a change in duties, reorganization, lack of work or lack of funds, the department director shall submit a report to the city manager, together with a recommendation as to whether or not the employee should be laid off. 
B.  The city manager shall determine the order of lay-off of employees on the basis of seniority, that is, those with the least seniority shall be laid off first, insofar as job classification permits. Whenever it becomes necessary to increase the working forces, laid-off employees shall be recalled in reverse order of their lay-off before any new help is hired. 
C.  Regular employees subject to lay-off shall be notified, in writing, two calendar weeks prior to the effective date, whenever possible. 
D.  Employees who are laid off shall, upon request, be placed on the open examination list for any class for which they are qualified. 
(Prior code § 288.04) 
3.32.050. - Dismissal. 
A.  The city manager may dismiss any employee for the good of the city service for any of the following reasons: 
1.  Failure to meet prescribed standards of work, morality and ethics to an extent that makes an employee unsuitable for any kind of employment in the city service; 
2.  Theft or destruction of city property; 
3.  Incompetency, inefficiency or negligence in the performance of duties; 
4.  Insubordination that constitutes a serious breach of discipline; 
5.  Conviction of a criminal offense; 
6.  Notoriously disgraceful personal conduct; 
7.  Unauthorized absences or abuse of leave privileges; 
8.  Acceptance of any valuable consideration which was given with the expectation of influencing the employee in the performance of his duties; 
9.  Falsification of records or use of official position for personal advantage. 
B.  The employee shall be furnished an advance written notice containing the nature of the proposed action, the reasons therefor and his or her right to answer the charges, orally or in writing. This notice shall be furnished at least one calendar week prior to the proposed effective date of the action. 
C.  During the advance notice period, the employee may be retained in duty status, placed on leave or suspended with or without pay, at the discretion of the city manager. 
D.  If the employee fails to respond to the advance notice, the proposed action of the city manager shall be effective on the date specified with no need for further action. Otherwise, the city manager shall carefully consider the reply of the employee before making a final decision, and at the earliest possible moment shall transmit to the employee a letter containing his final decision. 
E.  It is the policy of the city not to rehire former employees who have been dismissed or who resigned while charges where pending under this section. 
(Prior code § 288.05) 
3.32.060. - Termination of regular appointment during probationary period. 
A.  At any time during the probationary period, the city manager may separate an employee whose performance does not meet the required standards. 
B.  Department heads shall inform employees, in writing, of the evaluation of their performance prior to completion of the probationary period. However, an employee shall not acquire full status as a regular employee until approved by the city manager. 
C.  The reasons for the removal shall be furnished the employee verbally and confirmed in writing. 
(Prior code § 288.06) 
3.32.070. - Removal for disability. 
    An employee may be separated for disability when he or she cannot perform the required duties because of physical or mental impairment. Action may be initiated by the employee, his or her legal representative or the city, but in all cases such action must be supported by medical evidence acceptable to the city manager. The city may require an examination at its expense and performed by a physician of its choice. 
(Prior code § 288.07) 
3.32.080. - Death. 
    Separation shall be effective as of the date of death. 
(Prior code § 288.08) 
3.32.090. - Payment of compensation to estate. 
    All compensation due in accordance with Section 3.32.020 shall be paid to the estate of the employee, except for such sums as by law may be paid to the surviving spouse. 
(Prior code § 288.09) 
3.32.100. - Disciplinary actions. 
    Whenever employee performance, attitude, work habits or personal conduct at any time falls below a desirable level, supervisors shall inform them promptly and specifically of such lapses and give counsel and assistance. If appropriate and justified, a reasonable period of time for improvement may be allowed before initiating a disciplinary action. In some instances, a specific incident may justify severe disciplinary action in and of itself. However, the action to be taken depends on the seriousness of the incident and the whole pattern of the employee's past performance and conduct. 
(Prior code § 288.11) 
3.32.110. - Written reprimand. 
    In situations where an oral warning has not resulted in expected improvements, or where more severe initial action is warranted, a written reprimand shall be sent to the employee and a copy shall be placed in the employee's personnel folder. 
(Prior code § 288.12) 
3.32.120. - Suspension without pay. 
    An employee may be suspended without pay for reasons of misconduct, negligence, inefficiency, insubordination, disloyalty, unauthorized absence or other justifiable reasons when alternate personnel actions are not appropriate. The employee shall be furnished an advance written notice (except as provided below) containing the nature of the proposed action, the reasons therefor and his right to answer the charges orally or in writing. This notice shall be furnished at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the proposed effective date of the action. If the employee fails to respond to the advance notice, the proposed action shall be effective on the date specified with no need for future action. If the employee replies, his answer shall be carefully considered before a decision is reached. A final written decision shall be furnished. An immediate suspension may be made when the city manager determines that it is in the best interest of the city. Justification for such action may include, but is not limited to, shortage of funds, unlawful use of property, insubordination, intoxication on duty or arrest for a crime. 
(Prior code § 288.13) 
Chapter 3.36. - EMPLOYEE GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE 

3.36.010. - Statement of policy. 
    The most effective accomplishment of the work of the city requires prompt consideration and equitable adjustment of employee grievances. It is the desire of the city to adjust grievances informally, and both supervisors and employees are expected to make every effort to resolve problems as they arise. However, it is recognized that there will be occasional grievances which will be resolved only after a formal appeal and review. Accordingly, the following procedure is established to ensure fair and impartial review. 
A.  Members of the bargaining unit established by the State Labor Relations Board in Certification No. EE 1764 shall following the grievance procedure as outlined in the agreement between the council and the State Public Employee Council No. 94. 
B.  Members of the bargaining unit represented by the Newport Lodge No. 8, Fraternal Order of Police, shall follow the grievance procedure as outlined in the agreement between the city and Newport Lodge No. 8, Fraternal Order of Police. 
C.  Members of the bargaining unit represented by Local No. 1080, International Association of Firefighters, AFL-CIO, shall follow the grievance procedure as outlined in the agreement between the city and Local No. 1080, I.A.F.F., AFL-CIO. 
(Prior code § 292.01) 
3.36.020. - General procedure. 
A.  The aggrieved employee or his representative shall take up his or her grievance with his or her immediate supervisor who shall take the necessary steps to adjust the complaint if it is within his or her power to do so. 
B.  If the immediate supervisor is unable or unwilling to adjust the grievance, the grievance shall be put into writing and sent to his or her division or department head with a copy to the department of personnel. The department or division head shall discuss the grievance with the employee and his or her representatives, if any, and attempt to adjust the problem if it is within his or her power to do so. The division or department head shall reduce his or her findings in the case to writing within two days and advise the employee and the personnel department of his or her decision in the case. 
C.  Should the employee and/or the union representing such employee still be grieved, the employee and/or the union representing such employee should apply in writing to the city manager stating the reasons for his or her grievance, including all pertinent facts of the case. 
D.  Within ten days after receiving the complaint, the city manager shall call a meeting which shall include the department head, the complainant and representatives of his or her own choosing, and any other person or persons involved in the complaint. The city manager shall preside at the meeting and hear the entire case to obtain all the facts. 
E.  The city manager shall make a complete report of his or her findings and render a decision to the employee and department head in writing. 
F.  The personnel appeals board may review the decision of the city manager and its decision shall be final. 
(Prior code § 292.02) 
Chapter 3.40. - CONSULTANT SERVICES 

3.40.010. - Statement of policies. 
    It is the policy of the city to retain consultant services, when necessary, on the basis of demonstrated competence and qualification for the type of services required, at fair and reasonable prices. It is recognized that competence, experience and ability are important considerations and that the amount of the fee shall not be the only criterion in selecting professional services. It is further the policy of the city to give first preference, where the talents and experience are available and previous evaluation is satisfactory, to the selection of consulting services of firms or principals located in the city and second preference to state-based firms or principals. 
(Prior code § 297.01) 
3.40.020. - Classification of services. 
A.  Class I. Class I service is service for projects where the consultant's fee will exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The consultant shall be recommended by a staff screening and selection committee with final selection and contract approval to be accomplished by council at a regular or special council meeting. Members of the committee shall be the city manager, the director of engineering and inspections, the director of finance and the department head requesting the service. The city solicitor shall also serve as a member of the committee for the purpose of reviewing the legality of all proposed contracts. 
B.  Class II. Class II service is service for projects where the consultant's fee will not exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The city manager is authorized to select consultants based upon the department head's recommendation. A full report of all consultant screening and selection shall be contained in the city manager's report to council. 
(Prior code § 297.02) 
3.40.030. - General procedures and responsibilities. 
    The procedures and responsibilities outlined herein provide a general scope of the procedures for consultant selection. Detailed instructions and guidelines are contained in Section 3.40.040. 
A.  Project Initiation. When a department head identifies a project for which Class I consultant service will be necessary, he or she shall draft a scope of service for the specific project. The scope of service shall be submitted to the city manager for approval and for certification that funds are available in the budget for the service. The scope of service shall then be presented to council for authorization to initiate the project. 
B.  Roster of Consultants. Upon authorization to initiate the project, the city manager shall prepare a roster of firms interested in providing this type of service to the city. The roster shall be established and maintained using information set forth in Section 3.40.040I. 
C.  Expressions of Interest. The city manager shall contact those persons or firms on the consultants roster for a written expression of interest on the specific project. The request should invite interest in the project and comment by the date set forth in the request as to the special expertise in the project being considered and the availability of the firm or person to provide the required service. 
D.  Initial Screening and Request for Proposals. The expression of interest shall then be presented to the staff screening and selection committee for initial screening in accordance with the guidelines provided in Section 3.40.040D. Where possible, the committee shall designate at least three firms who shall be requested to present, in person, detailed proposals on the project. Detailed proposals shall include data as suggested in the guidelines in Section 3.40.040E. 
E.  Final Selection and Contract Negotiation. On the basis of the detailed proposals presented by the prospective consultants, the committee shall recommend a consultant and a form of written contract to council. If, for some reason, the committee cannot agree, the city manager shall make a recommendation to council. Council shall approve or disapprove the selection and contract. 
(Prior code § 297.03) 
3.40.040. - Detailed guidelines for consultant selection. 
A.  Scope of Services. The scope of services for the particular project shall be developed by the department requesting the service. The scope should define the project in specific terms and identify the various project components and phases. The degree, if any, of federal or state participation should also be defined at this time since certain planning and design criteria may be prerequisites for federal or state assistance. 
    A memorandum transmitting the scope of services to the city manager for presentation to council should define the need for the project, identify a budget estimate for the project and suggest the source of funds for payment to the consultant. 
B.  Organization of Screening Committee. The city manager shall serve as chairman of the staff screening and selection committee and the director of finance as vice-chairman. The department head requesting the project or his or her representative shall attend all committee meetings to provide data and recommendations on the project and to implement actions directed by the committee. 
C.  Expression of Interest. Letters requesting an expression of interest should ask the consultants to indicate their interest in the particular project, set forth special qualifications they may wish to call to the attention of the committee, describe previous experience with similar jobs and indicate their capability to perform the service within any time limitations. If the consultant does not have a brochure or resume on file, he or she should be asked to present that information. 
D.  Initial Screening. The committee shall review the expressions of interest and other qualification data on file with the city. Factors to be determined in initial screening shall include: 
1.  Specialized experience in the type of work required; 
2.  A record of the firm in accomplishing work on other projects in the required time; 
3.  The quality of work previously performed by the firm for the city; 
4.  The professional background, experience and expertise of principals and potential project managers; 
5.  Recent experience showing accuracy of cost estimates; 
6.  Community relations, including evidence of sensitivity to citizen concerns; and 
7.  The geographic location of the principal offices of the firm. 
E.  Detailed Proposals. Based on the results of the initial screening, not more than three firms shall be invited to submit a detailed proposal. Firms not asked to submit a detailed proposal should be so advised in writing and thanked for the their interest in the project. 
1.  Firms submitting detailed proposals should be asked to provide a resume of their proposed project supervisor, the name of the principal who would be responsible for the work, the amount of work presently under way, the ability of the firm to meet required time schedules, a description of how the project would be conducted and monitored, an evaluation of the adequacy of funds available to accomplish the proposed project, the proposed method of determining fees, with alternatives, if desired, the amount of administrative assistance during the first phases of the project and the amount of supervision during the construction phase of the project, as well as other facts they wish to present in favor of their firm. 
2.  The contract form for consulting services should, in general, follow the standards of the American Institute of Architects, the National Society of Professional Engineers or the American Society of Civil Engineers, as applicable to the specific project. 
3.  These firms shall also be advised that city policy requires that an equal employment opportunity and affirmative action program be provided prior to execution of a contract. 
F.  Interview and Selection. Upon receipt of the detailed proposals, the staff selection and screening committee shall be convened to review the proposals, interview the prospective consultants, review fee determination methods and rank the consultants for negotiation of fees. Association consultants who would be used by the primary consultant should be identified at this time. 
    Selection for negotiation should be based upon qualifications, availability, staffing, professional competence and such other matters as the committee may deem proper. 
G.  Contract Negotiation. The selected firm shall then be requested to come in for a final conference with the responsible department head to define precisely the scope of service to be provided and to submit a proposal covering the compensation requirements for the work. Consultant firms employing four or more people shall also be required to submit their equal employment opportunity and affirmative action program at this time. A fee shall then be negotiated with the funds available for the project and a contract shall be prepared and submitted to the city solicitor for review and then submitted to the city manager for presentation to council for approval. 
    If, after reasonable effort, a contract cannot be negotiated within available funds, the negotiations with the designated consultant shall be terminated in writing and negotiations shall be started with the next consultant recommended. 
H.  Contract Approval. The final action to implement consultant selection is approval of the consultant contract. All contracts are to be approved by council after thorough review by the city solicitor. 
I.  Consultant Records. Upon completion or termination of a contract, the department responsible for the project shall submit a one page summary evaluation of the consultant's handling of the project, which evaluation shall include the following data: 
1.  The name of the consultant; 
2.  The date of the contract and the date of completion; 
3.  The cost as stated in the initial contract, the amount paid and the reason for any difference; 
4.  The names of key personnel working on the project; 
5.  The special strengths exhibited by the consultant; 
6.  The problems or weaknesses in the consultant's handling of the project; 
7.  The title and date of any report documents prepared by the consultant; 
8.  Adherence to the time schedule by the consultant; and 
9.  Any comment on commitment to equal employment opportunity. 
    The summary evaluation shall be submitted to the city manager for review and subsequent filing with the consultant's resume in the city manager's office. Summary evaluations shall be retained for a period of five years. The summary evaluation shall be reported to council by the city manager. 
(Prior code § 297.04) 
3.40.050. - Contract extensions-Exceptions to regulations. 
A.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, where the scope of services states that the project may include additional services which are a logical extension of the original services, and if continuation or extension of the project is economically feasible and the evaluation of services performed to date is satisfactory, the city manager, with the final approval of council, may negotiate the continued employment of the same consultant without following procedural steps set forth in Section 3.40.030 and Section 3.40.040(A) through (F). 
B.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, council may, by resolution, authorize the city manager to negotiate the employment of a consultant without following the steps set forth in this chapter, for reasons of economy or expediency, or because selection of a consultant by following such steps would be, for any reason, impractical. 
(Prior code § 297.05) 
Chapter 3.44. - RETIREMENT 

3.44.010. - Notice of retirement. 
    The provisions of Section 3.32.030, "Resignation and Retirement," shall be applicable for an employee to be eligible to receive severance or retirement compensation. 
(Ord. 2006-34 § 2 (part), 2006) 
3.44.020. - Health insurance. 
    Supervisory employees who have retired from city employment after July 1, 1981, shall be entitled to receive family or individual health insurance coverage similar to active supervisory employees. This health insurance coverage shall not include any dental insurance coverage. The city shall only be responsible for such health insurance coverage for such employees from and after July 1, 1985. At age sixty-five (65), the city shall only supplement medicare entitlement by paying for Blue Cross Plan 65 or an equivalent plan. Such coverage shall be terminated if equal or greater health insurance benefits are provided by any other means or through any other employer to such retiree. Coverage shall remain in effect until the death of the retiree. 
(Ord. 2006-34 § 2 (part), 2006; prior code § 290.04) 
3.44.030. - Municipal Employees' Retirement System contributions. 
    Effective June 20, 1987, council shall, pursuant to Gen. Laws § 45-21-41.1, pick up and pay to the Municipal Employees' Retirement System of the state the contributions which would be otherwise payable to such system by its employees who are members of the system and shall treat, in all respects, such contributions in the manner specified in Gen. Laws § 45-21-41.1. 
(Ord. 2006-34 § 2 (part), 2006; prior code § 290.05) 
3.44.040. - Sick or injured police officers. 
    Pursuant to the authority established in Section 45-19-19 of the Rhode Island General Laws, any police officer who is absent from employment due to sickness contracted or injuries sustained in the performance of his or her duties which results in a total disability shall be placed on a disability retirement allowance of sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3) percent of his or her annual salary at the time of retirement. However, any pension cost-of-living increase or escalator clause contained within the collective bargaining agreement which applies to pensions received as a result of a line-of-duty injury shall remain applicable. 
(Ord. 2006-34 § 2 (part), 2006; Ord. 66-94 § 1, 1994) 
Chapter 3.48. - POLICE PENSION AND RETIREMENT PLAN 

3.48.010. - Intent and purpose. 
    The intent and purpose of this chapter are to provide benefits to members of the police division in addition to those provided in Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended. Benefits hereunder shall be paid by the city in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 294.01) 
3.48.020. - Minimum benefits. 
A.  The annual pension of any permanent member of the police division who retired after June 2, 1947, and before October 10, 1975, after serving twenty-five (25) years in the division, is established at fifty (50) percent of the regular annual salary for the position from which he or she retired, as the salary for such position is determined at the beginning of each fiscal year, excluding any longevity increment. 
B.  On or after October 10, 1975, any permanent member of the division shall be and is eligible for retirement after twenty (20) years of service and shall receive as his or her annual pension fifty (50) percent for twenty (20) years of service plus two percent per year, but not to exceed sixty (60) percent for each additional year served over twenty (20) years, of the annual salary for the position from which he or she retired, as the salary for such position is determined at the beginning of each fiscal year, including the additional longevity increment earned by such member within the limits as set forth in the police contract at the time of his or her retirement. 
C.  Any city police chief, deputy chief or assistant chief, who retired prior to December 31, 1967, and who at the time of his or her retirement was a member of Lodge No. 8, Fraternal Order of Police, shall be entitled to an annual percentage increase to his or her pension equal to the percentage wage increase awarded to active members of the police division, such increases to be made at the commencement of each fiscal year. 
D.  Any city police chief who retired subsequent to January 1, 1968, shall be entitled to an annual percentage increase to his or her pension equal to the wage increase, if any, awarded to active members of the division under the provisions of the police contract. 
E.  Members of the division who have served in excess of twenty-five (25) years after August 31, 1966, shall receive additional compensation of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year for each year of service beyond twenty-five (25) years, the total increment in no case to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Prior code § 294.02) 
3.48.030. - Survivor's benefits-Effect of certain elections. 
A.  Persons With Twenty-Five Years of Service. If a permanent member of the police division, while on active duty, or a member now retired on the inactive pension roll, or any member now on active duty who subsequently retires, having served twenty-five (25) years of active duty within the division, dies leaving a widow or widower surviving him or her, then his widow or widower shall receive as a survivor's benefit two-thirds of the amount of the pension the member was receiving or would have received were he or she retired at the time of his or her death based on his or her rank at the time of his or her death. 
B.  Persons With Less Than Twenty-Five Years of Service. If a permanent member of the division, either on the active or retired roll at the time of his or her death, has not served twenty-five (25) years with the division and dies leaving a widow or widower, his or her widow or widower shall receive as a survivor's benefit two-thirds of the amount computed by prorating the length of active service of the deceased member with the prerequisite of twenty-five (25) years for a full pension, based on his or her rank at the time of his or her death. 
C.  Survivor's Benefit-Dependent Children. If a member dies without leaving a widow or widower, but with a dependent child or children surviving him or her, or if he or she dies leaving a widow or widower and a dependent child or children, and the widow or widower subsequently dies, such child or children shall receive in the aggregate each year the amount the widow or widower would have received had he or she survived. If there is more than one child, then the survivor's benefit shall be reduced proportionately as each child reaches the age of eighteen (18) years. 
D.  Remarriage of Widow or Widower. If a member dies leaving a widow or widower surviving and the widow or widower subsequently remarries, then all benefits payable under subsections A, B and C of this section shall immediately cease. 
E.  Option of Widow or Widower. If any widow or widower or heir-at-law elects to withdraw the amount which the member has paid into the pension fund pursuant to Section 13(b) of Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended, then no benefits granted by this chapter shall be paid. 
F.  Existing State Law. Nothing in this chapter shall prevent a member or dependent from claiming benefits payable under Title 45-19 of the General Laws, but any person claiming under state law shall not receive any benefits under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 294.03) 
3.48.040. - Credit for service in armed forces. 
    Any active permanent police officers as of November 1, 1974, who was in the armed forces of the United States or in the Merchant Marine Service of the United States, as defined in Chapter 1721 of the Public Laws, 1946, as amended, during any period of one year or more commencing on September 16, 1940, and terminating February 1, 1973, may, prior to July 1, 1976, pay into the pension fund and retirement system a contribution equal to ten percent of his or her salary for the first year multiplied by the number of years and fraction thereof in the armed forces for which he or she desires credit up to a maximum of four years. Thereupon, he or she shall be credited with such service up to such four years maximum. Such credit shall apply only toward the twenty-five (25) years of active service in the police division needed to earn retirement and may not be used to purchase any extra retirement benefits. In the event that the time needed to earn retirement is reduced from twenty-five (25) years, this section shall have no effect, and any active officer who so purchased his or her military service time shall receive a refund of his or her payments made therefor at the time such reduction from twenty-five (25) years becomes effective. 
    Any member claiming his or her service time as herein provided shall sign an affidavit that he or she will retire from the division when he or she accrues twenty-five (25) years of service, including time purchased hereunder. 
(Prior code § 294.04) 
3.48.050. - Pension and retirement allowance for certain members. 
    Every member of the police division placed on the inactive roll and retirement list under Section 14 of Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended, shall receive an annual pension and retirement allowance in the following amounts: 
A.  For every year or portion of a year up to a maximum of twenty (20) years that a member serves on the permanent police force, he or she shall receive a sum equal to one-twentieth of the total sum provided for full retirement in Section 13 of Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended, based on his or her rank. However, the sum shall not be less than twenty (20) percent of the total sum, provided for full retirement in Section 13 based on his or her rank, regardless of the number of years served on the permanent force. 
B.  Every member who serves on the permanent force for more than twenty (20) years and applies for a nonservice medically certified disability retirement shall receive not less than the amount set forth in Section 13 of Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended. 
(Prior code § 294.05) 
3.48.060. - Allowance increase for certain members. 
    Every member of the police division who was placed on the inactive roll and retirement list as disabled prior to 1967 and who, at the time of retirement, had completed at least seven years of service as a permanent member of the division, is hereby granted an increase of one hundred (100) percent of his or her annual pension and retirement allowance. 
(Prior code § 294.06) 
3.48.070. - Annual physical examination for certain members-Reinstatement- Forfeiture of benefits. 
    Every member of the police division placed on the inactive roll and retirement list from April 17, 1963, under Section 14 of Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended, shall submit to an annual physical examination and the same procedure with respect to the physical examination shall be followed as is set forth in Section 14 of Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended. Should the annual physical examination result in a finding that such member is no longer physically or mentally incapacitated for the performance of duty, the city manager shall, forthwith, offer to reinstate the member as an active member of the division at the same grade as when he or she was placed on the inactive roll and retirement list and at the salary in effect at that time of such offer or re-employment. Should such member refuse the offer of re-employment, all of his or her pension rights under Section 14 of Chapter 1896 of the Public Laws of 1947, as amended, shall cease immediately. 
(Prior code § 294.07) 
3.48.080. - Benefits for widows and widowers of members who died prior to January 1, 1965, after serving more than twenty-five years. 
A.  The intent and purpose of this section are to provide monthly benefits to those unremarried widows and widowers of members of the police division who died prior to January 1, 1965, after rendering more than twenty-five (25) years of active duty in the division. The survivor's benefit provided herein shall be paid only to those widows and widowers whose spouses died prior to January 1, 1965. All other widows and widowers and dependents thereafter shall be paid in accordance with Section 3.48.030. 
B.  The surviving widow or widower of those members of the division who had served not less than twenty-five (25) years on active duty and who were placed on the retired rolls and then died, shall receive one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year for the rest of their lives, commencing July 1, 1970. 
C.  The surviving widows and widowers of those members of the division who served more than twenty-five (25) years in the division and died while on active duty shall receive one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year for the rest of their lives, commencing on July 1, 1970. No widow or widower who accepts a monthly survivor's benefit hereunder shall withdraw from the pension fund any contributions made by her or his deceased spouse, and if any widow or widower eligible for benefits hereunder has, in the past, withdrawn from the pension fund contributions made by her or his spouse, then such widow or widower shall, if financially able, repay such withdrawals to the pension fund. The director of finance shall determine the financial ability of any widow or widower to repay under this section. 
D.  If an eligible widow or widower, under this section, has remarried or subsequently remarries, no benefits shall be paid to such remarried widow or widower. 
(Prior code § 294.08) 
Chapter 3.52. - FIREMEN'S PENSION AND RETIREMENT SYSTEM 

3.52.010. - Intent and purpose. 
    The intent and purpose of this chapter are to provide benefits to members of the fire division in addition to those provided in Section 7 of Chapter 110 of the Public Laws of Rhode Island, 1957, as amended. Benefits hereunder shall be paid by the city in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 296.01) 
3.52.020. - Minimum benefits-Contributions. 
A.  Members of the fire division who have been placed on the retired rolls after having served twenty-five (25) years in the division shall receive as a pension fifty-five (55) percent of the regular annual salary for the position from which they retired, as salary for such position is determined at the beginning of each fiscal year. However, members of the division who has been placed on the retired rolls on or after July 1, 1977, after having served twenty-five (25) years in the division, shall receive as a pension fifty-five (55) percent of the regular annual salary, including the longevity increment, for the position from which they retired, as salary for such position is determined at the beginning of each fiscal year. Further, active members of the division as of July 1, 1977, after having served twenty-five (25) years in the division, shall receive as a pension after July 1, 1978, sixty (60) percent of the regular annual salary, including the longevity increment, for the position from which they retired, as salary for such position is determined at the beginning of each fiscal year. 
B.  Members of the division who are retired because of a physical or mental incapacity and who have served less than twenty-five (25) years in the division shall receive as a pension twenty-five (25) percent of the regular annual salary for the position from which they retired, as salary for such position is determined at the beginning of each fiscal year, if they have served ten years or less. If such members have served ten years, such members shall receive as a pension twenty-five (25) percent of the regular annual salary for the position from which they retired, as salary for such position is determined at the beginning of each fiscal year, plus two and one-half percent of such salary for each completed year of service over ten years up to a maximum of twenty-five (25) years of service. 
C.  If a permanent member of the division dies from injuries incurred or disease contracted in the line of duty (excluding heart and lung ailments), leaving a widow or widower, or dependent, his or her widow, widower or dependent shall receive a survivor's benefit as if the member had completed twenty-five (25) years of service, pursuant to Section 16(a) of Chapter 205 of the Public Laws of 1967, as amended. 
D.  Any call man, so-called, of the fire division, who has served as a call man for at least fifteen (15) years and who then becomes a permanent member of such division, shall, for each three years of service as a call man, prior to becoming a permanent member, be credited with one year of service towards the twenty-five (25) year regular employment set forth in subsection A of this section. However, any permanent member who qualifies under the foregoing provisions and who receives credit toward the twenty-five (25) year regular employment, as set forth in subsection A of this section, shall pay, for each year or any portion thereof so credited, into the pension fund, a sum equal to ten percent of the compensation earned in his or her first year as a permanent member of the division multiplied by the number of years for which he or she seeks credit. 
E.  Any city fire chief shall be entitled to an annual percentage increase to his or her pension equal to the wage increase, if any, awarded to active members of the fire division under the provisions of the fire contract. 
F.  Effective July 1, 1983, all employees shall be vested in the pension system after completing ten years in the division. Such members shall receive, as a pension for the position from which they retired, two and one-half percent of such salary for each completed year of service in the division, including their probationary time, and shall be allowed to collect their pension following the first day they would have completed twenty-five (25) years of service in the division. 
(Prior code § 296.02) 
3.52.030. - Survivor's benefits-Effect of certain elections. 
A.  Persons With Twenty-Five Years of Service. If a permanent member of the fire division, while on active duty, or a member now retired on the inactive pension roll, or any member now on active duty who subsequently retires, having served twenty-five (25) years of active duty with the division, dies leaving a widow or widower surviving him or her, then his or her widow or widower shall receive as a survivor's benefit two-thirds of the amount of the pension such member was receiving or should have received were he or she retired at the time of his or her death based on his or her rank at the time of his or her death. 
B.  Persons With Less Than Twenty-Five Years of Service. If a permanent member of the division, either on the active or retired roll at the time of his or her death, has not served twenty-five (25) years with the division and dies leaving a widow or widower, his widow or widower shall receive as a survivor's benefit two-thirds of an amount computed by prorating the length of active service of the deceased member with the prerequisite of twenty-five (25) years for a full pension, based on his or her rank at the time of his or her death, or one-third of the amount the deceased member was receiving at the time of his or her death under the provisions of Section 7-1(2) of Chapter 110 of the Public Laws of Rhode Island, 1957, as amended, whichever is greater. 
C.  Survivor's Benefit-Dependent Children. If a member dies without leaving a widow or widower but with a dependent child or children surviving him or her, or if he or she dies leaving a widow or widower and the widow or widower subsequently dies, or if he or she leaves a widow or widower and the widow or widower remarries, such child or children shall receive in the aggregate each year the amount the widow or widower would have received had he or she survived or not remarried. If there is more than one child, then the survivor's benefit shall be reduced proportionately as each child reaches the age of eighteen (18) years. 
D.  Remarriage of Widow or Widower. If a member dies leaving a widow or widower surviving and the widow or widower subsequently remarries, then all benefits payable under subsections A, B and C of this section shall immediately cease. 
E.  Option of Widow or Widower. If any widow or widower or heir-at-law elects to withdraw the amount which the member has paid into the pension fund pursuant to Section 16 of Chapter 110, Public Laws of 1957, as amended, then no benefits granted by this chapter shall be paid. 
F.  Existing State Law. Nothing in this chapter shall prevent a member or dependent from claiming benefits payable under Title 45-19 of the General Laws of 1956, as amended, but any person claiming under state law shall not receive any benefits under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 296.03) 
3.52.040. - Benefits for widows and widowers of members who died prior to January 1, 1965, after serving more than twenty-five years. 
A.  The intent and purpose of this section are to provide monthly benefits to those unremarried widows and widowers of members of the fire division who died prior to January 1, 1965, after rendering more than twenty-five (25) years of active duty in the division. The survivor's benefit provided herein shall be paid only to those widows and widowers whose spouses died prior to January 1, 1965. All other widows and widowers and dependents thereafter shall be paid in accordance with Section 3.52.030. 
B.  The surviving widow or widower of those members of the division who had served not less than twenty-five (25) years on active duty and who were placed on the retired rolls and then died, shall receive one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year for the rest of their lives, commencing July 1, 1970. 
C.  The surviving widows or widowers of those members of the division who served more than twenty-five (25) years in the division and died while on active duty shall receive one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per year for the rest of their lives, commencing July 1, 1970. No widow or widower who accepts a monthly survivor's benefit hereunder shall withdraw from the pension fund any contributions made by her or his deceased spouse, and if any widow or widower eligible for benefits hereunder has, in the past, withdrawn from the pension fund contributions made by her or his spouse, them such widow or widower shall, if financially able, repay such withdrawals to the pension fund. The director of finance shall determine the financial ability of any widow or widower to repay under this section. 
D.  If an eligible widow or widower, under this section, has remarried or subsequently remarries, then no benefits shall be paid to such remarried widow or widower. 
(Prior code § 296.04) 
3.52.050. - Credit for service in armed forces. 
A.  Any active member of the permanent paid fire division as of November 1, 1974, who was in the armed forces of the United States or in the Merchant Marine Service of the United States, as defined in Chapter 1721 of the Public Laws of 1946, as amended, during any period of one year or more commencing September 16, 1940, and terminating February 1, 1973, may, prior to July 1, 1976, pay into the pension fund and retirement system a contribution equal to ten percent of his or her salary for the first year multiplied by the number of years and fraction thereof in such armed forces for which he or she desires credit up to a maximum of four years. Thereupon, he or she shall be credited with such service up to such four years maximum. Such credit shall apply only toward the twenty-five (25) years of active service in the fire division needed to earn retirement and may not be used to purchase any extra retirement benefits. In the event that the time needed to earn retirement is reduced from twenty-five (25) years, this section shall have no effect, and any active officer who so purchased his or her military service time shall receive a refund of his or her payments made therefor at the time such reduction from twenty-five (25) years becomes effective. 
B.  Any member claiming his or her service time as herein provided shall sign an affidavit that he or she will retire from the division when he or she accrues twenty-five (25) years of service, including time purchased hereunder. 
(Prior code § 296.05) 
3.52.060. - Pension contributions. 
    Effective January 1, 1988, council shall, pursuant to Internal Revenue Code Section 414(h)(2), implement the pick-up plan as it relates to the pension contributions of the members of Local 1080, International Association of Fire Fighters, and shall defer such contributions. 
(Prior code § 296.06) 
Title 4. - REVENUE AND FINANCE 
Chapter 4.04. - FISCAL PROVISIONS GENERALLY 

4.04.010. - Fiscal year established. 
    The fiscal year for the city shall begin on July 1st and end of June 30th of each year. 
(Prior code § 222.12) 
4.04.020. - Copies of proposed budget to be available for inspection. 
    The city manager shall provide sufficient copies of his proposed annual budget so that a copy is available to any interested resident at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to council's public hearing thereon. 
(Prior code § 222.13) 
4.04.030. - Assignment of wages. 
    No officer or employee of the city shall transfer or assign to any person the salary or wages due, owing or payable to him or to become due, owing or payable to him by the city, under penalty of dismissal from service of the city. 
(Prior code § 222.14) 
4.04.040. - Deposit of city moneys. 
    Every officer, official or employee of the city who, in the ordinary and usual discharge of his duties, receives any money for issuing permits, licenses, copies or records, or receives money as filing fees for papers to be recorded in the office or department with which such officer, official or employee is connected or employed, or receives any other cash in connection with the duties of his or her official position, shall, through the chief official in such department, deposit the same in the office of the city treasurer on or before the fifth day of the month following that in which the money is received, and the city treasurer shall give his proper receipt therefor. However, the collector of taxes shall make daily transfers of his receipts, except where such accumulated daily receipts do not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), but in no event shall he or she hold any tax receipts longer than one week after their receipt. In the case of the city clerk, where fees are received with applications which may not be granted, he or she shall hold such fees only until such time as it is determined that they are actual revenue of the city. 
(Prior code § 222.15) 
4.04.050. - Officials not to deposit city moneys in own accounts. 
    No officer, official or employee of the city shall deposit any city moneys, obtained in his or her official capacity, in any banking institution in his or her own name or in any other name except that of the city. 
(Prior code § 222.16) 
4.04.060. - Account for cash receipts, etc. 
    All cash in the possession of any official of the city, received by him or her in connection with his or her official position, and all vouchers, stubs, cash books or other records or books evidencing the receipt of such cash, shall be subject to complete examination at any or all times by the properly authorized representative of the city. 
(Prior code § 222.17) 
4.04.070. - Payment of claims against city. 
A.  Any claim or demand against the city with a value of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) may be approved by the city manager without council approval. 
B.  No claim or demand against the city, with a value of over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), shall be paid until the same is ordered by council or where especially provided by the laws of the state. All orders for the payment of money as aforesaid shall be signed by the city clerk and delivered to the director of finance. 
(Ord. 20-96 § 1, 1996) 
4.04.080. - Director's records. 
    The director of finance shall, under the direction of the city manager, keep an accurate account of all his receipts and payments, and he shall, monthly, lay before the city manager a statement of the condition of the treasury, the amount paid out for the several departments and the balance on hand of each appropriation. 
(Prior code § 222.19) 
4.04.090. - Acceptance of money for real estate purchased at tax sales. 
    The director of finance shall accept for and on behalf of the city all money payable to the city for and on account of real estate purchased by the city at any tax sale authorized by Title 44 of the General Laws, and redeemable under Sections 44-9-19 and 44-9-21 of such General Laws. 
(Prior code § 222.20) 
4.04.100. - Execution of quitclaim deeds. 
    The director of finance, upon payment to him or her of the sums provided for by law, shall execute for and in the name and on behalf of the city, a quitclaim deed which has the approval of the person entitled thereto, granting all the right, title and interest of the city. 
(Prior code § 222.21) 
4.04.110. - Contents of tax bills. 
    Each tax bill, starting with fiscal year 1976-1977, shall include a chart indicating both the revenue and the city appropriations for each fiscal year and any other such pertinent information as the finance director deems important to inform the taxpayers. 
(Prior code § 222.23) 
4.04.120. - Gifts for parks and recreation trust fund. 
A.  There is established a special fund to be known as the "Gifts for Parks and Recreation Trust Fund" under the provisions of Section 1-2 of the City Charter. 
B.  All gifts given to the department of public recreation shall be credited to such trust fund and expended in accordance with the terms and provisions of the gift, devise or bequest and/or appropriate law. 
(Prior code § 222.25) 
4.04.130. - Persons in arrears for taxes. 
    No license, permit or permission of any kind which council or any agent of the city is empowered to grant shall be issued or renewed to any person who or which, at the time of application therefor, is in arrears with respect to any tax, water lien, assessment, debt or charge of any kind due to the city or who or which is in violation of any city law or ordinance. 
(Prior code § 802.01) 
4.04.140. - Verification of payment of taxes to accompany applications. 
    An applicant seeking a license or permit shall submit with his or her application verification from the proper tax or assessment collection agency of the city that all city taxes, water liens and assessments are paid to date, such verification to be submitted with his or her application to council. 
(Prior code § 802.02) 
Chapter 4.08. - PROPERTY TAXES 

4.08.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Due evidence" refers to the fact that no exemption from taxation on the valuation of real property, as herein provided, shall be allowed except upon written application therefor, which application shall be on a form prescribed by the assessor. The assessor may at any time inquire into the right of a claimant to the continuance of an exemption under this chapter and for that purpose may require the filing of a new application or the submission of such proof as he or she deems necessary to determine the right of the claimant to continuance of such exemption. 
    "Income" means all funds received by an individual and/or his or her spouse, from whatever source derived, including, but not limited to, realized capital gains, gifts and, in their entirety, pension, annuity, retirement and social security benefits. Income shall be determined on the basis of the calendar year ending with the date of assessment for the year for which exemption is claimed and each calendar year thereafter. 
    "Resident" means a person legally domiciled within the city for a period of five years ending with the date of assessment for the year for which the exemption is claimed. Mere seasonal or temporary residence within the city, of whatever duration, shall not constitute domicile within the city for the purposes of this chapter. Absence from the city for a period of twelve (12) months shall be prima facie evidence of abandonment of domicile in the city. The burden of establishing legal domicile within the city is upon the applicant. 
(Prior code §§ 880.01, 882.01) 
4.08.020. - Deferrals-Conditions. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 49 of the Public Laws of Rhode Island, 1971, as amended, residences of the city over the age of sixty-five (65) years, or, in the case of husband and wife, if either is over the age of sixty-five (65) years with the property held jointly in both names, who are otherwise eligible and who own and reside in a dwelling on real estate, excluding mobile homes and house trailers, may, if the combined annual income from all sources of husband and wife is at or below the low income level for Newport County, for the previous calendar year as published by U.S. Department of Housing & Urban Development each year for a two-person household or, in the case of a single person, is at or below the low income level for a single-person, is his or her gross income from all sources, apply annually for one deferment of the real estate taxes owed to the city assessed for each year. Such deferral, subject to the approval of the finance director, will be granted under the following conditions. 
A.  The applicant must have been a resident of the city and must have owned and occupied the subject property for five years prior to his or her application. 
B.  No tax deferral will be granted on an application for a real property unit assessed by the assessor at three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) or more for the 2001 revaluation year. 
C.  A deferral may be granted in subsequent years if the property is below the average recorded sale price for the previous year for the class of property for which the application is seeking deferment. That average is to be determined by the assessor and certified to the finance director at his or her request. 
D.  The applicant or, in the case of husband and wife, one of them, must have reached his or her sixty-fifth (65) birthday on or before the assessment date of the tax for which application for deferral is made and must apply during the months of November and December prior to the assessment day for each year in which a tax deferral is applied. The assessor, with the approval of the finance director, may consider an application after December if extenuating circumstances exist. 
E.  Deferrals will be considered only on applications for dwellings which are occupied by the applicant as a permanent domicile. 
F.  The applicant may choose to defer either fifty (50) percent or one hundred (100) percent of the annual tax at his or her option. 
G.  The deferred tax shall become a lien upon the property and the applicant may remove the lien at any time by paying the amount due in full, plus interest. The lien shall be recorded by the city clerk and shall continue until discharged by full payment of all deferred taxes and all interest thereon. 
H.  Interest on deferred taxes shall accrue at the rate set forth under the state of Rhode Island regulations. 
I.  Deferments of taxes will be granted, if the application is approved, only up to the amount of the equity owned by the applicant in the specific unit applied for. 
J.  A sufficient amount of hazard insurance shall be obtained by the applicant, as shall be required by the director of finance, for the protection of the city's lien. The city shall be named in such policy of insurance as a lien or/and a certificate of the policy shall be filed with the director of finance. 
K.  The applicant must reapply annually for each year of his or her deferment on the unit in which he or she resides. He or she must submit information with his or her annual application of his or her gross income for the previous year, as well as his or her spouse's gross income from all sources, as required by the director of finance. 
L.  The actual dollars deferred may not exceed one-half of the actual value of the real property. 
M.  No corporation or partnership or other form of business title holder shall be eligible for a tax deferment, nor any holder of a life estate or remainder interest. Title ownership eligibility shall be limited to owners in fee simple, joint tenants, tenants in common and tenants by the entirety. In the case of joint tenants or tenants in common, other than husband and wife, all such tenants must be over sixty-five (65) years of age and join in the application, and the restriction of gross income as for husband and wife, shall apply to such group of tenants. 
(Ord. 2003-35 § 1, 2003; prior code § 882.02) 
4.08.030. - Payment of deferred taxes and interest upon change in status. 
A.  Upon any change in the manner of holding title to the property or upon any transfer or mortgaging of the premises which are the subject of deferred taxes, other than the taking in fee simple of a husband or wife through survivorship of a joint tenancy or tenancy by the entireties, the entire amount of deferred taxes, with accrued interest thereon at the prescribed rate, must be paid to the finance director. The city's lien shall be discharged upon such full payment plus interest. 
B.
