The city's lien shall take priority to and be the subject of demand for immediate payment in full of all taxes deferred plus interest thereon in the event of any form of insolvency proceeding being filed with, by or against the applicant, petitioning the court to creditors arrangement, bankruptcy, partnership receivership or any other form of insolvency proceeding, immediately upon the filing of such petition. 
C.  Upon the death of an owner in fee simple applicant or, in the case of husband and wife, upon the death of the surviving spouse, the accrued deferments, plus the prescribed interest, shall be payable in full before the lien shall be discharged. Such lien shall rank as a priority claim against the assets and the estate of the applicant or survivor and as a priority lien against the real estate for which such deferred taxes were granted. 
(Prior code § 882.03) 
4.08.040. - Deferred taxes to remain as lien on property. 
    All taxes for which deferral is granted, as provided in this chapter, shall, together with interest as provided in this chapter, be and remain a lien upon the real estate against which assessed and such lien shall be enforceable and collectible in the same manner as real estate taxes generally. 
(Prior code § 882.04) 
4.08.045. - Senior resident property tax service credit program. 
A.  Established. A senior resident property tax service credit program is established, beginning July 1, 2004, to allow qualified senior residents, as determined by the provisions of this section, to receive limited real estate tax credits in exchange for services provided to the city of Newport municipal government, as described in this section. 
B.  Age and Income Limits. Taxpayers qualifying for a senior resident property tax service credit must be sixty-five (65) years of age or over by July 1st to earn property tax credit relief under this program, reside at the property as a full-time resident or residents, and have a gross annual income from all sources at or below the moderate-income level for Newport County for the previous calendar year as published by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development for a two-person household for jointly held property or in the case of a single person, at or below the published level as aforementioned for a one-person household. 
C.  Ownership. The taxpayer or taxpayers applying for the senior resident property tax service credit program must be the owner of the respective real estate to which the credit will apply. 
    If the property is held in trust, the beneficiary or beneficiaries of the trust must be the taxpayer or taxpayers applying for the senior resident property tax service credit program. 
D.  Maximum Abatement and Hourly Rate. The maximum credit taxpayers may earn is five hundred dollars ($500.00) per fiscal year. Credit for service will be at the state of Rhode Island hourly minimum wage at the time the service is performed. 
E.  Personal Exemptions and Deferrals. Taxpayers may earn tax credits under the service credit program in addition to any property tax exemptions for which they may be eligible under other statutes or city ordinances. 
F.  Adoption of Local Program Rules. The city manager may establish rules and procedures for the senior property tax service credit program. These rules and procedures will assure coordination of the assignment of program participants to the various municipal departments where they will perform their services. 
G.  Certification of Service. The board, officer or department supervising the senior taxpayer's service must certify to the assessor the hours, of service performed by the taxpayer before the actual tax for the fiscal year is committed. The certification must state the amount actually earned as of that time. Services performed after that date shall be credited toward the next fiscal year's actually tax bill to the extent they are consistent with the program rules established by the city manager. A copy of the certification must also be provided to the senior program participant prior to the actual tax bill being issued. 
H.  Status of Volunteers. Senior taxpayers performing services in return for property tax reductions shall be considered employees for the purposes of municipal tort liability. The city will be liable for damages for injuries to third parties and for indemnification of the seniors to the same extent as they are in the case of injuries caused by regular municipal employees. 
(Ord. 2006-35 § 1, 2006; Ord. 2004-19 § 1, 2004) 
4.08.050. - Exemptions-Conditions. 
A.  Pursuant to Chapter 194 of the Public Laws of Rhode Island, 1968, a tax exemption is granted to every person who is a citizen and resident of the city of the age of sixty-five (65) or more years and who resides in the city in a dwelling house owned by such person, which dwelling house is a constituent part of such person's real property, on proper claim being made therefor, on the following basis. 
1.  For unmarried taxpayers having an annual income of not more than the "low income" limit for a single person under family size for Newport, published annually by the RI Department of Administration at the beginning of the calendar year in which the tax bill will be issued, an exemption from taxation of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) or twenty (20) percent of the assessed value of such real property, whichever is greater, is granted. For married, or co-owned and inhabited, taxpayers having an annual income of not more than the "low income" limit for a two-person family for Newport published annually by the RI Department of Administration at the beginning of the calendar year in which the tax bill will be issued, an exemption from taxation of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) or twenty (20) percent of the assessed value of such real property, whichever is greater, is granted. Such exemptions shall be in addition to any other exemption to which such person, or persons, may be entitled. 
2.  For the purposes of this chapter, the income level of a husband shall be deemed to include the total income of his wife, and the income of a wife shall be deemed to include the total income of her husband, and only one such exemption shall be allowed in favor of a married couple. Only one such exemption shall be granted to co-tenants, joint tenants and tenants by the entirety even though all such co-tenants, joint tenants or tenants by the entirety are sixty-five (65) years of age or over or all occupy such property. 
3.  In addition to the requirement of domicile within the city, at the time of making application, the applicant must have been a resident of the city for a period of five years ending with the date of assessment for the year for which exemption is claimed. Further, the applicant for this exemption must have owned and had title to his or her dwelling house for the same five-year period. However, such exemption shall not be allowed in favor of any person unless he or she has presented to the assessor a true and exact account of his or her ratable estate as provided for in Title 45, Chapter 5, Sections 15 and 16, of the General Laws of Rhode Island, 1956, as amended for the year for which exemption is claimed, together with due evidence that he or she is so entitled to such exemption. 
B.  In addition to any exemptions heretofore provided, there shall be an additional fifty-two thousand dollars ($52,000.00) exemption from local taxation on real and personal property for any veteran of the military or naval service of the United States who has been or who is classified as or determined to be a prisoner of war by the Veterans Administration. 
C.  A veteran who served in any conflict or war, either declared or undeclared, as defined in Section 44-3-4 of the Rhode Island General Laws, or the unmarried widow or widower of the veteran, shall have an exemption of twenty-one thousand four hundred dollars ($21,400.00) from local taxation on real and personal property. 
D.  The property of each person who has permanent impairment of both eyes, as defined in Section 44-3-12 of the Rhode Island General Laws, shall be exempted from taxation in an amount not to exceed thirty-nine thousand eight hundred dollars ($39,800.00), pursuant to RIGL 44-3-12. 
E.  Any veteran of the military or naval service of the U.S. who is determined under applicable federal law by the Veterans' Administration to be totally disabled through service-connected disability shall have an exemption of eighteen thousand dollars ($18,000.00) from local taxation on real and personal property. 
(Ord. 2006-28 § 1, 2006; Ord. 2003-2 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2002-36 § 1, 2002; Ord. 2001-4 § 1, 2001; Ord. 44-93 § 1, 1993; Ord. 29-89 § 1, 1989; prior code §§ 880.02, 884.01) 
4.08.060. - Conveyance of real property to a tax exempt entity. 
    When the assessor of taxes receives notification, as required by Section 44-3-14 of the Rhode Island General Laws, of the conveyance of real property to an entity which is exempted from the apportionment of any tax on its real estate, the assessor of taxes shall notify the city manager and the city solicitor within seven days of the receipt of such notification. The city solicitor shall advise the assessor of taxes and the city manager as to the eligibility for exemption from the apportionment of any tax on the real estate of the entity making such notification. 
(Ord. 1-92 § 1, 1992: prior code § 886) 
4.08.070. - Exclusion of income-bearing property, etc. 
    No income-bearing residential property, business property or combination of business and residential property, owned and occupied by any person sixty-five (65) years of age or over, shall be entitled to the exemptions provided for in Section 4.08.050. It is the express purpose of this chapter to confine such exemptions to residential property exclusively used as such by the owners thereof. Professional persons who operate and conduct their respective professions from their residences shall not be entitled to the exemptions provided for herein. The practice of a profession from a residence shall be deemed, for the purpose of this chapter, to constitute its income-bearing property. 
(Prior code § 880.03) 
4.08.080. - Termination of exemptions. 
    All exemptions shall terminate upon the conveyance of the subject property, upon the death of the person exempted or upon the moving of such person from the city, and also when the subject property is so altered as to character and use that the property becomes subject to the provisions of Section 4.08.070. 
(Prior code § 880.04) 
4.08.090. - Assessor's authority unchanged. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall abrogate or affect the authority conferred upon the assessor by the provisions of Section 44-3-3, subparagraph 16, of the General Laws. 
(Prior code § 880.05) 
4.08.100. - Right of city to borrow money in anticipation of payment. 
    The city may borrow in anticipation of payment of the cumulative total of all taxes and interest deferred pursuant to Section 4.08.020. 
(Prior code § 882.05) 
4.08.110. - Tax stabilization on capital improvements. 
A.  In conjunction with the city's comprehensive land use plan, as adopted by the city council on December 11, 1991, and as part of the city's policies to provide adequate areas and infrastructure for economic development, any industrial and/or commercial taxpayer shall, upon application to the city, be entitled to a pro-rata tax exemption of that portion of any increased assessment to real property resulting from the expansion, renovation, or adaptive reuse of an existing building or structure of greater than fifty (50) years old. The expansion shall conform with standards as set forth by the historic district commission. The pro-rata exemption for such expansion, renovation or adaptive use shall be computed as follows: 
YEAR % EXEMPTED 1st year of new assessment 80 2nd year of new assessment 60 3rd year of new assessment 40 4th year of new assessment 20 5th year of new assessment 0  
B.  The city council shall have the right to expand upon and modify the percentages of the exemptions and the number of years in which such exemptions shall occur for any vacant industrial and/or commercial property it shall be so determined, provided that such modification shall be in the furtherance of the city's comprehensive land use plan. 
C.  For the purposes of this chapter, the expansion, renovation and the development of real property shall only include: 
1.  Commercial and industrial property as defined under Title 17, Zoning; 
2.  Any real property with an increased assessment of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), or more. 
D.  All exemptions shall terminate when the subject property is so altered as to character and use that the property no longer qualifies for an exemption pursuant to subsection (C)(1) of this section. 
E.  The prior year's assessment will be used for the purpose of determining increased valuation attributable to expansion, renovation and development; provided, however, in those years in which a city-wide revaluation occurs, increased valuation shall be determined by: (1) deducting from such then-current revalued assessment the prior year's assessment to the subject property; and (2) multiplying the result by the average percentage increase by which neighboring revalued properties have increased from the previous year's valuation. 
(Ord. 17-97 § 1, 1997) 
4.08.120. - Property tax classification. 
A.  The city does adopt a system of classification of taxable property in the city of Newport. All ratable property in the city of Newport shall be classified by the assessor as follows: 
1.  Class One - all ratable tangible personal property; 
2.  Class Two - residential real estate with less than four units; 
3.  Class Three - all commercial and industrial real estate and residential real estate with four units or more; 
4.  Class Four - owner-occupied properties with mixed commercial and residential uses, in which the residential unit of the property owner shall be taxed at the residential rate, provided that: (a) the property owner has certified that, he/she is a permanent resident of the residential unit within the structure; (b) the property is in compliance with the city's zoning ordinance; and (c) an application for a mixed-use tax rate is received by the assessor no later than March 15th of each year; and 
5.  Class Five - motor vehicles and trailers subject to the excise tax created by Chapter 44-34 of the Rhode Island General Laws, and the city council hereby sets the motor vehicle exemption amount at five thousand five hundred dollars ($5,500.00). 
B.  The assessor of the city of Newport, on or before June 1st of each year, shall make a full and fair cash valuation of all the estate, real and personal, including motor vehicles and trailers, subject to taxation and determine the assessed valuation of each property class. 
1.  The designated classes of property shall be limited to the five classes as defined in Section 4.08.120(A); 
2.  The effective tax rate applicable to any class shall not exceed by fifty (50) percent the rate applicable to any other class; 
3.  Any tax rate changes from one year to the next shall be applied such that the same percentage rate change is applicable to all classes; 
4.  The tax rates applicable to motor vehicles within class four as defined in Section 4.08.120(A) are governed by Section 44-34.1-1 of the Rhode Island General Laws; 
5.  The provisions of Chapter 35 of Title 44 of the Rhode Island General Laws relating to property tax and fiscal disclosure applies to the reporting of, and compliance with, these classification restrictions. 
(Ord. 2004-21 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2002-30 § 1 (part), 2002) 
(Ord. No. 2010-27, § 1, 7-28-2010) 
4.08.130. - Property tax classification in Newport-Procedure for adopting. 
    The assessor shall provide to the finance director a list containing the full and fair cash valuation of each property class and, with the approval of the city council, annually determine the percentages of the tax levy to be apportioned each class of property and shall annually tax rates sufficient to produce the proportion of the total tax levy. 
(Ord. 2002-30 § 1 (part), 2002) 
4.08.140. - Homestead exemption in the city of Newport. 
A.  The city council of the city of Newport is authorized to annually fix the amount, if any, of a homestead exemption with respect to assessed value from local taxation on taxable real property used for residential purposes in the city of Newport and to grant homestead exemptions to the owner(s) of such residential real estate in amounts not to exceed the following percentages: 
1.  Single-family and condominiums - thirty-five (35) percent exemption; 
2.  Two family - twenty (20) percent exemption; 
3.  Three family - five percent exemption. 
B.  Any such exemption shall only apply to residential property improved with a dwelling house. There shall be no homestead exemption granted for vacant land or for the residential portion of mixed use property in the city of Newport, regardless of the number of units used for residential purposes. In order to determine compliance with the homestead exemption as outlined above, the city council shall provide by resolution or ordinance, rules and regulations governing eligibility for the exemption established by this section. 
C.  The city council of the city of Newport may provide for a proration of the homestead exemption in cases where title to the property passes from those not entitled to the exemption to those who are entitled to claim the exemption. 
(Ord. 2002-30 § 1 (part), 2002) 
Chapter 4.10. - NEWPORT ARTS AND ENTERTAINMENT DISTRICT 

4.10.010. - Intent. 
A.  The city of Newport identifies a need for an arts district to promote artisan business activity that will promote economic activity in harmony with the quality of life, and comply with the Newport zoning code. In accordance with Section 44-18-30.B of the Rhode Island General Laws, the adoption of a Newport arts and entertainment district shall: 
1.  Allow an exemption from Rhode Island state sales tax for consumers purchasing original art from an artist residing in the designated district with a principal place of business in the district, or a one-of-a-kind work of art sold by an art gallery located within the district; and 
2.  Allow an artist, writer, or composer to adjust his/her federal adjusted gross income for Rhode Island income tax purposes if the individual artist, writer or composer resides in the designated district and creates the work while living in the district and derives the income from such work while residing in the district. 
B.  An individual or gallery must apply to the Rhode Island Division of Taxation for a Certificate of Exemption for Artistic Works and meet all statutory requirements to benefit from the tax benefits. 
(Ord. 2005-27 § 1 (part), 2005) 
4.10.020. - Newport arts and entertainment district established. 
    In accordance with the provisions of Rhode Island General Laws Section 44-18-30.B, the following geographic areas of the city of Newport are hereby designated as the Newport artistic community, hereafter known as the "Newport arts and entertainment district": 
A.  Areas zoned as "general business"; 
B.  Areas zoned as "limited business"; 
C.  Areas zoned as "waterfront business"; 
D.  Areas zoned as "R-3"; and 
E.  Areas zoned as "R-10." 
(Ord. 2005-27 § 1 (part), 2005) 
Chapter 4.12. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PROJECTS 

4.12.010. - Capital improvements defined. 
    As used in this chapter, "capital improvements" means major projects undertaken by the city that generally do not recur on a "year in, year out" basis and fit within one or more of the following categories: 
A.  All projects requiring debt obligation or borrowing; 
B.  Any acquisition or lease of land; 
C.  Purchases of major equipment and vehicles valued in excess of seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) with a life expectancy of five years or more; 
D.  Construction of new buildings or facilities, including engineering, design and other preconstruction costs with an estimated cost in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); 
E.  Major building improvements that are not routine expenses and that substantially enhance the value of a structure with an estimated cost in excess of seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00); 
F.  Major equipment or furnishings required to furnish new buildings or other projects with an estimated cost in excess of seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00); and/or 
G.  Major studies requiring the employment of outside professional consultants in excess of seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00). 
(Prior code § 222.24 (a)) 
4.12.020. - General criteria for determining priorities of projects. 
    General criteria shall be established for the use of all department heads, submitting agencies and the city manager in determining priorities of projects, utilizing the following: 
A.  Will the project contribute to protection of life and property and to conservation of community resources? 
B.  What is the relationship of the project to the welfare and progress of the entire community? 
C.  How will the residents be affected by the project? How many will be benefitted or harmed if the project is (or is not) carried out? 
D.  Will the improvements replace existing facilities that are obsolete or is the item new? 
E.  Will the project add to the value of the area and increase the valuation of the city and private property? 
F.  Will the improvements reduce or increase current operating costs? 
G.  What social, aesthetic or environmental values will be enhanced by completion of the project? 
(Prior code § 222.24 (d)) 
4.12.030. - Capital improvement program-Submittal-Contents. 
A.  Not later than October 15th of each year, all city departments and agencies shall submit requests for capital improvement projects to the city manager. 
B.  Not later than February 1st of each year, the city manager shall prepare and submit to council a five-year capital improvement program, including a capital budget. The capital improvement program shall include: 
1.  A clear general summary of its contents; 
2.  A list of all capital improvements which are proposed to be undertaken during the five fiscal years next ensuing with appropriate supporting information as to the necessity for each improvement; 
3.  Cost estimates, method of financing and recommended time schedules for each improvement; 
4.  An estimate of the financial impact on the city for the support of the program; and 
5.  The estimated annual cost of operating and maintaining the facilities to be constructed or acquired. 
(Prior code § 222.24 (b), (c)) 
4.12.040. - Council action. 
    Council action on the capital improvement program shall proceed by certain steps as follows: 
A.  Council, by resolution, shall adopt the capital improvement program on or before the first regularly scheduled council meeting in March; the first year of the program to be incorporated into the city manager's proposed operating budget for the ensuing fiscal year. 
B.  Council, at least one week before the adoption of the capital improvement program, shall hold a public hearing thereon. 
C.  Not later than February 15th, the city manager shall publish, in a newspaper of general circulation, a general summary of the capital improvement program and a notice stating: 
1.  The time and place for the public hearing on the program; and 
2.  The location where copies of the program are available for inspection. 
(Prior code § 222.24 (e)) 
Chapter 4.14. - LAND AND BOARDING FEES 

4.14.010. - Assessment of fees. 
    As provided for in Section 45-2-35.1 of the Rhode Island General Laws, every cruise vessel landing at a dock in the city of Newport shall pay to the city a landing fee to two dollars per passenger, and any cruise vessel embarking from a dock shall pay a boarding fee of two dollars per passenger. 
    The term "cruise vessel" does not include ferries and water carriers of persons and/or property doing business as common carriers operating upon waters between termini within the state of Rhode Island. 
(Ord. 2004-31 § 1 (part), 2004) 
4.14.020. - Payment due date. 
    Landing and boarding fees shall be paid to the city no later than ninety (90) days after the date of the visit the cruise vessel took place. A penalty at a rate equal to that assessed by the city on tax delinquencies shall be imposed for any delinquency in the payment of the landing and boarding fees. 
(Ord. 2004-31 § 1 (part), 2004) 
Title 5. - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04. - BUSINESS LICENSING AND REGISTRATION GENERALLY 

5.04.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Business" means and includes every business which is not licensed or regulated by the state of Rhode Island or not otherwise licensed by or registered with the city of Newport, including but not limited to, wholesale, commercial, retail, professional service, or manufacturing, by sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation, or any other business entity conducting business from any site within the city. 
(Ord. 2000-7 § 1 (part), 2000: Ord. 6-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 847.01) 
5.04.020. - Registration of businesses. 
A.  Each business in the city is to be registered with the city clerk prior to conducting business in said city. Each registration shall contain the name of the firm or business, the name of the owner or operator of the firm or business, the type of business to be conducted, the original date of starting and beginning business, and the location of such business. 
B.  Upon the registration of a business, a certificate of registration shall be issued to the registrant. Every certificate of registration shall be renewed annually on or before the first of July. 
C.  The city clerk's office shall be notified within thirty (30) days of any change in name, ownership or location of a registered business, or if the business shall cease to operate. Copies of such notification, upon receipt by the city clerk's office, shall be forwarded to the tax assessor and the zoning officer. 
(Ord. 2000-7 § 1 (part), 2000; Ord. 6-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 847.02) 
5.04.030. - Registration fee. 
    There shall be a one-time initial application fee of ten dollars ($10.00). The registration fee, including annual renewals, shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. 6-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 847.03) 
5.04.040. - Payment of taxes-Condition of registration. 
A.  Each business, at the time of initial registration and upon all renewals of such registration, shall submit with its registration or renewal application a certificated executed by the collector of taxes that all debts or charges, as described in Section 4.04.130, have been paid and are current, with no outstanding balances. 
B.  Each business, at the time of initial registration which does not yet appear on the municipal tax roll shall, in addition to the business registration required as a condition of conducting business within the city, be liable for the payment of the business ratable tangible personal property tax from the date the business is started. Said tax may be prorated for the assessment year in which that business is started and conducted by filing an initial declaration with the assessor of taxes of the business ratable tangible property pursuant to Section 44-5-3 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
C.  The city clerk shall, within ten days of issuing the registration certificate, notify in writing the assessor of the issuance of the certificate of registration. 
D.  Not later than thirty (30) days after receipt by the assessor of such notice from the city clerk, or from a determination by the assessor that such business is occupying and using the location for the purpose of conducting business, the assessor shall determine the increment by which assessment for that business ratable personal property and an amount for the immediately preceding assessment date. He or she shall prorate such amount from the date of issuance of the registration certificate of the date on which that business first conducted the business, as the case may be, to the assessment date immediately following and shall add the increment as so prorated to the tax roll for the immediately preceding assessment date and shall within five days notify the record owner as appearing on the tax roll and the tax collector of such assessment. 
E.  Upon receipt of such notice from the assessor, the tax collector shall, if such notice is received after the normal billing date, within ten days thereafter mail or hand a bill to the business owner based upon amount prorated by the assessor. Such tax shall be due and payable and collectible as other municipal taxes and subject to the same liens and processes of collection; provided, such tax shall be due and payable in an initial or single installment due and payable not later than thirty (30) days after the date such bill is mailed or handed to the business owner, and in any remaining installments, as the same are due and payable, and the several installments of a tax so due and payable shall be equal. 
F.  Any person claiming to be aggrieved by the action of the assessor hereunder may appeal to the assessment board of review within sixty (60) days from notification of such assessment or to the superior court as provided. 
(Ord. 6-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 847.04) 
5.04.050. - Payment of fees and issuance of licenses and permits. 
    The fee for any license or permit granted pursuant to this title shall be paid within thirty (30) days of its granting, and such license or permit shall be issued within ninety (90) days to the applicant therefor. An applicant who or which does not pay for a license or permit, or who or which does not request the issuance of a license or permit, after all fees, taxes, liens, assessments or charges due thereon have been paid, shall be called before council to show cause why the license or permit should not be revoked or why the application therefor should not be canceled. 
(Prior code § 802.03) 
5.04.060. - Denial of license-Waiting period. 
    No person may apply for a license, permit or permission of any kind which the council or any agent of the city is empowered to grant for ninety (90) days after an application has been denied absent a substantial change in the application. 
(Ord. 65-89 § 1, 1989: prior code § 802.04) 
5.04.070. - Holiday selling. 
    No retail establishment or person conducting retail sales shall be open on a holiday, as defined in Section 5-23.1 of the Rhode Island General Laws, without first obtaining a holiday license from the city council. 
(Ord. 2005-21 § 1, 2005) 
5.04.080. - Itinerant vendors excluded. 
    The provisions of this chapter are not applicable to a business which has applied for and has been granted an itinerant vendor/transient trader license, or has been granted a special events or spectacular license in the city. 
(Ord. 6-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 847.05) 
Chapter 5.08. - ADVERTISING AND SOUND MACHINES 

5.08.010. - License required-Fee-Hours and streets of operations. 
A.  No person shall operate or use, or cause to be used, any vehicle commonly called an "advertising and sound machine" on any street of the city without first obtaining a license for that purpose from council. No such license shall be granted to a person who is not a resident of the city. 
B.  The fee for such a license shall be collected by the city clerk at the annual rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for each such license. All such licenses shall expire on May 1st of each year. The fee for any license issued for less than one year shall be at the rate of one dollar per day. 
C.  No such license shall authorize the operation or use of more than one such vehicle or machine, nor authorize the operation, use or parking of any such vehicle or machine between the hours of seven p.m. and nine a.m. of the following day, daily. The chief of police, at his discretion, may designate the street or streets on which such vehicle or machine may operate. 
(Prior code § 804.01) 
5.08.020. - Exemption for political rallies. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to bar an advertising and sound machine from broadcasting an outdoor rally of any political party held during a political campaign, subject to the control of the chief of police over the street or streets on which the vehicle may be used or operated. 
(Prior code § 804.02) 
Chapter 5.12. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE LICENSES 

5.12.010. - License required for sale of alcoholic beverages. 
    No person shall, at any time, sell on his/her premises or premises under his/her possession or his/her charge, any alcoholic beverage unless licensed thereto as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. 3-93 § 1, 1993: prior code § 806.01.1) 
5.12.020. - Applications for liquor licenses or transfers-Prerequisites to issuance. 
A.  The issuance of any liquor license or liquor license transfer is subject to the compliance by the applicant with all state and local building and fire prevention codes as well as the inspection and approval of the state department of health according to state law. Prior to the issuance of any license, a report must be presented to the board of license commissioners that the applicant is in compliance with all state and local building and fire prevention codes and has been inspected and approved by the state department of health. 
B.  The applicant or an official representative of the applicant must appear in person before the board of license commissioners when the application is considered. 
C.  With the filing of the application, the following must be provided: 
1.  A one hundred dollar ($100.00) filing and advertising fee; 
2.  Proof of compliance with Resolution 167-70; 
3.  If a corporation, a certified copy of the Articles of Incorporation thereof; 
4.  Certificates of good standing from the state and the city, where applicable; 
5.  A detailed site plan showing the premises, the interior and exterior and the parking areas; 
6.  A description and/or rendering of the architecture to be used; 
7.  A detailed description of the manner in which the license is to be used, including: 
a.  Whether or not there is to be entertainment, 
b.  The number of inside service bars, 
c.  Whether or not there is an outside service area, and 
d.  The number of outside service bars; 
8.  The proposed seating capacity; 
9.  The availability of parking; and 
10.  The estimated monetary investment involved. 
(Prior code § 806.02) 
5.12.030. - Transfers of alcoholic beverage licenses. 
    An applicant for a transfer of an alcoholic beverage license shall pay to the city clerk a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) prior to the presentation to the board of license commissioners of the application. The purpose of such fee is to defray the expense of advertising and other costs. 
(Prior code § 806.01) 
5.12.040. - Number of licenses permitted. 
    Pursuant to the authority of the General Laws of the state, the maximum number of liquor licenses in the city is determined to be as follows: 
Class BV 56 Class BT 11 Class BL 11 Class BH 3 Class C 1 Class D 16 Class K 1 Class T 1  
(Ord. 2007-29 § 1, 2007; Ord. 2003-51 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2003-34 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2003-3 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2001-35 § 1, 2001; Ord. 2000-1 § 1, 2000; Ord. 98-1 § 1, 1998; Ord. 97-43 § 1, 1997; Ord. 97-41 § 1, 1997; Ord. 9-97 § 1, 1997; Ord. 32-95 § 1, 1995) 
(Ord. No. 2009-20, § 1, 7-8-2009; Ord. No. 2009-25, 8-26-2009; Ord. No. 2009-31, § 1, 11-18-2009; Ord. No. 2010-15, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2012-008, § 1, 4-11-2012; Ord. No. 2012-015, § 1, 9-12-2012) 
5.12.050. - Hours of operation of liquor establishments. 
    The hours of operation for all establishments having Class B, C or D liquor licenses in the city shall be as prescribed by the General Laws of the state, except that within the city limits, no licensee shall serve alcoholic beverages after one a.m. 
(Prior code § 806.04) 
5.12.060. - Regulations of the board of license commissioners. 
A.  Intent. The intent of this section is to pursue the declared purpose of the Rhode Island Alcoholic Beverages Legislation, which purpose is the promotion of temperance and the reasonable control of traffic in alcoholic beverages. 
B.  Definitions. Words and phrases used in this section shall be given the same definitions and sense given to them in Section 3-1-1 of the General Laws, which is hereby adopted by reference. 
C.  Authority. This section is enacted pursuant to the authority contained in Sections 3-5-20 and 3-5-21 of the General Laws and pursuant to the provisions of Section 3-5-15 of the General Laws which provides that "the right, power, and jurisdiction to issue licenses shall be in the mayors and city councils of the several cities." 
D.  Notice-Amendments. 
1.  Notice. The board of license commissioners of the city, upon issuance of any liquor license under the authority contained in Title 3 of the General Laws, shall cause a true copy of this section to be delivered to the licensee at the time of its issuance. The city clerk shall cause the licensee, if an individual, to personally sign for and to acknowledge receipt of the license and the copy of this section. If the licensee is a corporation, the recipient of the liquor license and the copy of this section shall be acknowledged and receipted by an attorney-at-law acting on behalf of the corporation or by an officer in such corporation. If the licensee is a partnership, the license and copy shall be delivered only to a general or limited partner. The business manager of any establishment may also sign for the copy of this section with the approval of the licensee. 
2.  Amendments. Amendments to this section, as enacted by the board, shall be mailed to the licensees by regular mail, postage prepaid. Such changes shall be effective upon passage. 
E.  Class A License Rules. The following regulations shall apply to Class A license holders: 
1.  All existing state regulations shall be complied with. 
2.  Consumption of alcoholic beverages is not allowed on the premises of the license holder. 
3.  Consumption of alcoholic beverages is not allowed on the property or in the parking area of the license holder. 
4.  Any attempt to utilize false identification shall be immediately reported to the police. 
5.  Minors shall not be allowed to loiter in or around the premises. 
6.  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold after the legal closing hour. 
7.  At all times while the premises are occupied, police and other enforcement officials, while on duty, must be admitted and granted access to the entire licensed premises, including the parking lot and other areas surrounding the building. 
8.  No licensee or any agent, servant, employee or representative thereof shall in any way interfere with the official duties or activities of any such police or enforcement official. 
9.  No licensee or any agent, servant, employee or representative thereof shall harass, either verbally or physically, any police or other enforcement official while such police or other enforcement official is performing his or her official duties on or within the licensed premises or adjacent parking lot and other areas surrounding the building. 
10.  The licensee shall notify the city clerk within thirty (30) days of any change by the licensee of a trade name (d/b/a), whether such licensee is a corporation, partnership, or individual (sole proprietor). 
F.  Class B and C License Rules. The following regulations shall apply to Class B and C license holders: 
1.  A license must be posted in plain view and shown to any authorized person upon demand. 
2.  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served or dispensed after the legal closing hour. 
3.  No person shall be admitted to the premises after the legal closing hour. 
4.  All patrons shall leave the licensed premises within thirty (30) minutes after the legal closing hour. 
5.  Management and bona fide employees may remain on the premises for a period of not longer than one hour after the legal closing hour. Management and bona fide employees may not consume alcoholic beverages after patrons have left the premises. 
6.  Routine periodic services such as duct cleaning and carpet shampooing, the performance of which are outside these hour restrictions, shall require the permission of the police chief or his or her designee at least two days in advance of the services. Such request shall be submitted in writing. Any emergency services shall be permitted with the permission of the police division. However, a written explanation of the incident shall be submitted to the board within twenty-four (24) hours after the incident. 
7.  At all times while the premises are occupied, police and other enforcement officials, while on duty, shall be admitted and granted access to the entire licensed premises, including the parking lot and other areas surrounding the building. 
8.  No licensee or agent, servant, employee or representative thereof shall in any way interfere with the official duties or activities of any such police or other enforcement official. 
9.  No licensee or any agent, servant, employee or representative thereof shall harass, either verbally or physically, any police or other enforcement official while such police or other enforcement official is performing his or her official duties on or within the licensed premises or adjacent parking lot and other areas surrounding the building. 
10.  All fights, disturbances, violence or any other violation of law shall be reported to the police division immediately by management or employees. 
11.  No alcoholic beverage shall be permitted to be removed from the interior of a licensed establishment by any patron. 
12.  No container for alcoholic beverages offered by the licensee to its patrons shall be permitted to be removed from the interior of a licensed establishment by any patron, whether or not such container is purchased from the licensee. 
13.  No dancing shall be permitted unless an entertainment license is issued by council. 
14.  All licensees shall maintain efficient and affirmative supervision over the conduct of their patrons on the licensed premises, on the sidewalks contiguous to licensed premises, to include maintaining free and clear passage on public rights-of-way, on real property owned by the licensee on which the licensed premises are located, and in parking areas owned or leased by the licensee for use by patrons of the licensed premises. 
15.  All existing state regulations shall be complied with. 
16.  The licensee shall notify the city clerk within thirty (30) days of any change by the licensee of a trade name (d/b/a), whether such licensee is a corporation, partnership, or individual (sole proprietor). 
17.  At least fifty (50) percent of outdoor patios, ground floor decks, courtyards and the like, is to be covered by tables and chairs. The maximum occupancy load of the area covered by tables and chairs shall be at a rate of one person for each fifteen (15) square feet. The maximum occupancy load of the remaining available area shall be at a rate of one person for each five square feet. The occupancy load shall be determined by dividing the net floor area or space assigned for use by patrons, exclusive of service areas. Where all due regard for public safety has been taken into account and based upon the recommendation of the Newport public safety director, upon application of the licensee the city may enter into a specific agreement to exempt the licensee from the placement of tables and chairs otherwise mandated by this subsection. 
    Appeals of the limits set forth under this section shall be in writing and sent by certified mail to the city manager. Said appeal shall be reviewed and a response made in writing within fourteen (14) calendar days from the date of receipt of said appeal. Appeals of the decision of the city manager shall be made to the municipal court, as set forth under Chapter 2.48 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Newport, RI, entitled, Municipal Court. Said appeal to the municipal court shall be final. 
18.  All outdoor entertainment at real property located in a residential zoning district is limited to the restrictions the licensing body has placed on the entertainment license. 
    "Entertainment," for purposes of this section, includes any gathering at which music or entertainment is provided by live performances, or by pre-recorded means, or a show, or exhibition. 
19.  No license shall allow the use of its premises as part of an organized pub crawl, so-called. A pub crawl shall be defined as an organized event intended to promote the organized, commercial travel of significantly large groups of individuals between licensed premises for the primary purpose of consuming alcoholic beverages at more than one premises. Evidence of a pub crawl shall include, but not be limited by: 
a.  The existence of advertising, flyers, tickets or other printed or electronic material promoting or describing a planned pub crawl, 
b.  Organized, commercial transportation intended to move a total of fifty (50) or more individuals from one premises to another in an organized fashion, and 
c.  Evidence of compensation paid to an organizer by participants in a pub crawl. 
G.  Regulations of Rhode Island Liquor Control Administration. The contents of this subsection are the Rules and Regulations of the Rhode Island Liquor Control Administration, as established and authorized by the Liquor Control Administration, are adopted by the city, being particularly the Revised 1993 Rules and Regulations with certain deletions. Any portion of the foregoing subsections inconsistent with this subsection shall be controlled by the General Laws and this section, in that order. Any amendment to the provisions of this subsection by the liquor control administrator is adopted and incorporated by reference, except an amendment to the portions deleted herefrom. 
1.  Holders of licenses must notify the board within ten days of any of the following changes occurring in the business of the licensee: 
a.  If a partnership, any change in the partnership agreement, oral or written, whereby any interest in the business, financial or otherwise, is given to any person, firm or corporation not mentioned in the license application, shall be reported. 
b.  If a corporation having less than twenty-five (25) stockholders, any pledge, transfer or contract to pledge or transfer stock of the licensed corporation to a person, firm or corporation not mentioned in the application for a license, shall be reported. 
c.  All newly elected officers or directors must be reported to the board within thirty (30) days. 
d.  Any acquisition by any person of more than ten percent of any class of corporate stock must be reported within thirty (30) days. 
e.  Any transfer of fifty (50) percent or more of any class of corporate stock can be made only by written application to the board, subject to the procedures for a transfer of a license. 
    The substance of this rule is to be a condition of the license issued. 
2.  Regulations applicable to Class D licenses are as follows: 
a.  A Class D license authorized the sale of beverages to members of the licensed club or their guests, which beverages are to be consumed on the premises where sold and nowhere else. 
b.  The limited Class D license does not authorize the sale or possession of beverages consisting in whole or in part of alcohol produced by distillation. 
c.  No alcoholic beverage shall be sold or served by the holders of Class D licenses after one a.m. or before six a.m. and the possession of any alcoholic beverage by any member or guest of the club between the hours of one a.m. and six a.m. shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this regulation. 
3.  The area within two hundred (200) feet of a proposed licensed place referred to in Section 3-7-19 of the General Laws, as amended, means the area within a line two hundred (200) feet distant from every side of the proposed licensed place. 
4.  In the granting of tavern licenses, the acting licensing body: 
a.  Should ascertain that the taverns are, in fact, operating or about to be operated with reasonable sleeping accommodations, as well as kitchens properly equipped, and in use, or ready to be put in use. 
b.  Class B victualing licenses shall be issued and reissued and shall operate only under the following conditions: 
i.  The applicant is actually operating or is about to operate a restaurant business at the time the application is made. 
ii.  Subject to the provisions of paragraph G.9 of this section, the establishment of the applicant is open and regularly patronized daily at least from nine a.m. to seven p.m. However, a license may be granted to be issued when the above conditions are met. 
iii.  The menu shall be delivered for inspection, upon request of the chief of police or his or her designee, or the city clerk, at any time. 
5.  In advertising applications for, or transfers of, a license, notice shall be given once a week for two weeks on days other than Sunday or legal holidays and at least fourteen (14) days must elapse between the first publication and the date of the hearing on the application. 
6.  Each license granted by the board shall be held by the licensee subject to his or her conforming to the zoning code, the building code and other police laws of the city. 
7.  The law does not authorize the issuance of licenses to be paid for in installments. 
8.  All licensees holding Class A, B and C licenses shall preserve, as a part of their records, the consignor's bill or sales slips showing each purchase of alcoholic beverages made by the licensee. These records, on the forms of the consignors, shall be kept by the licensees upon their licensed premises for one year from the date of each bill of sale or sales slip, and shall at all times be available for inspection by representatives of the board. 
9.  No beverages shall be sold or served by the holder of any Class B (victuallers and taverns) or Class D (clubs) license after one a.m. or before twelve noon on any Sunday or on Christmas Day. After twelve noon on such days, beverages may be sold and served by such licensees only in accordance with Section 3-8-1 of the General Laws, as amended. 
a.  Holders of retailers' Class A beverages licenses shall not sell or serve any beverage or be open for business on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day or New Year's Day. 
b.  Holders of retailers' Class C beverage licenses shall not sell or serve any beverages or be open for business prior to twelve noon on Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day or New Year's Day, provided, however, that the board may authorize places operating under a Class C license to be open on New Year's Day. 
10.  No malt beverage shall be sold on draught from a tap, faucet or other draughting device unless there plainly appears on or attached to such device, in legible letters, the brand or trade name of the malt beverage so sold therefrom. 
H.  Sales or Service to Underaged Persons. No alcoholic beverage shall be sold or served to any underaged person by any license holder. 
I.  Litter. All licensees shall be responsible for maintaining licensed premises, contiguous sidewalks and adjacent parking lots used for licensed premises in a neat and orderly condition. 
J.  Noise. This subsection is derived from Chapter 8.12. Compliance with the provisions of this subsection shall not relieve any person from otherwise complying with such chapter in its entirety. 
1.  Findings-Intent. The board finds and declares that: 
a.  Excessive noise is a serious hazard to the public health and welfare and the quality of life in a close urban society. 
b.  A substantial body of science and technology exists by which excessive noise can be substantially abated without serious inconvenience to the public. 
c.  Certain of the noise producing equipment in this community is essential to the quality of life herein and should be allowed to continue at reasonable levels with moderate regulation. 
d.  Each person has a right to an environment reasonably free from noise which jeopardizes health or welfare or unnecessarily degrades the quality of life. 
e.  It is the declared policy of the city to promote an environment free from excessive noise, otherwise properly called noise pollution, which unnecessarily jeopardizes the health and welfare and degrades the quality of the lives of the residents of this community, without unduly prohibiting, limiting or otherwise regulating the function of certain noise producing equipment which is not amendable to such controls and yet is essential to the economy and qualify of life of the community. 
2.  Purpose. The purpose of this subsection is to establish standards for the control of noise pollution in the city by setting maximum permissible sound levels for various activities related to establishments holding Class A, B and C liquor licenses. 
3.  Measurement of Sound. 
a.  If the measurements are made with a sound level meter, it shall be an instrument in good operating condition, meeting the requirements of a Type I or Type II meter, as specified by A.N.S.I. Standard 1.4-1983, or the latest approved revision thereof. For purposes of this subsection, a sound level meter shall contain at least an A- and C-weighted scale and both fast and slow meter response capability. 
b.  If the measurements are made with other instruments, the procedure shall be carried out in such a manner that the overall accuracy shall be at least that called for in A.N.S.I. Standard 1.4-1983, or the latest approved revision thereof for Type II instruments. 
c.  When the location or distance prescribed in this subsection for measurement of sound is impractical or would provide misleading or inaccurate results, measurements may be taken at other locations or distances using appropriate correction factors specified in this subsection or in other rules promulgated by the noise control office of the city. 
d.  Procedures and tests required by this subsection and not specified herein shall be placed on file with the city clerk. 
4.  Definitions. The definitions of words and terms used in this subsection shall be the same as those set forth in Section 8.12.040 of these Codified Ordinances. 
5.  Noise Disturbance Prohibited. No person shall make, continue or cause to be made or continued, except as permitted, any noise or sound which constitutes a noise disturbance, as defined in Chapter 8.12. 
6.  Maximum Permissible Sound Levels by Receiving Land Use. 
a.  With the exception of sound levels elsewhere specifically authorized or allowed in this subsection or in Chapter 8.12, the following are the maximum permissible sound levels allowed at or within the real property boundary of a receiving land use:

b.  Notwithstanding any other provision of this subsection, any business with a liquor license which is cited for a noise disturbance is subject to the penalty for a violation in the general business district, as set forth in Table I. 
c.  For any source of sound which emits a pure tone, the maximum sound level limits set forth hereinabove shall be reduced by five dBA. 
d.  Exceptions to Table I are: 
i.  Emergency signaling devices, as provided in Section 8.12.090; 
ii.  Sound equipment and sound amplifying equipment, as provided in Section 8.12.120; 
iii.  Motorized vehicles, as provided in Section 8.12.130; 
iv.  Stationary nonemergency signaling devices, as provided in Section 8.12.150; and 
v.  Sound variances, as provided in Section 8.12.180. 
7.  Specific Activities Prohibited. 
a.  Sales by "Hawking" or "Barking." No person shall create a noise disturbance by offering for sale or selling anything by shouting or outcry across a real property boundary or in a noise sensitive area. 
b.  Vehicle or Motorboat Repairs or Testing. No person shall repair, rebuild, modify or test any motor vehicle, motorcycle, or motorboat in such a manner as to cause a noise disturbance across a real property boundary or within a noise sensitive area. 
c.  Powered Model Vehicles. No person shall operate or permit the operation of a powered model vehicle in a public or private space out of doors or within a noise sensitive area between the hours of ten p.m. and seven a.m. of the following day. 
8.  Musical Instruments and Similar Devices. No person shall operate, play or permit the operation or playing of any drum, musical instrument or similar device which produces sound in such a manner as to create a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary or outdoors within a noise sensitive area. 
9.  Sound Equipment and Sound Amplifying Equipment. Except for activities open to the public and for which a permit and a noise variance have been issued by the city, no person shall operate, play or permit the operation or playing of any radio, television, phonograph or other sound amplifying equipment so as to create a noise disturbance. 
K.  Show Cause Hearings. 
1.  Every license holder shall comply with all pertinent state regulations. 
2.  Every license holder shall comply with all pertinent local regulations. 
3.  Upon complaint to the board, such board may hold a show cause hearing to determine if a violation of the state or local rules has occurred. 
4.  The license holder shall be served with a notice of the day and time of any such hearing. 
5.  The license holder has the right to be present at any such hearing, to be represented by counsel if he or she so chooses, to cross-examine witnesses and to present sworn testimony on his or her own behalf. 
6.  After hearing, the board may, if it finds that a violation has occurred, take disciplinary action against the license holder, including, but not limited to, suspension and/or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. 2004-30 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2002-39 § 1, 2002; Ord. 98-52 § 1, 1998; Ord. 98-44 § 1, 1998; Ord. 98-39 § 1, 1998; Ord. 54-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 39-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 32-93 § 1, 1993; prior code § 806.05) 
(Ord. No. 2011-018, § 1, 8-10-2011) 
5.12.070. - Exemptions for charitable entities. 
A.  Council shall impose a license fee on all Class F and F-1 licenses, except that charitable entities shall be exempt. 
B.  "Charitable," as used in this section, includes relief of the poor and distressed or of the under-privileged; advancement of religion; advancement of education, science or culture; erection or maintenance of public buildings, monuments or works; lessening of the burdens of government; and promotion of social welfare by organizations designed to accomplish any of the purposes described in this section; or to lessen neighborhood tensions, to eliminate prejudice and discrimination, to defend human and civil rights secured by law or to combat community deterioration and juvenile delinquency. 
(Prior code § 806.06) 
5.12.080. - License renewal. 
    No Class B or Class C license shall be renewed if the applicant has ceased to operate its business for a period of ninety (90) days or more immediately prior to the date of the expiration of the license. 
(Ord. 17-94 § 1, 1994: prior code § 806.07) 
5.12.090. - Unlawful drinking and misrepresentation of age. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for: 
1.  Any person who has not reached his or her twenty-first (21st) birthday to enter any premises licensed for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages for the purpose of purchasing or having served or delivered to him or her alcoholic beverages; and 
2.  Any person who has not reached his or her twenty-first (21st) birthday to consume any alcoholic beverages on premises licensed for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages or to purchase, attempt to purchase, or have another purchase for him or her any alcoholic beverage; or 
3.  Any person to misrepresent or misstate his or her age, or the age of any other persons, or to misrepresent his or her age through the presentation of any document, including the following: 
a.  An armed services identification card, the identification card license or any other documentation used for identification purposes that may belong to any other person who is of the age of twenty-one (21) years or older; 
b.  A motor vehicle operator's license which bears the date of birth of the licensee, and which is issued by the state of Rhode Island or any other state; 
c.  A Rhode Island identification card as defined by Section 3-8.6, Rhode Island General Laws, for the purpose of inducing any licensee or any employee of any licensee, to sell, serve or delivery any alcoholic beverage to a minor. 
B.  Any person who violates this section shall be subject to a fine and/or imprisonment as follows: 
1.  First Offense. A minimum fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00), plus the cost of prosecution for such offense, and may be further punished by a suspension of his/her motor vehicle operator's license or driving privileges for a period of not more than three months; 
2.  Second Offense. A minimum fine of three hundred dollars ($300.00), plus the cost of prosecution for such offense, and may be further punished by a suspension of his/her motor vehicle operator's license or driving privileges for a period of not more than six months; 
3.  Third and Subsequent Offenses. The maximum fine allowable in Newport Municipal Court, plus the cost of prosecution for such offense, imprisonment of up to, but not more than thirty (30) days, and may be further punished by suspension of his/her motor vehicle operator's license or driving privileges for a period of not more than one year. 
(Ord. 9-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 4-93, § 1, 1993; Ord. 17-92 § 1, 1992; Ord. 25-89 § 1, 1989: prior code § 806.10) 
Chapter 5.16. - AMUSEMENT ARCADES 

5.16.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Arcade" means a game room subject to Rhode Island General Law § 5-2-10, "A Game Room"; a premises where the principal use is maintaining coin-operated machines for the general public. 
    "Coin-operated machine" means any machine used or operated by the public, generally as a game or amusement, that is activated upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token or plate, or other representative form of currency. 
(Prior code §§ 808.01, 808.02) 
5.16.020. - License application. 
A.  Any person desiring to erect, maintain, operate or conduct an amusement arcade shall make application therefor to council upon a form to be supplied by the city clerk for that purpose, which application shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the person seeking to erect, maintain, operate or conduct the amusement arcade; 
2.  The age of the individual applicant or applicants; 
3.  A statement of any prior arrest or conviction of the applicant or applicants, if any; and 
4.  A description of the size and location of the premises proposed for the amusement arcade, including the total number and type of machines applied for. 
B.  No license shall be issued to any applicant unless he or she is over eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Prior code § 808.04) 
5.16.030. - Investigation of applicant and premises. 
    The application for the license required by this chapter shall be made out in duplicate. One copy shall be referred to the chief of police and the other copy to the director of engineering and inspections, for the following purposes: 
A.  The chief of police shall investigate the proposed location of the arcade, determine whether or not the applicant is a person of good moral character and either approve or disapprove the application. The police chief shall submit to council, in writing, his or her approval or disapproval of the application and state his or her reasons therefor. 
B.  The director shall inspect all wiring in connection with the amusement devices, determine whether or not it complies with the National Electrical Code and either approve or disapprove the application. 
C.  No license shall be issued unless the application is approved by both the chief of police and the director prior to its submission to council for approval. 
(Prior code § 808.05) 
5.16.040. - License required-Transferability-Fees. 
A.  No person shall operate an arcade for public patronage without first obtaining a license therefor from the city. This license shall either be a coin-operated amusement device license, as defined in the General Laws, or an arcade license, as defined in this chapter. Title to an arcade license and/or a coin-operated amusement device license is not transferable. 
B.  The fee for an arcade license shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) per year and only two shall be issued in the city, subject to Section S5-2-11 of the General Laws. 
C.  The fee for a coin-operated amusement device license shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per machine per year. 
D.  Holders or arcade licenses shall also pay twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per machine for individual coin-operated amusement device licenses. 
(Ord. 14-90 § 1, 1990; prior code § 808.03) 
5.16.050. - License display. 
    Licenses provided for in this chapter shall be posted permanently and conspicuously at the premises wherein the arcade is to be operated and maintained. 
(Prior code § 808.09) 
5.16.060. - License transfers. 
    No licensee shall move his or her place of business to any other location in the city without first applying for permission to transfer the license from council. The approvals as provided for in Section 5.16.030 by the chief of police and the director of engineering and inspections shall be prerequisites to an application to council to transfer a license. 
(Prior code § 808.10) 
5.16.070. - License revocation. 
    Each license issued under this chapter shall be subject to the right of council to expressly reserve or revoke the same should the licensee directly or indirectly permit the operation of any amusement device contract to any of the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city or law of the state. Such license may be revoked by council after written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the section of these Codified Ordinances or the ordinance or statute the licensee is charged with violating, and shall state that a hearing is to be held. The licensee shall receive ten (10) days notice of such hearing and shall be given an opportunity to present evidence in his or her defense at such hearing. 
(Prior code § 808.11) 
5.16.080. - License expiration. 
    Licenses issued under this chapter shall expire on December 31st of each and every year. 
(Prior code § 808.12) 
5.16.090. - Hours of operation. 
    Coin-operated amusement devices located in an amusement arcade shall not be operated between the hours of twelve midnight and ten a.m. the following morning. 
(Prior code § 808.06) 
5.16.100. - Supervision required. 
    An amusement arcade, whenever operated or used, shall be supervised by a responsible person eighteen (18) years of age or older. Such person shall enforce this chapter and ensure that the premises are used and operated in an orderly manner. 
(Prior code § 808.07) 
5.16.110. - Capacity, occupancy and fire regulations. 
    No amusement arcade shall be maintained, operated or conducted unless the arcade is in compliance with all state and local capacity, occupancy and fire regulations. 
(Prior code § 808.08) 
Chapter 5.20. - BILLIARD HALLS AND POOLROOMS 

5.20.010. - License required-Fee. 
A.  No person shall keep a billiard table, bagatelle table, pool table, scippio table, or any table of a similar character, in any saloon, shop or place of business within the city, or own or keep any such table for public use or profit within the city, without first obtaining a license therefor from council, for which license an annual fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first table, and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional table, shall be paid. 
B.  An application for a new license under this section shall be advertised in a local newspaper at least once a week for two weeks before being considered by council. 
(Ord. 56-94 § 1 (part), 1994; prior code § 848.01) 
5.20.020. - Additional fee for Sunday operation. 
    For a license to be granted separately by council to use a table of a kind specified in Section 5.20.010 on the first day of the week, a further fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year for each table shall be paid. 
(Ord. 56-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 848.02) 
5.20.030. - Hours of operation on Sunday-Proximity to places of worship. 
    Billiard halls and poolrooms shall be permitted to be open on the first day of the week only between the hours of one p.m. and twelve midnight. No billiard hall or poolroom shall be operated on the first day of the week within two hundred (200) feet of a place of public worship used for such worship. 
(Prior code § 848.03) 
5.20.040. - Minors prohibited. 
    No minor under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be in, remain in, enter or visit any billiard hall or poolroom which is operated in the city as a business for profit. No person having charge or control of any such billiard hall or poolroom shall permit or suffer any such minor under eighteen (18) years to be in, remain in, enter or visit any such billiard hall or poolroom. 
(Prior code § 848.04) 
Chapter 5.24. - BINGO 

5.24.010. - License fee. 
    Pursuant to Section 11-19-37 of the General Laws, the license fee for holding a "bingo" or "beano" game shall be five dollars, which fee may, at the discretion of council, be waived where the game is directed and carried on by members of the kinds of organizations enumerated in Section 11-19-37 of the General Laws. 
(Prior code 810.01) 
Chapter 5.28. - CABLE TELEVISION SYSTEMS 

5.28.010. - Certificate and permission of council required-Compliance with other laws. 
    No person shall install, maintain or operate a cable television system within the city without first obtaining a valid certificate therefor from the administrator of the division of public utilities and permission from council, and without being in full compliance with all statutes, ordinances and regulations relating to the operation of such business. 
    As used in this chapter, "holder" means any person with a valid certificate and permission of council as set forth in this section. 
(Prior code § 1052.01) 
5.28.020. - Costs of relocating existing utility systems. 
    The holder shall pay all costs of relocating existing public or private utility systems, which relocations are necessitated by the installation of the cable system. 
(Prior code § 1052.02) 
5.28.030. - Coordination with existing utilities. 
    The holder shall provide all necessary coordination with utility companies prior to and during the period of construction. 
(Prior code § 1052.03) 
5.28.040. - Underground installations in certain areas. 
    The holder shall install cable systems underground in the Historic Hill Redevelopment area, the Goat Island Redevelopment area, the Long Wharf/Market Redevelopment area, and all areas of the city where existing utility systems are installed underground. 
(Prior code § 1052.04) 
5.28.050. - Liability of subcontractors and agents. 
    All requirements imposed upon holders shall apply in kind to subcontractors and agents of holders. 
(Prior code § 1052.05) 
5.28.060. - As-built drawings. 
    The holder shall provide the department of engineering and inspections with "as-built" drawings of cable facilities installed, at a suitable scale to show the character and nature of the facilities. 
(Prior code § 1052.06) 
5.28.070. - Notification of property owners. 
    The holder shall provide reasonable and timely notification to property owners as needed for installation of the cable systems in easement areas. 
(Prior code § 1052.07) 
5.28.080. - Traffic control. 
    The holder shall hire off-duty police division patrolmen for traffic control, in compliance with city excavating and obstruction procedures. 
(Prior code § 1052.08) 
5.28.090. - Excavations. 
    The holder shall comply with all provisions of Chapter 12.08 of these Codified Ordinances. 
(Prior code § 1052.09) 
5.28.100. - Construction requirements. 
    Prior to the commencement of construction, the holder shall submit to the department of engineering and inspections a planned location of sectors in the city to receive cable service and an approximate schedule of completion of each sector. For each such sector, the holder shall submit to the department a complete application for an excavation and obstruction permit, pursuant to Chapter 12.08 of these Codified Ordinances, which shall include the following items: 
A.  An excavation fee based on the linear footage of excavations needed for cable installation; 
B.  An obstruction fee needed for the temporary blockage of any city property; 
C.  A street-by-street plan prepared at a scale of one inch equals five hundred (500) feet, or larger, defining the location, type, size and nature (above ground or below ground) of cable installation, as well as any pertinent facilities proposed; 
D.  Structural computations demonstrating that the pole systems are adequate to handle the added load, where requested by the department of engineering and inspections; 
E.  Identification of locations where barricading and other traffic control devices will be needed and locations where uniformed trafficmen will be needed; 
F.  In the case of the use of a utility system not owned by the holder, a statement from that utility that capacity exists for all locations and that permission for use is granted; 
G.  A bond to the city for work in an amount determined by the city to be sufficient to ensure satisfactory completion of all excavation work on city property; and 
H.  A description of the intended method of trenching to be used for approval of the department of engineering and inspections. 
(Prior code § 1052.10) 
5.28.110. - Schedule of completion. 
    The holder shall submit a proposed time schedule of installation for each street or group of streets. No construction will proceed without the specific approval of the department of engineering and inspections for the construction dates desired. 
(Prior code § 1052.11) 
Chapter 5.32. - FLEA MARKETS AND YARD SALES 

5.32.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Flea markets" and "yard sales" mean and include all sales referred to as "flea markets," "yard sales," "garage sales," "attic sales" and any other similar casual sale of tangible person property which is advertised by any means whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of such sale. 
    "Goods" means and includes any goods, merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder. 
(Prior code § 818.01) 
5.32.020. - License required-Fee-Exception. 
A.  No person shall conduct a flea market or yard sale in the city without first filing an application with the city clerk for a license to do so. Such license shall be known as a flea market license and the fee for such license shall be ten dollars ($10.00). The city clerk may issue such license subject to the approval of the chief of police. 
B.  The first sale in every calendar year held by a resident of the city in a residential area, as defined in the zoning code, shall be subject to all the provisions of this chapter except that no license fee shall be required. 
(Prior code § 818.02) 
5.32.030. - Frequency of licensing-Display of license. 
A.  The license required by Section 5.32.020 shall be issued to any one person only twice within a twelve-month period and no such license shall be issued for more than one calendar day. 
B.  Each license issued under this chapter must be displayed on the premises upon which the yard sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the licensed sale. 
C.  A yard sale shall not be permitted and/or licensed at any one location, lot or parcel of land more than twice within a twelve-month period. 
(Prior code § 818.03) 
5.32.040. - Approval of chief of police required-Application information. 
    Each license issued under this chapter shall be issued only with the approval of the chief of police. The application for such license shall be made on a form provided by the city clerk and shall contain the following information: 
A.  The name of the person conducting the sale; 
B.  The name of the owner of the property on which the sale is to be conducted and the consent of the owner if the applicant is other than the owner; 
C.  The location at which the sale is to be conducted; 
D.  The date and nature of any past sale; 
E.  The relationship or connection the applicant may have had with any other person conducting such a sale and the date or dates of such sale; 
F.  Whether or not the applicant has been issued any other vendor's licensed by any local, state or federal agency; and 
G.  A sworn statement or affirmation by the person signing that the information therein given is full and true and known by him to be so. 
(Prior code § 818.04) 
5.32.050. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
A.  A person selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
B.  A person acting in accordance with his or her powers and duties as a public official; 
C.  A person selling or advertising for sale an item or items of personal property which are specifically named or described in the advertisement and which separate items do not exceed five in number; and 
D.  Any bona fide religious or charitable organization. 
(Prior code § 818.05) 
5.32.060. - Sale of new goods prohibited. 
    No person shall sell new goods at any sale licensed under this chapter, nor at any sale exempted by Section 5.32.050D. 
(Prior code § 818.06) 
5.32.070. - Termination of sales which create traffic or fire hazards. 
    The chief of police is authorized to terminate any sale the holding of which creates a traffic hazard. The fire chief is authorized to terminate any sale the holding of which creates a fire hazard. 
(Prior code § 818.07) 
5.32.080. - Permitted number of advertising signs-Removal of same. 
    Not more than five signs shall be used to advertise a sale licensed under this chapter, which signs shall be removed promptly upon termination of the sale. 
(Prior code § 818.08) 
Chapter 5.36. - FORTUNETELLERS 

5.36.010. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of palmistry, phrenology or fortunetelling, in any manner whatsoever, without first obtaining a license therefor from the city. 
(Prior code § 820.01) 
5.36.020. - License application-Application fee. 
    An application for a license required by Section 5.36.010 shall be in the form prescribed by this chapter. A fee of five dollars shall be paid to the city clerk at the time the application is filed. 
(Prior code § 820.02) 
5.36.030. - Contents of application.
