    Each applicant for a license under this chapter shall file with the city clerk a written application stating his or her full name and address, and former business, previous experience or qualifications as to palmistry, phrenology or fortunetelling in any manner whatsoever, together with the names and addresses of at least three citizens who own real estate in the city as references regarding such previous experience or qualifications and the character of such applicant. Such application shall be signed by the applicant and sworn to as to the truth thereof before any official authorized to administer an oath in the city. 
(Prior code § 820.03) 
5.36.040. - Investigation of character of applicant. 
    The city clerk shall forward the application to the police division which shall cause an investigation to be made as to the character and background of the applicant. The chief of police shall make a report, in writing, as to his findings, which report shall be referred to council with the application. 
(Prior code § 820.04) 
5.36.050. - Issuance of license-Qualifications of licensee. 
    Council, upon the receipt of the application and the recommendations of the chief of police, may grant such license if, in its opinion, the applicant is properly qualified to carry on such business. Each applicant shall be given an opportunity to be present when council considers the application and shall be given an opportunity to be heard on his or her application before council. No license shall be granted to a person who is not a citizen of the United States or who does not possess a good moral character. 
(Prior code § 820.05) 
5.36.060. - Bond required. 
    Each person whose application for a license has been approved under this chapter shall, before receiving such license from the city clerk's office to engage in such business, execute and file a surety bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to the city, conditioned to reimburse any person for all damages resulting from any act on the part of such licensee in the course of carrying on such business or for damages resulting to any person from any act on the part of such licensee contrary to the provisions of this chapter or any omission or his or her part to perform any duties prescribed by this chapter. Before such bond is accepted by the city clerk's office, the surety thereon shall first be approved by the city manager. 
(Prior code § 820.06) 
5.36.070. - License fee. 
A.  Each person to whom a license is granted shall pay to the city clerk's office therefor a license fee in the following amount: 
1.  Ten dollars ($10.00) per day; 
2.  Thirty dollars ($30.00) per week; 
3.  Fifty dollars ($50.00) per month; or 
4.  Two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year. 
B.  The annual fee herein provided for shall be assessed on a calendar year basis. On and after July 1st, the amount of such fee for an annual license shall be one-half the amount stipulated above for the remainder of the year. 
(Prior code § 820.07) 
5.36.080. - Authority conferred by license-Display. 
    Each license issued under this chapter shall allow only the person named therein to conduct the business and the license granted shall be displayed in plain view to the public patronizing such licensee. 
(Prior code § 820.08) 
5.36.090. - License revocation. 
    A license granted under this chapter shall be canceled and revoked by council upon the conviction of the holder thereof for any misdemeanor or felony by any court of competent jurisdiction or upon the conviction of such holder for a violation of any of the provisions of these Codified Ordinances or any other ordinance, rule or regulation of the city. 
(Prior code § 820.09) 
5.36.100. - False advertising prohibited. 
    No licensee under this chapter shall make any false or fraudulent representation by advertising or otherwise. A violation of this section shall be sufficient grounds for a revocation of the license. 
(Prior code § 820.10) 
5.36.110. - Exemptions. 
    No license shall be required of persons pretending to tell fortunes or practice palmistry, phrenology or any form of fortunetelling in a regularly licensed theater or as a part of any play, exhibition, fair or show presented or offered in aid of any benevolent, charitable or educational purpose. 
(Prior code § 820.11) 
Chapter 5.40. - HOTELS 

5.40.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Consideration" means the monetary charge for the use of space devoted to transient lodging accommodations. 
    "Hotels" for the purpose of this chapter means any transient guest facility and guest house offering one or more rooms for which the public may, for consideration, obtain transient lodging accommodations. The term "hotel" includes hotels, motels, guest houses with one or more rooms, tourist homes, tourist camps, lodging houses and inns, and shall exclude schools when used for non-profit education uses, hospitals, sanitariums, nursing homes and chronic-care centers. 
    "Occupancy" means a person, firm or corporation's use of space ordinarily used for transient lodging accommodations not to exceed thirty (30) days. Excluded from occupancy is use of space for which the occupant has a written lease for the space, which lease covers a rental period of twelve (12) months or more. 
    "Tax" means the hotel tax imposed by Section 44-18-36.1, Rhode Island General Laws. 
(Ord. 98-30 § 1 (part), 1998; Ord. 15-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
5.40.020. - Registration of hotels and guest houses. 
A.  Each transient guest facility and all guest houses in the city, as defined in Section 5.40.010, are to be registered with the city clerk on or before June 1st. Each registration shall contain the name and address of the hotel or guest house, the names and addresses of the owner and operator of the hotel or guest house, and the number of rooms utilized for transient lodging accommodations. The city shall be notified within thirty (30) days of any change in ownership. 
B.  Upon registration of a hotel or guest house, a certificate of registration shall be issued to the registrant. Every certificate of registration shall be renewed annually during the month of May. 
(Ord. 15-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
5.40.030. - Registration fee. 
    The annual registration fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per location. 
(Ord. 13-91 § 1 (part), 1991: prior code § 843.03) 
5.40.040. - Certificate of registration. 
    Certificates of registration issued hereunder shall be signed by the city clerk and shall identify the number of rooms and shall not be transferable, and shall be kept posted in plain view by the registrant in the lobby or entrance area of the place registered, and shall be exhibited on demand to a city official. 
(Ord. 13-91 § 1 (part), 1991: prior code § 843.04) 
5.40.050. - Certificates of payment of taxes. 
A.  Every hotel, at the time of initial registration and upon all renewals of such registration shall submit, with its registration or renewal application, a certificate executed by the collector of taxes that all debts or charges, as described in Section 4.04.140 of the City Code, and the tax imposed by Section 44-18-36.1, Rhode Island General Laws, have been paid and are current, with no outstanding balances. No certificate of registration shall be issued or renewed without said tax certificate. 
B.  Each hotel must make payment of the taxes imposed by Section 44-18-36.1, Rhode Island General Laws, on a monthly basis in order to remain current and in good standing for registration purposes. Failure to do so shall result in the revocation of the certificate of registration and an enforcement action, as described in Section 5.04.060. 
C.  Each guest house with one or more rooms, at the time of initial registration and upon all renewals of such registration shall submit, with its registration or renewal application, a certificate executed by the Collector of Taxes that all debts or charges, as described in Section 4.04.140 of the City Code, and the tax imposed by Section 44-18-18, Rhode Island General Laws, if applicable, having been paid and are current with no outstanding balances. No certificate of registration shall be issued or renewed without said tax certificate. 
(Ord. 98-30 § 1 (part), 1998; Ord. 15-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
Chapter 5.44. - ITINERANT VENDORS AND TRANSIENT TRADERS 

5.44.010. - Itinerant vendor/transient trader-Generally. 
    Itinerant vendor/transient traders, other than those defined in this chapter, shall be prohibited. No such itinerant vendor/transient trader shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter by reason of associating himself or herself temporarily with any local dealer, trader or auctioneer or by continuing such temporary or transient business in connection with, or as a part of, the business of, or in the name of, any local dealer, trader or auctioneer. 
(Ord. 5-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 846.16) 
5.44.020. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, "building" means a constructed edifice, with a foundation, designed to stand permanently, covered by a roof and completely enclosed by walls, and eligible for a certificate of occupancy. A temporary structure or building erected for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days pursuant to the building code shall not be considered a building for purposes of this section. All zoning requirements, as set forth in the Newport zoning code, must be complied with. 
    As used in this chapter, "itinerant vendor/transient trader" means and includes any person, either by himself or herself or by his or her agents, who engages in a temporary or transient business in the city, selling goods, wares, services and merchandise and, for the purpose of carrying on such business, hires, leases or occupies any permanent building for the exhibition or sale of such goods, wares, services and merchandise. 
    "Temporary or transient business" means a business which fails to file an initial declaration with the assessor, has a lease for a period of less than one year, and is not subject to tangible personal property taxes in the city. 
(Ord. 5-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 846.16.1) 
5.44.030. - Exemptions. 
A.  This chapter shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business or to bona fide sales of goods, wares, services and merchandise by sample and future delivery, or to sheriffs, constables or public officers of the state or city selling goods, wares and merchandise according to law, or to bona fide assignees for the benefit of creditors residing within the state, or to receivers appointed in the state, selling goods, wares and merchandise in the state. 
B.  The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any business licensed by the city as a special event. 
(Ord. 5-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 846.16.2) 
5.44.040. - License required-Application-Fee-Issuance. 
A.  Each itinerant vendor/transient trader shall, before engaging in business, procure from the city clerk an itinerant vendor's/transient trader's license and for this purpose shall file with the city clerk an application therefor under oath, disclosing the names and residences of the owners or parties in whose interest such business is to be conducted and setting forth the nature and the place of business intended to be engaged in by such applicant. 
B.  The itinerant vendor/transient trader shall, upon making said application in writing, indicate in the application the place and manner of conducting the sale, including an inventory of the goods, wares, services and merchandise to be sold at such sale together with the established retail price of such goods, wares, services and merchandise. 
C.  The itinerant vendor/transient trader shall pay to the city clerk a fee of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for such license. The itinerant vendor/ transient trader shall provide to the clerk proof of payment of all other license fees, if any, that are legally chargeable upon local sale. Such license, when issued, shall be signed by the city clerk, who shall affix the seal of the city. 
(Ord. 5-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 846.17) 
5.44.050. - Duration of license. 
    All transient trader licenses shall expire by limitation three months from the date thereof, and may, if so desired, be surrendered at any time prior thereto for cancellation. 
(Ord. 5-93 § 1 (part), 1993: prior code § 846.17.1) 
Chapter 5.46. - FARMERS' MARKET 

5.46.010. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of the city council to permit the operation of farmers' markets in the city for the benefit of local farmers. 
(Ord. 14-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
5.46.020. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Market manager" is the individual designated with full responsibility and authority to enforce all rules of the market. 
    "Producer" is a grower or producer or any person who is offering for sale articles for human consumption, such as fruits, vegetables, edible grains, nuts and berries, and apiary products which have been grown or prepared by the grower or producer, and homemade baked goods, jams, jellies, fruit and herbal vinegars, and sauces, and/or non-edible items, such as herbal wreaths, potpourri, cut flowers, beeswax candles and scented oils. Sale of any type of meat, fish, poultry, or beverages shall be subject to state department of health regulations. 
(Ord. 14-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
(Ord. No. 2011-017, § 1, 7-11-2011) 
5.46.040. - Permit required. 
    No person or organization shall conduct or operate a farmer's market without first obtaining a farmers' market permit from the city council. 
(Ord. 14-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
5.46.060. - Conditions. 
A.  Farmers' markets shall be permitted only in those locations where the sale of items primarily at retail is a permitted use, pursuant to the provision of the zoning ordinance of the city. 
B.  If a farmers' market permit is granted, the permit granted hereunder shall be only during daylight hours between May 1st and November 1st. When Sunday is a designated day for the farmers' market, the market manager shall obtain a Sunday selling license. 
C.  The names of producers and the location of land used for production shall be provided to the city prior to the opening date of the market and shall be updated on a regular basis. 
D.  The city council may place conditions on the issuance of a farmers' market permit, as required for the public's convenience, welfare, health and safety. 
(Ord. 14-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
5.46.080. - Application for permit. 
    Applications for permits issued under this chapter shall be made upon forms prepared and made available by the council and shall state: 
A.  The full name of the applicant; 
B.  A specific description of the location of the market; 
C.  The open and closing dates of the market and the hours of operation; 
D.  The number of stalls and/or participants; 
E.  A description of stall size, length of trucks, etc.; 
F.  Designation of a market manager; 
G.  A copy of the market rules. 
(Ord. 14-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
5.46.100. - Fee required. 
    There shall be an application fee of ten dollars ($10.00). The registration fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per season. 
(Ord. 14-96 § 1 (part), 1996) 
Chapter 5.48. - JUKE BOXES AND MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES 

5.48.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Juke box" means any music vending machine, contrivance or device which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate, disc or key into any slot, crevice or other opening, or by the payment of any price, operates or may be operated for the emission of songs, music or similar amusement. 
    "Mechanical amusement device" means any machine which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score. It includes such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, skill ball, mechanical grab machines, mechanical pool tables and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto under whatever name they may be described. 
(Prior code § 828.01) 
5.48.020. - License required. 
    No person shall have or keep in any store, shop, tavern, restaurant or any other place of business, or for public use or profit, within the city, any juke box or mechanical amusement device unless the owner thereof has obtained a license therefor from the city upon payment of a license fee as hereinafter provided. 
(Prior code § 828.02) 
5.48.030. - License application. 
A.  Application for the license required in Section 5.48.020 shall be made to council upon a form approved by council and supplied by the city clerk. 
B.  The application shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the applicant and his or her age, date and place of birth, when applicable; 
2.  Prior arrests and convictions of the applicant, if an individual, or any stockholders or officers, if the applicant is a corporation or an association, including the names and addresses of all officers; 
3.  The place where the machine or device is to be displayed or operated and the businesses conducted at that place; and 
4.  A description of the machine to be covered by the license, including its mechanical features and serial number. 
(Prior code § 828.03) 
5.48.040. - Age of licensee. 
    No license shall be issued to an individual unless he or she is over twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(Prior code § 828.04) 
5.48.050. - Referral of application. 
    The application for a license shall be made out in duplicate, one copy being referred to the chief of police and the other to the office of the chief of the division of building inspection. 
(Prior code § 828.05) 
5.48.060. - Investigation of application. 
    The chief of police shall investigate the machine or device sought to be licensed, the location wherein it is proposed to be operated, and the applicant, and shall report to council his findings. 
(Prior code § 828.06) 
5.48.070. - Electrical inspection required. 
    Cord and plug connected devices, used in accordance with their listing and labeling by an approved testing agency, need not be inspected. Permanently connected devices must be accompanied by an electrical permit and a wiring inspection. The applicant must indicate those machines that are not cord and plug connected or not listed and labeled. Further, the applicant is responsible for the daily inspection of the cord and plug. Upon notice of a faulty condition, the device shall be immediately placed out of service and removed from the premises for repair. 
(Prior code § 828.07) 
5.48.080. - Gambling devices. 
    Council shall not approve the issuance of a license for any machine or device which would constitute a "gambling device," as defined by Section 11-19-18 of the General Laws or any other section of the General Laws. 
(Prior code § 828.08) 
5.48.090. - License-Display. 
    A license granted under this chapter shall be displayed on each machine and each and every machine is required to be licensed. 
(Prior code § 828.09) 
5.48.100. - License fee-Expiration. 
A.  Each applicant, before being granted a license, shall pay an annual license fee as provided in Section 2.120.010 for the privilege of operating, or maintaining for operation, each juke box or mechanical amusement device. 
B.  Each license shall expire on December 31st next following the date of issue. 
(Prior code § 828.10) 
5.48.110. - License revocation. 
    Each license issued by the city is subject to revocation by council should the licensee, directly or indirectly, permit the operation of any juke box or mechanical amusement device contrary to any of the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance or the laws of the state. Such license may be revoked by council after written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the violations with which the licensee is charged. The licensee may ask for a hearing on such charges to be held not later than ten (10) days after notice has been received by the licensee. At such hearing, the licensee and his attorney may present and submit evidence and witnesses in his or her defense. 
(Prior code § 828.11) 
5.48.120. - Hours of operation-Use by minors. 
A.  No person shall permit the playing of juke boxes between the hours of two a.m. and eight a.m. or, at all other times, fail to modulate the volume of music so as not to cause a nuisance. 
B.  No person licensed under this chapter shall permit any pinball machine, the use of which has been permitted under the license granted to him, to be used by a minor under the age of sixteen (16) years. If such use is permitted, the person holding such license shall thereupon forfeit the same. 
(Prior code § 828.12) 
Chapter 5.52. - JUNK DEALERS 

5.52.010. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of purchasing, selling, bartering or dealing in junk or old metals, whether as keeper of a shop or storehouse for the reception of the same or as a gatherer of the same in a bag, wagon or cart or as a foundry man or other person receiving the same for the purpose of melting the same or of converting the same into castings, unless such person is duly licensed under the provisions of Section 5-21-1 of the General Laws. 
(Prior code § 830.01) 
5.52.020. - Exceptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply to the keepers of shops for the purchase, sale or barter of books, pamphlets, periodicals or household furniture. 
(Prior code § 830.02) 
Chapter 5.56. - PEDDLERS AND HAWKERS 

5.56.010. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall hawk, peddle, offer for sale or sell, on any public or private street, square, lane or alley within the city or upon any undeveloped property or upon any open area designed primarily for pedestrian passage, any goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or other articles or substances, either hand-carried or from any vehicle, cart or basket, without first obtaining a license therefore issued by the city pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the above provisions of Section 5.56.010(a) to the contrary, no person shall offer for sale any goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or other articles or substances for sale on the Cliff Walk, either hand-carried, from any vehicle, cart, basket, cooler or other display or carrying device. For the purposes of this section only, a sale shall not only include the transfer of such items for a price but the transfer of such items for a donation, tip or gratuity with the intent of such transfer being the transfer of such items for the payment of financial consideration. 
(Prior code § 846.01) 
(Ord. 2017-15, § 1, 6-28-2017) 
5.56.020. - License application and issuance-Approval of health department required for certain licenses-Application fee. 
    All hawkers and peddlers and all persons selling or offering for sale any goods, wares, merchandise or any other article or substance on any street or other public way within the city shall make application to council for a license. Such application shall be made even if such applicant holds a state peddler's license. Upon approval of such application by council, the city clerk shall issue a license to such person to sell the articles or substances herein mentioned upon any street or public way in the city except those enumerated in Section 5.56.080. However, no license to sell or to offer to sell shall be issued for the sale of any meats, fruits, poultry, fish, vegetables or food products of a perishable nature unless the issuance of the license has first been approved by the state department of health. The filing fee for such application shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Prior code § 846.02) 
5.56.030. - License fees-Vehicle certificates and employee badges-Display. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in Section 5.56.130, each person to whom a license is granted by council, before receiving the same, shall pay to the city clerk the following fees: 
1.  For the selling or offering for sale, as a hawker or peddler, of jewelry, watches, gold, silverware, other articles manufactured of German silver, or patent medicines, fifty dollars ($50.00) per year; 
2.  For the selling or offering for sale, as a hawker or peddler, of goods, wares, merchandise, articles or substances other than those enumerated in subsection A.1 of this section, fifteen dollars ($15.00) per year. 
B.  In addition to the fees enumerated in subsection A of this section, each car, vehicle or basket used in connection with a license to hawk or peddle shall have affixed in a conspicuous place upon it a certificate of registration issued by the city. The cost of such certificate shall be five dollars per cart, vehicle or basket and council shall determine, at the time of the issuance of the license, how many carts, vehicles or baskets may be used by the hawker or peddler. Also, each employee of the peddler operating a cart, vehicle or basket or peddling by hand, shall pay a fee of five dollars for the issuance of a badge to be prominently displayed upon his or her person, such badge to be issued by the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 846.03) 
5.56.040. - Exemptions from fee. 
    No license fee shall be charged to any person selling religious books and publications on behalf of bible or other religious or moral improvement societies, which items are sold for that purpose and not for any pecuniary profit, nor to any person who receives a license from the general treasurer of the state in accordance with the provisions of Title 5, Chapter 11, Section 1, of the General Laws. 
(Prior code § 846.04) 
5.56.050. - Authority of license-Transferability. 
    No license shall authorize any person other than the person named therein to act thereunder, and no license shall be transferable. 
(Prior code § 846.05) 
5.56.060. - Exhibition of license and certificate. 
    No person shall neglect or refuse, upon demand of any police officer or duly authorized officer of the state health department, to exhibit to him or her both the license to peddle and the certificate of registration for the cart, vehicle or basket. If a person so refuses or neglects to do so, he or she shall be deemed to be unlicensed and to be in violation of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 846.06) 
5.56.070. - Inspection of vehicles and food peddlers-Sale of beverages. 
    All peddlers, industrial caterers or itinerant tradesmen who sell food or beverages of any kind or any product for human consumption shall, before the license is issued, have their truck, wagon or other equipment inspected and approved by the state health department. No beverage of any kind shall be sold other than in a single service disposable-type container. 
(Prior code § 846.07) 
5.56.080. - Sales prohibited on certain streets. 
A.  No peddler, solicitor, canvasser, industrial caterer or itinerant tradesman of any kind shall sell or attempt to sell or take orders for the sale of food or merchandise of any kind on the following public highways of the city: 
1.  American's Cup Avenue, the entire length; 
2.  Bellevue Avenue, the entire length; 
3.  Castle Hill Avenue, the entire length; 
4.  Halidon Avenue, the entire length; 
5.  Harrison Avenue, from the intersection with Ridge Road to the intersection with Halidon Avenue; 
6.  Memorial Boulevard, the entire length; 
7.  Market Square, the entire length; 
8.  Ocean Avenue, the entire length; 
9.  Ridge Road, the entire length; 
10.  Spring Street, the entire length; 
11.  Thames Street, the entire length; 
12.  Wellington Avenue, the entire length; 
13.  West Pelham Street, the entire length; 
14.  That certain area bounded westerly by Bellevue Avenue, northerly by Narragansett Avenue, easterly by Cliff Walk and southerly by Ruggles Avenue. 
B.  The chief of police shall, from time to time, submit to council additional streets and public ways throughout the city which, in his opinion, because of excess traffic and congestion, are unsafe for the public welfare and safety for the selling or offering for sale of merchandise by peddlers or hawkers. 
C.  At no time shall a peddler or hawker impede the free flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. The chief of police is authorized to suspend the operation of peddlers or hawkers at any time and for such periods of time on streets and ways where conditions exist that require him, in his opinion, in the interest of public safety, to do so without a prior request to council. 
(Prior code § 846.08) 
5.56.090. - Sales prohibited during certain hours in certain areas. 
    No person shall peddle, solicit or canvass on any highway in the city, except between the hours of nine a.m. to eight p.m. in residential areas and between the hours of nine a.m. to twelve midnight in business areas, as such areas are shown on the zoning map of the city on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Prior code § 846.09) 
5.56.100. - Sales prohibited near establishments selling similar goods. 
    No peddler, solicitor, industrial caterer or itinerant tradesman of any kind shall sell or attempt to sell his or her products within two hundred fifty (250) feet of any business establishment in the city which sells the same products. 
(Prior code § 846.10) 
5.56.110. - Use of loudspeakers, etc.-Nuisances. 
A.  No peddler, solicitor, industrial caterer or canvasser of any kind shall attempt to sell or offer to sell his or her wares by means of a loudspeaker or other noise-making device intended to attract public attention, nor shall he or she create a nuisance situation as defined in Chapter 8.16. 
(Prior code § 846.11) 
5.56.120. - Categories of peddlers-Maximum number of licenses. 
A.  For the purpose of Sections 5.56.010 through 5.56.140, the city shall have three categories of peddlers: 
1.  Those persons selling or offering to sell perishable foodstuffs and soft drinks; 
2.  Those persons selling or offering for sale portraits or sketches made by their own hand or drawn of a customer while he or she waits, or selling or offering for sale other articles personally made by the peddler or hawker; and 
3.  Those persons selling or offering to sell other articles of general merchandise. 
B.  Such peddlers shall be allowed by council a maximum of five licenses in each of the above categories. 
(Prior code § 846.12) 
5.56.130. - Expiration of licenses-Fee. 
A.  Each license to peddle or hawk shall be for one day only. There shall be a daily fee of five dollars for each such license issued. 
B.  Nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the issuance of annual licenses to any person who continuously held an annual peddlers license for more than five years prior to the effective date of this section. 
(Prior code § 846.13) 
5.56.140. - Revocation or suspension of licenses. 
    A license issued under Sections 5.56.010 through 5.56.130 may be suspended or revoked for cause after notice and hearing before council. 
(Prior code § 846.15) 
Chapter 5.60. - PRIVATE DETECTIVES 

5.60.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Applicant" means any person who has applied for permission to engage in any act or activity which is regulated under the provisions of this chapter. 
    "License" means any license required by this chapter. 
    "License fee" means any moneys required by law to be paid for the issuance or renewal of any license required by the regulations. 
    "Private detective" means a person who is hired for the purpose of conducting investigations involving: 
A.  Inquiries into unsolved crimes; 
B.  Clandestine surveillance; 
C.  The search for missing persons; and 
D.  The search for lost or stolen property. 
    Words in the singular shall include the plural and the plural shall include the singular. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.020. - Exemptions. 
A.  Nothing in this chapter shall include the activities of any person employed by any federal or state agency or any city or town as an investigator. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to require a detective's license in order to interview parties and/or witnesses in legal matters. 
B.  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to require a detective's license of an agent, employee or assistant to a licensed detective whose duties are in connection with the regular and customary business of his or her contracting agency; or person engaged in earning his or her livelihood by genealogical work and the compilation of family history while so engaged; or an insurance investigator; or a credit reporting bureau or agency whose business is principally the furnishing of information as to business and financial standing and credit responsibility. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.030. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or be engaged as a private detective in the city without first making application for and obtaining a license therefore from the council as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.040. - Application for license. 
    Applications for licenses issued under this chapter shall be made upon blank forms prepared and made available by council and shall state: 
A.  The full name, age, residence, and present and previous occupations of the applicant; 
B.  Whether the person signing the application is a citizen of the United States; 
C.  A specific description of the location of the principal place of business of the applicant; 
D.  The number of years of experience the applicant has had as a private detective or in related fields; 
E.  The length of time the applicant has been a bona fide resident of the state immediately preceding the filing of the application; 
F.  The length of time the applicant has been a bona fide resident of the city immediately preceding the filing of the application; and 
G.  Such other information as the chief of police finds reasonably necessary to effectuate the general purpose of this chapter and to make a fair determination of whether the provisions of this chapter have been complied with. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.050. - Registration and license fee. 
A.  The registration and license fee for a private detective shall be one hundred fifty ($150.00) dollars annually. 
B.  No license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be assigned or transferred, either by operation of law or otherwise. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.060. - License qualifications. 
    In order to be eligible for a license, an applicant must: 
A.  Be a citizen of the United States or a resident alien; 
B.  Not have been convicted in any jurisdiction of a felony; 
C.  Not have had any previous private investigator license or registration revoked or application for such license or registration denied by the appropriate authority of any local licensing authority; 
D.  Not have been declared by any court of competent jurisdiction incompetent by reason of mental defect or disease unless said court has subsequently determined that his or her competency has been restored; 
E.  Not suffer from habitual drunkenness or from narcotics addiction or dependence; 
F.  Be of good moral character; 
G.  Have such experience as has been gained through: 
1.  At least five years experience as an investigator or as a police officer with a state, county or municipal police department or with an investigative agency of the United States of America or of any state, county or municipality; or 
2.  Has received a degree in criminal justice from an accredited college or university; or 
3.  Has been employed by a private detective as an investigator for at least five years; or 
4.  Has substantively equivalent training or experience. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.070. - Investigation and action on application. 
A.  Within sixty (60) days after receipt of an application as provided for in this chapter, the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his or her proposed operation. 
B.  After an examination of the application and such further inquiry and investigation as is deemed proper and necessary as to the good character, competency and integrity of the applicant and the persons named in the application, the local licensing authority shall, as soon as practicable, issue a license in a form prescribed by it to the applicant or notify the applicant of a denial of the license application. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.080. - Grounds for denial of application for license or renewal of license. 
    The council shall deny the application for or renewal of license if it finds that the applicant: 
A.  Has violated any provisions of this chapter or rules and regulations promulgated hereunder; or 
B.  Commits any act which would disqualify him under Section 5.56.110 or where such applicant has failed to meet the qualifications of this chapter; 
C.  Practices fraud, deceit or misrepresentation; 
D.  Makes a material misstatement in the application for or renewal of a license; or 
E.  Demonstrates incompetence or untrustworthiness in actions affecting the conduct of the business required to be licensed under this chapter. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.090. - Procedure for approval or denial of application-Hearings. 
    The council, in approving or denying an application for a license or renewal thereof shall: 
A.  Issue a license in the form as provided in this chapter if the application is approved; 
B.  Notify the applicant or licensee in writing if the application is denied and shall state the reasons for its action; 
C.  Allow applicant or licensee to request a hearing in writing within fifteen (15) days from the receipt of notice; 
D.  Set a date for hearing and notify the parties of the time and place thereof if a request for a hearing is timely received; 
E.  Hold all hearings in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 35 of Title 42 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.100. - Renewal of licenses. 
    Each license shall expire one year after its date of issuance. Subject to the power of the council to deny, revoke or suspend license, any license shall be renewable by the council for the next one year period upon proper application for renewal payment of license fees. An application for renewal of a license must be received by the council on a form provided by the city clerk not less than thirty (30) days prior to the expiration date of the license, and the city clerk shall promptly notify the licensee of the council's intent to refuse to renew the license. The licensee may, within fifteen (15) days after receipt of such notice of intent to refuse to renew a license, request a hearing on such refusal in the manner prescribed by this chapter. A licensee shall be permitted to continue to engage in business while its renewal application is pending. Upon renewal of any license, the council shall issue a renewal license. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.110. - Grounds for suspension and revocation of licenses. 
A.  A license may be suspended or revoked if the licensee: 
1.  Violates any provisions of this chapter or rules and regulations promulgated hereunder; 
2.  Practices fraud, deceit or misrepresentation; 
3.  Makes a material misstatement in the application for or renewal of the license; 
4.  Commits any act which would disqualify the qualifying agent. 
B.  After the licensee has exhausted the right of appeal or, if the licensee does not seek a hearing, the licensee shall immediately cease to operate the business for the time period provided in the order of suspension or permanently in the case of revocation and shall notify all of its clients of such revocation or suspension and shall maintain a copy of such notices in its business records. 
C.  Under the circumstances in which the council determines that the public health, welfare or safety may be jeopardized by the termination of a licensee's services, the council may, upon its own motion or upon application by the licensee or any party affected by such termination, extend the time for the termination of the licensee's operations, subject to such reasonable, necessary and proper conditions or restrictions as it deems appropriate. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.120. - Surrender of license. 
    Each license shall be surrendered to the council within seventy-two (72) hours after it has been revoked or after the licensee ceases to do business pursuant to an order of suspension. If, however, the council or a court of competent jurisdiction has pending before it any matter relating to the renewal, revocation, or transfer of a license, the licensee shall not be required to surrender the license until the matter has been adjudicated and all appeals have been exhausted provided that a stay has been obtained in accordance with the provisions of this chapter pertaining to judicial review. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.130. - Change in status of licensee. 
    The licensee shall notify the council in writing within five days of any material change in the information previously furnished or required to be furnished to the council or any occurrence which could reasonably be expected to affect the licensee's privilege to a license under this chapter. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994) 
5.60.140. - Uniform and equipment. 
A.  No individual licensed by, registered by, or subject to the provisions of this chapter, shall wear or display any insignia, patch, or pattern which shall indicate or tend to indicate that he is a law enforcement officer of the federal government, a state, or any political subdivision thereof, or which contains or includes the word "police" or the equivalent thereof, or is similar in wording to any law enforcement agency in this state. All badges, shields and any other devices shall not indicate or tend to indicate that it represents that of any law enforcement officer of the federal government, a state or any other political subdivision thereof. All such wording shall be approved by the local licensing authority. 
B.  No person, while performing any activities licensed by this chapter, shall have or utilize any vehicle or equipment displaying the words "police," "law enforcement officer," or the equivalent thereof or have any sign, shield, marking, accessory or insignia that may indicate that such vehicle is a vehicle of a public law enforcement agency. All such wording must indicate private detective or private investigating agency and be approved by the council or the chief of police acting as their designee. 
C.  No licensee shall, by the use of any letterhead, advertisement, or other printed matter, or in any manner whatsoever, represent that he is an instrumentality or agency of the federal government or of the state of Rhode Island or political subdivision thereof. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 849.14) 
5.60.150. - Bonding requirements. 
    Any licensee or private detective shall deliver to the council or its designee a bond with a surety company authorized to do business in the state of Rhode Island conditioned for the benefit of any person injured by wilful, malicious or wrongful act of the licensee which in the case of an individual shall be five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 849.15) 
5.60.160. - Prohibited activities. 
    It is unlawful for any person to knowingly commit any of the following: 
A.  Provide any service required to be licensed under this chapter without possessing a valid license; 
B.  Employ any individual to perform the duties of an unarmed employee or armed employee who has not first complied with all provisions of this chapter and the regulations in all respects; 
C.  Falsely represent that a person is the holder of a valid license; 
D.  Possess a license or identification card issued to another person. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 849.16) 
5.60.170. - Identification cards. 
    Every person licensed hereunder shall be given a permanent license number and shall be issued an identification card which shall be approximately two and one-half inches wide and three and one-half inches long and shall bear thereon the number assigned to the licensee, the full name, date of birth, residence address, brief description of the licensee, his fingerprints and photograph, and a space upon which the licensee shall write his usual signature with pen and ink, or a facsimile of such signature. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 849.17) 
5.60.180. - Licensee business procedures. 
    Any licensee shall, on notice from the council or their designee, discontinue any advertising or the use of any advertisement, seal, or card which, in the opinion of the council, may tend to mislead the public. Failure to comply with any such order of the council shall be cause for revocation of the license. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 849.18) 
5.60.190. - Promulgation of regulations by chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to enact and enforce reasonable rules and regulations for the operation of private detectives in the interest of the public safety, morals and welfare and to effectuate the general purpose of this chapter. 
(Ord. 57-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 849.19) 
Chapter 5.64. - PUBLIC CONVEYANCES 

5.64.010. - Vehicles for hire-License required-Display. 
    Each vehicle used for hire within the city for the conveyance of any merchandise, material or thing shall be licensed and shall have placed upon the outside and upon each side of the same the number of the licensee in plain legible figures of not less than one and one-half inches in size so that they may be distinctly seen. No person shall use any such vehicle without its being licensed as hereinafter provided, nor without having the number so placed as aforesaid. 
(Prior code § 850.02) 
5.64.020. - Issuance of licenses-Conditions-Records. 
    The director of public safety may, from time to time, at his discretion, grant licenses for vehicles specified in Section 5.64.010 to such persons as he thinks proper and upon such terms and conditions as he sees fit to prescribe. All such licenses so granted shall be numbered and a record thereof shall be kept by the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 850.03) 
5.64.030. - Expiration of licenses-Transferability. 
    All licenses required by Section 5.64.010 shall expire on the first Monday in June next after the date thereof and no such license shall be sold, assigned or transferred without the consent of the director of public safety endorsed thereon, which transfer shall be recorded by the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 850.04) 
5.64.040. - Fees. 
    The fee for the license required by Section 5.64.010 shall be as set forth in Section 2.120.010 and shall be paid to the division of police. 
(Prior code § 850.05) 
5.64.050. - Revocation of licenses. 
    The director of public safety shall have the power to revoke any license granted under this chapter for vehicles for hire. 
(Prior code § 850.06) 
5.64.060. - Responsibility of licensee. 
    The person in whose name a license is taken out for a vehicle for hire shall, for the purposes of this chapter, be considered the owner of the same and liable for the fines and penalties imposed for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, unless upon the sale of any such vehicle notice is given to the city clerk and the license is delivered up to such clerk. 
(Prior code § 850.07) 
5.64.070. - Soliciting baggage and merchandise. 
    No person, other than the owner or driver of a vehicle licensed under this chapter, shall solicit baggage or merchandise to be conveyed for hire within the city. 
(Prior code § 850.08) 
5.64.080. - Smoking on buses prohibited-Signs required. 
A.  No person shall smoke or have in his possession any lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe at any time on any bus within the city. 
B.  Each person operating a bus or jitney in the city shall post in a conspicuous place in such bus or jitney "no smoking" signs. 
(Prior code § 850.01) 
5.64.090. - Standing vehicles. 
    Standing buses, trains (passenger and/or freight), and other means of public conveyance shall not idle their engines for more than five minutes at any given time throughout the city. 
(Ord. 2008-38 § 1, 2008) 
Chapter 5.68. - PUBLIC ENTERTAINMENT 

5.68.010. - Intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety and general welfare through the regulation of public entertainment. As used in this chapter, the term "public entertainment" shall mean any gathering at which music or entertainment is provided by live performances or prerecorded means or a show or exhibition which is held indoors or out of doors to which members of the public are invited or admitted for a charge, or free of charge, by any person or organization doing business in the city for sixty (60) or more days. 
(Ord. 13-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
5.68.020. - License required. 
A.  No person or organization shall conduct or operate indoor public entertainment without first obtaining a Class A public entertainment license from the city council. No person or organization shall conduct or operate outdoor entertainment without first obtaining a Class B public entertainment license from the city council. Only a person or organization holding a Class A public entertainment license may apply for a Class B public entertainment license. Whenever a Class A or Class B public entertainment license is granted by the city council, it shall be the duty of the police chief and fire chief to determine whether or not the assignment of a detail police officer or detail fire fighter is needed. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a new or an expanded Class A or Class B public entertainment license, an advertisement shall be placed in a local newspaper by the city clerk, at the applicant's expense, providing notice to the public of the two consecutive council meeting dates on which the application will be heard. Notice of the hearing dates shall also be mailed, at least two weeks prior to the date of the first hearing, by the applicant to the abutters within a two hundred (200) foot radius of the premises at which the new or expanded entertainment is to occur. Certification of such mailing and a list of the abutters is to be submitted to the city clerk prior to the council's consideration of the application. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a new or an expanded Class A or Class B public entertainment license, the city clerk shall also notify the police chief and fire chief, who shall make such determinations and notify the city clerk accordingly. 
    If the application is denied by the council at the first hearing, there shall be no second hearing; an affirmative vote of the council at the first hearing shall result in a second hearing at the next regularly scheduled council meeting. 
B.  If a Class A or Class B public entertainment license is granted to the holder of a victualing license or alcoholic-beverage license, the license granted hereunder shall not permit such entertainment to extend beyond the authorized serving time of such victualing or alcoholic-beverage license. Outside entertainment that involves amplification shall cease at eleven p.m., Sunday to Thursday, and at midnight on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays before holidays. 
C.  In all other instances where a Class A or Class B public entertainment license is issued, the hours of entertainment to be held shall be as determined by the city council, having due regard for the public convenience, welfare, health and safety. 
D.  The city council, pursuant to Title 5, Chapter 22, of the General Laws of Rhode Island, may place reasonable conditions on the issuance of a Class A or Class B public entertainment license having due regard for the public convenience, welfare and safety of its residents. 
    Any application for a public entertainment license shall identify the specific types and nature of entertainment intended, as well as specifically delineating and defining through an attached plan, the location of the proposed entertainment. The approval of a public entertainment license shall allow for those specific types of entertainment for which an application has been completed, and no other. 
    The council may specifically require the use of audio speakers with short throw symmetrical coverage unidirectional patterns and baffling to contain and mitigate the dispersion of amplified sound as a condition to the issuance or renewal of a Class B public entertainment license. 
E.  The city council may also authorize a Class C public entertainment license to any holder of a Class J convention hall license consistent with this chapter notwithstanding the lack of a Class A public entertainment license. The holder of a Class C license shall have the rights of the holder of a Class A public entertainment license and the holder of a Class B public entertainment license. 
F.  The city council may also authorize the issuance of a Class D public entertainment license to nonprofit community theater groups located in the city that have indoor performances at the same location on a regular basis. 
G.  Daily Class A and Class B entertainment licenses may be issued upon the authorization of the city manager if an application is submitted to the city clerk for an event that will occur prior to the next regularly-scheduled council meeting and the city manager is satisfied that all applicable sections of this chapter have been met. A non-refundable fifty dollar ($50.00) filing fee shall be imposed at such time as the application is filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. 2002-40 § 1, 2002; Ord. 2001-12 (part) 2001; Ord. 97-42 § 1, 1997; Ord. 28-97 § 1 (part), 1997; Ord. 13-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
(Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.68.030. - License application fee. 
A.  The fee for an annual Class A public entertainment license shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) yearly. 
B.  A Class A public entertainment license may be issued on a daily basis at a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day. 
C.  In conjunction with a Class A public entertainment license issued under this section, public entertainment may also be authorized to occur outside a building or a permanently enclosed structure, as long as such outside entertainment shall occur concurrently with and be contiguous and accessory to entertainment duly licensed and held within a building or permanently enclosed structure on the same premises and under the same ownership. Unless a Class B public entertainment license is specifically approved by the city council as part of a license application, outside accessory entertainment shall not be authorized. 
    All outdoor entertainment involving sound amplification shall occur under an enclosed tent/canopy. The requirement of a tent/canopy shall be to mitigate any amplified sounds being emitted. The square-foot area of any such tent/canopy shall not exceed the square-foot area of the Class A license to which it is accessory and contiguous. 
D.  An additional annual fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be paid, along with the base fee referenced in subsection A of this section for outside entertainment licensed on a yearly basis under a Class B public entertainment license. 
E.  An additional fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid, along with the base fee referenced in subsection B of this section, for a Class B public entertainment license issued on a daily basis. 
F.  All fees shall be payable in full when the license is issued. 
G.  The fee for an annual Class C public entertainment license shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) yearly. 
(Ord. 97-37 § 1, 1997; Ord. 28-97 § 1 (part), 1997; Ord. 13-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
5.68.040. - Annual license year. 
    The annual entertainment license year shall be from June 1st through May 31st. 
(Ord. 13-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
Chapter 5.70. - SPECIAL EVENTS 

5.70.010. - Intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety and general welfare through the regulation of special events. As used in this chapter the term "special event" means any outdoor gathering to which members of the public are invited or admitted for a charge or free of charge and for which neither a Class A nor a Class B public entertainment license has been issued, pursuant to Chapter 5.68. The term "special event" includes, but is not limited to, any live or prerecorded music, theatrical performance, dance, concert, carnival, circus, fireworks display, professional sporting event, show or exhibition, as well as an event which involves the sale of goods and/or services. Should a carnival, circus, professional sporting event, show or exhibition, as well as an event which involves the sale of goods and/or services, be held within a building or permanently enclosed structure, a special event license shall be required. 
(Ord. 12-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
(Ord. 2017-16, § 1, 7-12-2017) 
5.70.020. - License required. 
A.  No person or organization shall conduct or operate a special event without first obtaining a special event license from the city council. The property owner, as well as the event sponsor shall be the applicant and sign the license application. Whenever a license is granted by the city council, it shall be the duty of the police chief and fire chief to determine whether or not the assignment of a detail police officer or detail fire fighter is needed. Upon receipt of a special event license application, the city clerk shall notify the police chief and fire chief, who shall make such determination and notify the city clerk accordingly. 
B.  The city council may place any conditions or restrictions it deems proper and reasonable on the issuance of a special event license. This may include a limitation of the hours of operation or the conduct of the license activity. 
C.  Every licensee under this chapter shall provide the city clerk with the true name of the person or organization that will conduct the licensed activity, any alias or fictitious name under which the activity may be conducted. 
D.  For those events that include the sale of goods or services at retail, the licensee shall provide the city clerk a list of the general type and nature of the goods and services. 
E.  A special event license may be issued upon the authorization of the city manager if an application is submitted to the city clerk for an event that will occur prior to the next regularly-scheduled council meeting and the city manager is satisfied that all provisions of this chapter have been met. A non-refundable fifty dollar ($50.00) filing fee shall be imposed at such time as the application is filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. 12-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
(Ord. No. 2014-004, § 2, 2-26-2014; Ord. 2017-16, § 1, 7-12-2017) 
5.70.030. - Duty of licensee. 
    If the activity sought to be licensed under this chapter involves the engaging of independent vendors or contractors, it shall be the duty of the person or organization seeking a license under this chapter to inform each independent vendor or contractor of applicable state and local licensing requirements. 
(Ord. 12-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
5.70.040. - License application fee. 
A.  Applications for licenses issued under this chapter shall be on a form provided by the city clerk. Any such license approved by the city council may be valid for one day, or for any period of time not exceeding fourteen (14) days. 
B.  The license fee associated with any activity regulated under this chapter shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.120.010. For purposes of this chapter, a "vendor" shall be defined as a person or entity selling goods or services at retail. The city council may waive such vendor fees in the initial year of an event. 
C.  In the case of an event that is to include several activities in combination, each individual activity of which would necessitate the payment of a license fee under this chapter, the special event fee shall be the total of the individual fee amounts. 
D.  All fees shall be payable in full when the license is issued. 
(Ord. 12-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
5.70.050. - Inspection a prerequisite to license. 
A.  A license shall not be issued under the provisions of this chapter until the building or site to be used for the activity for which the license is desired, together with any apparatus used therein, has been inspected by the city building official, where required by law, and the city building official has filed with the city clerk a certificate in writing showing that the building, site, or apparatus meets in all respects the requirements of all applicable law and is otherwise safe to use for the purpose for which the license is desired. 
B.  A license shall not be issued until the building, site or apparatus has been inspected by the fire chief, or his or her designee, where required by law, who shall also file with the city clerk a certificate in writing showing that the building, site, or apparatus meets in all respects the requirements of laws set forth for the protection of life and property against the menace of fire. 
C.  The zoning officer of the city shall also confirm compliance with any applicable provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
D.  If the building, site or apparatus does not meet the requirements of applicable law, as determined in subsections A through C of this section, or is otherwise found to be unsafe, then no such license shall be issued, and if any license is so issued it shall be void. 
E.  Whenever a license is granted for a period of more than seven days, where required by law the city council shall cause the building, site or apparatus for which the license is issued to be inspected and reported upon at least once each week during the period covered by the license. The inspection fee shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 2.120.010. 
(Ord. 12-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
5.70.060. - Sunday sales permit. 
    If any activity licensed under this chapter is to be conducted on a Sunday, and if the activity involves the buying, selling or otherwise exchange of tangible personal property or goods, the licensee shall be required to obtain a Sunday sales permit, as required by state law and this chapter. 
(Ord. 12-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
5.70.070. - Disposal of solid waste and recyclable materials at special events. 
    Any person or organization being licensed to conduct or sponsor a special event shall: 
A.  Provide equal number of containers, side-by-side, to collect solid waste and recycling. 
B.  Capture and separate recyclable materials. 
C.  Take reasonable measures to ensure that all vendors, staff and attendees know where the recyclables and trash need to be placed (the use of signs is encouraged). 
D.  Ensure that each recycling receptacle is clearly identified and displays a list of the types of recyclable materials which may be deposited into the recycling receptacle. 
E.  Provide for collection and delivery of recyclable materials to a recycling facility, either directly or through a hauler. 
F.  Upon request, provide to the city a copy of the invoice or agreement with the hauler, and/or a facilities map identifying the receptacles and/or other information, which can serve as proof of recycling. 
G.  If possible, provide the city with the weight of recycled materials diverted from any landfill. 
H.  Any licensee who willfully violates any of the above requirements for the collection and disposal of recyclable materials at special events shall be subject to prosecution before the municipal court for the city and fined up to one hundred ($100.00) dollars for each violation. 
I.  Event holders who follow a carry in/carry out policy of disposable waste and recyclables at special events shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2015-22, § 1, 9-9-2015) 
Chapter 5.72. - RESTAURANTS 

5.72.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Victualer" means a restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, lunch cart, delicatessen, caterer, ice cream parlor, cafe, bar, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, and all other types of eating or drinking establishments. 
(Ord. 59-95 § 1, 1994) 
5.72.020. - Prerequisites to issuance of licenses-Applications. 
    The following regulations are established as prerequisites to the issuance of a victualing license by the city: 
A.  The issuance of a victualing license is subject to the compliance by the applicant with all state and local building and fire prevention codes as well as the inspection and approval of the state department of health according to state law. Prior to the issuance of any license, a report must be presented to council that the applicant meets all state and local building and fire prevention codes and has been inspected and approved by the state department of health. 
B.  The applicant or an official representative of the applicant must appear in person before council when the application is considered. 
C.  With the application presented to council, the following information must be provided: 
1.  A detailed site plan showing the premises, interior and exterior, and parking areas; 
2.  A description and/or rendering of the architecture to be used; 
3.  A detailed description of the manner in which such license is to be used; 
4.  The proposed seating capacity; 
5.  Parking availability; 
6.  Whether or not a liquor license for the same premises is being applied for by the applicant; 
7.  If a liquor license is not being applied for, whether or not a liquor license for the same premises will be applied for in the future by the applicant; and 
8.  The estimated monetary investment involved. 
(Prior code § 870.01) 
Chapter 5.76. - SECONDHAND DEALERS 

5.76.010. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of purchasing, selling or dealing in secondhand furniture, gold, silver, precious metals and stones, clothing or other articles, without first obtaining a license therefor from council. All such licenses shall be granted for one year and the fee therefor shall be as provided in Section 2.120.010. 
(Prior code § 858.01) 
5.76.020. - Licensed premises-Display of goods. 
A.  No dealer in secondhand articles shall carry on business at any other place than the one designated in the license therefor or continue to carry on business after such license is suspended, revoked or expired. 
B.  No dealer in secondhand articles shall display his goods publicly, but shall keep all such goods within the confines of the licensed building. 
(Prior code § 858.02) 
5.76.030. - Record of purchases. 
    Each dealer in secondhand articles shall keep a book in which shall be legibly written, in English, at the time of each purchase, a description of each article so purchased, the name and residence of the person from whom such purchase was made and the day and hour of such purchase. Such book shall, at all reasonable times, be open to the inspection of council and any member of the police division, or any person duly authorized, in writing, for such purpose by any of such authorities, who shall exhibit such written authority to such dealer. 
(Prior code § 858.03) 
5.76.040. - Purchases from minors. 
    No dealer in secondhand goods shall purchase any goods, article or thing from any minor, knowing or having reason to believe the seller to be such. 
(Prior code § 858.04) 
5.76.050. - Retention period for purchased goods. 
    No article or thing, except wooden furniture, stoves or kitchen utensils, purchased in the way of business, shall be sold or disposed of by any dealer in secondhand articles until the expiration of one month after such purchase, and no such dealer shall receive any article by way of pledge or pawn. 
(Prior code § 858.05) 
5.76.060. - License as pawnbroker or junk dealer prohibited. 
    No dealer in secondhand articles, while licensed as such, shall be licensed as a pawnbroker or junk dealer in the city. 
(Prior code § 858.06) 
Chapter 5.80. - SOLICITORS 

5.80.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Registered solicitor" means and includes any person who has obtained a valid certificate of registration as provided in this chapter, which certificate is in the possession of the solicitor or on his or her person while engaged in soliciting. 
    "Residence" means and includes every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    "Soliciting"means and includes any one or more of the following activities: 
A.  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind for any kind of consideration; 
B.  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any kind; 
C.  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other kind of publication; or 
D.  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project. 
(Prior code § 846.18) 
5.80.020. - Certificate of registration required. 
    Every person desiring to engage in soliciting from persons in residences within the city is required to make written application for a certificate of registration as provided in Section 5.80.030. Such certificate shall be carried by the solicitor. 
(Prior code § 846.19) 
5.80.030. - Application for certificate. 
A.  Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the city. The applicant shall truthfully state, in full, the information requested on the application, as follows: 
1.  The name and address of the present place of residence, the period of residence at such address, and the business address if other than the present address; 
2.  The address of the place of residence during the past three years if other than the present address; 
3.  The age of the applicant; 
4.  A passport size photograph taken within six months of the date of the application; 
5.  The name and address of the person whom or which the applicant is employed by or represents and the length of time of such employment or representation; 
6.  The name and address of the employer during the past three years if other than the present employer; 
7.  A description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage; 
8.  The period of time for which the certificate is applied; 
9.  The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for a certificate under this chapter, if any; 
10.  A statement as to whether or not a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under this chapter has ever been revoked; 
11.  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or the United States; 
12.  The names of the magazines, journals or books to be offered; 
13.  The names of the three most recent communities where the applicant has solicited house to house; 
14.  The proposed method of operation; 
15.  The signature of the applicant; and 
16.  The social security number of the applicant. 
B.  All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
C.  The city clerk shall cause to be kept in his or her office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with all other information and data pertaining thereto, including certificates of registration issued under this chapter and a record of the denial of applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every certificate issued and any renewal thereof shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. 
D.  No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or the United States within five years of the date of the application, nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, nor to any person whose certificate of registration issued under this chapter has previously been revoked as provided in Section 5.80.040. 
E.  All applications shall be acted upon by the city within ten (10) days. 
(Prior code § 846.20) 
5.80.040. - Revocation of certificate. 
A.  Any certificate of registration issued under this chapter shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or has made a false material statement in the application or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration under this chapter. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified United States mail addressed to his or her residence address set forth in the application. 
B.  Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of registration shall become null and void. 
C.  The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof. 
(Prior code § 846.21) 
5.80.050. - Notice regulating soliciting. 
    Every occupant of a residence who desires to secure the protection provided by the provisions of this chapter pertaining to soliciting shall give notice of his or her determination to invite or not to invite solicitors to his or her residence by exhibiting a weatherproof card, approximately three inches by four inches in size, upon or near the main entrance doors to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant and containing the applicable words as follows: 
    "Only Solicitors Registered in Newport Invited" 
    or 
    "No Solicitors Invited." 
The letters shall be at least one-third inch in height. For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the chief of police to persons requesting the same, at cost. Such cards, so exhibited, shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the information contained thereon. 
(Prior code § 846.22) 
5.80.060. - Duty of solicitors. 
A.  Every solicitor, upon going onto any premises in the city upon which a residence is located, shall first examine the notice provided for in Section 5.80.050, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on any notice. If the notice states "Only Solicitors Registered in Newport Invited," then a solicitor not possessing a valid certificate of registration, as provided in this chapter, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises, and if the notice states "No Solicitors Invited," then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
B.  Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(Prior code § 846.23) 
5.80.070. - Uninvited soliciting prohibited. 
    No person shall go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with Section 5.80.050. A violation of this section is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Prior code § 846.24) 
5.80.080. - Time limit on soliciting. 
    No person, whether registered under this chapter or not, shall go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door or create any sound in any manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting prior to nine a.m. or after eight p.m. of any weekday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday. A violation of this section is declared to be a nuisance. 
(Prior code § 846.25) 
5.80.090. - Tag days. 
    No "tag day," so called, for street solicitation for a charitable or other purpose shall be held unless the organization conducting the same has obtained a written permit therefor from council. 
(Prior code § 846.29) 
Chapter 5.84. - TATTOO PARLORS 

5.84.010. - License required. 
    No person shall tattoo another, offer to tattoo another or operate or conduct a tattooing establishment of any kind within the city without first obtaining a license therefor from council. 
(Prior code § 864.01) 
5.84.020. - License application. 
    Applicants for a license under this chapter shall file a written sworn application, in duplicate, signed by the applicant with the city clerk, giving the following information: 
A.  The name, address (both legal and local address), age, date and place of birth of the applicant; 
B.  The names and addresses of all partners, if a partnership, and the names and addresses of all officers and stockholders, if a corporation; 
C.  A complete list of all prior arrests and all convictions, whether of felonies or misdemeanors, of the applicant and of all persons having any interest in the business of the applicant; and 
D.  The location where the applicant proposes to conduct the tattooing. 
(Ord. 2000-41 § 1 (part), 2000; prior code § 864.02) 
5.84.030. - Investigation of applicant and premises. 
    One copy of the application shall be referred to the chief of police and the other copy to the state health department. 
A.  The state health department shall inspect the proposed location to determine if there is a supply of cool running water, boiling water, alcohol and adequate means of sterilization of equipment and also to determine that all equipment and materials used are such as to protect the health and safety of persons tattooed. 
B.  No license shall be issued to any applicant unless the application is approved by both the chief of police and the state health department. 
(Ord. 2000-41 § 1 (part), 2000; Prior code § 864.03) 
5.84.040. - License fee-Expiration. 
    Each applicant, before being granted a license, shall pay an annual license fee as provided in Section 2.210.010. Each license shall expire one year from the date of issuance. 
(Prior code § 864.04) 
5.84.050. - Display of license. 
    The license provided for in this chapter shall be posted conspicuously at the location where the applicant conducts the tattooing. 
(Prior code § 864.05) 
5.84.060. - Transferability of licenses. 
    If the licensee moves his or her tattooing business to another location within the city, the license may be transferred to such new location upon application to council, giving the street and number of the new location. The new location shall first be approved by the state health department in the same manner as provided in Section 5.84.030. 
(Prior code § 864.06) 
5.84.070. - Revocation of licenses.
