    Each license issued under this chapter is subject to the right of council, which is expressly reserved, to revoke the same for any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for the license, for a conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, or of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or of failure to comply with any regulation or order issued by the state health department. The applicant shall, if he or she desires, have the right to a hearing upon such revocation, which hearing shall be held subject to such rules and regulations as may be set by council, provided that if the state health department orders a revocation for sanitary or health reasons, the applicant shall not be entitled to a hearing prior to revocation. 
(Prior code § 864.07) 
5.84.080. - Prohibited acts-Records-Hours of operation-Sanitary measures. 
    Notwithstanding the holding of a license, the following prohibitions and restrictions shall apply to all tattooing in the city: 
A.  No person under the influence of alcoholic beverages shall be tattooed. 
B.  No tattooing work shall be done on the hands, feet, face or private parts. 
C.  No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall be tattooed and the licensee shall require proof of age in all instances. 
D.  A record shall be kept of all persons tattooed, giving the design applied, the name and address of such person, if a civilian, and the name, serial number and ship or station of all service personnel. This record shall at all times be available for inspection by proper police and service personnel. 
E.  No tattooing establishment shall remain open later than one a.m. 
F.  No person shall be tattooed more often than once in any one week, nor in any case until any prior work has completed healed. 
G.  New needles shall be installed daily and machine tubes shall be placed in boiling water before use. Color dyes shall be kept in white glass jars with plastic tops and kept clean. All tubes shall have stainless steel points. 
(Prior code § 864.08) 
5.84.090. - Compliance with statute. 
    Any applicant for a tattoo license shall be required to comply with the provisions of Section 23-1-39 of the Rhode Island General Laws entitled "Tattooing," as the same may be amended, and any rules and regulations established by the Department of Health pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. 29-95 § 1, 1995) 
Chapter 5.88. - TAXICABS 

5.88.010. - Definitions. 
    The term "hackney vehicle" means every motor vehicle used in the city for the conveyance of persons for hire within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 866.01) 
5.88.020. - Use of hackney vehicles-Vehicle license required-Minimum age. 
    No person shall use or operate a hackney vehicle within the city without first obtaining a license therefor. No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall be granted such a license. 
(Prior code § 866.02) 
5.88.030. - Same-Driver's license required. 
    No person shall, either on his or her own account, or for another, drive a hackney vehicle within the city without first obtaining a license to act as operator or driver thereof. 
(Prior code § 866.03) 
5.88.040. - State driver's license required. 
    No driver's license for hackney vehicles shall be issued to any person not properly licensed by the state. 
(Prior code § 866.04) 
5.88.050. - Vehicle license fee. 
    The fee for a vehicle license for each hackney vehicle shall be forty dollars ($40.00). 
(Prior code § 866.05) 
5.88.060. - Application for licenses. 
    The director of public safety may, from time to time, upon presentation of the application, at his discretion, grant licenses to operate or drive hackney vehicles to such persons as he thinks proper and upon such terms and conditions as prescribed in this chapter, subject to the provisions of Sections 39-14-1 through 39-14-24 of the General Laws. The application for each hackney vehicle license, in addition to stating the name and address of the applicant, shall contain a brief description of the vehicle and all other information required on the application. Applications to drive hackney vehicles shall be made on forms furnished at the police station and shall set forth under oath all required information. 
(Prior code § 866.06) 
5.88.070. - Issuance of licenses-Records. 
    The chief of police or his representatives shall issue all licenses under this chapter, subject to the approval of the director of public safety, upon payment of the license fees. The chief of police or his representatives shall keep a full and complete record of the name and place of residence of the owner of each such licensed vehicle, with the number and description of such vehicle, and the name and place of residence of each person licensed to drive or have charge of a hackney vehicle. 
(Prior code § 866.07) 
5.88.080. - Driver's license fee. 
    The license fee for each driver of a hackney vehicle shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. 38-89 § 1, 1989; prior code § 866.08) 
5.88.090. - Expiration of licenses. 
    All licenses under this chapter shall expire on the first Monday of June next after the date thereof. 
(Prior code § 866.09) 
5.88.100. - Revocation of licenses. 
    The director of public safety shall have the power to revoke and wholly annual and make void any license granted under this chapter, whether the license is for a hackney vehicle or to authorize a person to act as a driver of a hackney vehicle. A violation of any such licensed person of any penal statute of the state or of any rule or regulation issued by any agency of the state, under authority of any general or special laws of the state, or of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any other ordinance of the city, shall be deemed sufficient reason for the immediate revocation of the license of such person. Upon notification of such revocation, an appeal with the right to be heard may be made to council. 
(Prior code § 866.10) 
5.88.110. - Carrying and exhibiting identification information. 
    Each hackney vehicle shall display a distinguishing card and the license number thereof in such manner as may be prescribed by this chapter and by Sections 39-14-1 through 39-14-24 of the General Laws, as follows: 
A.  The name of the owner, the number of the license, a recent photo and the name of the driver, and the rates of fare, shall be placed on a card in all hackney vehicles in the most conspicuous place for the information of passengers. 
B.  The provisions herein contained relative to displaying such card shall not apply to a hackney vehicle exclusively rented for funerals or weddings or to a hackney vehicle the exclusive use of which is rented to one person for a consecutive period of at least one month. However, the owner of any such hackney vehicle shall satisfy the chief of police that such vehicle is to be used only as aforesaid and shall obtain his permission to use such vehicle without the display of the card. 
(Prior code § 866.11) 
5.88.120. - Soliciting passengers. 
    No person, other than the licensed owner or driver of a hackney vehicle, shall solicit passengers, baggage or merchandise to be conveyed for hire within the city. No owner or driver shall solicit patronage for a taxicab unless such taxicab is within a space designated as a taxicab stand. 
(Prior code § 866.12) 
5.88.130. - Refusal to serve prospective passengers. 
    No owner or driver having charge of any hackney vehicle shall neglect or refuse the application of any orderly person for conveyance in such vehicle if such vehicle is not occupied at the time of making such application and the legal fare is tendered if demanded. Each person so neglecting or refusing shall be liable to the forfeiture of his or her license in addition to the penalty provided in Section 1.12.010. 
(Prior code § 866.13) 
5.88.140. - Refusal to pay legal fares. 
    No person shall refuse to pay, for the use of any hackney vehicle, the lawful price or rate of fare as established. 
(Prior code § 866.14) 
5.88.150. - Responsibility of owners. 
    The person in whose name a license is granted to own or operate a hackney vehicle, for all purposes of this chapter, shall be considered the owner thereof. The owner shall be liable to all forfeitures, fines and penalties herein contained. The owner shall not be responsible for the wilful acts of employees. 
(Prior code § 866.15) 
5.88.160. - Obedience of taxicab operators to police directions. 
    In any street or square, or at any theater, opera house, hall, concert room, ballroom or similar place of entertainment, or at any church or lecture room, where taxicabs may come or attend for passengers, the chief of police, or any person authorized by him, may give directions respecting location, management, conduct, standing and disposal of such taxicabs while waiting for their passengers and the route they shall take in going or coming to or leaving such places of entertainment or other place. No owner, operator or other person having charge of any such taxicab shall neglect or refuse to obey any such direction. 
(Prior code § 850.09) 
Chapter 5.92. - TOW TRUCK COMPANIES 

5.92.010. - General regulations. 
    All persons who operate tow trucks in the city must be properly licensed by the state. If such persons conduct any towing business for any department of the city, they must comply with the following regulations: 
A.  All cars towed must be stored in an area that is located no farther than two miles from the city of Newport, and is fenced or otherwise enclosed so as to be inaccessible to the general public or is within a building. 
B.  Vehicles ordered towed by the police division for a violation of any of the provisions of the traffic code must be picked up in the presence of an officer, and the tow truck operator must give a receipt to the officer. Any visible damage to a vehicle should be noted on the receipt. 
    All tow companies must respond to a call within a reasonable period of time, as determined by the chief of police. 
C.  The operator of a motor vehicle found in violation of a parking law necessitating towing of such vehicle shall first be issued a violation citation, prior to towing, payable to the police division. 
D.  All persons towing cars at the city's request must be fully insured and accept complete responsibility for damage to a towed vehicle or to the contents thereof while it is in their possession. No towing company or employee thereof shall offer to pay any gratuity or thing of value to any city employee. 
E.  Cars shall be towed from private property where the city has no jurisdiction only at the request of the property owner; such private tows do not fall within the purview of this chapter except for violations of clearly marked fire lanes. 
    Tow companies shall notify the police division of all private tows so as to prevent unnecessary reports of stolen cars and so that the owner can be informed as to the location of his or her car. 
F.  No vehicle requested to be towed by the city shall be towed if the owner thereof appears before the vehicle is actually towed. Once a vehicle is hooked to a tow truck, the owner thereof may reclaim the same before it reaches the impounding area by paying a fair percentage of a complete tow job. The suggested percent is fifty (50) percent. 
G.  No licensed person shall be eligible for city business unless he or she is current in payment of all city taxes, and unless he or she or his or her authorized agent is in conformity with existing zoning ordinances with respect to his or her towing business within the city. 
H.  All tow companies performing services for the city must notify the police division, within sixty (60) minutes after the pick-up of a car, of the following: 
1.  The registration number, make, model and color of the car; 
2.  The location from where the vehicle was towed; and 
3.  The location where the vehicle is being held. 
I.  All tow companies shall have an employee on duty on a twenty-four (24) hour basis so as to be able to return towed vehicles to the owner. 
J.  All tow companies shall notify the police division once each week, on Monday, by providing the division with a written list of all vehicles on their property or in their custody that are there as a result of a private or city tow, whose owners they have not made contact with or who have not made contact with them. This list shall be made out on a form provided by the division. Tow companies shall also notify the division of plans they have to dispose of unclaimed vehicles under Sections 31-22-13 through 31-22-18 of the General Laws. 
K.  All tow companies performing towing services whose principal place of business is not located in the city shall provide transportation to the owner of any vehicle which has been towed, for a reasonable charge. 
L.  All tow companies performing towing services in the city must register with the division of police and shall file a copy of their approved list of charges, which list of charges shall be reviewed and approved by the division. 
(Ord. 2002-25 § 1, 2002; Prior code § 868.01) 
Chapter 5.96. - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES 

5.96.010. - Carriage licenses-Application-Insurance-Term. 
A.  It shall be unlawful to operate or permit another to operate a horse-drawn carriage for public hire on public roadways unless the owner shall have obtained a license from the Newport city council. 
B.  Application for a horse-drawn carriage license shall be made in writing, signed, sworn to by the applicant, or, if the applicant is a corporation, by its duly authorized agent, upon forms provided by the city clerk. 
C.  Proof of insurance must be submitted with any license application or license renewal. The city shall be held harmless and included as an added insured on said insurance. Coverage shall consist of liability insurance in the amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). 
D.  An annual horse-drawn carriage license shall be for the time period of May 1st through April 30th. The annual fee for a horse-drawn carriage license or its annual renewal shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) per carriage and initial horse. Additional horses shall be licensed at fifty dollars ($50.00) each. A license may be issued for a time period of less than one year at a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) daily. 
(Ord. 24-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 872.01) 
5.96.020. - Inspection and operating requirements. 
A.  Prior to the issuance of the license, including a renewal license, the applicant must certify by notarized affidavit that the carriage is in safe operating condition and meets all applicable regulatory standards that may apply. 
B.  Harnesses and all other equipment affecting a horse shall be properly fitted, kept clean and in good repair. 
C.  Each horse shall be examined by a veterinarian prior to the issuance of a license, including a renewal license. Said veterinarian shall certify the horse's fitness to perform carriage work. The horse's general physical condition shall be examined. This shall be demonstrated in the form of an affidavit on the part of the veterinarian. 
D.  Each carriage shall display its license, along with its passenger capacity and schedule of rates. 
(Ord. 24-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 872.02) 
5.96.030. - Care of carriage horses. 
A.  No horse shall be used to draw a carriage unless the animal is in good health, as specified in Section 5.96.020(C). The Newport animal control officer, or, in his absence, a Newport police officer, may at any time order the licensee to have any horse examined by a veterinarian to determine the horse's fitness for work if it should appear that the horse may be in any pain or distress, physical or behavioral. Upon such a determination on the part of the city animal control officer, the horse shall be removed from work and not returned to service until inspected by a licensed veterinarian who attests to the horse's fitness to return to work. 
B.  No horse younger than three years or older than twenty (20) years shall be licensed. 
C.  No horse shall be subject to any cruel or harassing treatment by the licensee, driver, employees of the licensee, or by any other person. 
D.  The licensee shall provide to the city the name, address, and telephone number of a veterinarian to be contacted in an emergency. 
E.  If stable facilities are utilized, conditions shall be such that the horse's health, safety and comfort are met. 
(Ord. 24-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 872.03) 
5.96.040. - Working conditions. 
A.  Horses shall never be left unattended by the driver. The driver shall maintain both hands on the reins when seated or in motion. 
B.  Horses used to pull carriages shall not be worked more than a total of six hours in a twenty-four (24) hour period, including hours worked pursuant to any private contacts or for any other purpose. 
C.  Horses shall be given one day of rest after every three consecutive days worked; and ten (10) minutes of rest between each fare. 
D.  Potable water shall be made freely available to horses during rest periods. Watering shall meet work and weather requirements. 
E.  Each carriage shall be equipped with a device to catch manure. A catcher shall not be affixed to nor hang from any part of the horse's body, and shall be emptied, at a minimum, after every second use. 
F.  Whips shall not be used. 
G.  Carriage horses shall not be worked at a speed faster than a slow trot. When traffic permits, they shall be walked. 
H.  Horses shall be driven on routes and during hours which minimize exposure to heavy traffic congestion as much as possible. Proposed routes and hours must be approved by the Newport police department. 
(Ord. 24-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 872.04) 
5.96.050. - Weather conditions. 
A.  Owners and drivers shall not allow a horse to be worked during adverse weather conditions, which shall include, but not be restricted to, snow or extreme cold, heat or humidity. 
B.  Horses shall not be worked in temperatures that exceed eighty-nine (89) degrees Fahrenheit, or a combined temperature and humidity equal to one hundred forty (140) degrees or above; or a temperature of thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit or below, or a combined temperature and wind chill factor of thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit or below. 
C.  Horses shall be curbed for work in areas protected from extremes of weather, as seasonally appropriate, including, but not limited to, shade during hot months, protection from high winds, and shall be blanketed during cold months. 
(Ord. 24-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 872.05) 
5.96.060. - Requirements for carriage drivers. 
A.  Drivers shall be a minimum of eighteen (18) years of age, or older. 
B.  Each driver must possess a valid automobile driver's license. 
C.  Each driver shall not have been convicted within the past five years of driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol or narcotics, nor have had his/her license suspended or revoked for any other reason. 
D.  No person who has ever been convicted of cruelty to animals shall be permitted to be employed by a carriage operator. 
(Ord. 24-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 872.06) 
Chapter 5.97. - PEDICAB[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, adopted February 26, 2014, amended Chapter 5.97 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Chapter 5.97, §§ 5.97.010-5.97.280, pertained to similar material, and derived from Ord. No. 2006-13, 2006; Ord. No. 2011-009, adopted May 25, 2011; Ord. No. 2011-010, adopted May 25, 2011; Ord. No. 2011-016, adopted June 22, 2011; Ord. No. 2011-019, adopted August 10, 2011 and Ord. No. 2012-010, adopted April 11, 2012. 

5.97.010. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to encourage the development of alternative public transportation that is environmentally friendly, such as pedicabs, and to provide uniform regulation thereof for the health, safety, and welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.020. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "'Applicant' means an individual or a business's authorized representative." 
    "Bicycle" means any device upon which a person may ride, which is propelled by human power through a system of belts, chains, or gears, and which has wheels at least twenty-two (22) inches in diameter and a frame size of at least twenty (20) inches. 
    "Darkness" means any time from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise and any time when visibility is not sufficient to render clearly discernible any person or vehicle on the highway at a distance of one thousand (1,000) feet. 
    "Decal" means the numbered decal issued by the city to a pedicab owner holding a pedicab business license for display on the pedicab to indicate that the pedicab is permitted to operate. 
    "Identification badge" means a badge issued to a pedicab operator that includes a color passport-size photo. 
    "Business license" means a written license issued by the city authorizing an individual, partnership, corporation, or limited liability corporation to operate a pedicab as a business. 
    "Operator" means any individual who operates a pedicab within the City of Newport. 
    "Owner" means any person who owns a pedicab. 
    "Pedicab" means a bicycle that has three wheels, that transports, or is capable of transporting passengers on seats attached to the bicycle that is operated by an individual, and that is used for transporting passengers for hire. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.030. - Pedicab business license requirement and duration. 
    It is unlawful for a pedicab to be operated within the city unless the owner has first obtained a pedicab business license issued by the city pursuant to this ordinance section. 
    A pedicab business license shall be valid for a two-year period, from May 1 through April 30, unless otherwise revoked for cause. 
    An application for a pedicab business license not made by January 31st shall be rejected. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.040. - Application for pedicab business license. 
A.  The owner of a pedicab business shall apply to the Newport city clerk's office for a pedicab business license. 
B.  The pedicab business license forms shall be prescribed by the city. 
C.  An applicant for a pedicab business license shall provide the following information to complete the application: 
1.  The full name and address of the applicant; 
2.  The name and address of each of the principal officers of a corporation, if the applicant is a corporation. If the applicant is not a corporation, the names and addresses of the partners, trustees, owners or other persons controlling the entity shall be given; 
3.  The number of decals needed for existing pedicabs only; 
4.  A description of the vehicle, including trade name, if any, serial number and body style; 
5.  A map of the city showing locations of proposed routes or methods of operation and showing locations of any proposed stations, places to keep vehicles, stands or pick-up points; 
6.  Proof of insurance in accordance with the provisions of this chapter in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; and 
7.  Such other material as the city may require. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.050. - Requirements for pedicab decal. 
    It is unlawful for any owner to lease, rent, or allow a pedicab to be operated for hire within the city without first having obtained a pedicab decal pursuant to this chapter. 
A.  Pedicab decals will be issued only when a pedicab meets all of the following requirements: 
1.  The pedicab shall be equipped with a battery-operated headlight capable of projecting a beam of white light for a distance of three hundred (300) feet. 
2.  The pedicab shall be equipped with battery-operated taillights mounted on the right and the left respectively, at the same level on the rear exterior of the passenger compartment. Taillights shall be plainly visible from all distances within five hundred (500) feet to the rear of the pedicab. 
B.  The pedicab decal shall be affixed to the rear of the pedicab and be clearly visible and unobstructed at all times. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.060. - Restriction on monopolies. 
    A maximum of eighteen (18) pedicab decals shall be issued per year and no pedicab business licensee (individual, corporation, partnership, etc.) shall be issued more than six pedicab decals for the term of the license. 
A.  No pedicab business licensee of a pedicab company, together with its subsidiary, parent or affiliated company (for purposes of this chapter, meaning any company that has interlocking directors or officers, or any of the same person or directors or officers or any person who owns five percent or more of the stock of the company) shall be the recipient of more than fifty (50) percent of the decals available for issuance. 
B.  Additional pedicab decals may be available after the license application deadline of January 31st. In that case, a written request addressed to the city clerk may be made requesting the issuance of additional pedicab decals for existing pedicabs, notwithstanding any limitation in this chapter. Additional decals may be issued by the city clerk with the approval of the police chief or his/her designee on a first come, first served basis. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.070. - Insurance requirements. 
A.  It is unlawful for any pedicab business licensee to allow the operation of a pedicab within the City of Newport, unless at the time of such operation the pedicab owner has in effect a valid policy of commercial general liability coverage with a pedicab endorsement on the vehicle. 
B.  The insurance policy required to be issued shall be executed and delivered by a company with a rating of "A" in Best's Key Rating, the financial responsibility of which company has been approved by the city. The terms of the policy shall provide that the insurance company assumes financial responsibility in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence for bodily injuries and personal injuries or property damage caused by the operation of the pedicab, including, but not limited to, pedicabs operated by the officers, employees, agents, or lessees of the pedicab owner. 
C.  A valid certificate of insurance issued by a company providing the required insurance policy shall be available for inspection at the owner's principal place of business. A certificate of insurance shall provide that the insurer will notify the city council of any cancellation of the owner's insurance policy and that the cancellation notice shall be in writing and such notice shall be sent by registered mail at least thirty (30) days before cancellation of the policy. The certificate shall include all of the following: 
1.  The full name of the insurer; 
2.  The name and address of the insured; 
3.  The insurance policy number; 
4.  The type and limits of coverage; 
5.  The specific vehicles insured; 
6.  The effective dates of the insurance policy; and 
7.  The certificate issue date. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.080. - Pedicab business license fee. 
    The city shall charge a nonrefundable fee to recover the cost of activities associated with the administration, regulation, and issuance of a pedicab business license. 
    The fee shall be based upon the number of decals issued to the pedicab business. The fee schedule shall be filed in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.090. - Pedicab business license renewal. 
    Pedicab business licenses are the property of the city and shall be renewable every two years upon filing and approval of a new application and payment of a pedicab business license fee as determined by the city council. 
    Pedicab business licensees filing applications for renewal of their licenses prior to January 1st shall be given preference over new applicants, subject to review and recommendation by the police department. 
    The approval of a pedicab business license is contingent upon compliance with all tenets of this chapter taking into account whether the licensee has complied with all the standards of operation contained in this chapter as well as giving due consideration to public health, safety and welfare. Pedicab business licenses may not be transferred, sold or assigned. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.100 - Pedicab operator permit. 
A.  Before operating a pedicab within the city, the operator must obtain a pedicab operator permit from the city clerk's office. 
B.  Pedicab operator permits are valid for a one-year period only, from May 1 thru April 30, unless otherwise revoked for cause. 
C.  The pedicab operator permit application shall be prescribed the city. 
D.  An applicant for a pedicab operator permit shall provide the following documentation to complete the application: 
1.  The full name and address of the applicant; 
2.  Proof that the applicant is eighteen (18) years or older; 
3.  A valid driver's license, issued in the United States; 
4.  Two recent color passport-sized photographs; 
5.  Results of recent background checks (local and state BCI criminal check and motor vehicle operator's check); 
6.  Such other information as the city may require. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.110. - Identification badges issued to pedicab operators. 
A.  The city shall issue an identification badge to an individual operating a pedicab on behalf of a pedicab business licensee. 
B.  While the pedicab is in operation, the pedicab operator shall wear the identification badge at all times, in a manner clearly visible to the public. 
C.  It is unlawful for a pedicab operator to fail to wear an identification badge in a manner clearly visible to the public, while operating a pedicab. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.120. - Regulations for pedicab operations. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, a pedicab during the hours of darkness, without using a headlight capable of projecting a beam of white light for a distance of three hundred (300) feet. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, a pedicab during the hours of darkness, without using battery-operated taillights mounted on the right and left respectively, at the same level on the rear exterior of the passenger compartment. Taillights shall be visible from all distances within five hundred (500) feet to the rear of the pedicab. 
C.  Pedicabs shall not operate between the hours of two a.m. and six a.m. 
D.  It is unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, a pedicab in an unsafe condition. 
E.  No driver shall stop or off-load passengers in any location which would disrupt the flow of traffic. 
F.  The operation will not appear to be designed to defraud any person. 
G.  There will be notices in each vehicle stating the charges and routes or methods of operation. 
H.  No drivers shall park in any restricted zones identified for other vehicles. 
I.  Pedicab operators shall not park at any time in the recessed parking area on America's Cup Avenue south of Long Wharf designated for bus parking. 
J.  Pedicab operators shall not park at any time in the turn area on the south side of Memorial Boulevard West at Thames Street. 
K.  Pedicab operators offering tours at the Humphrey J. Donnelly, III, Transportation and Visitors Center must register their vehicles in the visitors center and operate through the visitors center consolidated tour program. 
L.  Pedicabs shall be maintained in a business appearance acceptable to the public. This includes a clean interior and exterior appearance. 
M.  Nothing shall be transported in a pedicab that will cause the interior of such cab to become soiled or offensive to passengers because of odor or appearance. 
N.  Smoking by operator or passengers in a pedicab is prohibited. 
O.  All pedicab drivers must be dressed in a neat and professional manner. 
P.  It shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab in or upon any street in the city unless such operator has a valid U.S. driver's license and a pedicab operator permit. 
Q.  It shall be unlawful while the pedicab is in motion for the operator to collect fares, make change or embark or debark passengers. 
R.  It shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab upon a sidewalk. 
S.  It shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab wearing headphones. 
T.  It shall be unlawful to operate a pedicab more than one pedicab abreast, except when overtaking and passing another pedicab proceeding in the same direction. 
U.  It shall be unlawful for an operator to allow a passenger in the pedicab to drink or consume alcoholic beverages or to possess an open container of alcohol. 
V.  It shall be unlawful for an operator to drink or consume alcoholic beverages or to possess an open container of alcohol while operating the pedicab. 
W.  It shall be unlawful for an operator to refuse to provide a receipt in legible writing containing the name of the operator, the decal number, the total amount paid and the date of payment. 
X.  Pedicabs shall be operated in a manner as to be part of the normal traffic flow; provided, however, slower moving pedicabs shall safely pull temporarily to the side of streets and out of traffic flow so as to prevent unnecessary delays to following traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.130. - Passenger seating requirements. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a pedicab while carrying a number of passengers that exceeds the number of available seats, but in no case shall the number of passengers exceed three adult passengers. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.140. - Damage to public property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a pedicab in a manner that results in damage to public property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.150. - Fare schedule. 
A.  Pedicab operators shall post a fare schedule in a manner clearly visible to the public at all times while operating a pedicab. 
B.  Pedicab operators offering tours must have the fee schedule for such tours clearly visible to the public at all times. 
C.  It is unlawful for any pedicab operator to demand from a passenger a fare or tour fee greater than that contained in the posted schedule. 
D.  Subsection B does not apply to fares for special tours, provided that the fare for the special tour is agreed upon between the passenger and the pedicab operator prior to the beginning of the tour. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.160. - Denial of pedicab business license and/or pedicab operator permit for failure to comply with chapter. 
    The police chief, or his designee, shall deny issuance of a pedicab business license and/or pedicab operator permit if the applicant fails to comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.170. - Denial, suspension or revocation of business license and/or operator permit. 
    The police chief, or his designee, shall deny the issuance of a pedicab business license and/or pedicab operator permit if the applicant misrepresents facts relevant to the fitness of the applicant to be granted a pedicab business license or pedicab operator permit. If such misrepresentation becomes known after a pedicab business license or pedicab operator permit has been issued, the police chief, or his designee, may summarily suspend or revoke the pedicab business license or pedicab operator permit. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.180. - Other laws applicable to pedicab owners and operators. 
    Pedicab owners and operators are subject to all applicable laws, rules and regulations of the City of Newport and the State of Rhode Island Motor Vehicle Code pertaining to the operation of bicycles upon streets, except those provisions that by their very nature can have no application. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.190. - Suspension or revocation of pedicab business license and/or pedicab operator permit. 
    Pedicab operator permits may be suspended or revoked by the police chief, or his designee, at any time based upon any of the following grounds: 
A.  The pedicab business licensee or pedicab operator has failed to comply with the applicable provisions of this chapter, or the rules and regulations prescribed by the city council; 
B.  The pedicab operator has been convicted of assaults; battery; resisting arrest; any felony involving force and violence; any misdemeanor or felony reckless driving or driving under the influence offense; or any crime reasonably related to the qualifications, functions, or duties of the passenger transport business or the ability of the pedicab operator to safely transport passengers, unless five years has elapsed from the date of discharge from a penal institution, or the successful completion of probation for such conviction; 
C.  The applicant for a pedicab business license or pedicab operator permit has knowingly made a false statement of material fact, or knowingly failed to state a material fact in the application process for the pedicab business license and pedicab decal, or pedicab operator permit; 
D.  The pedicab operator's ability to drive lawfully in Rhode Island has expired or has been suspended or revoked; 
E.  When the police chief, or his designee, determines that a pedicab business licensee or pedicab operator has engaged in criminal activity or an activity that constitutes a threat to public health, safety or welfare, a pedicab business license/decal and/or pedicab operator permit may be summarily suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.200. - Enforcement authority. 
    The city manager or his designee is authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of the chapter. In the interest of public safety, the city manager, acting in the capacity of public safety director, or his designee, may at any time cancel, alter, or limit any and all pedicab licenses based upon a determination that the pedicab operation creates a public safety risk or hazard, and that the changes imposed serve to reduce such risk or hazard and generally serve the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
5.97.210. - Pedicabs prohibited from certain streets. 
    In the interest of public safety, and to prevent interference with the smooth flow of traffic, the city manager may prohibit the operation of pedicabs on certain streets, herein listed below: 
A.  Memorial Boulevard; 
B.  Memorial Boulevard West, between the hours of six a.m. and six p.m. (except to cross over when traveling on Spring Street or Bellevue Avenue); 
C.  Franklin Street. 
(Ord. No. 2014-007, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
Chapter 5.98. - SIDEWALK CAFES 

5.98.010. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, "sidewalk cafe" means any area situated on a public sidewalk where food, refreshments, and/or beverages are sold by a restaurant, delicatessen, ice cream shop or coffee shop (hereinafter "operating establishment") for public consumption at tables or counters located on the sidewalk fronting the operating establishment. Sidewalk cafes shall operate only as authorized pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 7-8-2015) 
5.98.020. - Permit required. 
A.  A person shall not construct, maintain, use or operate a sidewalk cafe without first obtaining a permit as provided in this chapter. 
B.  An application for a sidewalk cafe permit shall be made to the city clerk's office on forms provided by the city clerk. The city clerk shall transmit the applications to the city council for approval at the next council meeting. The application shall be made by the operating establishment. 
C.  A sidewalk cafe permit shall be for one year from May 1st in each year until the following April 30th. The holder of a permit shall pay an annual fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00). The annual fee shall be paid with the original permit application and with the request for renewal of permit. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 7-8-2015) 
5.98.030. - Standards. 
A.  Sidewalk cafes shall be permitted only in the general business, limited business and waterfront business districts and that portion of Broadway located in an R-10 district, which extends from Equality Park Place to the intersection of Broadway and Admiral Kalbfus Road. 
B.  No part of a sidewalk cafe area shall encroach upon any part of the sidewalk frontage of any adjacent premises, right-of-way or alley. 
C.  A sidewalk cafe must leave a minimum six-foot unobstructed passageway for pedestrians between the sidewalk cafe and the curb, along the length of the cafe. 
D.  The holder of a sidewalk cafe permit shall fully insure, indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city and in their capacity as such, the officers, agents, and employees thereof from and against any and all claims and damages in any way arising out of or through the acts or omissions of the permit holder or its employees in the construction, operation, maintenance, use, placement or condition of the sidewalk cafe. An applicant for a sidewalk cafe shall provide proof of such insurance before a permit may be issued or renewed under this chapter. 
E.  A sidewalk café shall close and all cafe seating shall be removed from the cafe area no later than eleven p.m. The cafe area shall be cleared of all furniture, obstructions and trash and swept clean of litter, cigarette butts and other debris no later than midnight. 
F.  An operating establishment shall not sell, serve or allow consumption of alcoholic beverages on its sidewalk cafe without receiving the required license from the board of license commissioners. Alcoholic beverages shall be served on the sidewalk cafe only in conjunction with the service of food. Notwithstanding any contrary or different hours of operations in its alcoholic beverages license, an operating establishment shall not sell, serve or allow consumption of alcoholic beverages on its sidewalk cafe after the sidewalk cafe's closing time. 
G.  The following are prohibited in the cafe area: cooking of food, unshielded trash or refuse storage, advertisements (exclusive of menus from the cafe intended to be read); outdoor entertainment, music, speakers or public address systems; and exclusively carry out transactions. 
H.  A sidewalk cafe shall comply with all applicable building, health, safety, fire, zoning, and environmental standards. 
(Ord. No. 2015-19, § 1, 7-8-2015) 
Title 6. - ANIMALS 
Chapter 6.04. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

6.04.010. - Title-Intent and purpose. 
A.  This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Newport Animal Control Ordinance." 
B.  It is the intent and purpose of council that this chapter, and any amendments and additions hereto, will protect animals from neglect, injury, abuse and inhumane treatment; assist in providing and ensuring proper care, treatment and shelter for animals and, when necessary, proper and humane destruction or disposal of the same; and, at the same time, protect the health, welfare and safety of the public generally. 
(Prior code § 612.01) 
6.04.020. - Definitions. 
    Words in this chapter shall be construed according to their common use and definitions and not as so-called "words of art" whenever possible and practical. Specifically, as used in this chapter: 
    "Animal" means any vertebrate member of the animal kingdom other than man. 
    "Animal control officer" or "control officer" means a person employed and so designed by the city for the enforcement of this chapter and related ordinances and, where appropriate, statutes of the state, and, generally, any member of the police division. 
    "Animal shelter" means any premises now or hereafter designated by the city for the impoundment, confinement, care and shelter of any animal in the enforcement of this chapter. Such term shall be construed as being synonymous with "pound." 
    "At large" means any animal when it is free in or on any public street, sidewalk, way, beach, park, grounds or building without or beyond the physical restraint or control of its owner. 
    "Bite" means the actual puncture or tearing of the skin inflicted by the teeth of any animal. 
    "Collared" refers to a dog that is wearing a collar around its neck. If such a dog is on or in a public street, sidewalk, way, beach, park, grounds or building, such collar shall bear a plate or tag whereon the name and address of its owner is displayed and, when appropriate, a license tag as prescribed herein. 
    "Director" means the director of public safety or his or her authorized delegate, designee or agent. 
    "In heat" means sexual excitement in a female animal and such periods of time when animals are particularly attractive to male animals of the same species. 
    "Leashed" means restrained by a cord, chain or similar device not in excess of eight feet in length attached to an animal's collar and held or led by a person capable of maintaining control of such an animal. 
    "Licensed" refers to a dog, or other animal when appropriate, required by licensed by any ordinance of the city or statute of the state, that has lawfully attached or affixed to its collar a tag or identifying device issued pursuant to law. 
    "Owner" means any person who owns, keeps, harbors, has custody and control of, or who otherwise physically possesses and controls, an animal. "Owner" does not include an animal control officer, police officer or director, keeper, manager or employee of a shelter or pound. 
    "Spayed female" means any female animal that has been surgically rendered incapable of conception. 
    "Vicious" means an animal that is dangerously aggressive, savage, ferocious or depraved in its attitudes toward other animals or to persons to the extent that it injures or is likely to injure or cause injury to such animals or persons, or an animal that has a propensity to want to attack or attempt to attack other animals or persons. An animal shall not be deemed vicious if it is provoked or if it bites, attacks or attempts to attack, any other animal or a person in self-defense or in defense of its owner or its owner's property. An animal shall not be deemed vicious merely by reason of growling or barking. 
(Prior code § 612.02) 
6.04.030. - Enforcement-Rules and regulations. 
A.  The director of public safety shall be responsible for the enforcement of this chapter. The director may designate the chief of police, members of the police division and the animal control officer and his agents to effectuate such enforcement and to issue citations, which may be paid by mail, to the owners of dogs for violations of any animal control ordinance. 
B.  Rules and regulations issued or approved by the director shall be promulgated from time to time to implement enforcement of this chapter. Copies of such rules and regulations shall be published and made available to the public at the police division and at the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 612.03) 
6.04.040. - Animal control officer. 
A.  Upon recommendation of the chief of police, the director of public safety shall designate one or more animal control officers who shall be charged with specific enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and any related ordinances or statutes, except as may be otherwise provided by law. 
B.  In the event of a vacancy in the office of the control officer, or his or her absence or unavailability, any member of the police division shall exercise his or her duties. 
C.  The control officer shall wear a uniform approved by the director and a numbered badge designed to identify him or her as such officer, which badge shall be the property of the city and which badge shall be surrendered by the officer upon his or her termination of employment or separation or suspension from office. 
(Prior code § 612.04) 
6.04.050. - Complaints and investigations. 
A.  A complaint of an alleged violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be made to the police division, to which the complainant shall furnish his or her name, address and telephone number, if any, and the details of the alleged offense. Every such complaint shall be verified by the animal control officer by confirming the alleged violation himself or herself or by one or more persons having separate residences or regularly employed in the neighborhood. 
B.  Upon receipt of such a complaint, if it appears that a violation of the law does probably exist, the control officer shall investigate the same and, when necessary, seize and impound any animal about which the complaint is made. Such seizure and impoundment may be made only in the event of an emergency such as when the animal presents a threat to itself, when it is injured and its owner fails or refuses to make provision for the confinement or treatment of such animal, or when such animal presents an immediate threat to public health, safety or welfare in any degree. In all other instances, if the complaint is found to be justified, the control officer shall take such appropriate action as is prescribed by this chapter. 
C.  The control officer shall forthwith submit to the chief of police a report of his or her investigation. If it is determined by the chief or by the director of public safety that prosecutive action for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or any related ordinance or statute is warranted as a result of such report, he or she shall direct that such action be initiated. 
D.  When a complaint is made in writing to the chief of police or the control officer by one or more persons who reside or are employed in an area frequented by an animal about which a complaint is made, which complaint is that such animal is vicious, exhibits a propensity for viciousness, is destructive of their property or the property of others, is regularly permitted to roam free upon public highways and sidewalks or upon their property, or creates a disturbance by regular prolonged and persistent barking or howling, then upon verification of such complaint by the control officer, the officer shall direct the owner of such animal to forthwith restrain, confine or, in cases of such barking or howling, muzzle such animal. If such owner refuses or neglects to comply with such direction, the control officer shall seize and impound the animal. 
E.  If a further complaint is made about such animal, the officer may issue to the owner a citation for a violation hereof, in a manner and sum as hereinafter provided in Sections 6.08.030(F) and 6.04.110, or, where deemed appropriate, may take prosecutive action against the owner. 
F.  Any person claiming to have been bitten by an animal must submit to the control officer or the chief of police satisfactory evidence that such person did in fact suffer a bite and that an identified animal did probably effect such bite. 
(Prior code § 612.05) 
6.04.060. - Reports of bites, poisonings and wounds. 
A.  Every person who treats any person for bite injuries, including bite injuries sustained by an owner, caused by any animal, shall report the same to the control officer, which report shall contain the name and address of the person treated and the circumstances under which the injuries were sustained. 
B.  Every person who treats any animal for poisoning or gunshot or arrow wounds shall similarly report the same to the control officer. 
(Prior code § 612.13) 
6.04.070. - Rabies. 
A.  Every licensed veterinarian shall report to the control officer any animal known or suspected by him or her to be rabid or to have been exposed to rabies in any manner. 
B.  All licensed physicians or practitioners of medical science, including nurses, shall report to the control officer any person treated by them for rabies or the prevention thereof, the name and address of the person so treated and the manner in which such person was exposed to such disease. 
C.  The owner of any dog over the age of six months shall have such dog vaccinated against rabies, which vaccination shall provide immunization against such disease for not less than twelve (12) months. Such vaccination shall be a prerequisite to the issuance of a license for such dog and such owner shall present proof of the same upon request by the city clerk, the control officer or any police officer of the city. 
D.  Any person who has custody or control of an animal that has bitten a person shall immediately notify the control officer if the animal shows signs of illness, unusual behavior or escapes the confinement required by Section 6.08.070A and B. If the animal dies while in such confinement, the person in possession thereof shall immediately notify the control officer of such fact, and, when required by law, shall immediately surrender the body of such animal to the state department of health. 
(Prior code § 612.14) 
6.04.080. - Animal shelter and control vehicles. 
A.  The city shall either establish an animal shelter for the impoundment and maintenance of animals seized or impounded under the provisions of this chapter or otherwise according to law, or avail itself of the use of a nonprofit animal shelter designated by it and authorized to operated as such shelter under law. 
B.  The shelter so established or designated shall be available for the use of the control officer at any time and shall be available to the public during regular hours established by the keeper or manager of the same. 
C.  No person shall break into or open any pound or shelter wherein animals are impounded or any vehicle used by the control officer for the impoundment, confinement or transportation of animals, and no person shall in any way unlawfully remove or release any animal from such pound, shelter or vehicle. 
(Prior code § 612.15) 
6.04.090. - Records-Control officer's duties. 
A.  The control officer shall daily compile in duplicate a list of animals seized and impounded, which list shall be kept at the police division and at the shelter and which list shall be available for public examination on request. 
B.  The control officer shall maintain for two years a record of all citations issued pursuant to this chapter during the period of July 1st through June 30th of any year, which record shall set forth in detail the descriptions of all animals which were subject to the citations, the reasons such citations were issued, the date of issuance thereof, the names and addresses of the persons cited and the disposition of all fees received in relation thereto. 
C.  The control officer shall also maintain a record for a like period of two years of all animals seized and impounded within such period of July 1st through June 30th, setting forth detailed descriptions of such animals, dates of seizure and impoundment and reasons therefor, dates and manner of disposal of such animals and disposition of all moneys received in relation thereto. 
D.  The shelter shall maintain a record similar to that hereinbefore described but including the dates of spaying or neutering of such animals. 
(Prior code § 612.16) 
6.04.100. - Dogs aiding handicapped persons-Interference with control officer. 
A.  Unless otherwise provided by law, no person owning, operating or maintaining any place of business to which the public is invited, or any means of public conveyance, shall exclude therefrom any dog trained to assist blind or handicapped persons when such dogs are actually being used for that purpose. 
B.  No person shall interfere with, hinder or obstruct the control officer in the performance of his or her duties or attempt to release any animal from his or her custody except as may be authorized in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 612.17) 
Chapter 6.08. - ANIMAL CONTROL REGULATIONS 

6.08.010. - Licensing-Dogs. 
A.  Every owner of a dog who resides within the city shall, annually, in the month of April, cause such dog to be licensed from the first day of the ensuing May in the office of the city clerk and shall pay the city clerk a fee, as provided for in Chapter 2.120, for each license issued. 
B.  Any person who becomes the owner or keeper of any dog after May 1st shall cause the same to be licensed as aforesaid within thirty (30) days after he or she becomes such owner or keeper. 
C.  Every person applying for a license for a dog, as provided herein, shall furnish picture identification to show proof of being eighteen (18) years of age or older and shall furnish the city clerk with the name and address of the owner thereof and the breed, sex, color and name of the dog to be licensed. The city clerk shall thereupon assign to such dog a registered number and tag, which tag shall be firmly affixed or attached to the dog's collar, for each dog so registered. He or she shall also issue a license for such dog bearing such registered number, the name and address of such owner, and the breed, sex, color and name of the dog licensed. Lost tags and/or licenses may be replaced upon payment of a fee in the amount of three dollars to the city clerk for the benefit of the city and the city clerk shall issue a new tag and license. 
D.  The city clerk shall, annually, in the month of March, give notice by publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city of the licensing requirements of this chapter. 
E.  No license shall be required for any dog under the age of six months. 
F.  Owners of dogs used for guiding and protecting blind persons or other handicapped persons shall be issued license without charge. 
G.  Every owner or keeper having control of a dog shall, upon demand and within twenty-four (24) hours, produce the license of the dog to the animal control officer or his/her authorized delegate, designee or agent. 
(Ord. 2003-43 § 1, 2003; Ord. 20-97 § 1, 1997; Ord. 13-97 § 1, 1997; Ord. 52-94 § 1, 1994; prior code § 612.06) 
6.08.020. - Exemption for thoroughbred dogs-Kennel licenses. 
A.  No license fee shall be imposed on any thoroughbred dog kept for breeding and stud purposes only, provided that such dogs are owned by a breeder or annual exhibitor of thoroughbred dogs and provided, further, that such dogs are kept in a breeding kennel duly licensed in accordance with this chapter and only allowed at large when in charge of the owner or keeper of such kennel. The use of the words "at large" herein shall not be construed to exempt such dogs or their owners or keepers from the requirements regarding restraint, confinement, collaring and control as otherwise required in this chapter. 
B.  Every owner or keeper of such dogs may apply to the city clerk for a kennel license. An application for such a license shall state the name and address of the owner and keeper of such kennel, the proposed location of the same, the number of dogs to be kept therein and that the same are to be kept for breeding and stud purposes only. Thereupon, if the city clerk and the director of public safety or the chief of police deem the such kennel and its use and operation at its proposed location will not constitute a public nuisance, the city clerk shall issue a kennel license authorizing the owner or keeper to keep such kennel in the definition location to be specified in such license upon payment to the city clerk, by the applicant, of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for such license, which sum shall be credited to the dog fund of the city. 
C.  No person shall establish or keep such a kennel without first obtaining a license therefor as provided for herein. 
D.  Nothing herein shall be construed to repeal or contravene any portion of the zoning code of the city or to establish an exception thereto. 
(Prior code § 612.07) 
6.08.030. - Collaring of dogs-Impoundment. 
A.  Every owner of a dog shall cause such dog to wear a collar around its neck distinctly marked with such owner's name and its registered number. Any person, upon complaint duly made, may cause any dog not so collared to be impounded in any designated, authorized or approved animal shelter maintained or utilized by the city. 
B.  If such a dog is not claimed by its owner within a period of five days after its impoundment, the same may be disposed of by sale by the control officer to any responsible person upon payment of all necessary fees and charges relative to its maintenance and care during its impoundment and proper licensing as herein provided for, or, if necessary, by humane destruction. The expense of keeping such dog shall be on a per diem basis as prescribed by law, and such sum shall be paid to the keeper of the shelter. Any animal disposed of by sale shall be spayed or neutered prior to delivery to the purchaser, the cost of such spaying or neutering to be borne by such purchaser. 
C.  Under no circumstances shall any living dog be released from the pound to any person to be used in animal experimentation or for purposes involving mutilation, disfigurement or vivisection. 
D.  Any dog or other animal found at large or not collared within the city shall be taken into possession by the control officer and impounded as hereinbefore prescribed and subject to the conditions hereinbefore set forth. 
E.  Notwithstanding anything hereinbefore set forth, prior to the expiration of five days, when it is determined by the control officer, the keeper of such shelter or a licensed veterinarian that any animal so impounded poses a safety threat to itself, to other animals or to persons because of health reasons or temperament, or is incurably ill or injured, such animal may be humanely destroyed. 
F.  When any dog or other animal is found at large, the ownership of which is known to the control officer, the animal need not be impounded but shall be returned to its owner. If it is determined by the control officer that such owner negligently or knowingly permitted the animal to be at large, the officer shall issue to such owner a citation for a violation of this chapter. 
G.  Immediately upon impoundment of an animal, the control officer shall make a reasonable effort to notify the owner thereof. The officer shall also compile and keep a current list of animals so impounded which shall be kept available for the public at the police division. The preparation and maintenance of such list shall be a minimum reasonable effort of the control officer to notify owners of animals so impounded. Such list shall set forth the kind of animal impounded, its estimated age, its size, breed, sex, color and distinctive markings, if any, the location where seized, and, if applicable, from whom seized, with notice of its present location. 
H.  Upon redemption, the owner shall be required to pay such daily charge for keeping such animal as may be fixed by law. In all cases, it shall be a prerequisite to redemption that the animal be licensed according to law. 
(Prior code § 612.08) 
6.08.040. - Wrongful removal of collars-Poisoning-Shooting. 
A.  No person shall wrongfully remove the collar from the neck of any dog licensed and collared according to the provisions of this chapter or any statute of the state. 
B.  No person shall wrongfully remove such a collar and affix it to another dog. 
C.  No person shall distribute or expose a poisonous substance with the intent that the same shall be taken or eaten by any dog. 
D.  No person shall unlawfully shoot any dog by discharge of a firearm or with an arrow. 
(Prior code § 612.09) 
6.08.050. - Restraint of animals. 
A.  No owner shall fail to keep or cause to be kept his or her dog or other animal under restraint at all times or permit the same to be at large. 
B.  Dogs shall be permitted on streets, sidewalks and public places only when collared and on a secure leash not in excess of eight feet in length, and only when under the immediate physical control of a responsible person. 
C.  No dog shall be permitted on any public beach between Memorial Day and September 30, inclusive; or at any time in and upon any schoolyard, school premises, public historic cemetery with the exception of leashed dogs in the Common Burying Ground, fenced athletic field, or the tot lots located on Third Street, Edward Street, Kingston Avenue, adjacent to Cardines Field, and within Freebody Park, or in any eating establishment open to the public, or in any eating establishment open to the public, except dogs assisting blind or handicapped persons which are controlled by such persons or their companions. 
D.  No person shall allow or permit any animal owned or kept by him or her to run at large in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public property or in or upon any private property without the consent of the owner thereof. 
E.  No horse shall be permitted on any public beach at any time in and upon any, fenced or open athletic field, running track, and within Cardines Field, and Freebody Park. 
F.  No person shall keep an animal at any place in the city under unhealthy, filthy or unsanitary conditions or in such a manner that vile, rank, nauseous or obnoxious odors are created. 
G.  No person having control of an animal shall knowingly permit the same to defecate in or upon any sidewalk, public place, park or building, or in or upon any part of a building used by or open to the public, or upon the property of a person other than the owner of such animal. Any person having control of an animal which defecates in or upon any sidewalk, public place, park or building, or in or upon any part of a building used by or open to the public, or upon the property of a person other than the owner of such animal, shall forthwith remove the feces. 
H.  No owner or keeper of a dog shall suffer such animal to kill, wound or worry any seeing-eye dog which is certified for use as a guide dog for a blind person. Any such owner or keeper who knows or should know that his or her animal has such a propensity shall be punished as provided in Section 6.04.110(H) for each offense. 
    This subsection shall not be construed to limit any owner's or keeper's civil or criminal liability pursuant to any other authority contained in state or local law. No owner or keeper of a dog shall leave said dog outside unattended between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. 
I.  No owner or keeper of a dog shall leave such dog outside unattended between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. 
J.  Off Leash Dog Park-Regulations. The city of Newport may from time to time establish certain areas or parks wherein dogs may be allowed to remain off of any leash or similar restraint mechanisms. A dog may remain off leash in such areas or parks only in the specific areas so designated by the city of Newport and only if the owner, keeper or other person having care custody or control of the dog complies at all times with the following rules and regulations: 
1.  No person may bring into an off-leash area site: 
a.  A dangerous dog which is defined as a dog which attacks another animal or person, or otherwise shows aggression towards another animal or person; 
b.  A female dog in heat; 
c.  More than three dogs at one time; and 
d.  A dog that is not wearing tags showing that it is currently registered and vaccinated in compliance with Section 6.08.010. 
2.  Any person who brings into an off-leash site shall: 
a.  Carry materials and implements for removing and disposing of dog excreta and remove all excreta deposited by the dog in the off-leash site, in compliance with Section 6.08.050; 
b.  Lead the dog on a leash and retain the dog in custody when entering and exiting an off-leash site; 
c.  Keep the dog under visual and voice control at all times while in the off-leash site; 
d.  Fill any hole that the dog digs in the off-leash site; and 
e.  Remove the dog from the off-leash site at the first sign of aggression. 
3.  Any person who brings a child under twelve (12) years of age into an off-leash site shall keep the child under strict supervision. No child under twelve (12) may enter without an adult. 
4.  Use of an off-leash site by any dog constitutes: 
a.  Implied consent of the owner, harborer, or person having care, custody or control of the dog to comply with all ordinances, rules and regulations enacted by the city of Newport or rules and regulations which may be posted at the off-leash site from time to time; and 
b.  A release or waiver of any and all liability on the part of the city of Newport by the owner, or person having care, custody, or control of the dog with respect to the use of the off-leash area, and an agreement and undertaking to protect, indemnify, defend, and hold the city harmless, for any injury or damage caused by the dog during any time that the dog is in the off-leash site. 
K.  For a violation of any of the provisions of this section, a citation may be issued. 
(Ord. 2007-35 § 1, 2007; Ord. 2006-23 § 1, 2006; Ord. 2004-14 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2003-25 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2001-37 § 1, 2002; Ord. 2001-19 § 1, 2001; Ord. 2000-25 § 1, 2000; prior code § 612.10; Ord. No. 2017-19, § 1, 8-23-2017) 
6.08.060. - Guard or sentry dogs. 
A.  The owner of a guard, sentry or attack dog, so-called, shall register the location and address of such dog with the control officer and shall immediately inform such officer of any change of location or address of the same and of the escape, theft or disappearance of such dog. The control officer shall provide the police and fire divisions with a current list of the locations and addresses of all such animals and the names, addresses and telephone numbers of their owners. 
B.  The owner of any such dog shall cause to be prominently displayed signs designed to clearly inform all persons of the location and presence of such animals. No person shall display such a sign when no such animal is in fact present. 
(Prior code § 612.11) 
6.08.070. - Control of vicious animals, animals in heat and wild animals. 
A.  No owner shall fail to confine within a building or secure enclosure any vicious, fierce or dangerous animal or remove the same therefrom unless securely collared, muzzled and leashed or caged. 
B.  An owner shall cause to be so confined or enclosed for two weeks or such longer period as may be required by the control officer, not to exceed three months, any animal which has bitten, mauled or attacked any person and shall not remove such animal from such building or enclosure except as provided in subsection A of this section. 
C.  Any female animal in heat shall be confined in a building, secure enclosure, veterinary hospital or kennel in such a manner that other animals cannot come into contact with such animal except for intentional breeding purposes. 
D.  No wild animal may be kept within the city without permission of the control officer under such conditions as such officer may prescribe. However, wild animals may be kept for exhibition purposes in the city by circuses, zoos and educational or scientific institutions, without application to such office, as may be permitted by law. 
E.  Any wild animal found within the city may be destroyed by the control officer when such animal presents a threat to itself, other animals or to the public. Nothing herein shall be construed to permit the destruction of a wild animal otherwise protected by law. 
(Prior code § 612.12) 
6.08.080. - Swine prohibited. 
    No swine shall be kept within the limits of the city. 
(Prior code § 612.18) 
6.08.100. - Spaying and neutering of cats. 
A.  No person shall own or harbor within the city any cat over the age of six months which has not been spayed or neutered, unless such person holds a license, issued by the Newport animal control officer, to keep an unaltered cat; or unless the caretaker states that because of age, health or illness it would be inappropriate to spay or neuter the cat and having in their possession a letter from a licensed veterinarian stating such, which shall be provided to the animal control officer. 
B.  An "intact" permit shall be issued for an unaltered cat if the owner signs a written statement that such animal will not be allowed to breed. An "intact" permit may be issued by the animal control officer to an individual who refuses to spay or neuter his or her cat. The fee for such permit shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year. All funds from the "intact" permit shall be deposited in the city's spay/neuter account. 
C.  Any person providing care or sustenance for an uninterrupted period of sixty (60) days or longer shall be deemed the owner of such animal and shall adhere to the provisions of this section. 
D.  The breeding of cats in the City of Newport is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2010-17, § 1, 6-9-2010) 
Chapter 6.12. - FEEDING OF NON- DOMESTICATED ANIMALS. 

6.12.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to protect the health and safety of residents in the city of Newport with respect to dangers associated with coyotes and other non-domesticated animals by minimizing opportunities for such animals to obtain food from sources controlled or controllable by humans. 
(Ord. No. 2013-003, § 1, 6-12-2013) 
6.12.020 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    "Attractant" means any substance which could reasonably be expected to attract or does attract coyotes or other non-domesticated animals, including but not limited to, garbage, food products, pet food, carcasses, feed, grain. 
    "Feeding" means the leaving of food of any kind where it is accessible to coyotes or other non-domesticated animals. 
    "Food" means all substances consumed by humans or animals for nourishment except grass and other vegetation, growing crops, and food that is canned or stored in sealed or closable containers. 
(Ord. No. 2013-003, § 1, 6-12-2013) 
6.12.030 - Prohibitions. 
A.  No person shall feed or in any manner provide an attractant to coyotes or other non-domesticated animals; provided that domestic pets are not attractants, and feeding pets outdoors does not create an attractant if the pet eats all the food immediately, or the remaining food is removed as soon as the pet stops eating, or the pet is fed in a secure cage or other enclosure. 
B.  No person shall leave, store, or maintain any food or attractant in a manner, area, or location accessible to coyotes or other non-domesticated animals. 
(Ord. No. 2013-003, § 1, 6-12-2013) 
6.12.040 - Exceptions. 
A.  Food for birds or squirrels that is in a feeder located within one hundred (100) feet of a residence and elevated to be inaccessible to coyotes. 
B.  Outdoor feeding of farm animals, provided: 
1.  Animal food, when not being fed to animals, is stored in a building or a closed container; 
2.  Excessive amounts of food, based on the animals' eating history, are not provided to the animals; 
3.  Injured, old, feeble, or prey-sized animals are not left outside unattended; and 
4.  All other reasonable efforts are made to reduce attractants to coyotes and other non-domesticated animals. 
(Ord. No. 2013-003, § 1, 6-12-2013) 
6.12.050 - Enforcement. 
    Violations of this chapter are punishable by a fine of from one hundred dollars ($100.00) to five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day of violation. 
(Ord. No. 2013-003, § 1, 6-12-2013) 
Title 8. - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapter 8.04. - CEMETERIES AND BURIALS 

8.04.010. - Perpetual care lots. 
A.  Fee. The director of finance is authorized to accept not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) to provide for the perpetual care of a burial lot in a city cemetery. Upon receipt of the same, the director shall forthwith transmit to the board of commissioners of the sinking funds all sums so received by him or her. 
B.  Transfer and Use of Funds. The board of commissioners of the sinking funds for the city shall, upon the request of the director of finance and after approval by council, transfer to the department of finance such part of income earned and received by such board from funds in its custody, care and control as may be required to meet costs incurred by the director of public works in accordance with the budget approved by council. 
(Prior code § 1064.01) 
8.04.020. - Burial or removal of bodies-Permit required. 
    No person shall bury or entomb a dead body of a human being in the city, or remove the same from the city, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city clerk. Every person in charge of a cemetery or burying place in the city shall require and receive such permit from the person who procured the same before allowing the interment or entombment of any body in such cemetery or burying place, and shall, every Monday, before twelve noon, return to the office of the city clerk every permit so received by him or her during the week ending with the previous Saturday. 
(Prior code § 1064.02) 
8.04.030. - Burial places. 
    No undertaker or other person shall bury or cause to be buried, or deposit or cause to be deposited, in any vault or tomb, the body of any deceased person in any grounds other than the Common Burying Ground, the Island Cemetery, the Willow Cemetery, the Friends' Burying Ground on Green Lane, the Roman Catholic Cemetery on Warner Street, the City Cemetery, the ground on Warner Street west of the Island Cemetery, the Braman Cemetery and St. Joseph of Cluny Sisters' Cemetery, such cemetery being located on a plot of land on Brenton Road adjacent to the Sisters of Cluny Novitiate, Touro Cemetery at the corner of Kay Street and Bellevue Avenue, or in such grounds as are hereafter designated by council as burying grounds and authorized to be used as such without first obtaining permission to do so from council. Council shall cause to be taken up and removed to such burial ground or cemetery, as may be designed by council, and there decently interred, any dead body which may hereafter be buried in violation of this chapter, at the expense of the person who has caused the dead body to have been so illegally interred, such expense to be recovered by council in an action before any court competent to try the same. 
(Ord. 99-52 § 1, 1999; prior code § 1064.03) 
8.04.040. - Funerals-Permit required-Deaths due to contagious diseases. 
A.  No person, other than a licensed undertaker, shall manager or conduct a funeral, or inter or deposit in a vault or tomb, or remove from the city, a dead body, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the city clerk. After such interment, deposit or removal is made, the permittee shall make a return as is directed to be made by undertakers by state law. 
B.  The body of every person who has died of smallpox, diphtheria, scarlet fever, yellow fever, typhus fever, Asiatic cholera or any contagious infection or pestilential disease shall be removed for interment in a hearse and not in any other vehicle. 
(Prior code § 1064.04) 
8.04.050. - Fences, walls, etc., around graves. 
    No person shall make any fence, wall, curb or other barrier or enclosure around any lot or piece of land in the Common Burying Ground, so called, in the city, or in or upon any part of such Common Burying Ground, or maintain any such fence, wall, curb, barrier or enclosure hereafter made, without first obtaining a license therefor from council. 
(Prior code § 1064.05) 
8.04.060. - Hours closed.
