As provided in the collection contract, each owner and occupant of dwelling houses and apartment houses having a common owner not exceeding eight units located on the same property shall be entitled to one set of city-issued carts per household. One set of city-issued carts is comprised of a 65-gallon or 35-gallon cart for each trash and recycling, which is the weekly limit for trash and recycling except as otherwise provided for in subsections D, E, and G herein. 
D.  Leaf and yard waste shall be placed curbside in unlined barrels up to 32-gallons or in thirty (30) gallon kraft paper bags. Plastic bags shall not be used. Leaf and yard waste shall be kept separate from municipal solid waste. Leaf and yard waste must be free of litter. 
    Leaf and yard waste will be collected once per week on the regularly-scheduled collection day during one week in January and March, four weeks in April, every other week during the months of May, June, July, August, September and October, and four weeks in November and December combined, with these collections to be determined by and prominently notified to residents by the public services director. Up to twenty (20) containers will be picked up per collection day, per household. 
E.  Christmas trees shall be placed curbside for collection for one week in conjunction with January's yard waste collection week, with the collection schedule to be determined by and prominently notified to residents by the public services director. All ornaments, tinsel and tree bags must be removed from Christmas trees upon placement at the curb. 
F.  Residential recyclables collected under city contract shall be transported to a city-designated facility. 
G.  Overflow Bags. The City of Newport may allow excess trash that does not fit into city-issued trash carts with the lid closed, to be placed in overflow bags, purchased by each generator of municipal solid waste on an as-needed basis. Overflow bags shall be placed on the side or the top of the city-issued cart. Overflow bags can be purchased at select retailers. 
(Ord. 97-46 § 1 (part), 1997; Ord. 10-93 § 1, 1993; prior code § 1063.05) 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 2-11-2015) 
8.24.055. - Mandatory recycling. 
A.  Recycling is mandatory in the city pursuant to GLRI 1956, as amended, Title 23, Chapters 18.8, 18.9, and 19. The city shall follow the guidelines as established by the Rhode Island Resource Recovery Corporation (RIRRC) and the Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management (RIDEM) regarding which materials are considered recyclable and are to be included in the city's recycling program. Examples include, but are not limited to, the below list, and are subject to change. Each generator of residential solid waste is required to place the following recyclable materials loosely (un-bagged) into the city-issued cart for recycling: 
1.  Glass Containers. Rinsed, whole bottles and jars, free from cooking ware, plate glass, safety glass, light bulbs, ceramics and non-glass materials, shall be collected. Caps, lids and any type of top must be removed from the bottles. Metal lids may be recycled separately. Labels may remain on the bottles, but bottles shall be empty, rinsed and unbroken. 
a.  Jars from pasta sauce, jelly and baby food; 
b.  Bottles from soda, beer and wine. 
2.  Metal Cans and Foil. 
a.  Tin cans from soup, vegetables, tuna and pet foods. Steel and tin-coated steel cans shall be empty and rinsed. Cans shall not be crushed. 
b.  Empty aerosol cans from air freshener, hairspray, whipped cream. Must be emptied completely. 
c.  Aluminum. Aluminum cans, containers, foil and foil pie pans shall be clean and dry. 
3.  Paper and Cardboard. 
a.  Newspapers, including inserts; 
b.  Mail, including junk mail and envelopes; 
c.  Magazines; 
d.  Phone books; 
e.  Paperback books. Hardcover books may be recycled if the cover is removed and thrown away; 
f.  Writing paper; 
g.  Spiral notebooks; 
h.  Corrugated cardboard, empty and flattened; 
i.  Paperboard, empty and flattened. Examples include shoe boxes, cereal boxes, egg cartons, paper towel and toilet paper rolls; 
j.  Wrapping and tissue paper, as well as gift bags; 
k.  Paper bags; 
l.  Magazines and catalogs; 
m.  Shredded paper: must be in double bagged see-through bags (grocery bags OK). 
4.  Plastic Containers Less Than Two Gallons. Must be empty and rinsed with top, caps or lids gently replaced. Containers must remain intact and not crushed. 
a.  Bottles such as those from juice, shampoo, water; 
b.  Jugs from milk, juice, detergent; 
c.  Jars from mayonnaise, peanut butter, jelly; 
d.  Tubs from butter, margarine, cottage cheese; 
e.  Plastic take-out containers; 
f.  Plastic cups, such as iced coffee and other beverages; 
g.  Yogurt containers; 
h.  Plastic egg cartons. 
5.  Cartons. Must be emptied, rinsed and remain intact. 
a.  Coated-paper milk, juice, soup and broth cartons; 
b.  Drink boxes, aseptic containers with straws removed and discarded. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 2-11-2015) 
8.24.060. - Time and frequency of collection. 
    Residential solid waste and recyclables shall be collected once per week, pursuant to the city's collection contract. The public services director shall prominently publish a schedule for the collection of recyclables when there is a change in the material to be collected, collection procedure or schedule. 
    Collection of solid waste, recyclables, and bulky waste, either residential or commercial, whether under the municipal contract or by private contract, shall not be made earlier than six-thirty a.m. nor later than five p.m. 
(Ord. 2005-30 § 1, 2005) 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 2-11-2015) 
8.24.065. - Transfer stations-Hours of operation. 
    The hours of operation of a transfer station located within the city boundaries shall be limited to six-thirty a.m. to six-thirty p.m. 
(Ord. 2008-26 § 1, 2008) 
8.24.070. - Storage between collections. 
A.  Municipal. All municipal solid waste shall be placed in plastic trash bags with all openings securely closed and shall be securely stored in the city-issued trash cart with the lid completely closed. City-issued carts must be stored inside the boundaries of the property the carts were assigned to and no city-issued carts may be left on city property in between collections. All materials to be collected must be placed curbside by six a.m. on the scheduled collection day in city-issued carts. Residents may place materials to be collected only at the curb no earlier than five p.m. the night before scheduled collection. Lids of city-issued carts must be completely closed in order to be collected by the collection contractor. 
B.  Nonresidential. All occupants of nonresidential premises shall provide a sufficient number of approved containers for the storage of solid waste generated and shall place all such solid waste therein. 
(Ord. 97-46 § 1 (part), 1997; prior code § 1063.07) 
8.24.080. - Carts. 
A.  City Ownership of Carts. As part of instituting the cart based collection program, the city shall initially distribute two coded carts for solid waste and recycling to each eligible household in the city. Said carts shall bear the clean city program logo. All carts distributed shall be the property of the city. All containers shall be coded with a serial number which shall correspond to a designated street address. Upon moving or vacating a household, residents shall leave all city carts at the property for use by the next owner and/or tenant. 
1.  Vandalism of Carts. City-issued carts may only be marked on the lid, specifically the white bar provided, in which each household can mark their address. Carts may not be marked, vandalized or damaged in any other fashion, including, but not limited to, spray painting address numbers on the side of the carts, spray painting to change the color of the carts, drilling holes, or using the carts for any other purpose besides for weekly trash and recycling collection. 
B.  City-issued Cart Replacement. If a household or resident has a cart that is unserviceable, the department of public services can be contacted to secure a replacement. Serviceability shall be determined by the department of public services. 
C.  Cart Sizes. A resident may switch their cart size from a 65-gallon set to a 35-gallon set, or from a 35-gallon set to a 65-gallon set. 
D.  Sanitation. Residents shall maintain city-issued carts and the adjacent area in a nuisance-free and odor-free condition. Before being deposited in waste containers, parcels of household garbage shall be drained of moisture and placed in a plastic bag. Containers shall be kept clean and disinfected. 
E.  Defective Containers. All city-issued carts incapable of meeting the requirements of approved containers shall be tagged by the collection contractor who shall notify the public services director of any defective containers that may be eligible for replacement through the cart warranty. 
F.  Extra Containers. 
1.  Residents may rent an additional city-issued trash cart for an annual fee based on the cost of the cart plus associated waste collection and waste disposal costs. This fee is subject to change based on fluctuations in cart, collection and disposal costs. 
2.  Residents may rent an additional city-issued recycling cart for an annual fee based on current cart and recycling collection costs. This fee is subject to change based on fluctuations in cart and collection costs. 
3.  Any resident requesting an additional trash or recycling cart who requests same on or before May 1, 2015 will not be charged a rental fee. 
(Ord. 97-46 § 1 (part), 1997; prior code § 1063.08) 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 2-11-2015) 
8.24.090. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, adopted February 11, 2015, repealed § 8.24.090, which pertained to noncontainerized waste and derived from prior code § 1063.09 and Ord. No. 97-4, 1997. 
8.24.100. - Household bulky waste and appliances. 
A.  Household bulky waste and appliances shall be placed curbside for collection to be collected on the days scheduled for the same as determined by the city and its collection contractor. 
B.  Residents shall be responsible for calling the office of the current collection contractor at least seventy-two (72) hours in advance of the first and third Thursdays of the month to schedule collection of appliances, tires, and scrap metal heavier than thirty-five (35) pounds or longer than two and one-half feet, or any other bulky waste item that does not fit in the city-issued trash cart, which collection shall be subject to the fee set forth in the bulky waste fee list published by the public services director. Up to three items may be placed curbside for collection at one time. The bulky waste collection schedule may be changed from time to time. 
C.  At the time appliances and scrap metal are set out at the curb they become the property of the City of Newport. No person engaged in the business of separation, recovery, collection, removal, storage or disposition of solid waste shall pick up or procure appliances or scrap metal unless specifically authorized by the director of public services. This restriction shall also apply to any resident, taxpayer, or other person who might engage in this practice for personal gain. 
D.  Every owner or occupant of any premises, and every landlord or agent of a landlord having general charge of the same, or any other person, who shall throw, dump, or deposit any refuse, rubbish, waste matter of a similar nature upon any premises without being contained in a city-issued cart or without a bulky waste sticker affixed to bulky waste item shall, after notice by city officials, remove such refuse, rubbish, waste matter and material so thrown, dumped, or deposited on such premises within forty-eight (48) hours after receiving such notice. Failure to comply shall be a violation of this section, subject to prosecution before the Municipal Court for the City of Newport. 
(Ord. 2008-43 § 1, 2008; Ord. 97-46 § 1 (part), 1997: prior code § 1063.10) 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 2-11-2015) 
8.24.110. - Recyclables. 
A.  Ownership. At the time recyclables are set out at the curb they are the property of the City of Newport. No person engaged in the business of separation, recovery, collection, removal, storage or disposition of solid waste shall pick up or procure any recyclable material unless specifically authorized and licensed to do so by the director of public services. This restriction shall also include any resident, taxpayer or other person who might engage in this practice for personal gain. 
B.  Noncompliance. For the first and second occurrence, the collection contractor will collect all recyclable materials except those contaminated by putrescences or those which cannot be retrieved from the recyclable container. Improperly sorted materials or contaminated materials will be left in the city-issued recycling cart. The contractor shall leave a city-provided notice in the city-issued recycling cart. The notice will inform the resident that the material has been rejected for recycling collection and provide information on how to contact the city's clean city coordinator for further information. 
    The contractor shall supply a record of violations to the city. It shall be a responsibility of a designee of the public services director to contact residents who repeatedly place improperly-prepared items at the curb to encourage them to properly prepare and sort the materials. If the resident still fails to be in compliance, such failure shall be a violation of this section and subject to prosecution in the municipal court of the City of Newport for failure to segregate recyclables and shall be subject to a fine as set forth in Section 1.14.145. 
(Ord. 97-46 § 1 (part), 1997; prior code § 1063.11) 
(Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 2-11-2015) 
8.24.120. - Prohibited activities. 
A.  Littering. Litter barrels are provided in parks and on sidewalks solely for the collection of litter from pedestrian traffic. No person shall place or allow to be placed any solid waste upon roads, streets or public or private property in the city contrary to this chapter. 
B.  Acts Contrary to Chapter. No person shall store, collect, transport, transfer, recover, incinerate or dispose of any solid waste in the city contrary to this chapter. 
C.  Vehicle Construction. No person shall transport any solid waste in any vehicle which permits the contents to blow, shift, leak or fall therefrom. All vehicles shall have either totally enclosed bodies or box-type bodies with provision at all times for a heavy tarpaulin cover permanently attached at the front end of the vehicle body when fully loaded. Vehicles not properly covered shall not be permitted. 
D.  Interference With Authorized Solid Waste Management. No person shall interfere with any employee of the city or any employee of a contractor while in the performance of his or her duties as authorized by this chapter. 
E.  Scavenging. No person shall scavenge any municipal solid waste in the city, except with the consent of the owner or lessee of the premises on which the solid waste is located. 
F.  Open Burning. No person shall burn solid waste in any manner other than as authorized in Chapter 8.08. 
G.  Animal Feeding. No person shall engage in the feeding of food waste to animals for commercial purposes. 
H.  Hazardous Waste. No person shall place any hazardous waste in any container for collection, transport, processing or disposal. 
(Ord. 98-4 § 1 (part), 1998; Ord. 97-46 § 1 (part), 1997; prior code § 1063.12) 
Chapter 8.28. - SMOKING PROHIBITED 

8.28.010. - Smoking prohibited in and around municipal and school buildings. 
A.  The smoking of any tobacco product is prohibited in any building, office space, or portions of buildings owned, rented, leased, or used by the city or school department, or any agencies of the city. 
B.  Smoking is prohibited within twenty-five (25) feet of the public entrances/exits of the city/school department buildings cited in subsection (A). 
(Ord. 2004-3 § 1, 2004) 
Chapter 8.32. - HEALTH AND SAFETY 

8.32.010. - Legislative findings and intent. 
A.  The city council has the authority under Article 13 of the Rhode Island Constitution and the ordinances of the City of Newport to regulate issues of solid waste, litter and pollution as a local concern. 
B.  The production, use and disposal of single-use plastic carryout bags, which are commonly not recycled, has been shown to have significant detrimental impacts on the environment, including but not limited to contributing to pollution of the terrestrial and coastal environment, clogging of storm water drainage systems, and contributing to the injury and death of terrestrial and marine life through ingestion and entanglement. 
C.  The manufacture, transport and recycling of single-use plastic carryout bags requires substantial energy consumption and contributes to greenhouse gases. 
D.  Single-use plastic carryout bags create a burden to solid waste collection and recycling facilities. 
E.  Prohibiting the use of single-use plastic carryout bags is necessary to protect the environment and the public health, safety and welfare of all residents and visitors. 
(Ord. No. 2017-08, § 1, 3-8-2017) 
8.32.020. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to improve the overall environment in the City of Newport for the health, safety, and welfare of its residents and for the protection of our wildlife and coastal ecosystems by: 
1.  Encouraging the use of reusable carryout bags and banning the use of single-use plastic carryout bags, 
2.  Maintaining the ability to recycle single-use plastic carryout bags, and 
3.  Reducing the number of single-use plastic carryout bags. 
    Business establishments are encouraged to make reusable carryout bags available for sale. 
(Ord. No. 2017-08, § 1, 3-8-2017) 
8.32.030. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated: 
    "Business establishment." Any commercial enterprise, including sole proprietorships, joint ventures, partnerships, corporations, or any other legal entity, and includes all employees of the business and any independent contractors associated with the business. "Business establishment" does not include the sale of goods at yard sales, tag sales and other sales by residents at their homes. 
    "Double-opening plastic bag." Any thin plastic bag with a double opening (top and bottom) to protect clothing or other items for transport. 
    "Plastic bag." A bag where any portion of the bag is made of plastic, including but not limited to those called "biodegradable", "compostable" or "oxo-biodegradable." 
    "Plastic barrier bag." Any thin plastic bag with a single opening used to: 
  Transport fruit, vegetables, nuts, grains, small hardware items, or other items selected by customers to the point of sale; 
  Contain or wrap fresh or frozen foods, meat, or fish, whether prepackaged or not; 
  Contain or wrap flowers, potted plants, or other items where damage to a good or contamination of other goods placed together in the same bag may be a problem; 
  Contain unwrapped prepared foods or bakery goods; or 
  Provide protection for newspapers and other printed material delivered to consumers. 
    "Reusable carryout bag." A bag, that is specifically designed and manufactured for multiple reuse, where the handle is stitched to the bag. The "bag" is a container made of washable cloth, durable woven or nonwoven fabric, or durable plastic with a minimum thickness of four (4) mils, with an opening at the top, used for carrying things. The "handle" is the part by which the bag is held, carried or controlled. 
    "Single-use plastic carryout bag." A single-use plastic bag used by the customer at the point of sale for the purpose of removing products purchased from a business establishment. Single-use plastic carryout bag shall include any plastic bag except plastic barrier bags, double-opening plastic bags, plastic bags measuring larger than twenty-eight (28) inches by thirty-six (36) inches, or plastic bags four (4) mils or more in thickness. 
(Ord. No. 2017-08, § 1, 3-8-2017; Ord. No. 2018-10, § 1, 9-26-2018) 
8.32.040. - Regulations. 
    No business establishment shall provide or make available any plastic bag, either complementary or for a fee, for any sales transaction or other use to members of the public, that does not comply with the definition of a reusable carryout bag under § 8.32.030 of this chapter. A plastic bag, regardless of thickness, without a sewn-on handle is prohibited. 
    All business establishments that provide plastic barrier bags or double-opening bags as defined under § 8.32.030 of this chapter shall offer a recycling opportunity on site for the recycling of any plastic bags or clean plastic bag film as defined by the Rhode Island Resource Recovery Corporation RESTORE program. 
    Nothing in this section shall preclude business establishments from making reusable bags or recyclable paper bags, as defined under § 8.32.030 of this chapter, available to customers, by sale or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2017-08, § 1, 3-8-2017; Ord. No. 2018-10, § 2, 9-26-2018) 
8.32.050. - Enforcement; violations and penalties. 
A.  Upon a violation of the provisions of this chapter, the business establishment shall be provided written notice ordering cessation of the violation. Notice shall be given to the business establishment owner or manager or may be served on the business establishment's agent for service. 
B.  A violation shall be subject to a fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
C.  For any violation of the provisions of this chapter, the city council may revoke any municipally issued license granted to the business establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2017-08, § 1, 3-8-2017) 
8.32.060. - Implementation. 
    This chapter shall be effective upon passage. Enforcement of violations shall be stayed until November 1, 2017. 
(Ord. No. 2017-08, § 1, 3-8-2017) 
Title 9. - PUBLIC PEACE AND WELFARE 
Chapter 9.04. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND DECENCY 

9.04.010. - Alcoholic beverages-Consumption or possession by minors. 
    No person who has not attained the age of twenty-one (21) years shall consume or have in his or her possession alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. 26-89 § 1, 1989) 
(Ord. No. 2009-21, 7-22-2009) 
9.04.020. - Alcoholic beverages-Consumption or possession in public places. 
    No person shall consume, possess or drink alcoholic beverages, or transport alcoholic beverages in an open container, on the public streets, public sidewalks, public roadways, public parks or public beaches in the city. 
(Prior code § 606.02) 
9.04.030. - Intoxication. 
    No person shall be indecently intoxicated in the city. 
(Prior code § 606.04) 
9.04.040. - Bungee jumping-Prohibited. 
    The activity, commonly referred to as "bungee jumping," is prohibited in any public place or in connection with any activity licensed by the council of the city. 
(Ord. 13-93 § 1, 1993) 
9.04.050. - Disorderly conduct. 
A.  No person acting along or in concert with others shall: 
1.  Act in an intimidating, violent or tumultuous manner toward another or others whereby any person is placed in fear of safety for his or her life, limb, health or well-being; 
2.  Act in an intimidating, violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being damaged, mutilated, defaced or destroyed, or is, in fact, mutilated, damaged, defaced or destroyed; 
3.  In a public place, use words that are calculated, designed or likely to disrupt the peace, or language or words which by their very nature or utterance inflict, or are likely to inflict, injury, or which tend to incite outrage, turmoil or disturbance of the public peace; 
4.  Behave in an intimidating, violent or forceful manner at any time in, upon or in the proximity of a public place in such a manner that such conduct constitutes a clear and present danger to the free and lawful movement of any person or to the extent that any other person will be, or is likely to be, restrained, enjoined, incapacitated or stopped in the lawful exercise of his or her business, occupation, amusement, recreation or any other lawful pursuit; 
5.  Cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or tumultuous or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or well-being of another; 
6.  Join, assemble or congregate with one or more persons for the purpose of causing, provoking or engaging in any fight or brawl; 
7.  Disturb the peace of another or others by violent, indecent, offensive, hostile, boisterous or obscene conduct, language or gestures, which conduct, language or gestures is designed or calculated or likely to cause anguish or injury to another or others; 
8.  Throw any stone, snowball or other missile or object upon or at any person, vehicle, building, tree, sign or other public or private property; 
9.  Roughly or forcefully crowd, jostle or push any person in any public place; 
10.  Expectorate, urinate or defecate on any public street, alley or sidewalk or the floor of any public place or public building or any place or building where the public has the right to gather or to which it has access; 
11.  By acts of violence, interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; 
12.  Wilfully, knowingly, wantonly or recklessly make a false alarm or cry of fire or a false request for the assistance of any firefighting apparatus or personnel, or willfully, knowingly, wantonly or recklessly make a false report or request for assistance of any public or private rescue or assistance services, or, similarly, make a false cry, alarm or request for police assistance; 
13.  Prowl or wander in or upon the private property of another or, without good reason, or without visible or lawful business with the owner or occupant thereof, peek, peep or peer in any door or window of any building or structure thereon; 
14.  Maliciously, or without good cause, interrupt, harass or molest any speaker at any lawful assembly, meeting or gathering, or impair the lawful rights of others to participate in such assembly, meeting or gathering, when such conduct is calculated or likely to provoke disorderly conduct and interfere with the orderly conduct or procedure of such assembly, meeting or gathering or to cause turmoil or disturbance at the same; 
15.  Act in a manner designed, likely or tending to cause or provoke a disturbance in any public building or place of business, wherein matters affecting the public are being considered or deliberated, which action is designed, likely or tending to interfere with the orderly conduct or procedure of such consideration or deliberation; 
16.  Frequent any public place with the intention to obtain money or other thing of value from another or others by illegal or fraudulent schemes, tricks, artifices or devices; 
17.  Assemble for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device, artifice or trick to obtain any money or thing of value in any place from any person; 
18.  Display any deadly weapon, or instrument or thing which by its appearance may be considered a deadly weapon, in any public place in a manner calculated or likely to alarm or frighten another or others; 
19.  Join, collect or assemble in bodies or crowds for unlawful purposes as defined by any ordinance of the city; or 
20.  Yell, shout, hoot, whistle, sing or make or cause to be made any other noise on the public streets, particularly between the hours of eleven p.m.. and seven a.m. of the following day, or at any other time or at any place, so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of any person in any hospital, dwelling, hotel or other type of residence or of any person in the vicinity. 
B.  The foregoing prohibitions shall be applicable to all persons whether acting alone or in concert with others. 
C.  Whoever violates the foregoing provisions shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and/or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. 45-92 § 1, 1992; prior code § 660.01) 
9.04.060. - Loitering. 
A.  As used in this section, "loitering," or "loiter" means remaining idly in essentially one location, including the concepts of spending time idly, loafing or standing about aimlessly, and also including the colloquial expression "hanging around." 
B.  No person shall stand or loiter on any street, sidewalk, lane, parking lot or alley, or at the entrance to, or in the hallway, passageway or vestibule of, any church, hall, theater, place of entertainment or place of public assembly, or in and upon any parking lot, fence, stoop, sidewalk or platform attached to any dwelling house, store or other building or forming or being a part of a shopping center, so as to obstruct a free passage for foot passengers and/or vehicles, except with the express permission and consent of the owner of the premises of which such parking lot, fence, stoop, sidewalk or platform is a part, and in no case after such dwelling house, store, shopping center or other building has been closed for the night. 
C.  Any person loitering, as provided in subsection B of this section, shall immediately move on and away when requested to do so by any officer or member of the police division. 
(Prior code § 660.02) 
9.04.070. - Obstructing free passage on sidewalks, streets and wharves. 
    No person shall stand, be or remain in or upon a sidewalk, street or wharf in the city so as to obstruct free and uninterrupted passing thereon. 
(Prior code § 660.03) 
9.04.080. - Ringing bells. 
    No person shall, between sunset and one hour after sunrise, ring or cause to be rung the bell of any house of public worship, for any purpose whatever, except for an alarm of fire, and except for the ringing of such bells as may from time to time be provided for by council. However, nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent the tolling, at a moderate rate, of any such bells for lectures or any other lawful meeting between the times hereinbefore mentioned. 
(Prior code § 660.04) 
9.04.090. - Indecent exposure. 
    No person shall expose his or her person in an indecent manner in any of the streets, highways, lanes, alleys, wharves, yards or fields in the city or upon the piazza or doorsteps of any building in the city. 
(Prior code § 684.01) 
Chapter 9.08. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

9.08.010. - Desecration. 
A.  No person shall: 
1.  Wilfully destroy, defile, deface or otherwise injure any public building, any private or public cemetery or any other property or part thereof or appurtenance thereto; 
2.  Wilfully destroy, defile, deface or otherwise injure any building or structure used or designed for use as a place of religious worship or instruction, or any part thereof or appurtenance thereto, or any book, religious vestment, furniture, ornament, musical instrument, article of silver or plated ware or other chattel or property kept therein; 
3.  Brand, write, mark or paint any sign, letter or character of an obscene or disparaging nature on any public building or structure used or designed for use as a place of religious worship or instruction, or upon any part of such building, whether such part is interior or exterior; 
4.  Wilfully, without the express consent of the property owner, paint, deface, disfigure, or damage property (including but not limited to: buildings, walls, fences, poles, containers, bridges, vehicles, and all other structures and hard surfaces), through the use of paint or other indelible materials used to write names, initials, letters, symbols, or other miscellaneous markings commonly known as "graffiti"; 
5.  Mar, deface, alter, impair, remove, cover, replace, or change city-installed or approved signs, designations, or markings, including those designating public rights-of-way, other public information signs, symbols, and related city-sanctioned directional aides and devices; or 
6.  Attempt to commit any of the acts set forth in subparagraphs 1 through 5 of this subsection. 
B.  The possession of paint, ink, stain, varnish, dye or any other substance which leaves a mark, without authority of the owner or the lessee or agent of the owner of the property in question, by a person apprehended upon public property, in a public building or upon the grounds of any building or structure used or designed to be used as a place of religious worship or instruction, shall be prima facie evidence of an intent to defile, deface, brand, write, mark or paint such structure or building in the manner prohibited by this section. 
(Ord. 2008-8 § 1, 2008; Ord. 46-94 § 1, 1994; prior code § 666.01) 
9.08.020. - Injuring or tampering with fire hydrants. 
    No person shall willfully injure any hydrant erected in any street or public place in the city, or, without authorization, except upon an alarm of fire, open any such hydrant. 
(Prior code § 666.02) 
9.08.030. - Failure to return book or other library property. 
A.  Any person who shall take or borrow from the Newport Public Library any book, pamphlet, periodical, paper, or other piece of property of said library, and who, upon neglect to return the same within the time required and specified in the bylaws, rules, or regulations of the library owning the property, has been notified by the librarian or other proper custodian of the property that the same is overdue, shall, upon further neglect to return the same within two months from the date of such notice, or upon neglect to pay the charges on the book, or other article, be fined not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). A written or printed notice given personally or sent by mail to a last known or registered place of residence shall be considered a sufficient notice. In addition, if such book should be lost, destroyed or not returned, such person shall, within sixty (60) days after being so notified, pay to the custodian the replacement value of such book, including all reasonable processing costs, as determined by the Newport Public Library. 
B.  All library users shall be notified of the aforementioned penalties at the time they obtain or renew their library privileges. The final notice provided for in subsection A shall also contain notice of the said penalties. 
(Ord. 35-91 § 1, 1991: prior code § 666.05) 
9.08.040. - Breaking firewood, lumber or coal on sidewalks. 
    No person shall saw, split or cut any firewood or lumber or break up any coal on a sidewalk in the city. 
(Prior code § 678.09) 
9.08.050. - Cleaning fish on streets. 
    No person shall gut, scale or otherwise clean fish at any time in any of the public streets or squares of the city. 
(Prior code § 678.01) 
9.08.060. - Storing goods on sidewalks and streets. 
    No person shall deposit, place or put any goods, wares, firewood, coal or article of any kind on the sidewalks or in any part of any public highway, except while actually removing the same into or out of some building or enclosure. 
(Prior code § 678.08) 
9.08.070. - Use of sharp tools on sidewalks. 
    No owner or occupant of any land bordering on any sidewalk, or any other person, shall use any pick, axe, hatchet or other sharp tool or implement upon any sidewalk for the purpose of removing therefrom snow, ice or other obstruction. 
(Prior code § 666.04) 
9.08.080. - Handbills, cards, circulars and other advertising material. 
    No person shall throw, cast or distribute, or cause or permit to be thrown, cast or distributed, any advertising bill, advertising circular, advertising card, advertising booklet, advertising placard or other advertising matter, in or upon any street or public place, or in a front yard or courtyard, or on any porch or in the vestibule or any hall of any building, or in a letter box therein, provided, however, that nothing herein shall be deemed to prohibit or otherwise regulate the delivery of any such matter by the United States Postal Service or prohibit the distribution of sample copies of newspapers regularly sold by the copy or by subscription, and provided, further, that nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit the distribution of materials as aforesaid on private property that is open to the public where such private property is in a building. This section is not intended to prevent the lawful distribution of anything other than commercial and business advertising matter. 
(Prior code § 678.11) 
9.08.090. - Unlawful deposits-Littering-Water pollution. 
A.  No person shall throw, pour or in any way deposit, place or cause to be placed any filth, brine, dirty water, dirt, rubbish, paper, cigarette or cigar butts, sawdust, shavings, refuse, animal or vegetable matter of any kind, or any other offensive substance in any street, wharf, lane, highway, common or park, or into any sewer, catch basin or gravel catcher in the city. 
B.  No person shall throw, dispose of or deposit, or cause to be thrown, disposed of or deposited, bottles, glass, crockery, cans, scrap metal, junk, paper, cigarette or cigar butts, garbage, refuse or debris of any kind or any noxious substance in or upon any of the waters within the territorial jurisdiction of the city, including, but not limited to, all fresh water ponds and the waters of Newport Harbor. 
C.  No person shall throw, deposit, place, cast, scatter, pile, leave or lay any litter, including cigarette and cigar butts, in, about, or upon any public property or public waters in the city, except in authorized private receptacles for collection. No person shall throw, deposit, place or leave any household or commercial litter, garbage or refuse in such public receptacle. 
D.  All owners or operators of businesses licensed by the City of Newport or otherwise whose business premises borders on a public sidewalk shall keep said sidewalk along the length of their business premises free of all trash, debris, litter and cigarette butts at all times. The term sidewalk as used herein shall include areas occupied by tree wells and planters. Debris must be picked up and disposed of in proper receptacles. Sweeping debris into the street, curb line or storm drains is strictly prohibited. 
    Any person or business which violates or otherwise fails to comply with the above provisions shall be subject to a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per offense with each day constituting a separate offense. In addition, license holders shall be subject to the provisions of Section 1.12.010(C). 
(Ord. 2003-48 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2017-11, § 1, 6-14-2017) 
9.08.100. - Spilling loads. 
    No person, using a truck, cart or other means of conveyance, shall haul dirt, loam or any other material liable to sift through the sides or be blown from the top causing litter, dust or other nuisance on the streets or to the householders along the streets unless such dirt, loam or other material is so loaded that such sifting or blowing is impossible and unless such truck, cart or other conveyance is provided with a tight cover or tarpaulin so disposed as to prevent spillage, sifting or blowing. 
(Prior code § 678.07) 
9.08.110. - Snow removal and disposal. 
A.  No owner, occupant, or other person having the care of any building or lot or land bordering on any street, square or public place in the city where there is a sidewalk, shall fail, within five hours of daylight, after the ceasing to fall of any snow, to cause the same to be removed from the sidewalk adjoining such building or lot, and in all streets where there is no curbstone set, a pathway at least three feet wide, shall be made on and along the sidewalk aforesaid for the convenience of pedestrians. 
B.  No person shall dispose of any snow by throwing or plowing it onto the travel lane portion of any public roadway; not shall any snow that is shoveled, plowed or collected be deposited directly into any waterway, including, but not limited to, all fresh water ponds and the waters of Newport Harbor. 
(Ord. No. 2011-003, § 1, 2-23-2011) 
Editor's note- Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 2011-003, adopted Feb. 23, 2011, amended ch. 9.08 by deleting § 9.08.110 and adding in lieu thereof provisions to read as herein set out. Formerly § 9.08.110 pertained to snow removal and derived from § 678.12 of the prior code. 
9.08.120. - Ice removal. 
    Whenever any sidewalk, or any part thereof, adjoining any building or lot of land on any street is encumbered with ice, no owner, occupant or other person having the care of such building or lot shall fail to cause such sidewalks to be made safe and convenient, by removing the ice therefrom or by covering the same with sand or ashes within four hours during the daytime. 
(Prior code § 678.13) 
9.08.130. - Sleeping in public prohibited at certain times. 
    Whenever council declares, by resolution, that the public safety requires that there shall be no sleeping in any public or private area of the city, including beaches, parks, streets and automobiles parked in any public area or any privately owned land opened and used for the temporary parking of vehicles of the general public, then no person shall sleep in any public or private area of the city, except those places which provide sleeping accommodations for transient visitors. 
(Prior code § 678.14) 
Chapter 9.12. - OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS 

9.12.010. - Curfew-Responsibility of parents. 
A.  No person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age shall loiter about any public street, avenue, alley, park or other public place between the hour of eleven p.m. and the time of sunrise of the following day, and no person under the age of sixteen (16) years of age shall loiter about any public street, avenue, alley, park or other public place between the hour of ten p.m. and the time of sunrise of the following day, unless accompanied by his or her parent or legal guardian having legal custody of his or her person, or by his or her spouse over the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
B.  No parent, guardian or other person having legal care, custody or control of any person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall permit such person to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(Prior code § 648.01) 
9.12.020. - Truancy. 
    Every child who has completed or will have completed six years of life on or before December 31st of any school year and has not completed sixteen (16) years of life, who is residing within the city and who does not attend any other school, shall attend the public schools according to law, unless excluded therefrom under and by force of the laws governing the public schools. 
(Ord. 53-94 § 1, 1994: prior code § 648.02) 
9.12.030. - Appointment of truant officers-Duties. 
    Annually during the month of December, the school committee shall appoint one or more truant officers, at such compensation as may be determined from time to time, whose duty it shall be, under the discretion of the school committee, to apprehend without a warrant and take into school all truants whose names are reported by their teachers, to inquire into all cases of violation of the law in regard to the employment and schooling of minors, and to render any other such lawful service connected with the attendance at school as may be required by the school committee. 
(Prior code § 648.03) 
9.12.040. - Notifications-Prosecutions. 
    Truant officers, prior to making any complaint under the law relating to truants and absentees from school, or under this chapter, shall notify the offending party, and, if he or she is a minor, his or her parent or guardian, both of the offense committed and also of the penalty therefor; and if the truant officer can secure satisfactory pledges for the proper compliance with the law, he or she may forbear to prosecute, so long as such pledges are faithfully kept. 
(Prior code § 648.04) 
9.12.050. - Records. 
    Truant officers shall keep a full record of all their official acts and make such reports thereof as may be required by the school committee. 
(Prior code § 648.05) 
9.12.060. - Sale of airplane glue to minors. 
    No person shall sell, offer for sale, give away or distribute "airplane glue," so-called, to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. For the purpose of this section, "airplane glue" is defined as a substance having a chemical composition of acetone and methyl ketone radical. 
(Prior code § 624.01) 
Chapter 9.16. - WEAPONS 

9.16.010. - Air guns prohibited-Exceptions. 
    No person shall use, sell, offer to sell or have in his or her possession an air rifle or air pistol or any similar instrument in which the propelling force is a spring or air, except that such devices used in connection with an amusement licensed by council or at pistol ranges duly authorized by law shall not be considered a violation of this section. 
(Prior code § 696.01) 
9.16.020. - Discharge of air or spring guns. 
    Subject to the qualification made in Section 9.16.010, no person shall fire or discharge within the city any air gun, spring gun or other device which is calculated or intended to propel or project a bullet, pellet or similar projectile. 
(Prior code § 696.02) 
9.16.030. - Switch blade knives, darts and other dangerous toys and weapons. 
A.  No person shall use or have in his or her possession any knife which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle of the knife, any dart of any type, whether or not the point thereof is covered, or any bow and arrow, slingshot, beanblower or other toy or device which propels a projectile or pellet by air, spring, rubber band, explosive substance or other force. 
B.  No person shall sell, offer for sale, give away or distribute any of the weapons and implements referred to in subsection A of this section. 
C.  The provisions of subsections A and B of this section shall not apply to the sale or purchase of any archery equipment by any person licensed by the state to shoot a bow and arrow, or by a member of any duly organized archery club, nor shall such subsections apply to the use of any bow and arrow at any archery range or contest conducted and supervised by a duly organized archery club or other similar organization, nor shall such subsections apply to the sale, purchase or use of any scientific or educational toy, including rocket kits, missiles and other scientific toys of such nature. 
(Prior code § 696.03) 
9.16.040. - Carrying loaded spearguns in public. 
    No person shall possess or carry a loaded weapon, ready to fire, in or on any public park, public beach, public pier or other public place in the city or on any public way in the city. 
(Prior code § 696.04) 
Chapter 9.17. - PUBLIC NUISANCE 

9.17.010. - Public nuisance. 
A.  It shall be considered a public nuisance to conduct a gathering of any number of individuals on any private property in a manner which constitutes a substantial disturbance of the quiet enjoyment of private or public property in a significant segment of a neighborhood, as a result of conduct constituting a violation of law. 
B.  Illustrative of such unlawful conduct for purposes of this ordinance is excessive noise or traffic, obstruction of public streets by crowds or vehicles, illegal parking, public drunkenness, public urination, the service of alcohol to minors, fights, disturbances of the peace and litter; illegal drug activity, and the illegal use of fireworks. 
C.  A public nuisance may be abated by all reasonable means, including, but not limited to, an order requiring any gathering to be disbanded and citation and/or arrest of any law violators under any applicable ordinances and state statutes. 
D.  When the police department intervenes at a gathering as described herein which constitutes a nuisance under this article, notice of said intervention shall be mailed to the property owner on the City of Newport's property tax assessment records and shall advise the property owner that any subsequent such intervention within the twelve (12) month period on the same premises will result in liability of the property owner for all penalties associated with such intervention as more particularly set forth herein. 
E.  If the police department is required to respond to a gathering constituting a public nuisance on the premises more than once in any twelve (12) month period of time, the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for fines as set forth below: 
1.  The person or persons who own the property where the gathering constituting the public nuisance took place, provided that notice has been mailed to the owner of the property as set forth herein, and the gathering occurs at least two weeks after the mailing of such notice. 
2.  The person or persons residing on or otherwise in control of the property where such gathering took place. 
3.  The person or persons who organized or sponsored such gathering. 
4.  All persons attending such gatherings who engage in any activity resulting in the public nuisance. 
    Nothing in this section shall be construed to impose liability on the resident or owners of the premises or sponsor of the gathering, for the conduct of persons who are present without the express or implied consent of the resident or sponsor, as long as the resident and sponsor have taken all steps reasonably necessary to exclude such uninvited participants from the premises, including landlords who are actively attempting to evict a tenant from the premises. 
    Where an uninvited guest engages in conduct which the sponsor or resident could not reasonably foresee and the conduct is an isolated instance of a guest at the event violating the law which the sponsor is unable to reasonably control without the intervention of the police, the unlawful conduct of the individual guest shall not be attributable to the sponsor or resident for the purposes of determining whether the event constitutes a public nuisance under this section." 
(Ord. No. 2013-012, § 1, 9-11-2013) 
9.17.020. - Penalty. 
    A violation of this chapter shall result in a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), at the discretion of the municipal court, plus court costs, and/or community service, or any combination thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2013-012, § 1, 9-11-2013) 
Title 10. - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapter 10.04. - STATE MOTOR VEHICLE CODE ADOPTED 

10.04.010. - State Motor Vehicle Code adopted. 
A.  The state of Rhode Island Motor Vehicle Code, 1988 edition, as amended, and any subsequent amendments thereto, is adopted by the city and its provisions incorporated herein, save and except the specific variations as enumerated in Title 10 of the Codified Ordinances of the city of Newport. 
B.  Any individual who violates or fails or refuses to comply with the Motor Vehicle Code, as amended, shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the Newport municipal court. 
(Ord. 49-90 § 1, 1990: prior code § 500.01) 
Chapter 10.08. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

10.08.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this title, unless otherwise expressly provided: 
    "Authorized emergency vehicle" means vehicles of the fire division (fire patrol), police vehicles, vehicles used by committing officers in the state Department of Corrections and such ambulances and emergency vehicles of municipal departments or public service corporations as are designated or authorized by the chief of police. 
    "Crosswalk" means: 
A.  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs, or in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway; 
B.  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    "Driver" means any operator or chauffeur who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    "Intersection" means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon differing highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
    Where a highway includes two roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting highway also includes two roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of two roadways of such highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    "Motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails, except vehicles moved exclusively by human power. 
    "Official traffic control device" means a sign, signal, marking or other device, not inconsistent with this title, placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    "Official traffic signal" means any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
    "Park," when prohibited, means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading. 
    "Pedestrian" means any person afoot. 
    "Police officer" means every officer of the municipal police division or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    "Private road or driveway" means every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not other persons. 
    "Railroad" means a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than street cars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    "Railroad train" means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except street cars. 
    "Right-of-way" means the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
    "Roadway" means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the sidewalk, berm or shoulder even though such sidewalk, berm or shoulder is used by persons riding bicycles. In the event that a street includes two or more separate roadways, the term roadway shall refer to any such roadway separately, but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    "Safety zone" means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    "Sidewalk" means that portion of a street between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    "Sign" means a sign or appropriate marking on a curb or road. 
    "Standing," when prohibited, means any stopping or standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    "Stop," when required, means complete cessation of movement. 
    "Stop" or "stopping," when prohibited, means any stopping or standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    "Street" or "highway" means the entire width between boundary lines of every way when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
    "Traffic" means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any street for purposes of travel. 
    "Truck" means any motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property. 
    "Vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. 42-96 § 1, 1996; prior code § 420.01) 
10.08.020. - Compliance with title required. 
    No person shall do any act prohibited or fail to perform any act required in this title. 
(Prior code § 422.01) 
10.08.030. - Compliance with orders of police officers. 
    No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer invested by law with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic. 
(Prior code § 422.02) 
10.08.040. - Application of title to drivers of government vehicles. 
    The provisions of this title shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, the state or the city, and no such driver shall violate any of the provisions of this title, except as otherwise permitted in this title or by state statute. 
(Prior code § 422.03) 
10.08.050. - Application of title to drivers of emergency vehicles. 
A.  The provisions of this title regulating the operation, parking and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicles, except that a driver of such a vehicle when operating the same in an emergency, except when otherwise directed by a police officer, may: 
1.  Park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this title; 
2.  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation; 
3.  Exceed the prima facie speed limits so long as he or she does not endanger life or property; and 
4.  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he or she does not endanger life or property. 
B.  The foregoing exemptions shall not, however, protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of his or her reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Prior code § 422.04) 
10.08.060. - Application of title to pushcarts, bicycles and animal riders. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding a bicycle or an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this title applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
(Prior code § 422.05) 
10.08.070. - Obstruction of intersections or crosswalks. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he or she is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Prior code § 460.01) 
10.08.080. - Emerging from alleys or private driveways. 
    The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a sidewalk or into the sidewalk area extending across any alleyway and shall yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians prior to entering the roadway and shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such roadway. 
(Prior code § 460.02) 
10.08.090. - Driving through processions. 
    No driver of a vehicle or operator of a bus shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this title. This provision shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signals or a police officer. 
(Prior code § 460.03) 
10.08.100. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. This section shall have no application to light carriages for the conveyance of children. 
(Prior code § 460.04) 
10.08.110. - Backing a vehicle. 
    No person shall back a vehicle into an intersection or over a crosswalk, or, in any event or at any place, back a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety. 
(Prior code § 460.05) 
10.08.120. - Funerals and other processions. 
A.  A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant of a type designated by the traffic engineer. 
B.  Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and follow the vehicle ahead as closely as is practical and safe. 
(Prior code § 460.06) 
10.08.130. - Boarding or alighting from moving vehicles. 
    No person shall board or alight from any bus or other vehicle while such bus or other vehicle is in motion. 
(Prior code § 460.07) 
10.08.140. - Riding in nonpassenger areas. 
    No person shall ride on any bus or other vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to any employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Prior code § 460.08) 
10.08.150. - Obedience to turning signs. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right, left or "U" turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign, and when authorized marks, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Prior code § 460.09) 
10.08.160. - "U" turns. 
    No person shall turn a vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district, or upon any curve or upon the approach to or near the crest of a grade, where such vehicle cannot be seen by the driver of any other vehicle approaching from either direction within five hundred (500) feet, or upon any other street unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Prior code § 460.10) 
10.08.170. - Crossing fire hose. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle over any unprotected hose of a fire department when laid down on any street or private driveway, to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Prior code § 460.11) 
10.08.180. - Speed restrictions. 
A.  Reasonable and Prudent Speeds. No person shall drive a vehicle on any street, road or highway within the city at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and with regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing. In every event, speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street or roadway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
B.  Prima Facie Limits. Where no special hazard exists that requires lower speed for compliance with subsection A of this section, the speed of any vehicle not in excess of the limit specified in this subsection shall be lawful, but any speed in excess of the limit specified in this subsection shall be prima facie unreasonable and imprudent and therefore unlawful: 
1.  Fifteen (15) miles per hour on the Goat Island Causeway; 
2.  Fifteen (15) miles per hour on Beacon Court; 
3.  Fifteen (15) miles per hour on Cummings Road. 
4.  Twenty (20) miles per hour on Thames Street, from Poplar Street to Marlborough Street. 
(Ord. 2002-24 § 1, 2002; Prior code § 460.115) 
(Ord. No. 2011-024, § 1, 8-24-2011) 
10.08.190. - Alteration of state highway speed limits. 
    Alteration of the speed limit on state highways shall not be effective until such alteration and such highway have been approved by the state traffic commission. 
(Prior code § 460.12) 
10.08.200. - Using vehicles for advertising purposes. 
    No person shall operate or park on any street any vehicle for the purpose of advertising. 
(Prior code § 460.13) 
Chapter 10.12. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

10.12.010. - Duties of director of public safety. 
    It shall be the general duty of the director of public safety to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, to conduct engineering analyses of accidents and to devise remedial measures, to conduct engineering investigation of traffic conditions and to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions. 
(Prior code § 424.01) 
10.12.020. - Duties of traffic engineer-Determination and placement of official traffic control devices. 
A.  The traffic engineer shall place and maintain traffic control devices when and as required under this title to make effective its provisions, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as he or she may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the provisions of this title or under state law or to guide or warn traffic. 
B.  All traffic control devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by resolution adopted by council. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this title shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Prior code § 424.02) 
10.12.030. - Designation of crosswalks, safety zones and traffic lanes. 
    The traffic engineer is authorized to: 
A.  Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where, in his or her opinion, there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he or she may deem necessary; 
B.  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such place as he or she may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians; and 
C.  Mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he or she may deem advisable, consistent with the provisions of this title. 
(Prior code § 424.03) 
10.12.040. - Turning restrictions. 
A.  The traffic engineer is authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right, left or "U" turn and shall place proper signs at such intersections. 
B.  The traffic engineer is authorized to place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections, and such course to be traveled as so indicated may conform to or be other than as prescribed by law or ordinance. 
(Prior code § 424.04) 
10.12.050. - Quiet zones and play streets. 
A.  The traffic engineer is authorized to establish a temporary zone of quiet upon any street where a person is seriously ill if requested to do so by the written statement of at least one registered physician certifying to its necessity. Such temporary zone of quiet shall embrace all territory within a radius of two hundred (200) feet of the building occupied by the person named in the request of such physician. Such temporary zone of quiet and any other zone of quiet declared by any ordinance shall be designated by the traffic engineer by placing at a conspicuous place in the street a sign or marking bearing the words "Quiet Zone." 
B.  The traffic engineer is authorized to declare any street or part thereof a "play street" and to place appropriate signs or devices in the roadway indicating and helping to protect the same. 
(Prior code § 424.05) 
10.12.060. - Parking regulations. 
A.  Schools. The traffic engineer is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon that side of any street adjacent to any school property when such parking would, in his or her opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
B.  Angle Parking. The traffic engineer shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets. 
C.  Narrow Streets. The traffic engineer is authorized to erect signs indicating no parking upon any street when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty (20) feet or upon one side of a street as indicated by such signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed thirty (30) feet. 
D.  Hazardous Areas. The traffic engineer is authorized to determine and designate by proper signs distances not exceeding one hundred (100) feet at places where the stopping or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay in traffic. 
E.  Parking for Handicapped Persons. The director of engineering and inspections is authorized to determine and designate parking spaces to be reserved for the handicapped with vehicles displaying the required state certificate, and shall properly post the requisite signs therefor. 
(Prior code § 424.06) 
10.12.070. - Stop and yield signs. 
A.  Whenever any provision of this title or other ordinance designates and describes a through way it shall be the duty of the traffic engineer to place and maintain, at his or her discretion, either a stop sign or a yield sign on each and every street intersecting such through way or that portion thereof described and designated as such. 
B.  The traffic engineer is authorized to determine and designate intersections where a particular hazard exists upon other than through ways and to determine whether vehicles shall stop at one or more entrances to any such stop intersection and he or she shall erect a stop sign at every such place where a stop is required. 
C.  The traffic engineer is authorized to determine intersections where vehicles shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles on a different street or highway at such intersections and he or she shall cause to be erected a yield sign at every place where obedience thereto is required. 
(Prior code § 424.07) 
10.12.080. - One-way street and no parking signs. 
    Whenever, by this title or by any other ordinance, a one-way street is described or parking is prohibited or limited, the traffic engineer shall erect appropriate signs or markings giving notice thereof on the pavements or curbs. 
(Prior code § 424.08) 
10.12.090. - Temporary rules-Variances to suit special conditions. 
A.  The director of public services, by and with the approval of the council, may make temporary rules regulating traffic or may test traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. No such experimental rule regulating traffic shall remain in effect for more than thirty (30) days, except as otherwise provided in paragraph C., of this section. 
B.  Whenever certain conditions exist, such as construction work, parades, extreme weather conditions, etc., then the director of public safety is authorized to alter the flow of traffic and any and all traffic regulations as he or she deems best in the public interest to meet the needs of the conditions that exist, first giving such public notice of the temporary changes as is possible. 
C.  Hazard Road shall be closed to vehicular traffic from December 1 through March 31 of each year, and on any day between March 31 and December 1 when conditions warrant its closure, as determined by the director of public services. 
(Prior code § 424.09) 
(Ord. No. 2010-02, § 1, 1-27-2010) 
Chapter 10.16. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 

10.16.010. - Obedience to official traffic control devices. 
A.  The driver of any vehicle and the operator of any bus shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with this title and other traffic ordinances of the city unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in this title. 
B.  No provision of this title for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective without signs being erected to give notice thereof. 
(Prior code § 442.01) 
10.16.020. - Traffic control signal legend. 
    Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting the words "go," "caution" or "stop," or exhibiting different colored lights successively one at a time, or with arrows, the following colors only shall be used and such terms and lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
A.  Green Alone or "Go." 
1.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. But vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited. 
2.  Pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
B.  Yellow Alone or "Caution" When Shown Following the Green or "Go" Signal. 
1.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering an intersection on a red or "stop" signal, which will be exhibited immediately thereafter. Such vehicle traffic shall not enter or be crossing the intersection when the red or "stop" signal is exhibited. 
2.  Pedestrians facing such signal are thereby advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway, and any pedestrian then starting to cross shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles. 
C.  Red Alone or "Stop." 
1.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection, and shall remain standing until the green or "go" is shown alone, and shall not, prior to reaching such intersection, make any turn over or through private property in order to avoid such signal; provided, however, that a right-hand turn shall be permitted after vehicular traffic reaches a complete stop, at intersections when safety would permit such a turn and no sign forbids it. 
2.  No pedestrians facing such signal shall enter the roadway unless he or she can do so safely and without interfering with any vehicular traffic. 
D.  Red With Green Arrow. 
1.  Vehicular traffic facing the signal may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow, but shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within a crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
2.  No pedestrian facing such signal shall enter the roadway unless he or she can do so safely and without interfering with any vehicular traffic. 
(Prior code § 442.02) 
10.16.030. - Flashing signals. 
    Whenever an illuminated flashing red or yellow signal is used in a traffic sign or signal it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
A.  Flashing Red (Stop Signal). When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at a limit line when marked, or, if none, then before entering the intersection, and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
B.  Flashing Yellow (Caution Signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
C.  Flashing Green (Pedestrian Signal). When a green lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or crosswalk past such a signal only with caution. 
(Prior code § 442.03) 
Chapter 10.20. - PARKING GENERALLY 

10.20.010. - Responsibility of owners. 
    No person shall allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his or her name to stand or park in any street in the city in violation of any of the provisions of this title or other ordinances of the city regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
    The illegal use of handicapped parking spaces, the standards of which are defined in the Rhode Island General Laws, shall be subject to towing and a fine of not less than one hundred ($100.00) dollars in accordance with said General Laws. 
    No person shall allow a truck with a tare weight in excess of five thousand five hundred (5,500) pounds to idle its engine for more than five minutes at any time while it is parked or standing on any city street or right-of-way throughout the City, including those areas designated in Chapter 10.68 of this code as loading zones. 
(Ord. 2004-38 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2004-29 § 2, 2004; Prior code § 480.01) 
(Ord. No. 2012-006, § 1, 3-28-2012) 
10.20.020. - Parking in narrow streets. 
    When signs prohibiting parking are erected on narrow streets, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Prior code § 480.02) 
10.20.030. - Parking so as to leave less than ten (10) feet for traffic. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic, except that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or personal property, such stop not to exceed five minutes at any one time and such driver to move immediately if any other vehicle is obstructed from using such roadway, and except that a driver may stop when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations, traffic signs or signals or a police officer. 
(Prior code § 480.03) 
10.20.040. - Stopping or parking near hazardous or congested places. 
    When signs are erected upon the approach to hazardous or congested places, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Prior code § 480.04) 
10.20.050. - Parking adjacent to schools. 
    When signs are erected indicating that no parking is permitted upon that side of a street adjacent to school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Prior code § 480.05) 
10.20.060. - Parallel and angle parking. 
A.  No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic and with the curb side wheels of the vehicle within twelve (12) inches of the edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided herein. 
B.  Upon those streets that have been marked or signed for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such mark or signs. 
(Prior code § 480.06) 
10.20.070. - Parking in marked or signed areas. 
    Parking shall be parallel except where otherwise marked. Parking on all streets which have been marked or signed shall be within the area indicated by such mark or sign. No vehicle shall occupy more than one space so marked or signed. 
(Prior code § 480.07) 
10.20.080. - Double parking prohibited.
