    No person shall double park a vehicle on any street at any time. 
(Prior code § 480.08) 
10.20.090. - Parking for longer than twenty-four hours prohibited. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on any street for longer than twenty-four (24) hours on any day or night. 
(Prior code § 480.09) 
10.20.100. - Street sweeping streets. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on any street between the hours of twelve midnight and eight a.m. when the street is posted with a sign indicating street sweeping. 
(Prior code § 480.10) 
10.20.110. - Parking vehicles for sale or repair on streets. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
A.  Displaying it for sale; 
B.  Greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; or 
C.  Storing such vehicle while it is awaiting repairs. 
(Prior code § 480.11) 
10.20.120. - Parking prohibited in specified places-Unauthorized moving in prohibited areas. 
A.  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
1.  On a sidewalk; 
2.  In front of a public or private driveway, or within five feet of either side thereof; 
3.  Within an intersection; 
4.  Within eight feet of a fire hydrant; 
5.  On a crosswalk; 
6.  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; and, for oncoming traffic at non-intersection crosswalks, within fifteen (15) feet of a crosswalk where there is diagonal parking, and within ten feet of a crosswalk where there is parallel parking; 
7.  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
8.  In front of any place of public worship while any service is being carried on; 
9.  On the left side of any street, unless otherwise permitted under this chapter; 
10.  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings; 
11.  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; 
12.  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within seventy-five (75) feet of such entrance when properly sign-posted; 
13.  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
14.  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
15.  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway; 
16.  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping; or 
17.  On any roadway adjacent to a curb painted yellow. 
B.  No person shall move a vehicle not owned by such person into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
C.  It is unlawful to alter, cover, deface, paint over, or otherwise compromise or change a city-installed or sanctioned curb marking or other traffic control sign, marking or designation. 
D.  It is unlawful for any person or persons not authorized or sanctioned by the city to paint, alter, duplicate, or create a yellow curb marking, or any other traffic control or public safety device, sign or designation. 
(Ord. 2008-9 § 1, 2008; Ord. 2000-34 § 1, 2000; prior code § 480.12) 
10.20.130. - Snow removal. 
A.  The director of public safety is authorized to eliminate all parking of automobiles on certain streets for certain limited periods to facilitate the removal of snow from such streets. Motor vehicles parked on such a street one-half hour after the public ban has been announced may be towed to a place of storage at the owner's expense. 
B.  Pursuant to subsection A of this section, the director of public safety is directed to mark the following streets as tow zones for emergency snow removal work: 
    Annandale; 
    Bedlow Avenue; 
    Bellevue Avenue: Kay Street to Bowery Street; 
    Bliss Road; 
    Broadway; 
    Coggeshall Avenue; 
    East Bowery Street; 
    Farewell Street; 
    Friendship Street; 
    Gibbs Avenue; 
    Gould Street; 
    Kay Street; 
    Powell Avenue; 
    Spring Street; 
    Summer Street; 
    Thames Street; 
    Third Street; 
    Van Zandt Avenue, from J.T. Connell Memorial Road east to Malbone Road; 
    Warner Street; 
    Washington Square; 
    Washington Street; 
    West Marlborough Street; 
    West Narragansett Avenue; 
    William Street. 
(Ord. 2004-7 § 1, 2004; Ord. 67-94 § 1, 1994; prior code § 480.13) 
(Ord. 2016-05, § 1, 1-27-2016) 
10.20.140. - Parking boat trailers. 
A.  No boat trailer of any size, shape or description shall be parked on a public highway in the city, whether attached to a motor vehicle or unattached. Boat trailers attached to motor vehicles and boat trailers shall be parked only at the King Park parking lot. The director of public services shall further establish proper signs designating the manner, time and mode of parking such motor vehicles with boat trailers and boat trailers, effective May 1st through October 15th of each year. 
B.  All persons using the boat launching facilities at King Park and parking a motor vehicle with boat trailer or boat trailer at the King Park parking lot or in the designated area on Wellington Avenue shall first apply to the department of economic development for a parking sticker which shall be affixed to the boat trailer in a manner designated by the department. For each trailer parking sticker, there shall be a twenty-five-dollar ($25.00) charge for residents of the city; all other persons shall pay a seasonal charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each parking sticker. 
(Ord. 2008-29 § 1, 2008: Ord. 30-95 § 1, 1995) 
(Ord. No. 2010-26, § 1, 7-14-2010) 
10.20.150. - Parking trailers for more than two hours prohibited. 
A.  No person shall park or leave a trailer, either alone or attached to another conveyance, on a street or public highway in the city for longer than two hours in any twenty-four (24) hour period. 
B.  As used in this section, "trailer" means any structure or vehicle used or intended to be used or capable of being used as permanent or temporary living quarters by any person, which structure or vehicle is mounted upon wheels and may be moved from place to place either by its own power or power supplied by some vehicle attached to it or to be attached to it. 
(Prior code § 480.15) 
10.20.160. - Unregistered and junk vehicles. 
A.  No person shall deposit, store or keep, or permit to be deposited, stored or kept, in the open on public property, a dismantled, unserviceable, junked or abandoned vehicle, a vehicle legally or physically incapable of being operated or a vehicle that is not displaying a current safety inspection certificate on its windshield. 
B.  Dismantled, junked or abandoned vehicles shall be deemed to include major parts thereof, including bodies, engines, transmissions, rear ends, etc. 
C.  Public property shall include property owned by the city or the state, property acquired by the city at tax sales and all streets and highways in the city, whether or not they are public highways. 
D.  Any person, firm or corporation in violation of this section shall be guilty of an offense punishable by a fine not to exceed the maximum allowable in Newport municipal court and/or thirty (30) days in jail. 
E.  All provisions and definitions contained in Section 31-42-1 of the General Laws of Rhode Island, as amended, are hereby incorporated and made a part of this section by reference as if fully rewritten herein. 
(Ord. 2-94 § 1, 1994; prior code § 480.17) 
10.20.170. - Towing by police division. 
    The police division and all members thereof are authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service, in accordance with Chapter 5.92, the following: 
A.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle parked in any place where such parked vehicle creates or constitutes a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle; 
B.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle so parked on a street or public right-of-way as to prevent access and egress from a recognized curb-cut, if that area of the street or public right-of-way is so marked or signed or is a designated curb-cut; 
C.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle parked on any of the following designated streets, public rights-of-way or fire lanes during the hours when parking thereon is prohibited, provided that such street, or part thereof, public right-of-way or fire lane is marked or signed as a tow zone: 
1.  All fire lanes designated pursuant to Section 8.08.140, 
2.  Bellevue Avenue turnaround at the intersection of Ocean Avenue,

15.  East Street, east side,

F.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle parked in a designated loading zone contrary to Section 10.68.020, provided such loading zone is marked or signed as a tow zone;

Any vehicle not bearing a legal resident sticker, visitor pass, or temporary permit that is parked on a designated residential parking street which receives a violation notice and is not moved prior to the next twelve (12) hour period of resident-only parking; and on those streets where resident-only parking is in effect twenty-four (24) hours, if the vehicle is not moved within twenty-four (24) hours of receipt of a violation notice; 
I.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle not bearing an official city of Newport parking pass that is parked in the Edward Street Parking Lot between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m., Monday through Friday;

K.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle parked in designated "Library Staff" parking spaces in Aquidneck Park, shall be subject to tow, daily, between the hours of nine a.m. and nine p.m., provided such spaces are duly signed as tow zones; 
L.  Any unauthorized motor vehicle parked between eight a.m. and six p.m., Monday through Friday, in a space designated for court personnel shall be towed, provided such spaces are duly signed as tow zones. 
M.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle parked in designated "valet parking" spaces shall be subject to tow, provided such spaces are duly signed as tow zones. 
N.  Any motor vehicle or other vehicle parked in a designated accessible parking space, the standards of which are defined in the Rhode Island General Law, shall be subject to tow, provided such space is duly signed as accessible parking. 
(Ord. 2007-42 § 1, 2007; Ord. 2003-49 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2003-15 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2002-19 § 1, 2002; Ord. 99-35 § 1, 1999; Ord. 11-96 § 1, 1996; Ord. 16-95 § 1, 1995; Ord. 68-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 37-91 § 1, 1991; Ord. 36-91 § 1, 1991; Ord. 20-91 §§ 1, 2, 1991; Ord. 25-90 § 1, 1990; Ord. 28-89 § 1, 1989; prior code § 480.18) 
(Ord. No. 2011-022, § 1, 8-10-2011; Ord. No 2012-006, § 1, 3-28-2012)

10.20.190. - Spaces with special provisions. 
A.  Parking spaces approved, designated and restricted by the city to handicap usage shall not be metered. 
B.  Metered parking in designated loading zone spaces shall not be in effect weekdays until eleven-thirty a.m. 
C.  Metered parking on Thames Street in the vicinity of the Post Office Street shall not be in effect weekdays until six p.m., and on Saturdays until one p.m. 
(Ord. 20-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 496.02) 
10.20.200. - Regulation of parking in metered areas. 
A.  Each meter shall be so constructed as to display a signal showing legal parking upon the deposit therein of the proper coin or coins of the United States, or a valid credit card, as indicated by instructions on said meters. 
B.  Whenever any vehicle shall be parked adjacent to a parking meter or within a designated parking meter area, the owner or operator of said vehicle shall park within the space designated by pavement marking lines and, upon entering such space, shall immediately deposit in said meter the required coin or coins of the United States or a valid credit card for the maximum legal parking period, or portion thereof, as indicated or shown on the meter, or by display on the vehicle windshield of a valid receipt where the metered area is designated as "pay-and-display," and, if so required, set the meter in motion. 
C.  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in a parking meter any coin for the purpose of permitting the vehicle of which he or she is in charge to remain in a parking space beyond the maximum period of time otherwise established by other parking provisions contained elsewhere in this code. 
D.  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle within a metered parking space unless said vehicle is wholly within the space so designated for that purpose. 
E.  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to tamper with, break, injure or destroy any parking meter or to deposit or cause to be deposited in such meter any slugs, device or metallic substance or any other substitute for the coins required. 
(Ord. 20-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 496.03) 
(Ord. No. 2014-010, § 1, 4-23-2014) 
10.20.210. - Meter charges. 
A.  Payment for parking in designated parking meter areas at the rate established by this chapter shall be for the time period of May 1st through October 31st of each year. Such period shall be defined as "the season" for the purpose of this title. 
B.  During said season, meters shall not be in operation between the hours of nine p.m. and nine a.m. 
C.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection D of this section, the fee for the maximum parking time shall be one dollar and twenty-five cents ($1.25) per hour, at increments of twenty-five cents ($0.25) for twelve (12) minutes. 
D.  The fee for the maximum parking time on Memorial Boulevard at Easton's Beach (described in Section 10.20.180(B)(12) shall be two dollars ($2.00) per hour, at increments of fifty cents ($0.50) per fifteen (15) minutes, the revenue from which shall be deposited into the Easton's Beach Enterprise Fund. 
E.  When at such time as the city permits the reservation of a metered parking space or spaces for a special event, construction work, or for any other reason deemed acceptable to the city, a flat fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per day shall be paid to the city for each reserved metered parking space. Said flat fee shall not be prorated based upon the number of hours said space is reserved within a twenty-four (24) hour period. 
(Ord. 2008-7 § 1, 2008; Ord. 2007-18 § 1, 2007; Ord. 2000-12 § 1, 2000; Ord. 3-96 § 1 (part), 1996; Ord. 20-94 § 1 (part), 1994: prior code § 496.04) 
(Ord. No. 2012-001, § 1, 1-11-2012) 
10.20.220. - Parking permits for fishing vehicles-Purpose. 
    The provisions of Sections 10.20.220 through 10.20.250 are enacted to provide parking for legitimate fishermen in areas where parking has otherwise been prohibited in an effort to promote the peace, comfort, convenience and welfare of the residents and visitors to the city. 
(Ord. 51-89 § 1 (part), 1989) 
10.20.230. - Designation of permitted parking for fishing vehicles. 
    The city council may allow parking for fishermen in areas where parking is otherwise restricted or prohibited by amending Chapter 10.24 of the Codified Ordinances, entitled, Parking Restrictions on Specific Streets, to reflect where such parking for fishermen shall be allowed. These streets shall include certain areas, as defined in Chapter 10.24, of Ledge Road, Ruggles Avenue, Webster Street and Wetmore Avenue. 
(Ord. 2006-31 § 1 (part), 2006) 
10.20.240. - Fishing vehicle parking permits. 
A.  The city, through its collection office, shall issue "City of Newport Fishing Vehicle Parking Permits" upon presentation of a valid vehicle registration, which shall be recorded by the collection office, and payment of a ten-dollar fee for property owners and those whose vehicles carry a Rhode Island registration with a Newport address and a sixty dollar ($60.00) fee for all others. 
B.  The issuance of such fishing vehicle parking permits shall occur only during the time period of September through April of each year and shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance; however, military personnel deployed in defense of our country during the permit issuance period may, upon their return, apply for such fishing vehicle permit. 
C.  Fishing vehicle parking permits shall be displayed on the dashboards of vehicles in such a manner that they may be easily inspected by the Newport police department. 
D.  Fishing vehicle parking permits shall not be limited to residents of the city. 
E.  Fishing vehicle parking permits shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. 2006-31 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 2003-45 § 1, 2003; Ord. 51-89 § 1 (part), 1989) 
10.20.250. - Revocation of permits. 
    In addition to the penalties set forth in Section 10.20.260, the city manager shall have the responsibility and authority to revoke the fishing vehicle parking permit issued to any person or persons for the abuse of such parking permit, or for the use of the same in a manner contrary to any of the provisions of this chapter. Revocation of the fishing vehicle parking permit of a permit-holder, or conviction of a permit-holder of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be considered just cause for denial of a future fishing vehicle parking permit to a permit-holder. 
(Ord. 51-89 § 1 (part), 1989) 
Chapter 10.22 - VALET PARKING 

10.22.010. - Purpose; permit and license required. 
A.  The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Reduce the disruption of vehicular and pedestrian traffic that valet parking service operations may create; 
(2)  Minimize hazardous conditions that valet parking service operations may create in order to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public; 
(3)  Promote the safe and legal operation of valet parking services for the use and convenience of businesses and the general public. 
B.  No person(s), business, or other entity shall operate a valet parking program, as described in this chapter, on public property without first obtaining a permit, as defined herein, and paying the fee therefor to the city clerk. This requirement shall not prohibit the operation of a valet parking service that operates exclusively on private property. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
10.22.020. - Definitions. 
    "Officer" means police and code enforcement officer. 
    "Permit" means the receipt of a valet parking permit under the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
    "Permittee/operator" means valet company and its employees. 
    "Tandem parking" means the storage of vehicles, irrespective of how configured, that requires moving at least one other vehicle in order to reach the vehicle sought. 
    "Valet parking service area or ramping" means the public right-of-way to be utilized for the valet parking service. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
10.22.030. - Boundaries. 
    Valet parking service shall only be permitted within the following zones: Waterfront business, general business, traditional maritime, commercial/industrial, and limited business. Exceptions to the zoning restrictions may be made by the city council for businesses currently permitted to operate a legal nonconforming use. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
10.22.040. - Permit fee; exceptions. 
    The annual permit fee for establishing or maintaining a valet parking service shall be one hundred twenty dollars ($120.00) from the effective date, paid to the city clerk or, in the alternative, in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for a one-time event fee for a one day permit. 
Ramping Fee: 
A.  If the operation of the valet parking service requires the rental of metered parking spaces or area, the permittee/operator shall also pay a ramping fee of the daily rate established by the city per metered parking space. 
B.  The city manager, or his/her designee, may waive said permit fee and ramping fee for valet parking service exclusively serving a city-owned and operated facility. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
10.22.050. - Permit application. 
A.  Application for a permit to conduct a valet parking service shall be made at the city clerk's office in a form deemed appropriate by the city. Such application shall include, but not limited to, the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the proposed permittee/operator. If incorporated, permittee/operator must provide copies of their articles of incorporation and bylaws; 
(2)  Copy of current liability insurance in accordance with the provisions of this Code; 
(3)  Site plan (at an appropriate scale) showing the proposed tandem parking arrangement, if any, the lay-out and dimensions of the existing public right-of-way and adjacent private property, proposed location, size of proposed mobile stands, tables, chairs, umbrellas, key-box, location of doorways, location of trees, parking meters, bus shelters, sidewalk benches, trash receptacles, driveways, and any other sidewalk obstruction either existing or proposed within the pedestrian areas. Under no circumstances shall permanent structures or equipment be permitted. The site plan shall clearly identify the valet parking service area, and shall also show the proposed location, number of parking stalls, distance to the off-street parking facility providing the parking spaces for the valet parking service, and the route(s) to be used to transport vehicles to and from the drop-off site and the vehicle storage site. 
(4)  Photographs, drawings, or manufacturers' brochures fully describing the appearance of proposed mobile stands, tables, chairs, umbrellas, key-box or other objects related to the valet parking service. 
(5)  Copy of the agreement/contract for the provision of the off-street parking spaces that includes identification of the location of vehicle storage spaces. 
B.  Applications shall be accompanied by an annual nonrefundable application fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
C.  Applications shall be forwarded by the city clerk to other departments within the city which may be affected by the granting of the permit, including, but not limited to, public works, building, planning and zoning, police, and fire. The city departments shall, within ten (10) business days, review and submit comments on the application(s) back to the city clerk. 
D.  Within thirty (30) calendar days of receipt of a completed application, the city council shall approve or deny the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
10.22.060. - Permit requirements, restrictions and when not permitted. 
A.  Permits shall be issued only for pedestrian areas and public right-of-way under the maintenance and jurisdiction of the City of Newport. 
B.  Valet parking service shall be operated only by individuals, businesses, entities licensed by the City of Newport for said business activities. 
C.  Permits shall be issued only to permittees/operators that provide certification, in a format approved by the city council, that they have procured sufficient accessible off-street parking spaces for their valet parking services. On-street parking spaces shall not be included in the computation of sufficient parking spaces for valet parking. 
D.  A permit shall not be issued when another valet parking permit has already been issued for a valet parking area immediately adjacent to the proposed permit area. Furthermore, a permit shall not be issued when the proposed permit area is on the same city block of another valet parking area, unless authorized by the city manager. 
E.  Permits or copy of valid permit must be at valet ramping area at all times. 
F.  The city reserves the right to deny an application if the director of public safety determines that it is likely to create a public safety risk or hazard, or unreasonably impedes pedestrian or vehicular traffic flow. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
10.22.070. - Standards and criteria for application review. 
    The following standards and criteria shall be used in reviewing the application required in section 10.22.050. 
(1)  The location of the valet parking service area is restricted to existing designated on-street parking spaces, or other sites approved by the director of public safety. 
(2)  The width of the valet parking service area shall comprise a minimum of three parking spaces (approximately sixty (60) linear feet). 
(3)  Mobile stands, tables, chairs, umbrellas, key-boxes and any other objects necessary for the operation of the valet parking service shall be located on the sidewalk in such a manner that a minimum six-foot wide clear pedestrian path is maintained at all times. In areas of congested pedestrian activity, the director is authorized to require a wider pedestrian path, as circumstances dictate. Under no circumstances shall permanent structures or equipment be permitted. 
(4)  Mobile stands, tables, chairs, umbrellas, key-boxes and any other objects necessary for the operation of the valet parking service shall be of quality design, materials, and workmanship, both to ensure the safety and convenience of users, and to enhance the visual and aesthetic quality of the urban environment. Design, materials, and colors shall be sympathetic and harmonious with an urban environment. 
(5)  Permits will not be issued where the drop-off and pick-up of vehicles interferes with the safe traffic operation of driveways, street intersections, crosswalks or other prohibited areas. 
(6)  Permits will not be issued where stacking of drop-off and pick-up of vehicles interferes with the safe traffic operation on adjacent streets or unduly delays normal traffic operations. 
(7)  Tandem storage of vehicles arrangements will be evaluated for meeting technical standards. 
(8)  The director of public safety may deny, or required modification of any application based on his/her judgment that the proposed site and/or proposed operation is likely to create an impairment to public safety, impedes safe and efficient pedestrian or vehicle traffic flow, or otherwise interferes with the operation of area businesses or commerce. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011) 
10.22.080. - Liability and insurance. 
A.  Prior to the issuance of a permit, the permittee /operator shall furnish the City of Newport with a signed statement that the permittee/operator shall hold harmless, indemnify and defend the City of Newport, its officers and employees for any claims for damages to property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by any activity carried on under the terms of the permit. 
B.  Permittee shall furnish and maintain such public liability and property damage insurance to protect from all claims and damage to property or bodily injury, including death, which may arise from operations under the permit or in connection therewith. Such insurance shall be provided from an insurance company with an A.M. Best rating of not less than "A" and a financial strength rating that has a positive outlook, and shall provide coverage of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury and property damage respectively per occurrence. Such insurance shall be without prejudice to coverage otherwise existing therein and shall name as additional insured the City of Newport and shall further provide that the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the completion of the permit period without forty-five (45) days' written notice to the City of Newport at the address shown in the permit. Additionally, permittee shall provide "garage or lot keepers" legal liability insurance providing collision and comprehensive coverage for vehicles under the control of the valet parking operator with a minimum of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per location with a maximum self-insured retention (SIR) or deductible of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
C.  The permittee/operator shall provide proof of all required insurance prior to receiving the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010) 
10.22.090. - Form and conditions of permit. 
    The permit shall be issued on a form deemed suitable by the city. In addition to naming the permittee/operator, the conditions set forth in preceding sections of this chapter, and any other information deemed appropriate by the city, the permit shall also contain the following conditions: 
(1)  Each permit shall be valid for a period of up to one year, and shall expire on December 1 of each calendar [year]. Any renewal of a permit shall require compliance with all requirements for permits in the same manner as an original application. 
(2)  The permit issued shall be personal to the permittee only and shall not be transferable in any manner. 
(3)  The permit may be temporarily suspended by the city for a "community" or "special event". Advance notice will be provided to permittees whenever practical. 
(4)  The city may require the temporary removal or relocation of valet parking service when street, sidewalk, or utility repairs necessitate such action. 
(5)  The fire department or the police department may immediately remove or relocate all or parts of the valet parking service in emergency situations. Officers of the police department are hereby authorized to direct traffic, including drop-off and pick-up vehicles, as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter or other applicable traffic ordinances. 
(6)  Under no circumstances shall the city, its officers and employees be deemed responsible or liable in any way for any damage or loss resulting from the removal of the permittee/operator equipment and other objects necessary for the operation of the valet parking service during emergencies. Furthermore, the permittee/operator agrees and acknowledges by accepting a permit issued pursuant to this chapter that the city, its officers and employees are to be held harmless in connection with its actions under this section. 
(7)  The permit shall be specifically limited to the area shown on the approved site plan attached to and made part of the permit. 
(8)  The permittee /operator shall use positive action to assure that its use of the sidewalk in no way interferes with sidewalk users or limits their free unobstructed passage. 
(9)  Mobile stands, tables, chairs, umbrellas, keyboxes and any other objects necessary for the operation of the valet parking service shall be maintained with a clean and attractive appearance and shall be in good repair at all times and removed at the close of business each day. 
(10)  The sidewalk area covered by the permit shall be maintained in a neat and orderly appearance at all times and the area shall be cleared of all debris on a periodic basis during the day, and again at the close of each business day. 
(11)  No advertising signs shall be permitted on the sidewalk or in the public right-of-way; this shall not prohibit the use of one business identification sign located on the sidewalk, bearing no advertising and not exceeding five square feet in area, to be affixed to the valet parking service stand to identify "Valet Parking". 
(12)  No mobile stands, tables, chairs, umbrellas, keyboxes or any other objects necessary for the operation of the valet parking service shall be attached, chained, or in any manner affixed to any tree, post, sign, or other fixtures, curb or sidewalk within or near the permitted area. All valet parking service objects necessary for the operation of the valet parking service, other than required traffic cones, shall be located no closer than thirty (30) inches behind the face of curb on the sidewalk. 
(13)  The permit covers only the pedestrian and public right-of-way. Valet parking services and objects necessary for the operation of the valet parking service located on private property shall be governed by other applicable city regulations. 
(14)  The permittee/operator shall provide written notification to the city manager and the chief of police when operation of the valet parking service begins. Said notice shall be delivered within twenty-four (24) hours of such commencement. 
(15)  Hours of operation shall be 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010) 
10.22.100. - Valet permittees/operators code of conduct; required customer protection regulations. 
    Permittees/operators shall require their employees and independent contractors to meet the following requirements: 
(1)  All employees who operate motor vehicles shall have in their possession a valid Rhode Island driver's license in good standing and shall abide by all city, and state traffic regulations. 
(2)  All employees shall be in similar uniform. 
(3)  All employees shall wear on their uniform a name tag identifying the employee's name and the name of the valet operator/company. 
(4)  All employees shall perform their duties in a courteous and professional manner. 
(5)  All employees must comply with the requirements of this chapter and all applicable laws, statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations relating to traffic safety. 
(6)  Pricing for services shall be identified on any "signage" used by the valet operator. The size print of the foregoing information shall be equal to the largest size print used on any 'signage' used to identify the service or valet operator. Claim tickets shall also indicate the price for the service. The print size of the foregoing shall be equal to that used for any other information displayed on the ticket. 
(7)  The claim ticket shall identify the valet operator's company name, correspondence address and a phone number for questions/complaints. All of the foregoing print shall be of equal size. 
(Ord. No. 2010-10, § 1, 5-12-2010) 
10.22.110. - Operational regulations and restrictions for valet parking service. 
A.  The public on-street/curbside parking spaces, metered or nonmetered, shall only be used for ramping of vehicles. Ramping of vehicles shall consist of allowing the customer to enter or exit a vehicle and to turn it over to or retrieve it from a valet parking operator employee. Ramping shall only be permitted and operated in the public on-street/curbside spaces provided by the city for ramping. There shall be no storage of vehicles in the area used for ramping. A vehicle will be considered stored if it remains in the ramping area for more than ten minutes. Ramping spaces shall not be blocked by any type of sign, structure or other type of object. These spaces shall not be cordoned off by any type of signage, rope or barrier of any kind; 
B.  The permittee/operator shall maintain a key control booth at all valet parking locations until all cars have been claimed; or the permittee/operator shall have a 24-hour phone number for after hours vehicle pick up information; 
C.  The permittee/operator shall not load or unload passengers within traffic lanes that are open to through traffic; 
D.  The valet parking service shall not interfere with the regular flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
E.  The operator of a valet parking business shall be responsible for the cost of labor and materials associated with the city's installation of, and removal of, signage designating an approved valet parking service area, which signage shall also indicate that it is a tow zone for non-authorized vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-021, § 1, 8-10-2011) 
10.22.120. - Department denial, revocation, or suspension of permit; removal of equipment or personal property of the permittee/operator and storage fees. 
A.  The city council or their designee may deny, revoke, or suspend a permit for any valet parking service authorized in the city if it is found that: 
(1)  The permittee/operator has not maintained required insurance; 
(2)  The city council determines that the operation of a valet parking service, due to changing or changed conditions of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, cause congestion necessitating removal of valet parking service which endangers the health, safety or welfare of persons or property; unreasonably interferes with pedestrian or vehicular traffic; unreasonably interferes with the use of any pole, sign, fire hydrant, traffic signal or other object already permitted at or near the valet parking service area; or otherwise not in the public interest; 
(3)  The permittee/operator has failed to correct violations of this section or conditions of the permit within three days of the city manager's notice of same being delivered in writing to the permittee at the address shown on the permit application; 
(4)  If permittee/operator is found in violation of the same offense three times within a permit period; 
(5)  The permittee/operator made any false statements or omission of material fact on the application, site plan or elsewhere in connection with securing a permit. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010) 
10.22.130. - Special events and residential areas. 
A.  Valet Service-Special Event. Valet services operating for a special event may apply for a special event permit. Special event parking shall be restricted to any event occurring no more than twice per year and lasting no longer than three days in length. 
    The special event permit will allow the valet operator to request from the city, additional ramping and/or storage space, if available, as long as it does not reduce the number of parking spaces needed to serve the general public in the area of the request. 
B.  Special event permits are distinct from annual valet parking permits, as described in this title. Holders of annual permits are not permitted to operate special events from their permitted site to the extent that such activity would exceed the typical customer volume, parking storage capacity, potential traffic delays or congestion, or other elements defined in their annual application. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 5-12-2010; Ord. No. 2011-002, § 1, 2-9-2011)

Chapter 10.28. - PUBLIC PARKING LOTS 

10.28.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, "public parking lot" means a parcel of land owned or operated by the city upon which the public is allowed to park motor vehicles for a specified period of time. 
(Prior code § 490.01) 
10.28.020. - Designation or acquisition of land for public parking. 
    Council may, upon request of the director of public safety, designate city-owned land for public parking purposes and may authorize the city manager to negotiate for city control of private property for public parking purposes. 
(Prior code § 490.02) 
10.28.030. - Fees and regulation. 
    Council may, upon request of the director of public safety, establish fees and regulations for public parking as it may deem proper. However, prior to the effective date of such fees and regulations, a statement shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and with the chief of police setting forth such fees and regulations, and such fees and regulations shall be published in a local newspaper. 
    The city administration may negotiate the use of parking lot space at all city-owned parking lots and facilities to not-for-profit, religious, or other charitable or special-purpose organizations at a reduced or no-charge rate, provided the reduced rate or no-fee parking does not compromise the effective utilization of the lot. 
(Ord. 2008-13 § 2, 2008; prior code § 490.03) 
10.28.040. - Unlawful parking. 
    No person shall park a motor vehicle in a public parking lot except in accordance with duly adopted fees and regulations. 
(Prior code § 490.04) 
10.28.050. - Mary Street parking lot. 
    The Mary Street parking lot is for use as a parking facility. Use of the parking lot for transit between Church Street and Mary Street is prohibited at any time during the entire year. Vehicles parked in the lot are at all times during the entire year parked at the owner's risk, whether or not a fee is being charged for parking, and the city will not be responsible for any loss as the result of fire, theft, accident or vandalism. Any vehicle parked at any time during the entire year in excess of seventy-two (72) hours will be removed by the city at the owner's expense. 
    The following fees and regulations shall apply to vehicles using the Mary Street parking lot: 
A.  Fee schedule for the period of May 1st through October 31st, and on any additional day or days during the calendar year that the city administration deems that implementation of the fee schedule would be beneficial because of a special event or a high volume of traffic within the city, shall be: 
1.  The basic daily rates may be charged Sunday through Saturday: 
a.  An hourly rate of not more than three dollars ($3.00) per hour; 
b.  A daily rate of not more than twenty-four dollars ($24.00) good until two a.m. of the following day; 
c.  An overnight rate of not more than thirty dollars ($30.00) good until nine a.m. of the following. 
B.  Delivery Vehicles. Delivery vehicles delivering goods to those stores which front Thames Street and whose rear delivery area abuts the lot shall be allowed one-half hour of free parking and charged accordingly thereafter. 
C.  City Residents. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, city residents shall be allowed three hours of continuous free parking for a three-hour period per day. For purposes of this subsection, a city resident is a person whose motor vehicle has a valid resident sticker issued by the city. 
D.  Hours of Operation. The lot shall remain open twenty-four (24) hours each day. 
E.  Seasonal passes, valid Monday through Friday, except on weekday holidays, shall be available for purchase to employers and employees working in the business district for one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per pass, per season. A bulk rate may be charged to businesses purchasing ten or more season passes. Non-employee, transient/visitor daily passes may be purchased in quantity at the rate of sixteen dollars ($16.00) per day. 
F.  Regulations for Vehicles. 
1.  Entrance to the lot shall be allowed only through Mary Street and Church Street, with vehicles exiting on Mary Street only. 
2.  The parking of vehicles in excess of twenty (20) feet, and the parking and/or storage of construction equipment, are prohibited. 
3.  Vehicles parking in excess of seventy-two (72) hours will be removed by the city at the owner's expense. 
4.  Vehicles parked in the lot are parked at the owner's risk and the city will not be responsible for any loss as the result of fire, theft, accident or vandalism. 
5.  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in the Mary Street, parking lot unless appropriate parking fees have been paid. 
6.  It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to park a vehicle in the parking lot unless said vehicle is wholly within a parking space so designated by pavement markings. 
(Ord. 2008-13 § 1, 2008; Ord. 2007-24 § 1, 2007; Ord. 2005-18 § 1, 2005; Ord. 2004-36 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2000-26 §§ 1, 2, 2000; Ord. 98-13 § 1, 1998; Ord. 98-12 § 1, 1998; Ord. 25-97 § 1, 1997; Ord. 35-96 § 1, 1996; Ord. 23-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 9-92 § 1, 1992; Ord. 23-89 § 1, 1989; prior code § 490.05; Ord. 2016-20, § 1, 11-9-2016) 
10.28.060. - Edward Street parking lot. 
    No person shall park a vehicle in the Edward Street parking lot between the hours of seven a.m. and five p.m., Monday through Friday, unless such vehicle bears an official city of Newport parking permit. 
(Ord. 2002-18 § 1, 2002) 
10.28.070. - King Park parking lot. 
    From May 1st through October 15th, the King Park parking lot, located on Wellington Avenue by the Stone Pier, is designated for the parking of motor vehicles, as well as the parking of boat trailers as provided for in Section 10.20.140. At no time, however, shall the boat launching facilities be blocked, by either a vehicle or a boat trailer. 
    No vehicle shall park in the King Park parking lot without displaying an official city of Newport parking permit, unless such vehicle has attached to it a boat trailer bearing a current boat-trailer parking sticker. 
    The fee for an official city of Newport King Park parking permit issued to non-boating-related vehicles shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per season, effective May 1st through October 15th of each year. 
(Ord. 2008-30 § 1, 2008) 
Chapter 10.32. - RESIDENTIAL PARKING PROGRAM 

10.32.010. - Statement of purpose. 
    The provisions of this chapter are enacted to: 
A.  Reduce high traffic volumes in certain congested residential districts and to encourage the use of public transportation and public and private parking facilities; 
B.  Protect such residential districts from polluted air, excessive noise and refuse caused by the entry of such vehicles; 
C.  Protect the residents of such residential districts from unreasonable burdens in gaining access to their residences; 
D.  Preserve the character of such districts are predominately residential districts; 
E.  Preserve the value of the property in such congested residential districts; 
F.  Promote traffic safety and the safety of children and other pedestrians in such congested residential districts; 
G.  Facilitate the movement of traffic in the event of accidents or other disasters by virtue of reduced traffic volumes; 
H.  Promote the peace, comfort, convenience and welfare of all residents, inhabitants and visitors of the city; and 
I.  Promote public involvement in the designation of specific residential parking streets in the program. 
(Prior code § 492.01) 
10.32.020. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Designated commercial parking street" means a street or portion thereof within a residential parking district that is primarily abutted by commercial or business properties and uses. No designated commercial parking street shall be considered for inclusion in this chapter as a residential parking street. 
    "Dwelling unit" means a unit of living area arranged, intended or designed to be occupied by a family or group of not more than five unrelated individuals living together as a single housekeeping unit. 
    "Resident" means any person, firm or corporation who or which lives, resides or pays real property taxes to the city on real estate or on a structure approved for residential or commercial occupancy, and who or which is the owner of such structure or a tenant therein, or who or which can demonstrate some other indication of exclusive right of occupancy. For the purposes of this chapter, tenancy shall refer only to a formal lease of six months' duration or longer. 
    "Residential parking district" means a contiguous or nearly contiguous area containing public highways or parts thereof, primarily abutted by residential property or residential and nonbusiness property, such as schools, parks, churches, hospitals or nursing homes. Residential parking districts are enumerated in Section 10.32.100. 
    "Residential parking street" means a street or portion thereof within a residential parking district where curbside parking is limited to vehicles properly displaying a residential parking permit authorized by this chapter. Designated streets will be enumerated in this chapter, as amended from time to time by the procedure provided for herein. 
(Ord. 4-95 § 1 (part), 1995; Ord. 7-92 § 1 (part), 1992; prior code § 492.02) 
10.32.030. - Designation of residential parking districts. 
    In addition to the other restrictions on parking contained in these Codified Ordinances, council, by a majority vote, and upon the recommendation of the city manager, if requested, may designate a residential parking district at any regularly scheduled council meeting in the same manner that an ordinance is amended. 
(Prior code § 492.03) 
10.32.040. - Designation of residential parking streets. 
A.  Council may designate a street or a portion of a street within a residential parking district as a residential parking street, provided a petition in a form suitable to the city clerk has been filed with the city manager that has been signed by residents representing at least fifty-one (51) percent of the resident households, and commercial units on a mixed-use residential/commercial street, with an address of the specific street within the residential parking district requesting designation as a residential parking street. Petitions requesting 24-hour residential parking must reflect representation of at least sixty-five (65) percent of the residents of the street, and be referred to the interdepartmental traffic committee for a recommendation prior to first reading of the ordinance. 
B.  After advertisement and notice to all landowners whose property abuts the proposed residential parking street, the petition of the residents of such proposed residential parking street shall be placed on the docket of a regular council meeting. At the meeting, council shall render a decision on the designation of the proposed residential parking street, provided that council makes a finding that it has sufficient information to make such decision and that the petition properly reflects the concurrence of at least fifty-one (51) percent of the residents of the proposed residential parking street, except a petition requesting 24-hour resident parking must reflect the concurrence of at least sixty-five (65) percent of the residents of the proposed 24-hour residential parking street, and be referred to the interdepartmental traffic committee for a recommendation prior to first reading of the ordinance. 
(Ord. 2002-37 § 1, 2002; Ord. 45-93 § 1, 1993: prior code § 492.04) 
(Ord. No. 2011-015, § 1, 6-8-2011) 
10.32.050. - Withdrawal of designations. 
    Council may, at any time, upon petition as aforesaid or on its own motion, withdraw the designation of an existing residential parking district or residential parking street in the same manner that an ordinance is amended. Such withdrawal shall become effective thirty (30) days after council votes thereon. Notice of such action shall also be made by advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation. 
(Prior code § 492.05) 
10.32.060. - Erection of signs. 
A.  Following council's affirmative vote to designate a residential parking street, parking signs shall be erected on such residential parking street. 
B.  The sign shall inform a vehicle operator that curbside parking on the street is restricted unless the vehicle displays a residential parking permit or a general visitor pass or temporary residential parking permit authorized by this chapter. Where possible, the sign shall also direct the vehicle operator to the nearest available municipal lot or private parking lot for hire. 
(Prior code § 492.06) 
10.32.070. - Residential parking permits-Visitor passes-Temporary permits. 
A.  Any resident over the age of sixteen (16) may apply for a residential parking permit for a noncommercial vehicle by completing an application therefor prescribed by the city manager, which application shall be designed to provide the following information: 
1.  The name and residential or commercial address of the owner of the vehicle; 
2.  The name, residential or commercial address and driver's license number of the principal operator and the vehicle; and 
3.  The make, model, color and registration number of the vehicle. 
    The driver's license and vehicle registration shall be presented with the application. 
B.  Any resident over the age of sixteen (16) may apply for a residential parking permit for a commercial motor vehicle for which the manufacturer's weight does not exceed ten thousand (10,000) pounds, provided the commercial vehicle is the only form of transportation available to and from work, by complying with subsection A of this section. The driver's license and vehicle registration shall be presented with the application. 
C.  Whenever the director of finance finds that the applicant qualifies under this chapter for a residential parking permit for the vehicle described in the application, he or she shall, upon payment of the fees set forth herein, issue one residential parking permit in the form of a sticker or other method prescribed by the city manager. There shall be no annual fee for residential parking permits for property owners and those whose vehicles carry a Rhode Island registration with a Newport address if they are sixty-five (65) years of age or older at the time of application, or for those whose applications are received by mail with a postmark prior to April 1 as long as the application includes the required documentation and no outstanding fees are due the city; the fee for applications postmarked April 1 or later shall remain two dollars per year. The fee for all others qualifying for a resident parking sticker shall be ten dollars per year. Said fee shall be payable at the time of the submission of the application for the permit. Regardless of any other provision of this chapter, a residential parking permit shall not be issued to any resident who owes the city outstanding payments for parking violations, fines or costs for motor vehicle-related violations, or motor vehicles excise taxes. The effective period of the permit shall be from May 1st through April 30th of the following year. The fee shall not be prorated and no portion of any fee shall be refundable. The permit shall also authorize three hours of free parking daily in the Mary Street parking lot. 
D.  The director of finance may issue one general visitor pass per dwelling unit on a residential parking street and per dwelling unit of a property located at the corner of a residential parking street but with a different street name address. Such visitor pass shall be utilized only for one visitor vehicle. Such visitor pass shall indicate the year for which it is valid. 
E.  The director of finance shall issue a temporary residential parking permit for use by a bona fide visitor to a dwelling unit on a residential parking street. An application for such a permit shall be made only by a resident of a dwelling unit on a residential parking street on such form as is prescribed by the city manager. The fee for a temporary residential parking permit for the same vehicle in a seven-day period shall be one dollar per permit for two days and two dollars for each subsequent day. 
F.  Guest houses located on residential parking streets shall be issued one blank visitor pass for each rooming unit, less the number of off-street spaces provided on a parking lot of the same ownership as the guest house. 
G.  Passes, as described in subsections D, E and F of this section, shall also be eligible to a dwelling unit or guest house located on a street, or section of a street, within a designated residential parking district on which all on-street parking is prohibited by city ordinance. 
H.  Owners of service vehicles doing business within the city shall qualify for issuance of temporary parking permits for specified periods of time at the discretion of the director of finance. Such temporary parking permits shall be in a form prescribed by the city manager and shall be valid only for the period indicated thereon. 
I.  A resident who would otherwise qualify for a residential parking permit but utilities as his or her principal vehicle a vehicle registered to an entity other than himself or herself shall qualify for the issuance of a fleet pass. Such fleet pass shall be in a form prescribed by the city manager and shall be valid only for the period indicated thereon. 
J.  The director of finance may issue one general visitor pass for each residential unit located on a commercial street where residential parking has been implemented on the surrounding streets. 
K.  A resident who would otherwise qualify for a residential parking permit but uses as his or her principal vehicle a leased vehicle must provide proof that the vehicle is leased in his or her name at the address on his/her driver's license or application for said permit. 
L.  An applicant for a residential parking permit whose lease is for a duration of between six and nine months must show proof of rental dwelling registration, as required by Section 15.16.040, or must complete an affidavit of exemption for an owner-occupied premises, prior to issuance of a residential parking permit. Falsification of the records, including the affidavit, will lead to revocation of the residential parking permit in accordance with Section 10.32.140. 
(Ord. 2006-16 § 1, 2006; Ord. 2005-4 § 1, 2005; Ord. 2004-20 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2004-9 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2003-12 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2002-32 § 1, 2002; Ord. 2000-14 § 1, 2000; Ord. 97-34 § 1, 1997; Ord. 15-95 § 1, 1995; Ord. 4-95 § 1 (part), 1995; Ord. 19-92 § 1, 1992; Ord. 7-92 § 1 (part), 1992; prior code § 492.07) 
10.32.080. - Effective period and hours of restriction-Renewal or transfer of permits. 
A.  The restriction on parking provided for in this chapter shall be in effect from May 1st to October 1st of each year. The restriction shall be in effect daily for designated streets from six p.m. to six a.m. (of the following day); for designated streets from six a.m. to six p.m.; or for designated streets twenty-four (24) hours per day. 
B.  A holder of a valid permit from a previous year shall be entitled to a new residential parking permit for a current year upon payment of the annual fee and submission of evidence to the director of finance that the holder still qualifies for the permit. 
C.  The holder of a valid residential parking permit shall receive a new residential parking permit for the purpose of transferring the same to another qualifying vehicle upon surrender of the holder's existing residential parking permit and completion of a new application. 
(Ord. 22-90 § 1 (part), 1990; prior code § 492.08) 
(Ord. No. 2013-002, § 2, 5-22-2013) 
10.32.090. - Use of permits. 
A.  A parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve a parking space nor shall it excuse the observance of any traffic or parking regulation. 
B.  No holder of a residential parking permit shall use such permit when such holder no longer fulfills one or more of the applicable provisions of this chapter controlling the issuance of permits. 
C.  No person shall represent, in any fashion, that a vehicle is entitled to a parking permit authorized by this chapter when it is not so entitled. No person shall cause a parking permit to be displayed on a vehicle that does not qualify for such a permit. 
D.  No person shall duplicate or attempt to duplicate a residential parking permit or display on any vehicle a duplicate parking permit. 
E.  A residential parking permit must be permanently affixed to the front windshield, lower left corner of the driver's side of the vehicle for which it is issued. Failure to display said residential parking permit, as described above, shall be deemed a violation of the provisions of the residential parking program. 
F.  For the purposes of this section, the term "permit" shall include and mean a residential parking permit, a visitor pass, a guest pass, temporary residential parking permit, fleet pass or tenant pass. Any violation of subsections B, C, and D of Section 10.32.090 shall be subject to prosecution in the municipal court and a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) with each day a permit or pass is used in violation of these provisions constituting a separate violation. 
(Ord. 98-48 § 1, 1998; Ord. 7-92 § 1 (part), 1992; prior code § 492.09)

10.32.130. - Special events. 
    Any resident on a residential parking street who sponsors a special function or event, which special function or event shall be limited to five hours in duration, shall notify the police division at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance as to the address of the function, the approximate duration of the function and an estimated number of vehicles to be present. 
(Prior code § 492.13) 
10.32.140. - Revocation of permits. 
    In addition to the penalties set forth in Section 10.32.150, the city manager shall have the responsibility and authority to revoke the residential parking permit of any resident for the abuse of a residential parking permit or for the use of the same in a manner contrary to any of the provisions of this chapter. Revocation of the residential parking permit of a resident or conviction of a resident for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be considered just cause for denial of a future residential parking permit to such resident. 
(Prior code § 492.15)

Chapter 10.60. - TURNING RESTRICTIONS ON SPECIFIC STREETS 

10.60.010. - No left turns. 
    There shall be no left turns at the following designated places: 
    America's Cup Avenue: northbound at Elm Street, between the hours of six a.m. and nine a.m. 
    America's Cup Avenue: northbound at Poplar Street, between the hours of six a.m. and nine a.m. 
    Bellevue Avenue: to John Street; 
    Broadway: northbound from Bull Street to Equality Park Place, except at Collins Street and Caleb Earl Street; 
    Broadway: southbound at or near the junction with Bull Street and Spring Street; 
    Spring Street: northbound at or near the junction with Broadway and Bull Street; 
    Wellington Avenue: to Thames Street. 
(Ord. 98-20 § 1, 1998; prior code § 448.01) 
10.60.020. - No right turns. 
    There shall be no right turns at the following designated places: 
    Broadway: northbound at or near the junction with Bull Street and Spring Street. 
(Prior code § 448.02) 
10.60.030. - Right turn only. 
    There shall be only right turns at the following designated places: 
A.  Gate 4 (U.S. Naval Base) exit roadway at Connell Highway. All traffic entering Connell Highway southbound from the Gate 4 exist roadway shall turn right and not enter Maple Avenue. 
B.  Intersection of Marlborough Street and Thames Street. There shall be a "right turn only" lane designated on the southern-most side of the Marlborough Street right-of-way and all vehicles traveling northeasterly in this southern-most lane on Marlborough Street shall turn right onto Thames Street at the intersection of Marlborough Street and Thames Street. 
C.  Junction of Bellevue Avenue and Memorial Boulevard. All northbound traffic in the easterly lane of Bellevue Avenue shall turn right at Memorial Boulevard. 
E.  Junction of Spring Street and Memorial Boulevard West. All northbound traffic in the easterly lane of Spring Street shall turn right at Memorial Boulevard. 
(Prior code § 448.03) 
10.60.040. - Right turns on red. 
    In the interests of pedestrian safety, the intersection of Friendship Street and Broadway shall be designated "NO RIGHT-TURN ON RED" when one is traveling west on Friendship Street and then making a right-hand turn, north, onto Broadway. All other right-hand turns on red at that intersection are to remain as is. 
(Prior code § 448.04) 
Chapter 10.64. - TAXICAB STANDS AND BUS STOPS 

10.64.010. - Locations for taxicab stands. 
    Newport Transportation and Visitor's Center. Designated areas. 
    Market Square. North side, starting at a point one hundred eighty-five (185) feet west of America's Cup Avenue, westerly for a distance forty (40) feet is reserved for taxicab parking nine p.m. to two a.m. 
    Thames Street. East side, between Memorial Boulevard West and Franklin Street, four spaces are reserved for taxicab parking from nine p.m. to two a.m. 
(Ord. 24-97 § 1, 1997; Ord. 16-97 § 1, 1997; prior code § 488.01) 
(Ord. No. 2012-018, § 1, 12-12-2012; Ord. 2015-07, § 1, 3-11-2015) 
10.64.020. - Parking in taxicab or express stands and bus stops. 
A.  The operator of a taxicab or express shall not stand or park upon any street other than at a taxicab or express stand, respectively, except that this provision shall not prevent the operator of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers or merchandise. Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to citation and the maximum penalties allowable as provided in Chapter 1.12, and/or revocation of his/her taxicab operator's license. 
B.  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, or other than an express in an express stand, when any such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed. 
(Prior code § 488.02) 
(Ord. No. 2012-018, § 1, 12-12-2012) 
10.64.030. - Designation and marking of bus stops. 
    The director of public safety shall, as in his or her judgment public convenience may require it, mark out and designate places where public buses shall stop to receive or discharge passengers. Such places shall be legibly marked "Bus Stop" by signs erected in close proximity thereto. 
(Prior code § 488.03) 
10.64.040. - Filing and publishing lists of locations of bus stops. 
    The director of public safety shall file in the office of the city clerk, and with the chief of police and the traffic engineer, a list showing the locations of bus stops, and shall file additional lists from time to time as such stops are designated and marked, and shall also publish notice of such designated bus stops, once a week for three consecutive weeks, in a newspaper published in the city. 
(Prior code § 488.04) 
10.64.050. - Responsibility of bus drivers. 
    The locations designated and marked out pursuant to Section 10.64.030 shall be and are established as bus stops in the city, and all public bus drivers shall stop their buses to receive or discharge passengers only at designated bus stops. 
(Prior code § 488.05) 
10.64.060. - Change of location or abandonment of bus stops. 
    The director of public safety may also, whenever, in his or her judgement, public convenience requires it, change the location of any designated bus stop, or abandon the same, filing and publishing notice thereof as provided in Section 10.64.040. 
(Prior code § 488.06) 
10.64.070. - Obstruction of buses and passengers. 
    No person shall stop or park a vehicle in a designated bus stop so as to interfere with the ingress or egress therefrom by any bus, or so as to interfere with the proper use and operation of a bus stop, or so as to interfere with any person entering or desiring to enter or depart from a bus at any bus stop. 
(Prior code § 488.07) 
Chapter 10.68. - LOADING ZONES 

10.68.010. - Loading prohibited in certain areas at certain times. 
    Between the hours of eleven-thirty a.m. and four-thirty a.m. of the following day on weekdays, holidays excepted, unless otherwise provided in this chapter, no driver of a commercial vehicle shall stand or park such vehicle for the purpose of loading or unloading, or making or pickup up deliveries, or for any other purpose, for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty (30) minutes, on any of the following streets: 
A.  Thames Street, between Farewell Street and Lee Avenue; 
B.  Spring Street, between Ann Street and Broadway; 
C.  All streets running between Spring Street and Thames Street, from and including Ann Street to and including Touro Street and also including Hozier Street and Stone Street; 
D.  Broadway, from Equality Park Place to Thames Street, including Washington Square; 
E.  All streets running between Broadway and Dr. Marcus F. Wheatland Boulevard, from and including Equality Park Place to and including Branch Street; 
F.  All streets between Broadway and Marlborough Street and Washington Square and Marlborough Street; and 
G.  Broadway, from Bliss Road to Friendship Street and from Malbone Road to Pleasant Street. 
(Prior code § 484.01) 
(Res. No. 19-93, 2-24-93) 
10.68.020. - Restrictions on use. 
A.  Designated. There shall be loading zones in the following locations: 
1.  Bellevue Avenue. East side, north of DeBlois Street and south of Downing Street twenty (20) feet in distance as designated, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinance after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone. 
2.  Bellevue Avenue. East side, north of Casino Terrace and south of Memorial Boulevard forty (40) feet in distance as designated, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
3.  Broadway. West side, beginning twenty (20) feet north of the corner of Farewell Street, extending northerly for fifty (50) feet, provided, however, that non-loading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m.; 
4.  Coddington Street. South side starting at a point twenty-seven (27) feet east of Thames Street, thence easterly thirty (30) feet as designated; 
5.  Findley Place. East side, twenty (20) feet south of Bliss Road as designated; 
6.  Market Square. South side, starting at a point twenty (20) feet west of America's Cup Avenue, thence westerly fifty (50) feet, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
7.  Reserved. 
8.  Spring Street. East side, north of Touro Street twenty (20) feet as designated, provided, however, that non-loading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
9.  Thames Street. East side, twenty-five (25) feet south of the intersection of Touro Street and Thames Street to a point twenty (20) feet north of Mary Street as designated; 
10.  Thames Street. East side, twenty (20) feet south of the intersection of Mary Street and Thames Street to a point twenty (20) feet north of Cottens Court as designated; 
11.  Thames Street. East side, twenty (20) feet south of the intersection of Cottens Court to a point twenty (20) feet north of Church Street as designated; 
12.  Thames Street. Each side, one twenty-foot space at each of the following locations as designated, in no event closer than twenty (20) feet to the intersection: 
a.  North of Green Street, and 
b.  North of Pelham Street; 
13.  Thames Street. East side, one twenty-foot space at each of the following locations as designated, in no event closer than twenty (20) feet to the intersection: 
a.  South of Fair Street, and 
b.  South of Pope Street; 
14.  Thames Street. East side, one twenty-foot space at each of the following locations as designated, in no event closer than twenty (20) feet to the intersection, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone: 
a.  South of Ann Street, 
b.  South of Extension Street, 
c.  South of Dearborn Street; 
15.  Thames Street. East side, south of Newton Court as designated, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
16.  Washington Square. North side, west of Colonial Street, forty (40) feet as designated, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
17.  Reserved; 
18.  Ann Street Way. North side, starting at a point one hundred fifty-five (155) feet west of Thames Street, thence westerly forty (40) feet as designated; 
19.  Bannister's Wharf. South side, south of America's Cup Avenue, as designated; 
20.  Charles Street. West side, starting at a point fifteen (15) feet from Marlborough Street for a distance of twenty (20) feet; 
21.  Broadway. East side, thirty (30) feet south from the intersection of Bliss Road as designated, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
22.  Franklin Street. South side, in front of Number 33, for a distance of forty (40) feet, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this zone; 
23.  Prospect Hill Road. South side, starting at a point forty (40) feet west of Bellevue Avenue, thence westerly twenty (20) feet as designated; 
24.  Prospect Hill Road. North side, starting at a point forty-five (45) feet west of Number 28 Prospect Hill Street, as designated; 
25.  Washington Square. West side, area opposite Number 5 Touro Street as designated; 
26.  Redwood Street. South side, starting at a point twenty (20) feet east of Bellevue Avenue, thence easterly forty (40) feet as designated, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after three-thirty p.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
27.  Broadway. East side, in front of No. 95 Broadway, beginning five feet north of the curb cut, north for a distance of forty (40) feet, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed, pursuant to city ordinances, after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this zone; 
28.  Thames Street. East side, one forty (40) foot space south of Dean Avenue, provided that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
29.  Market Square. North side, starting at a point one hundred eighty-five (185) feet west of Americas Cup Avenue, thence westerly for forty (40) feet, provided that nonloading parking shall be allowed, pursuant to city ordinances, after eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays in this designated zone; 
30.  Bridge Street. South side, starting at a point forty-eight (48) feet west of Third Street, thence westerly forty-seven (47) feet, as designated; 
31.  Colonial Street. West side, starting at a point thirty-two (32) feet north of Washington Square, thence northerly forty (40) feet, as designated; 
32.  East Bowery Street. North side, east of Bellevue Avenue, forty (40) feet in length, as designated, provided however that no parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinance before eight a.m. or after three p.m. in this designated zone; 
33.  Wellington Avenue. North side, beginning at a point one hundred ten (110) feet west of Thames Street, extending westerly a distance of twenty-five (25) feet, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. 
34.  Church Street. North side, starting at a point one hundred thirty-five (135) feet west of Bellevue Avenue, thence westerly a distance of fifty (50) feet, provided, however, that nonloading parking shall be allowed pursuant to city ordinances after eleven-thirty a.m. in this designated zone. 
B.  Signs to be Posted. The chief of police shall erect appropriate signs or markings on the pavement or curb, giving notice that such spaces are reserved for loading or unloading only between the hours of four-thirty a.m. and eleven-thirty a.m. weekdays, holidays excepted. 
C.  Thirty-Minute Limit. No operator shall stop, stand or park any vehicle in any loading zone except for the purpose of loading or unloading, or for a period longer than thirty (30) minutes at any one time. 
D.  Permit Display. Noncommercial vehicles are prohibited from utilizing the loading zones designated in this section unless the operator thereof properly displays on the vehicle windshield a permit secured from the chief of police as hereafter described. 
E.  Permit Issuance. Upon application, the chief of police shall issue, on a form satisfactory to him or her, two permits to each business utilizing the loading zones designated in this section. The operator of any noncommercial vehicle shall ensure placement of such permit in a conspicuous location on the windshield of his or her vehicle while servicing such business and utilizing a designated loading zone. 
(Ord. 2008-32 § 1, 2008; Ord. 2008-14 § 1, 2008; Ord. 2007-6 § 1, 2007; Ord. 2004-6 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2004-5 § 1, 2004; Ord. 2003-50 § 1, 2003; Ord. 99-14A § 1, 1999; Ord. 18-96 § 1, 1996; Ord. 16-92 § 1, 1992; prior code § 484.02) 
(Ord. No. 2009-02, § 1, 1-14-2009; Ord. No. 2014-022, § 1, 10-8-2014; Ord. No. 2019-04, § 1, 2-13-2019) 
10.68.030. - Exceptions. 
A.  The chief of police is authorized to issue permits for the moving of furniture and for construction projects, which permits shall authorize trucks to be loaded and unloaded in the restricted areas set forth in this chapter. 
B.  The delivery of coal and fuel oil shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter. 
C.  Loading and unloading in the restricted areas set forth in this chapter shall be permitted by commercial vehicles twenty-eight (28) feet or less in length between four-thirty a.m. and three-thirty p.m. on weekdays, holidays excepted. 
(Prior code § 484.03) 
Chapter 10.72. - BICYCLES 

10.72.010. - Authority of business establishments to erect stands. 
    Business establishments in the city are authorized to place bicycle stands on city sidewalks and public property for the use of the general bicycling public, subject, however, to the requirement that all such bicycle stands must first be approved as to construction and location by the city manager or his or her designated representative, and subject to such other rules which the city manager may find necessary. 
(Prior code § 266.02) 
10.72.020. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, "bicycle" means every vehicle propelled exclusively by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels, except scooters and similar devices. 
(Prior code § 462.01) 
10.72.030. - Bicycle license required. 
    No person residing in the city for a period of thirty (30) days or more shall ride or use a bicycle without first obtaining from the police division a license therefor as prescribed in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 462.02) 
10.72.040. - License application-Qualifications of applicant. 
    A designated representative of the chief of police shall inspect each bicycle on specified days of each week between the hours of eight a.m. and four p.m. at the police station. If the bicycle is in good rideable condition and properly equipped as provided for in this chapter, the registration will be accepted. 
(Ord. 40-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.72.050. - License issuance-Term. 
    The police department is authorized to issue to residents of the city, upon written application, bicycle licenses that shall be effective for the duration of the ownership of said bicycle. Such licenses shall entitle the licensee to operate the bicycle for which the license has been issued upon all the public streets of the city. 
(Ord. 40-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.72.060. - License fees. 
    The license fee to be paid for each bicycle registered shall be three dollars. 
(Ord. 40-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.72.070. - Transfers-Duties of transferors and transferees.
