    A person who sells or transfers ownership of a bicycle shall report such sale or transfer by returning to the police division the registration card issued to such person as the license thereof, together with the name of the person to whom the bicycle was sold or transferred and his or her address, and such report shall be made within one week of the date of sale or transfer thereof. The person who made the purchase or the transferee of the bicycle shall apply to the police division for registration thereof within one week of the date of sale or transfer. Any disposition of a bicycle not covered by this section shall in any event be reported to the police division. 
(Prior code § 462.06) 
10.72.080. - License plates and registration cards. 
    The police division shall provide each year a decal or metal license, together with registration certificate cards, which decals or licenses and cards shall have numerical numbers stamped thereon in numerical order beginning with number one, and shall indicate the year for which they were issued, with letters indicating that they were issued by the city. The license plate shall be suitable for attachment to the lower end of the rear fender, or to the frame at the rear of the bicycle, at a location where it will always be plainly visible. The police division shall attach the license plate to the bicycle or supervise its attachment in such a manner as will prevent its removal. The police division shall also provide and issue a registration card, with numbers corresponding to the numbers on the license plate. The issuance of the registration card and license plate to the licensee shall be after the collection of the registration fee for the license, as provided for in Section 10.72.060. Funds collected by the police division for the several licenses provided for in this chapter shall be returned by the police division as collected and under conditions to be determined by the director of finance, who shall authorize the expenditure of such moneys, at the request of the chief of police, for the purchase of supplies, equipment or other necessities for the operation of the school safety patrols and other safety projects for minors. The license plate shall remain attached to the bicycle during the valid term of such license. The police division shall keep a record of the date of issue of each license, the person to whom issued and the number thereof. 
(Prior code § 462.07) 
10.72.090. - Alteration or mutilation of plates, frame number or registration card. 
    No person shall wilfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame licensed pursuant to this chapter. No person shall remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any license plate, seal or registration card during the time such license plate, seal or registration card is operative, provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prohibit the police division from pressing an identification number on the frame of bicycles on which no serial number can be found, or on which such number is illegible for identification purposes. The police division may also press an identification number upon the frame of any bicycle registered, which number shall be the secret number of the police division, if so required, in the administration of this section to prevent bicycle larceny and aid the division in tracing and recovery of stolen bicycles. 
(Prior code § 462.08) 
10.72.100. - Operation of bicycle. 
    The following rules and regulations shall be observed in the operation of a bicycle on the streets, highways, parkways and public places of the city: 
A.  Generally. Every person operating a bicycle shall at all times operate the bicycle with due regard for the safety of other persons and vehicles lawfully upon the streets, highways, parkways and public places, as well as for his or her own safety, and shall at all times and under all conditions yield the right-of-way to pedestrians on the streets, highways, parkways, parks, public places and crosswalks and shall not operate upon any pedestrian paths in the public parks or upon any public school grounds of public playgrounds except when operated on such school grounds or playgrounds during festival parades or other activities sponsored by the department of public recreation or school authorities. 
B.  Obedience to Traffic Regulations. Every person operating a bicycle shall comply with all vehicle traffic laws, except where such laws, by their nature, do not apply to bicycles, and with all vehicle traffic signs and signals erected for the regulation of traffic. 
C.  Turn Signals. Before turning or changing the direction of any bicycle upon any street, highway, parkway or public place, it shall be the duty of the bicycle rider to give a signal, by the extension of the hand, to indicate the direction he or she intends to proceed. 
D.  Towing Persons or Vehicles. No person operating a bicycle shall tow or draw any coaster, sled, person on roller skates or other similar vehicle on a public highway, except as provided in Section 10.72.170(B). 
E.  Acrobatic Riding. No person operating a bicycle shall engage in fancy or trick riding without maintaining full control of such bicycle and keeping both hands on the handlebars, except when necessary to give a signal. 
F.  Persons thirteen (13) years of age and older are prohibited from operating bicycles on city sidewalks. Bicycle operators thirteen (13) years of age and older shall operate on public roadways, following the direction of traffic, operating on the right side of the road, if practical, and observing the traffic and vehicle laws, proscribed for bicycle operation, as specified in the Rhode Island General Laws. Persons younger than thirteen (13) years of age are permitted to operate on sidewalks, with caution given to pedestrians. Persons of any age are permitted to walk a bicycle on a public sidewalk. 
G.  No person may operate a bicycle in any designated skate park area in the city. 
H.  No person may operate a bicycle on a sidewalk on Memorial Boulevard, Bellevue Avenue, Thames Street, the west side of Broadway from Equality Park to Washington Square or the west side of America's Cup Avenue. 
(Ord. 2007-9 § 1, 2007; Ord. 2006-30 § 1, 2006; Ord. 99-45 § 1, 1999; Ord. 42-94 § 1, 1994; prior code § 462.09; Ord. 2018-02, § 1, 2-28-2018) 
10.72.110. - Bicycle dealers-License required-Fee. 
    No person shall carry on the business of buying and selling new and secondhand bicycles without first obtaining a license therefor from the police division. Every applicant shall pay a license fee as set forth in Section 2.120.010 and such license shall be effective for one year. No person engaged in the business of buying and selling new and secondhand bicycles shall also engage in the business of renting bicycles for public hire without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in Section 10.72.120. 
(Prior code § 462.10) 
10.72.120. - Bicycle rental agencies-License required-Fee. 
    No person shall carry on the business of renting bicycles for public hire without first obtaining a license therefor, in addition to the license fee prescribed for each bicycle, as provided for in Section 10.72.060. The fee for such license shall be as set forth in Section 2.210.010. No fee is required if a bicycle dealer's license has already been obtained. All bicycles owned by such agency offered for public hire shall be registered in the name of the agency, but a record of the name, address and age of such person hiring a bicycle shall be kept on file for the inspection of the police division. 
(Prior code § 462.11) 
10.72.130. - Restrictions on issuance of dealer and rental agency licenses. 
    In the matter of the issuance of business licenses for dealers in secondhand bicycles and the conduct and operation of a bicycle rental agency, the chief of police shall be satisfied that the applicants for such licenses are of good character and financially responsible before a license is issued. 
(Prior code § 462.12) 
10.72.140. - Reports by dealers. 
    A person engaged in the business of buying new or secondhand bicycles shall maintain a record available for inspection by a representative of the police department, giving a list of all purchases, transfers and sales made by such person, as well as the name and address of all persons to whom the bicycles are sold, a description of each bicycle purchased, transferred or sold, and the frame number thereof, and, in the case of a secondhand bicycle bought from an individual or taken in trade from a person buying a new bicycle, or a secondhand bicycle from the dealer's stock, the number of the license plate thereon, if any. 
(Ord. 40-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.72.150. - Rentals to minors. 
    No person engaged in the business of renting bicycles for hire shall rent a bicycle to a minor under ten years of age. In renting a bicycle to a minor over ten years of age, but not over eighteen (18) years of age, the renting agency shall have on file, for police division inspection, the written consent of the parents or guardian stating that the minor is ten years of age or over and is permitted to rent a bicycle. 
(Prior code § 462.14) 
10.72.160. - Impoundment and disposition of bicycles. 
    Whenever any bicycle is impounded for a violation of the provisions of this chapter, it shall be surrendered to the parent or guardian of the offender or, in the case of an adult offender, surrendered on Wednesdays of each week between the hours of eight a.m. and four p.m. In the case of the seizure of a bicycle because it has been found in the possession of a person who is not the legal owner thereof and the bicycle is not reclaimed by the owner thereof, it shall be sold at public auction after the expiration of thirty (30) days from the date of seizure. Notice containing a description of the bicycle shall be published in a newspaper circulating in the city, at least one week prior to the date of the sale. The proceeds of the sale shall be remitted to the director of finance. Offenders summoned to Newport municipal court may have their bicycles impounded until after their hearing is concluded. 
(Ord. 40-95 § 1 (part), 1995) 
10.72.170. - Clinging to moving vehicles. 
A.  No person riding upon a bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself or herself to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
B.  This section shall not prohibit attaching a trailer or semitrailer to a bicycle if such trailer or semitrailer has been designed for such attachment. 
(Prior code § 462.16) 
10.72.180. - Riding on handlebars. 
    No operator of a motorcycle or bicycle shall, when upon a street, carry any other person upon the handlebars, frame or tank or any such vehicle, nor shall any person so ride upon any such vehicle. 
(Prior code § 462.17) 
10.72.190. - Number of bicycles abreast. 
    Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast, except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. Persons riding two abreast shall not unduly impede traffic and, on a laned roadway, shall ride within a single lane. 
(Prior code § 462.18) 
10.72.195. - Helmets required. 
    Any person fifteen (15) years of age or younger shall be required to wear a safety helmet when riding a bicycle on any public street, highway, parkway, or public place in the city. Said helmet shall fit the person's head, shall be secured to the person's head by straps while the bicycle is being operated, and shall meet the standards for helmets established by the Snell Memorial Foundation's 1984 standard for use in bicycling, or subsequent standards, or standards established by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, or subsequent standards. 
(Ord. 2001-14 § 1, 2001) 
10.72.200. - Lamps and other equipment on bicycles. 
A.  Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least five hundred (500) feet to the front. 
B.  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a red reflector of a type approved by the traffic engineer which shall be visible for six hundred (600) feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful lower beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
C.  No person shall sell a new bicycle or a pedal for use on a bicycle that is not equipped with a reflector, of a type approved by the traffic engineer, on each pedal or such bicycle, which reflector is visible from the front and rear of the bicycle during darkness from a distance of two hundred (200) feet, nor shall any person operate a bicycle without such pedals. 
D.  A bicycle shall not be equipped with, nor shall any person use upon a bicycle, any siren or whistle. 
E.  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake or brakes which will enable the operator to stop the bicycle within twenty-five (25) feet at a speed of ten miles per hour on dry, level, clean pavement. 
F.  Every bicycle, when in use at nighttime, shall be equipped with a minimum of twenty (20) square inches on each side of the bicycle with white reflective material on the wheels or tires to indicate, as nearly as possible, the continuous circular shape and size of the wheels or tires of each bicycle. All reflective materials used in compliance with this subsection shall be visible during the hours of darkness from five hundred (500) feet when viewed under lawful low beam headlamps under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway, and shall meet the requirements as prescribed by the traffic engineer. 
(Prior code § 462.19) 
Chapter 10.80. - ELECTRONIC PERSONAL ASSISTIVE MOBILITY DEVICE (EPAMD) 

10.80.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "EPAMD" means an electric personal assistive mobility device which is a self-balancing device with two wheels not in tandem, designed to transport only one person, having a maximum speed on a paved level surface, when powered solely by such a propulsion system of less than fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(Ord. 2008-33 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.80.020. - Areas of operation. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, EPAMDs may be operated on roadways, shoulders and alleys, but not on sidewalks, bicycle lanes or public paths. 
B.  EPAMDs are subject to limitations imposed by Title 31 of the Rhode Island General Laws. 
C.  EPAMDs may not be operated on public schools playfields or public school playgrounds. 
D.  The provisions of this section limiting the use of EPAMDs in parks or on sidewalks, bicycle lanes, public paths, public school playfields, or public school playgrounds do not apply to an EPAMD when that device is operated by a person with a mobility impairment caused by a physical disability who uses that device to enhance that person's mobility. 
(Ord. 2008-33 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.80.030. - Rules of operation. 
    Subject to the limitations on areas of operation contained in this chapter, the following rules of operation apply to EPAMDs as indicated: 
A.  EPAMDs shall only be used between sunrise and sunset. 
B.  Only a person with a valid motor vehicle operator's license may operate an EPAMD on a roadway, shoulder or alley. 
C.  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, EPAMD operators shall have the same rights and duties as operators of bicycles. 
D.  Speed-limited zones for EPAMDs: 
1.  The director of public safety (director) is authorized to designate speed-limited zones for EPAMDs; 
2.  Speed-limited zones shall be those areas where, in the professional judgment of the director are: 
a.  Congested pedestrian or non-motorized traffic is present; 
b.  Without a speed limit, a significant speed differential would exist between pedestrians or non-motorized traffic and EPAMD; and 
c.  Without a speed limit the presence of EPAMD or electric foot scooter traffic could endanger public safety. 
3.  The director is also authorized, in his/her professional judgment, to establish times during which certain areas will be deemed speed-limited zones; 
4.  When within a designated speed-limited zone, EPAMDs shall not be operated at a speed in excess of five miles per hour. 
E.  Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, operators of EPAMDs shall have the same rights and duties as operators of bicycles when upon any portion of a highway except a sidewalk, crosswalk or pedestrian zone. 
F.  At all times, operators of EPAMDs shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and human-powered devices and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing a pedestrian or human-powered device. 
G.  Any person operating an EPAMD shall wear protective eye wear designed for motorcycle safety. 
H.  No motorized EPAMD shall be operated with any passenger or other person in addition to the operator. 
    Notwithstanding the aforementioned provisions, EPAMDs are further subject to all ordinances pertaining to bicycles found at Chapter 10.72 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Newport. To the extent conflict is found between the ordinance codified in this chapter and Chapter 10.72, the specific ordinance provisions on EPAMD shall govern. 
(Ord. 2008-33 § 1 (part), 2008) 
10.80.040. - Responsibility. 
    No person shall do any act forbidden by this chapter or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2008-33 § 1 (part), 2008) 
Title 12. - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapter 12.04. - MAPPED STREETS 

12.04.010. - Intent. 
A.  The city shall establish an official map of public streets and ways in the city showing the location of said city streets and ways theretofore existing and established by law as public streets or ways. 
B.  The city council may, from time to time, make additions or modifications to the official map by placing thereon the exterior lines of planned new streets or street extensions, widenings, narrowings, or vacations. 
C.  No changes in the official streets map shall become effective until after a public hearing in relation thereto, at which parties in interest and citizens shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
D.  At least ten (10) days' notice of the aforesaid public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Before making additions or changes, the city council shall refer the matter to the planning board for report thereon, but if the planning board shall not make its report within forty-five (45) days of the reference, the necessity for the report may be deemed to be waived. 
E.  The locating, widening, or closing, or the approval of the locating, widening, or closing of the streets by the city council, under provisions of law other than those contained in this chapter, shall be deemed to be a change or addition to the official map, and shall be subject to all the provisions of this chapter except provisions relating to public hearing and referral to the planning board. 
F.  No action by the city, pursuant to this chapter, shall impose upon the city a duty to improve or maintain said public street or public right-of-way. 
(Ord. 33-93 § 1 (part), 1993) 
12.04.020. - Buildings not on mapped streets. 
    No permit for the erection of any building shall be issued unless the building lot abuts a street which has been placed on the official map giving access to the proposed structure, and that before a permit shall be issued, the street shall have been certified to be suitably improved, or suitable improvements shall have been assured by means of a performance guarantee, in accordance with rules and regulations adopted in the same manner as rules and regulations for subdivisions as provided in Chapter 23 of the Rhode Island General Laws. Where the enforcement of this section would entail difficulty or unnecessary hardship, or where the circumstances of the case do not require the structure to be related to a street, the zoning board of review may, in a specific case and after a public hearing for which reasonable notice has been given to all interested parties at which parties in interest and others shall have an opportunity to be heard, make reasonable exceptions and issue a permit subject to conditions that will assure adequate access for firefighting equipment, ambulances, and other emergency vehicles necessary for the protection of health and safety and that will protect any future street layout shown on the official map. 
(Ord. 33-93 § 1 (part), 1993) 
12.04.030. - Waterfront public streets and rights-of-way. 
A.  The city shall designate with specificity, to include length and width, all public streets and rights-of-way on the waterfront in the city. 
B.  The city of Newport in the state of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations shall cease further construction and prevent any person or entity from obstructing in any way the public access on the aforementioned streets and rights-of-way. 
(Ord. 33-93 § 1 (part), 1993) 
12.04.040. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the zoning board of review may follow the appellate procedure set forth in Rhode Island General Laws Section 45-23.1-5, as amended. 
(Ord. 33-93 § 1 (part), 1993) 
Chapter 12.08. - EXCAVATIONS AND CURB CUTS 

12.08.010. - Notice required prior to beginning new work. 
    At least two weeks prior to commencing work in any street in the city for which a specific appropriation has been made by council for new construction or permanent pavement, the director of public services shall give notice to the public by U.S. mail. 
(Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.08.020. - Approval of director of public services required. 
A.  No person shall alter or modify any portion of the city right-of-way in order to install an entrance, curb cut or driveway in such public street or sidewalk, or make any other physical alteration or modification to the city right-of-way without first making application to the director of public services. The applicant shall file a plat or plan, in the manner and form prescribed by the director, showing the proposed location and dimensions of such alteration (i.e., entrance, curb cut, driveway, sidewalk improvement, etc.) being petitioned for approval. 
B.  The director shall, within fifteen (15) business days of the receipt of the complete application, examine into the necessity of such alteration and in so doing shall take into consideration the public welfare, traffic hazards, danger to pedestrians and the public generally and any and all matters pertaining thereto, and shall act upon and approve or disapprove the application. All applications that include any type of curb and sidewalk reconstruction or modification shall include provisions for transition curbing and wheelchair accessibility to the extent practicable. 
C.  If the director disapproves the application, he or she shall notify the applicant of his or her action. The applicant shall have the right to appeal the action of the director within ten calendar days thereafter, and council shall, after hearing the matter, affirm or reverse the action of the director without amendment or alteration. 
D.  If the director approves the application, or if council, upon appeal, approves the application, then the director shall notify the applicant of such approval, and the applicant shall hire a suitable contractor to do the work required, which work shall be done only under the supervision of the department of public services engineering division and in the manner prescribed by the department, and the applicant shall pay all costs of such work. 
(Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.08.030. - Conditions precedent-Agreement between applicant and city. 
    A condition precedent to any work done under Section 12.08.020 shall be an agreement, on a form approved by the city solicitor, wherein the applicant agrees, for himself or herself and his or her heirs, assigns and successors, that the alteration (i.e., entrance, curb cut, driveway, sidewalk improvement etc.) shall at all times be kept clean, free of grease and oil and safe for pedestrians and others passing on or over such entrance, curb cut or driveway, that he or she will make such repairs as may be, from time to time, ordered by the director of public services, and that he or she will indemnify the city for any and all damage that may arise by reason of the use of the entrance, curb cut, driveway, or sidewalk improvement, etc. For any breach of the agreement, the director may revoke the permit granted under Section 12.08.020 and may pursue any and all other legal and equitable remedies available to him or her. The agreement shall be recorded in the land evidence records of the city by the applicant and shall bind all subsequent owners of the land improved by work done hereunder. 
(Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.08.040. - Permit applications-Restoration of surface-Bonds-Insurance. 
A.  Every person who files an application for a permit to make an excavation in a sidewalk or street shall, in such application, state the exact location of the proposed excavation and the dimensions thereof and shall also agree to restore the sidewalk or pavement in accordance with the specifications prescribed by the director of public services. 
B.  Every person making application shall further agree that if, in the opinion of the director, the work or restoration is not in strict accordance with the specifications, then the applicant shall correct the work to the satisfaction of the director within fourteen (14) days. If the applicant does not act within fourteen (14) days, the city may restore the same and charge to the person the associated costs incurred by the director in making the restoration plus a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or one hundred (100) percent of the associated cost whichever is greater. 
C.  Every person making application for excavations as aforesaid shall also be required to file in the office of the department of public services engineering division a performance bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned upon the applicant performing the work for which he or she has applied in a first-class and workmanlike manner and restoring the sidewalk, curb or pavement in accordance with the specifications prescribed by the director, and with the understanding that if, in the opinion of the director, the work or restoration is not in strict accordance with the specifications, then the city may do the work or restore the sidewalk, curb or pavement and charge to such person the cost thereof plus a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or one hundred (100) percent of the associated cost whichever is greater. Thorough clean-up shall be accomplished at the end of each working day. 
D.  Before commencing excavation work covered by this chapter, the person seeking the permit shall establish, by means of an insurance binder, that he or she has in full force and effect, a certificate of insurance for a comprehensive general liability policy with a minimum coverage of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) combined single limit or three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) bodily injury limit/six hundred thousand dollars ($600,000.00) bodily injury limit/one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage limit to include broad form property damage and explosion/collapse/underground coverage and completed operations coverage. For sidewalk and street obstructions, the applicant must provide a certificate of insurance for a comprehensive general liability policy with a minimum coverage of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00). All policies must run to the benefit of the city to indemnify the city for any liability it may incur as a result of issuing a permit under this chapter. 
(Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.08.050. - Excavations and obstructions of public ways-Permits required-Fees-Barricades-Emergencies. 
A.  No person shall alter or modify city right-of-way in any way or for any purpose (i.e., connect any land or premises with any main drain or common sewer, or open any drain or sewer belonging to the city, or break ground or make any excavation in any of the sidewalks, streets or public places in the city, for the purpose of making a drain or sewer or laying or placing gas pipes or water pipes or for any other purpose,) without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director of public services, who shall first ascertain the feasibility of such excavations in relation to associated engineering standards for proposed work. Such person applying for a permit shall provide such information as the director may require. For such permit, the person obtaining the same shall pay the city through its department of public services engineering division, a fee as set forth in subsection B of this section and such person shall provide for proper traffic control and properly light and barricade such excavation to the satisfaction of the director. All fees received shall, from time to time, be deposited with the director of finance. 
    However, in the case of an emergency occurring weekdays between the hours of five p.m. and eight a.m. or any other time during any weekend or holiday, necessitating an excavation in a street or public place for the purpose of making repairs to a gas main, water main, cable or electric conduit or for any other purpose, the person required to make such excavation shall not be first required to obtain a permit from the director of public services. Such person, however, shall, before making such excavation, advise the police department of the location where such excavation is to be made, and the police department, upon receipt of such notice, shall forthwith notify the fire department of the location where the excavation is to be made. However, the person making an excavation as aforesaid because of an emergency shall, between the hours of nine a.m. and twelve noon of the next working day following, file a written application as herein provided. 
B.  The fee for all excavations within any city right-of-way, whether in a public street or sidewalk, shall be as follows: 
1.  One hundred dollars ($100.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. The area shall be calculated based upon standard mathematical principles and include all disturbed excavation related area within the right-of-way. 
2.  The director of public services shall give ninety (90) days advance notice to all public utilities when a street or sidewalk is to be constructed, reconstructed, or resurfaced. This will afford the utility companies an opportunity to complete any necessary work in such road or sidewalk prior to the paving work. For five years thereafter any construction, reconstruction or resurfacing, any longitudinal excavation associated with new mains and/or conduits, including the maintenance of existing ones, will require pavement restoration from curb to curb for the entire length of the excavation. 
3.  For five years following the construction, reconstruction, resurfacing or sealing of a street, any excavator of a lateral trench shall restore the surface as set forth in this section. The existing pavement will be completely removed and replaced, in kind, for a distance of ten feet on either side of the centerline of the trench, from curb to curb. With regard to lateral cuts, the director need not give notice as required in subsection (B)(2) of this section. 
C.  The fee for obstructing or barricading a public street or sidewalk shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per calendar day, or part thereof, for the first thirty (30) days of the obstruction, and one hundred dollars ($100.00) per calendar day, or part thereof, after the first thirty (30) days, which shall be paid to the city through the department of public services engineering division. Obstruction permits associated with obstructing or barricading a public street or sidewalk shall be in addition to other appropriate fees for any and all excavation within the right-of-way. 
D.  The fee associated with any curb cut permit application shall be as follows: 
    Residential Applications: 
1.  Single-family-One hundred dollars ($100.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. 
2.  Multifamily-Five units or less-Two hundred dollars ($200.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. 
3.  Multifamily-Six to forty-nine (49) units-Five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. 
    Commercial/Industrial Applications: 
1.  Less than twenty-five thousand (25,000) square feet building-One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. 
2.  Twenty-five thousand (25,000) to three hundred thousand (300,000) square feet building-One thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. 
3.  Three hundred thousand one (300,001) to seven hundred fifty thousand (750,000) square feet building-Two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. 
4.  Greater than seven hundred fifty thousand (750,000) square feet building-Three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) plus fifty cents ($0.50) per square foot of disturbed area proposed within the right-of-way. 
E.  The fee associated with any road closure shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day. 
F.  The fee associated with a drain layers permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per connection. 
G.  References throughout this chapter to "the city" mean the director of public services and his or her authorized representative. 
(Ord. 2008-44 § 1, 2008; Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.08.060. - Removal of barricades and warning lights prohibited. 
    No person shall remove any barrier or lantern which is required to be placed by the director of public services, or under his or her authority and direction, to protect the public from injury while any street or public place is being made or repaired, or while any work or improvement therein is being performed by or for the city. 
(Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
12.08.070. - Responsibilities of permit holders. 
A.  The permit holder shall furnish all labor, materials, tools and equipment necessary for protection of the excavation, traffic control, backfilling the excavation, placing a compacted gravel foundation, temporary pavement, landscaping and placing the permanent service and shall perform all other work necessary to restore the condition of the right-of-way. 
B.  The permit holder shall notify the city, in writing, twenty-four (24) hours prior to doing any work. 
C.  Backfill material, concrete, plant mix bituminous concrete pavement, crushed processed gravel, cold patch and top soil or loam shall be in accordance with engineering standards of the department of public services engineering division and/or the Rhode Island Department of Transportation's Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, 2004, as amended. 
D.  All excavations shall be protected with public safeguards and adequate traffic control and warning devices, such as traffic cones, traffic signs, barricades, lights, watchmen etc., to be provided and maintained by the permit holder. No open excavation shall be left unattended at any time. 
E.  All material removed from the excavation shall be immediately removed from the site of the work and shall not be left on any public right-of-way. That portion of excavated material which is to be used for backfilling the excavation may be stored on the site only with the specific permission of, and in a manner approved by, the city. 
F.  No construction materials or equipment shall be stored on any city property or public right-of-way without the written approval of the city. 
G.  Placement of backfill, gravel foundation, temporary pavement and permanent pavement shall be in accordance with the standards of the department of public services engineering division. 
H.  Regarding permanent pavement, final pavement restoration shall be deferred for a time period designated by the director of public services at the time of the placement of the temporary pavement. This time will be dependent upon soil characteristics, the depth of the excavation and the nature of the excavation. When this time has expired, the department shall give written notice to the permit holder to remove temporary pavement and replace it with permanent pavement within a period of ten working days or be subject to the penalty provided in Section 1.12.010 for each day of noncompliance. 
I.  Concrete on roadways and concrete sidewalks shall be in accordance with standards of the department of public services engineering division and/or the Rhode Island Department of Transportation's Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, 2004, as amended. However, the use of concrete curbing on any public street or pubic right-of-way is prohibited. 
J.  Any individual, corporation, public utility or activity that performs work in, upon, or effecting the roadway of Bellevue Avenue shall be required, as a condition of the issuance of a permit to cut the roadway, to repair and replace the roadway only in full slab units. All costs relative to the repair and replacement of slabs is to be borne by the individual, corporation, public utility or activity requesting the slab for which the director of public services shall require a completion bond for all such work. Contractors performing the work shall be approved by the director of public services. The slabs shall be of the same color, texture, thickness, etc. All concrete roadway slab replacements shall be the same as the standards of the department of public services engineering division and/or the Rhode Island Department of Transportation's Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, 2004, as amended and shall further be the same as the specifications of the Bellevue Avenue Reconstruction Contract, identified as Rhode Island Federal Aid Project No. CRP-FY89 (003). 
(Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
(Ord. No. 2011-029, § 1, 10-26-2011) 
12.08.080. - Failure to comply. 
    Failure to comply with application for permit procedures will be subject to a fine of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per incident. All work shall halt while appropriate permits are applied for and obtained. 
(Ord. 2008-24 § 1 (part), 2008) 
Chapter 12.12. - ENCROACHMENTS AND OBSTRUCTIONS 

12.12.010. - Encroachment of doorsteps. 
    No person shall project any doorstep, steps or entry-ramp, either of stone, wood or other material, beyond the boundary line of any lot upon any sidewalk, street or public place in the city, unless such doorstep, steps or ramp is part of a plan for the restoration, alteration or repair of a structure of historic and architectural value for which a permit has been issued by the Historic District Commission in accordance with Section 45-24.1-4 of the General Laws of Rhode Island, 1956, as amended by Chapter 131 of the Public Laws of Rhode Island, 1959, as amended, or unless such doorstep, steps or ramp is specifically approved by council for the benefit of the public health, safety and welfare. In all such cases, before any such permit is issued, the property owner shall indemnify the city in writing for any and all claims arising out of the encroachment. 
(Prior code § 1026.01) 
12.12.020. - Drainage onto sidewalks. 
    No owner, occupant or person having the care of any building standing on any lot of land bordering on any street, square or public place in which there is a sidewalk supported by a curbstone, shall cause or permit any flow of water upon the sidewalk from the roof, eaves, gutter or waterspout of the building or otherwise. 
(Prior code § 1026.02) 
12.12.030. - Bridges across gutters. 
    No person shall construct or maintain a bridge across any gutter in any highway in the city without first obtaining permission to do so from council or from some person authorized by council to grant such permission. Every person who is permitted to construct or maintain such a bridge shall shape it and keep it clear and open so that it does not obstruct the flow of surface water through or under the same. 
(Prior code § 1026.03) 
12.12.040. - Enclosures-Permit required. 
    No person shall fence in or enclose any portion of a sidewalk or footpath or construct any staging thereon, for any purpose, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director of public works and the chief of the division of inspection. 
(Prior code § 1026.04) 
12.12.050. - Gates. 
    No person shall allow any gate belonging to premises owned or occupied by him or her, or under his or her legal control, and adjoining any sidewalk or street, to swing on, over or into such sidewalk or street. 
(Prior code § 1026.05) 
12.12.060. - Openings-Safe grating required. 
    Every person owning real estate abutting on a public sidewalk in the city upon or in which sidewalk there is an opening or excavation made for the use of abutting real estate, whether used or not, shall cover such opening or excavation, when not in use, with a grating or other device securely fastened to the sidewalk so that members of the public using the sidewalk will not be endangered by the excavation or opening. 
(Prior code § 1026.06) 
12.12.070. - Openings-Liability of user. 
    Whenever an opening or excavation in a public sidewalk is being used for the benefit of the abutting real estate, and it is uncovered, the owner or person using the opening or excavation shall be liable for all damage suffered by any member of the public using the sidewalk. 
(Prior code § 1026.07) 
12.12.080. - Flags. 
    No person shall suspend, hoist, fasten or continue, anywhere within the city, any flag of any description, which projects into or overhangs any street or public square, provided that flags for decorative purposes may be suspended in or across the public streets and squares on the occasion of national or state holidays, or when military, political or society parades are to be had, at the discretion and with the written permission of the chief of police; and provided, further, that presidential campaign flags or banners which do not approach the road bed nearer than twelve (12) feet may be suspended in or across the public streets and squares during the months of September, October and November, at the discretion and with the written permission of the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 1026.08) 
12.12.090. - Awnings. 
    It shall be lawful to place or maintain awnings and shades before any house, shop or store, in any street, upon the terms and conditions set forth in this section, and not otherwise, provided that council, as to particular buildings or streets, may order that no awnings or shades shall be erected. Such awnings and shades shall be safely fixed and supported in such a manner as not to interfere with pedestrians and so that the lowest part thereof is not less than seven feet in height above the sidewalk or street and in no case to extend beyond the line of the sidewalk. The person so placing or continuing to maintain the same shall in all respects conform to any direction given by council in relation to the maintenance thereof. 
(Prior code § 1026.09) 
12.12.100. - Canopies. 
A.  Council may grant a license for the erection of canopies. 
B.  Application for a license required by subsection A of this section shall be made to the chief of the division of inspection. 
C.  The fee for the license required by subsection A of this section shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year, payable to the chief. 
D.  All licenses granted under this section shall expire on April 1st of each year. 
E.  All stanchions and braces for canopies shall be set in metal sockets which can be capped if the uprights are removed. 
(Prior code § 1026.10) 
12.12.110. - Plantings. 
    No person shall allow any planting of any kind on his or her property to encroach upon a public sidewalk so as to obstruct such sidewalk, unless specifically authorized to do so by council. Council may, at its discretion, permit the placement of planters or other obstructions where it finds that the proposed obstruction will not endanger the public health, safety or welfare and, further, where it makes an affirmative finding that the proposed obstruction will enhance the neighborhood. Authorization for sidewalk obstructions shall be granted subject to written agreement by the property owners to maintain the obstruction in good repair and to indemnify the city against any claims arising therefrom. The property owner shall maintain in full force and effect a general liability policy in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for the benefit of the city. Breach of any of the above conditions shall result in revocation of authorization to maintain the obstruction. Upon revocation, the property owner shall immediately remove the obstruction and restore the sidewalk to a condition acceptable to the city. If the property owner fails to remove the obstruction within fifteen (15) days of notice of revocation, the city may remove the obstruction and file the cost therefor as a lien against the property owner's realty. 
(Prior code § 1026.12) 
12.12.120. - Obstruction of vision of motorists. 
A.  Obstructions Prohibited. On a corner lot where a setback or side yard exists, no fence, wall, shrubbery, tree, ground sign, billboard or other obstruction to vision shall be erected or maintained so as to create a hazardous condition for vehicular travel by obstructing vision at the intersection. 
B.  Notice to Abate Obstruction. If the director of planning and zoning finds that an obstruction to vision has been erected or maintained on a corner lot where a setback or side yard exists, and that a hazardous condition for vehicular travel results thereby, he or she shall give notice to the record owner of the property, which notice shall: 
1.  Be in writing; 
2.  Include a statement of the reasons why it is being issued; 
3.  Allow a reasonable time, not to exceed twenty (20) days, for the performance of any act it requires; and 
4.  Be served upon the owner or his or her agent, or the occupant, as the case may require, provided that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such owner or agent, or upon such occupant, if a copy thereof is served upon him or her personally, or if a copy thereof is sent by certified mail to his or her last known address, or if service of such notice is made by any other method authorized or required under the laws of the state. 
C.  Hearings. Within one month after the service of the notice provided for in subsection B of this section, the owner of the property in question shall have the right to have a hearing before council to show that the alleged violation does not exist, or that the alleged violation does not constitute a hazardous condition for vehicular travel, or why such condition should not be remedied by the city at the expense of the owner of such property. At the hearing, the city and the property owner may introduce such witnesses and evidence as are deemed necessary by council in hearing the matter. 
D.  Abatement by City-Collection of Costs. If the condition described in the notice provided for in subsection B of this section has not been remedied, and if there has been a hearing as provided for herein after notice to the property owner, the city manager shall cause the condition to be remedied by the city at the expense of the owner of the property. After causing the condition to be remedied, the city manager shall certify to the director of finance the expense incurred in remedying the condition, together with a statement as to the condition of the property which necessitated incurring such expense, and a copy of the notice mentioned above with proof of service thereof, and a copy of the decision of the hearing before council. All expenses incurred in remedying the condition shall be paid by the owner, occupant or person who caused or permitted the same to exist. If such expenses are not paid within a reasonable time, then the same may be recovered in an action of the case brought in the name of the city. 
(Prior code § 1026.13) 
Chapter 12.16. - STREET USE REGULATIONS 

12.16.010. - Playing games-Throwing missiles. 
    No person shall play at ball or football or throw stones or other missiles in or upon any of the streets, highways, squares, parks, lanes, alleys or wharves in the city. 
(Prior code § 440.01) 
12.16.020. - Sledding. 
    No person shall slide on any sled or other machine or vehicle for amusement in any of the streets, highways, lanes or alleys, except in those places designated by the traffic engineer for such purpose. 
(Prior code § 440.02) 
12.16.030. - Washing vehicles. 
    No person shall wash any vehicle in any street, avenue or public place in the city. 
(Prior code § 440.03) 
12.16.040. - Parades and processions. 
A.  Permit Required. No funeral, procession or parade containing one hundred (100) or more persons or twenty-five (25) or more vehicles, except the forces of the United States Army or Navy, the military forces of the state and the forces of the police and fire divisions of the city, shall occupy, march or proceed along any street except in accordance with a permit issued by the traffic engineer with regulations set forth in this title which may apply. 
B.  Notice of Object, Time and Route. No person participating in a parade or procession shall occupy or march on any street to the exclusion or interruption of other persons in their individual rights and the use thereof, except the police and fire divisions of the city, the organized militia, the organized naval forces of the United States, the military forces of the United States, the independent chartered forces, associations wholly composed of soldiers, sailors or marines honorably discharged from the services of the United States, veterans of the National Guard or naval militia, and organizations of the order of sons of veterans, unless written notice of the object, time and route of such procession or parade is given by the chief officer thereof, not less than twenty-four (24) hours previous to its forming or marching, to the traffic engineer. The traffic engineer may designate how much of the street or streets in width and what portion thereof such procession or parade may occupy, with special reference to crowded thoroughfares through which such procession or parade may move, and when so designated, the chief officer of such procession or parade shall be responsible for obedience to such designation. 
(Prior code § 440.04) 
12.16.050. - Putting injurious materials on streets prohibited-Cleaning up after accidents. 
A.  No person shall throw or deposit upon any street any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wires, cans or any other substance likely to injure any person or animal or damage any vehicle upon such street. 
B.  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any street any destructive or injurious material shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. 
C.  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street from such vehicle. 
(Prior code § 440.05) 
12.16.055. - Pavement markings. 
    No person shall mark a street or right-of-way with paint or any other substance to provide directions during an event being conducted in the city, unless such paint or substance is water soluble. All such markings shall be completely removed no later than one week after the conclusion of the event. 
    This section shall not apply to utility companies, public, private, or municipal, or their designees, when street and sidewalk markings become necessary in the course of carrying out their work, nor to markings placed by the city for any other municipal purpose. 
(Ord. 2007-48 § 1, 2007) 
12.16.060. - Obstructions by railroad trains. 
    No directing officer or operator of a railroad train shall direct the operation of or operate the same in such a manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for longer than five minutes, except that this section shall not apply to trains or cars in motion, other than those engaged in switching. 
(Prior code § 440.06) 
12.16.070. - Quiet zones. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating a zone of quiet, no person operating a motor vehicle within any such zone shall sound the horn or other warning device of his or her vehicle except in an emergency. 
(Prior code § 440.07) 
12.16.080. - Play streets. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that any street or part thereof is a play street, no person shall drive a vehicle upon any such street or portion thereof except drivers of vehicles having business or whose residences are within such closed area, and then any driver shall exercise the greatest care in driving upon any such street or portion thereof. 
(Prior code § 440.08) 
12.16.090. - Safety zones. 
    No person shall at any time drive a vehicle through or within a safety zone. 
(Prior code § 440.09) 
12.16.100. - Toy vehicles upon roadways. 
A.  No person, riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway, or upon any side street except upon streets set aside as play streets designated in accordance with this title. 
B.  Roller skating/roller blading is permitted on any public street, highway or sidewalk exclusive of state highways, unless specifically prohibited. 
C.  No person shall ride or propel roller skates/roller blades upon a public street, highway or sidewalk, except in a prudent and careful manner and unless such a person is capable of efficient control and such roller skates/roller blades are operated with reasonable regard to the safety of the operator and other persons upon the streets, sidewalks and other public highways of the city, exclusive of state highways. 
D.  Roller skates/roller blades shall be used consistent with the traffic ordinance of the city. 
E.  Any person fifteen (15) years of age or younger shall be required to wear a safety helmet when riding or propelling roller skates, roller blades, or a scooter on any public street, highway, sidewalk, or public property. Such helmet shall fit the person's head, shall be secured to the person's head by straps while the roller skates, roller blades, or scooter is being operated, and shall meet the standards for helmets standard for use in bicycling, or subsequent standards, or standards established by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, or subsequent standards. 
F.  Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be fined not more than the maximum allowable in Newport Municipal Court and/or imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. 2001-13 § 1, 2001; Ord. 1-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 24-93 § 1, 1993) 
12.16.110. - Vendors in public roadways. 
    No person who is within a public roadway may solicit or sell, or distribute any material to an occupant of a public roadway, unless that person is on the surrounding sidewalk, median, island or unpaved shoulder and not on the roadway itself. 
(Ord. 2005-26 § 1, 2005) 
Chapter 12.20. - NEWSPAPER VENDING DEVICES 

12.20.010. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Newsrack" means any type of unmanned device placed upon any public right-of-way for the vending of, or for the free distribution of, newspapers or news periodicals. 
    "Public right-of-way" means any public street, highway, sidewalk, parkway or alley. 
(Prior code § 842.01) 
12.20.020. - Purposes. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to promote the public health, safety and welfare through the regulation of the placement, appearance, servicing and insuring of newsracks on public rights-of-way so as to: 
A.  Provide for pedestrian and driving safety and convenience; 
B.  Restrict unreasonable interference with the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business, or from the street to the sidewalk, by persons exiting or entering parked or standing vehicles; 
C.  Provide reasonable access for the use and maintenance of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes and locations used for public transportation purposes; 
D.  Eliminate newsracks which may result in visual blight on the public rights-of-way or which may unreasonably detract from the aesthetics of store window displays, adjacent landscaping and other improvements; 
E.  Maintain and protect the values of surrounding properties; 
F.  Reduce unnecessary exposure of the city to personal injury or property damage claims; and 
G.  Provide for and maintain the freedom of speech for newspapers or news periodicals using newsracks for distribution purposes. 
(Prior code § 842.02) 
12.20.030. - Permits. 
A.  Required. No person shall place, affix, erect, construct or maintain a newsrack upon any public right-of-way without first obtaining a permit therefor in accordance with this chapter. 
B.  Issuing Authority. The issuing authority for permits required by this chapter shall be the director of planning, zoning and development. 
C.  Approving Authorities. The approving authorities shall be the city manager and the director. 
D.  Applications. The applicant shall file with the department of planning, zoning and development a written application for a permit, which application shall contain the following information: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant; 
2.  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible person whom the city may notify or contact at any time concerning the applicant's newsracks; 
3.  The number of newsracks and the exact proposed location of each; 
4.  The names of newspapers and periodicals to be contained in each newsrack; 
5.  The type or brand of newsrack, including a description of the newsrack; 
6.  The method of securing such newsrack, including the structure such newsrack will be secured to; 
7.  The name of the owner of the structure such newsrack will be secured to; and 
8.  A statement as to whether or not permission of such property owner has been obtained for such securing. 
E.  Issuance. Upon a finding by the department that the applicant is in compliance with this chapter, and upon receipt of the required approvals from the approving authorities, the department shall cause a permit to be issued in accordance with the application and this chapter. Such permit shall be effective for one year. 
F.  Denial. If a permit is denied, the applicant shall be immediately notified of the specific cause of such denial by the director. 
G.  Fee. There shall be an annual permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each newsrack. 
(Prior code § 842.03) 
12.20.040. - Insurance. 
    Prior to the issuance of a permit required by this chapter by the director of planning, zoning and development, the applicant shall furnish to the director a certificate that the applicant has then in force a public liability and property damage insurance, naming the city as an additional insured, in an amount of not less than three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) minimum liability combined single limit (bodily injury and property damage) per person and per occurrence. The evidence of insurance filed with the director shall include a statement by the insurance carrier that thirty (30) days notice will be given to the city before any cancellation of coverage. 
(Prior code § 842.04) 
12.20.050. - Placement-Location restrictions. 
A.  Placement. Subject to the prohibitions set forth in subsection B of this section, newsracks shall be placed adjacent and parallel to the wall of a building and not more than six inches from the wall, unless the city determines that placement near a building is not suitable, in which case the city may authorize placement near a curb. Newsracks placed near a curb must be placed parallel to and not less than eighteen (18) inches nor more than twenty-four (24) inches from the edge of the curb. The number of newsracks at each location and their placement in front of vacant lots shall be controlled by the city. 
B.  Location Restrictions. No newsrack shall be placed, installed, used or maintained: 
1.  Within five feet of any marked crosswalk; 
2.  Within fifteen (15) feet of any intersection; 
3.  Within five feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box, police call box or emergency facility; 
4.  Within five feet of any driveway; 
5.  Within five feet ahead of, and fifteen (15) feet to the rear of, any sign marking a designated bus stop; 
6.  Within five feet of any bus bench; 
7.  At any location whereby the clear space for the passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than six feet; 
8.  On or within six feet of any area improved with lawn, ground cover, flowers, shrubs or trees; 
9.  Within three feet of any display window of any building abutting the sidewalk or parkway or in such a manner as to impede or interfere with the reasonable use of such window display purpose; 
10.  Within two hundred fifty (250) feet of another newsrack containing the same newspaper or news periodical, except where separated by a street or corner; or 
11.  Facing another newsrack, divided only by the width of a sidewalk or pedestrian walk. 
(Prior code § 842.05) 
12.20.060. - Size. 
    No single newspaper vending machine shall exceed five feet in height, thirty (30) inches in width or two feet in depth. 
(Prior code § 842.06) 
12.20.070. - Advertising-Maintenance-Display of contact's name. 
A.  Newsracks shall carry no advertising except the name of the newspaper or periodical being dispensed in the machine. 
B.  Newsracks shall be maintained in good working order at all times, freshly painted and with no broken parts. 
C.  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible person who may be contacted at any time concerning the newsrack shall be displayed on the hood of the newsrack in such a manner as to be readily visible and readable to a prospective customer thereof. 
(Prior code § 842.07) 
12.20.080. - Nonconforming and abandoned newsracks. 
A.  Nonconforming Newsracks. Within ninety (90) days after this chapter becomes effective (Ordinance 45-87, passed October 14, 1987), and at any time thereafter, any newsrack in violation of this chapter shall have a notice to correct attached thereto by the city reciting the nature of the violation. A copy of such notice shall be sent to the owner of such newsrack. If the violation is not corrected within five days after such notice is attached and if no appeal of such violation is taken pursuant to Section 12.20.100, the city may impound the newsrack and shall make all reasonable efforts to notify the permittee or his or her authorized agent of the impoundment. 
    Upon failure of the permittee to claim an impounded newsrack and pay the expenses of such removal and storage within thirty (30) days after removal, the newsrack shall be deemed unclaimed property and may be disposed of by the city. 
B.  Abandonment. If a newsrack installed pursuant to this chapter is found not to contain the publication specified in the application therefor within a period of five days after release of the current issue of such publication, the city may deem the newsrack abandoned and may thereafter remove the newsrack from the public right-of-way in accordance with the procedure set out in subsection A of this section. In addition, a newsrack shall be deemed abandoned when no publication is in the newsrack for more than ten consecutive days. 
    If a newsrack permittee desired to voluntarily abandon a newsrack location, such permittee shall completely remove the newsrack and restore the public right-of-way to a safe condition, leaving no holes or projections in the pavement. 
(Prior code § 842.08) 
12.20.090. - Enforcement. 
    The director of planning, zoning and development shall enforce this chapter. 
(Prior code § 842.10) 
12.20.100. - Violations-Notice to correct-Hearings-Appeals. 
A.  The director of planning, zoning and development shall notify the permittee whenever one or more of his or her newsracks fails to conforms to this chapter and shall give the specific reasons therefor. 
B.  The permittee, within five days after receipt of such notice, shall: 
1.  Bring his or her newsrack into compliance; 
2.  Remove the newsrack; or 
3.  Request a hearing with the director, which hearing shall be held within five working days of such request. 
    At the hearing, the director and the permittee shall produce all evidence each has in an attempt to ensure that the newsrack is in compliance. The director shall issue the permittee his or her written decision within five working days after the hearing. 
C.  If the permittee is not satisfied with the decision of the director, he or she may appeal directly to council. Council shall hold a hearing on the appeal within two weeks after receipt thereof. 
D.  At such hearing before council, the director shall have the burden of proof that the newsrack does not comply with this chapter. After a full hearing, council shall give its decision, either upholding the appeal or denying the appeal, or any other decision it feels is proper, based on the evidence. 
E.  Any applicant who has been denied a permit under this chapter may file an appeal with council in accordance with this section. 
(Prior code § 842.09) 
Chapter 12.24. - POLES AND WIRES 

12.24.010. - Maintenance and specifications. 
    All posts, poles, structures and supports used for supporting electric wires or other wires, and all wires used for conducting electric current or for telephone or other purposes, now existing or hereafter placed or put on, over or under any street, sidewalk, public square, park, wharf, lane or alley, shall be maintained subject to the orders of the fire chief. The location, height, arrangement, construction and attachments of all such wires, posts, poles, structures and supports shall be under the direction of the fire chief, who may at any time, and from time to time, at his discretion, direct changes to be made therein as the public good may require. Any permission given by council or by any officer or agent of the city to erect or maintain such poles, posts, structures, supports or wires, may be revoked in whole or in part at any time, and any of such posts, poles, wires, structures or supports may be removed by the city, its officers, agents or servants, from time to time, and at any time, without any notice except such, if any, as the statutes or acts of the state may require. 
(Prior code § 1030.01) 
12.24.020. - Removal or repair of unsafe poles, etc. 
    All posts, poles, structures, supports and wires referred to in Section 12.24.010 that may from any cause become unnecessary obstructions to the fire division, or dangerous or menacing to the public safety because of decay, insufficient support, defective insulation, expansion or contraction of wires, crossing other wires, proximity to other wires or to buildings, or because of any other reason, shall be reported to the owners thereof by the fire chief and shall be promptly removed, repaired or replaced by and at the expense of such owners to the satisfaction of the fire chief and as he may direct. 
(Prior code § 1030.02) 
12.24.030. - Concentration of wires upon supports. 
    The fire chief shall require all wires to be concentrated as much as practical upon the supports available therefor so that no unnecessary number of posts, poles, structures and supports are maintained in the city. 
(Prior code § 1030.03) 
12.24.040. - Removal of dead wires, unused poles, etc. 
    All dead wire, so called, and all posts, poles, structures, supports and wires that are not in use or not absolutely necessary for the purposes for which they were erected or established, shall be removed by the owners thereof. 
(Prior code § 1030.04) 
12.24.050. - Grounding or connection in metallic circuit required for certain wires. 
    Every wire designated for use during a part only of each year shall be at all times provided with a ground contact at one end at least or shall be connected in metallic circuit to the satisfaction of the fire chief. 
(Prior code § 1030.05) 
12.24.060. - Records. 
    A record shall be kept at the headquarters of the fire division of all posts, poles, structures and supports used for supporting electric or other wires and also of all wires used for conducting electric or other current or for telephone or other purposes in the city, with their locations and the names or titles of the owners thereof, and also of all additions or changes of locations that may hereafter be made. 
(Prior code § 1030.06) 
12.24.070. - Fire alarm telegraph system. 
    The wires, poles, posts, structures and supports of the fire alarm telegraph system shall at all times take precedence and right-of-way as to all other wires, poles, posts, structure or supports maintained or erected in the city. No lineman or other person, either in erecting wires, poles, posts, structures or supports, or in any other way, shall interfere with or disturb, disarrange or change the fire alarm or any appurtenance thereof. 
(Prior code § 1030.07) 
12.24.080. - Identification of poles, etc. 
    All posts, poles, structures and supports used for supporting electric or other wires in the city shall be marked, in a legible and permanent manner to the satisfaction of the fire chief, with the name or title or initials of the person owning the same and at his expense. In all cases where wires of more than one person are placed upon one post, pole, structure or support, the part to which such wires are attached shall be marked in such a manner as to designate the ownership of such wires and in such a way as is satisfactory to the fire chief. 
(Prior code § 1030.08) 
12.24.090. - Employees' badges. 
    Every person employing linemen or other persons in erecting, reconstructing, repairing, maintaining or removing any wire, post, pole, structure or support maintained for or intended to be used for electric, telephone or other purposes in the city, shall provide his or her employees with the medal or badge hereinafter described, and all such employees shall, at all times when so employed, have conspicuously attached to their dress, a medal or badge on which is legibly inscribed the name of the person by whom they are employed and a number by which they can be readily identified. 
(Prior code § 1030.09) 
12.24.100. - Registration of linemen-Notification of fire division of pole or wire changes. 
    All linemen and other persons employed on wires, posts, poles, structures or supports shall, before they proceed to work, register or be registered at the headquarters of the fire division with the name or title of their employer, their own name and the number of their badge. Before any new wire, post, pole, structure or support is erected or any change made in its location, or any removal of the same is made, the foreman in charge of the proposed work shall report, at the headquarters of the fire division, where and when the erection, change or removal is proposed to be made, and shall sign an agreement for and on behalf of his or her employer that the work will be done under the supervision of, and in a manner satisfactory to, the fire chief. 
(Prior code § 1030.10) 
12.24.110. - Nonliability of city. 
    Every person erecting, maintaining or using posts, poles, structures, supports or wires shall indemnify and save harmless the city, its officers, agents and servants, from and against all lawful claims and demands for injuries to persons or property occasioned by the existence of such posts, poles, structures, supports or wires, or by the transmission of electric current by means thereof. Council, the fire chief, the superintendent of fire alarm and the agents or servants of the city, exercising the rights, powers and responsibilities provided for herein, shall not be held liable by any person on account thereof or by reason of any injury or damage caused thereby. 
(Prior code § 1030.11) 
12.24.120. - Interpretation. 
    No provision of this chapter shall be construed as giving to any person any right to put up or maintain any post, pole, structure, support or wire of any kind. 
(Prior code § 1030.12) 
12.24.130. - Underground utility and communication lines. 
A.  Any building erected in a subdivision, as defined in "Rules and Regulations Governing the Subdivision of Land in the City of Newport, Rhode Island," (see Chapter 1222 of the Planning and Zoning Code), and any building hereafter erected on any other parcel of land in the city, having an area of twenty thousand (20,000) square feet or more, shall have all electrical utility lines and communication lines installed underground. 
B.  Appurtenants such as, but not limited to, surface mounted transformers, pedestal mounted terminal boxes and meter cabinets and associated equipment may be placed above ground. 
C.  The chief of the division of inspection shall enforce the requirements of this section and any person aggrieved by his or her decision may appeal to the zoning board of review, which is authorized to grant a variance to the requirements of this section if topographical, soil or other conditions affecting the real estate make compliance with this section unreasonable or impractical. The board, in hearing appeals under this section, shall follow the intent of this section so far as possible, so that all electrical utility lines and communication lines on the above described real estate shall be underground wherever feasible. 
(Prior code § 1030.13) 
Chapter 12.28. - CITY HARBOR[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-008, § 1, adopted February 26, 2014, repealed the former Chapter 12.28, §§ 12.28.010-12.28.130, and enacted a new Chapter 12.28 as set out herein. The former Chapter 12.28 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Prior Code Table; Ordinance List and Disposition Table; and the Code Comparative Table for the chapter's history. 

12.28.010. - Authority and purpose. 
A.  Pursuant to Section 46-4-6.6 of the General Laws of Rhode Island authority is granted to the city council of the City of Newport to regulate by ordinance the speed, management, and control of all vessels and the size, type, location, and use of all anchorages and moorings, within the public waters within the confines of the city including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the authority and power to prohibit waterskiing on any of the public waters, to designate upon a map of the public waters within the city the places where permanent or temporary moorings or anchorages may be maintained, to assign moorings, to remove moorings, to collect a fee for the use of moorings, to provide for minimum mooring specifications, to provide regulations for houseboats that are not self-propelled, to provide regulations for regattas, races, marine parades, tournaments, and exhibitions, to provide for the removal of wrecks or derelicts or abandoned boats or docks, and to impose penalties for violators of the ordinances. 
B.  The purpose of this chapter is to also provide consistency with the authority granted the city under Section 46-4-6.6 of the General Laws of Rhode Island and with the goals, policies, and regulations of the Newport Comprehensive Harbor Management Plan, the Rhode Island Coastal Resources Management Program, the Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management, and the United States Army Corps of Engineers. 
(Ord. No. 2014-006, § 1, 2-26-2014) 
12.28.020. - Definitions. 
    "ACOE" means the Army Corps of Engineers. 
    "Anchoring" means to temporarily secure a vessel to the bottom by dropping an anchor of appropriate size for the vessel. 
    "Channel" means the navigational portion of a waterway reserved for unobstructed movement of vessels. 
    "Commercial mooring" means a mooring type designation used in previous revisions of this chapter. This term has been replaced with the term "rental mooring" to clarify that this does not refer to the type of vessel accommodated. 
    "Commercial vessel" means a vessel that is to be used to generate financial or any other compensation 
    "Dinghy" means a vessel permitted by the City of Newport with a maximum length of twelve (12) feet, and is either a tender to a larger vessel in Newport Harbor or coastal water area or is a vessel owned by a resident of the City of Newport used for recreational purposes in Newport Harbor or coastal water area. 
    "Dinghy dock" means floating docks designated for in-water, short- and long-term dinghy tie-up; and, when and where designated, for on-dock long-term dinghy storage. 
    "Documented vessel" means a vessel holding a current U.S. Coast Guard Certificate of Documentation and appropriate state registration or title and displaying state decals showing that they have complied with state requirements. 
    "Domestic partner" is defined as a person in a domestic partnership. The term "domestic partnership" is defined as a committed relationship between two adults of the opposite sex or same sex, in which the partners: 
1.  Have been each other's sole domestic partner for a period of at least one year and intend to remain so indefinitely; 
2.  Maintain a common residence and intend to continue to do so; 
3.  Are at least eighteen (18) years of age and mentally competent to consent to a contract; 
4.  Share responsibility for a significant measure of each other's financial obligations; 
5.  Are not married or joined in a civil union to anyone else; 
6.  Are not a domestic partner of anyone else; 
7.  Are not related in a way that would prohibit legal marriage in the U.S. jurisdiction in which the partnership was formed; 
8.  Provide documentation demonstrating fulfillment of these requirements; and 
9.  Certify that they understand that willful falsification of the documentation required to establish that an individual is in a domestic partnership may lead to the revocation of any permits or rights granted under Chapter 12.28 and may constitute a violation or criminal offense. 
    "Floating business" means a building constructed on a raft, barge or hull that is represented as or principally used as a place of business, including but not limited to hotels, restaurants, marinas or marina-related businesses (RI CRMP Section 300.5). Specifically excluded by this definition are water dependent businesses as defined in this chapter. 
    "Houseboat" means a building constructed on a raft, barge, or hull that is used primarily for single or multiple-family habitation; if used for transportation this use is secondary (RI CRMP Section 300.5).
